title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a well with an expansion tank for the water. Does this tank require maintenance, and can you give me some idea of how it works?

title: GIFTED CHILDREN'S PROGRAMS
description: Elizabeth Stone's article ''Gifted Children's Programs: A Matter of Class'' (May 6) makes clear that a number of hard questions need to be answered if gifted education is to fulfill its mission in this country. However, to persist in debating whether gifted-education programs should exist at all is ludicrous. Consider.

title: Julia W. Barnes and Herbert A. May 3d Are Wed
description: Julia W. Barnes, the daughter of Mrs. William Barnes 3d of Decatur, Ill., and the late Mr. Barnes, was married yesterday to Herbert A. May 3d, the son of Mrs. May Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. May. The Rev. Alfred R. Shands 3d officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Decatur.

title: Tankleff on Trial: 'Sweet' or 'Cowardly'?
description: LIKE a student preparing for a test, he listens attentively and takes volumes of notes. But 18-year-old Martin H. Tankleff has not been inside a classroom in nearly two years. He has been mostly inside courtrooms, where the stakes are much higher.

title: NONFICTION
description: GREAT OCEAN: An Authorized Biography of the Buddhist Monk Tenzin Gyatso His Holiness the Fourteenth Dalai Lama. By Roger Hicks and Ngakpa Chogyam. (Penguin, Paper, $8.95.) The story of His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet is almost mythic in its beginning: the 2-year-old child who, in 1936, unerringly picked from a series of paired objects (two rosaries, two walking sticks, two drums) the one that had belonged to his predecessor, the 13th Dalai Lama, and eventually ascended to spiritual and political leadership of Tibet. But with the Chinese military occupation of Tibet in the 1950's, a harsher reality overtook the man Tibetans call Tenzin Gyatso, ''The Ocean of Wisdom.'' In 1959, the 25-year-old Dalai Lama fled in disguise on horseback over the Himalayas to India. As ''Great Ocean'' makes clear, in a sense he took the spirit of old Tibet with him for safekeeping: in the years to come the Chinese Communists destroyed more than 6,000 Tibetan temples and monasteries and killed tens of thousands of monks and nuns, as well as hundreds of thousands of Tibetans who resisted. In India the Dalai Lama set up a democratic government in exile to aid the growing flood of Tibetan refugees, to rebuild Tibet's culture in pockets of settlement abroad and to plan for the day when he could once again return - a mission that once seemed quixotic but now has the ring of plausibility, in the wake of Tiananmen Square and the fall of the Berlin Wall. For those who seek a picture of Tibet's suffering under the Chinese and of the Dalai Lama's remarkable response - he declines to get angry with the Chinese, though he opposes their rule - John F. Avedon's ''In Exile From the Land of Snows'' remains the biography of choice. But ''Great Ocean'' is an excellent introduction to the 1989 Nobel Peace Price laureate, an evocative thumbnail sketch. What shines through in this telling of the tale - by Roger Hicks, an independent scholar, and Ngakpa Chogyam, who teaches Buddhism in Britain - are the personal qualities that distinguish this monk turned statesman: candor, compassion and a gentleness of spirit.

title: THE DEFICIT: A LOOK AT THE BRIGHT SIDE
description: THE DEFICIT AND THE PUBLIC INTEREST

title: Men's Style;   Conservative Cool
description: You should see his passport picture,'' says henri Marc Kessler of his cohort and business partner, Mark Zeff, and laughs. Not so many years ago, Zeff used to wear long hair and earrings. More outrageous still, Kessler says, ''He almost got a tattoo.'' That was then. This is now. And these days, Zeff, an interior designer, and Kessler, a nightclub entrepreneur, have made a few revisions in their style. Shorn of his Samson locks and sporting Turnbull & Asser shirts, Zeff is the natty Anglophile. Only his shoes, with their mid-19th century vamp, betray a certain eccentricity.

title: YESTERDAY AND TODAY
description: American Dance Festival begins its 56th year (and its 13th summer in Durham, N.C.) on Thursday with the series ''American Masters Plus,'' a salute to the roots of modern dance. The festival has presented more than 40 foreign dance companies during the last decade, ''to see how American modern dance has taken root abroad,'' according to Charles L. Reinhart, the festival's director since 1969. ''We thought it fitting this year to celebrate the American masters - thoses who made the art form possible in the first place.''

title: Elizabeth Wright Weds A. C. Kaye
description: Elizabeth Anne Wright, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. Eugene Wright of Ogden, Utah, was married yesterday to Anthony Cummins Kaye, a son of Dr. Robert Edward Kaye and Wendy Burnham Kaye, both of New York. Judge David E. Roth of State District Court in Utah officiated at the home of Valeen Glasmann, the bride's aunt, in Ogden.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: COMPANIES

title: Memorable Gardens In England's Oxbridge
description: LEAD: The Backs at Cambridge offer one of the most famous scenes in England and, it has been said, one of the most beautiful in the world. The name refers to the wonderful semicircle of buildings, including King's College Chapel , Gibbs splendid Fellows Building and Wren Trinity College Library. What a grouping!

title: Botswana, Diamond Power, Is Still Dependent
description: The newest addition to the skyline in this desert capital boasts the hallmarks of a skyscraper in the first world: reflective glass and polished granite. Nearby, the Mercedes-Benz dealership sells more cars than dealerships in any city in neighboring South Africa.

title: Beijing's Bloody Thank You
description: President Bush knew he'd draw criticism at home for proposing, despite Beijing's violations of basic human rights, a 12-month renewal of China's commercial access to U.S. markets. But in return he must surely have expected gestures of reconciliation and good will. Instead, Beijing's answer is cynical and cruel: kind words for Mr. Bush and new repression for its suffering people.

title: U.S. Team Defeated By Swiss
description: It was a rude ending to a long season of World Cup preparation, but the lesson learned might prove valuable for the United States soccer team in the weeks ahead.

title: Caroline Brokaw to Wed R. S. Tucker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Brokaw of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caroline Johnston Brokaw to Robert Scott Tucker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Tucker of Montpelier, Vt. A September wedding is planned.

title: William Elliott Burch, Horse Trainer, 36
description: William Elliott Burch, a race-horse trainer and the son and grandson of members of horse racing's Hall of Fame, died of cancer on Friday. He was 36 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;

Successes of a Noted Plant Breeder
description: LEAD: A revolution in rhododendron bloom is about to begin. The coup will take place in midsummer when six late-blooming shrubs will flower. Dr. David Leach, a rhododendron breeder and geneticist, has broken through the spring flowering barrier.

title: Legislation Sought on Lip-Synced Concerts
description: The growing use of canned music and lip-syncing at concerts has drawn the ire of legislators in New York and New Jersey, who say listeners should be told if the live performances they are paying for are not entirely live.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Laborer's Lot Is Not Just Coffee
description: LEAD: OCCUPYING the low totem in the construction hierarchy is the laborer. The job demands the least skill, earns the lowest wage, is the most physically taxing and least prestigious..

title: How to Help Roses Keep Their Splendor
description: JUNE belongs to roses. The glorious flowers start to appear this month in all their colors: reds, pinks, yellows, creams, pure whites and everything in between.

title: Alabama Bound
description: During a recent visit to the Alabama Archives in Montgomery, I felt a heavy hand on my shoulder and turned to find the bearish figure of Clarke Stallworth, who was my first city editor 25 years ago at The Birmingham Post-Herald. Stallworth, now 64 years old, had been one of my early journalistic heroes for his crusade against the inequities of a tax system that soaked wage-earners so that United States Steel and other out-of-state corporations could pay token taxes on their vast acreage in Alabama. It seemed coincidence of a rare sort to run into this old fire-eater while I was visiting my native state to report on the post-Wallace era in Alabama politics. Serendipity piled atop coincidence when Stallworth revealed that he was on his way to join a panel discussion on the same subject.

title: State Orders Removal Of Debris in Katonah
description: WHEN Marilyn Dekker took her infant daughter, Nancy, for a walk in her Katonah subdivision last fall, she noticed an odd-looking pile of dirt that had recently been dumped on an empty lot on Old Village Lane. ''It looked funny, and it smelled,'' Mrs. Dekker recalled, adding that the ash-colored material ''was very sparkly in the sunlight.''

title: Audrey Weaver: Scarf Designer
description: ''A lot of women are intimidated by scarfs,'' said Audrey Weaver, a 33-year-old designer of scarfs and accessories who wants women to think of them as friends. Ms. Weaver herself seems to have a magician's touch. Taking a silk oblong leopard-skin print from around her neck, in two minutes she drapes it into a bandeau top, a shawl, a headwrap, a sarong and a sash for her purse. For customers who are less creative, Ms. Weaver includes a tag explaining the uses of the scarfs.

title: Wall Street;   Investing Goldman's New Money
description: Until recently, an investor needed $5 million to open an account at Goldman Sachs & Company. But times are tough on Wall Street. This prestigious investment bank has established a mutual fund and now welcomes smaller accounts.

title: Casino Supporter Wins Mohawk Council Vote
description: A Mohawk Indian who views reservation gambling as an economic boon unseated the tribe's only incumbent chief opposed to gambling in an election today.

title: Some Subjects for Summiteers to Ponder On;   Lithuanian Injustices
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: High Risk;   Colombia's Guerillas Break Into Politics
description: TEN weeks after burning their jungle fatigues and melting down their guns, the 800 former fighters of the M-19 guerrilla army watched with euphoria as their new political party won 800,000 votes in last Sunday's presidential election.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: U.S. Lawmakers Tie Soviet Trade Pact to Kremlin Progress on Lithuania
description: Members of Congress warned today that Congressional approval of an agreement expanding American trade with the Soviet Union would hinge on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's willingness to end Moscow's economic crackdown on Lithuania.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Southern Methodist;   Admissions Rule For Top Athletes Stirs Old Fears
description: Southern Methodist University's admissions procedures for athletes were tightened after a scandal that led to the cancellation of the 1987 and 1988 football seasons. Now those procedures are loosening, and that has some faculty members worried.

title:
DINING OUT;

Traditional and Updated French Dishes
description: LEAD: LA PETITE BRASSERIE offers a handful of appealing French provincial dishes in an intimate setting - but first you have to find it. Up a hill in a semiresidential section of Hawthorne, south of Ridgewood, this Passaic County restaurant has as its only clue a small pink neon sign at the foot of a driveway.

title: Senate Democrats Offer Real Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bequest Rewards Scholarly Mastery With College
description: LEAD: THE Bedford Central School District has announced the first winners in an unusual college scholarship program based not on high school seniors' financial need, standardized test scores or grades but on their ability to show scholarly mastery in one or more fields.

title: UNPOLLUTED BY PASSION
description: RACE AND HISTORY

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The world's highest bridge game will be played Friday with some high-visibility personalities taking part. Play, with identical deals and scoring, will be at the top of the Empire State Building in Manhattan, the Eiffel Tower in Paris, and other towers in Berlin, London, Montreal, Moscow, Rotterdam, Seattle, Sidney, Tokyo and Toronto.

title: All About/Platinum;   A Thriving Market Guaranteed By Both Vanity and Pollution
description: When the Ford Motor Company announced in December 1988 that it had developed a catalytic converter that would not require platinum, the metal's price plunged. Platinum producers feared that demand would evaporate. But Ford's new converter is still in testing, and platinum demand is near an all-time high.

title: Valvano TV Deal
description: It may not exactly be a case of feeding from the hand that bit you, but Jim Valvano, the former North Carolina State basketball coach who was forced to resign after ABC reported allegations that several of his former players had conspired to shave points, is apparently on the verge of joining the network as a basketball analyst.

title: Ms. Countryman To Marry in July
description: Rachel Carole Countryman and John Wescott Bracker are planning a July wedding, the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Joan Countryman and Edward Jakmauh of Philadelphia, have announced. Mr. Bracker is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Earl Bracker of Concord, Mass.

title: Preparing Classic Italian Dishes, but With a Twist
description: FOR a number of years, cooks and chefs have been taking some Italian classics as inspiration and giving them a new twist. Pesto is a good example.

title: Rock-a-Bye Baby Boomer
description: A guilty pleasure for which I have recently developed a minor addiction is the much-scorned national phenomenon of ''lite'' music radio, the latest variation of what is also called ''adult contemporary'' or ''easy listening.''

title: Red Smith Victory To Yankee Affair
description: It was beginning to look as if age was catching up with Yankee Affair.

title: Glacier
description: To the Editor: The article on Glacier National Park (Travel, April 1) painted a great picture, but the paragraph about the spawning salmon and the eagles feeding on them in the fall may be a thing of the past.

title: HE WORKED AT THE HERO'S TRADE
description: BEYOND THE BARRIER

title: Images of Infants; Words as Images
description: THE photographer Garry Winogrand's America is not as weird as Robert Frank's and not as nasty as Diane Arbus's. But it is for sure not the place that gave new meaning to glamour, a word that was first popularized by Sir Walter Scott, of all people.

title: Laureate in the Land of the Pharoahs
description: The Aly Baba Cafe in downtown Cairo is a cheerless place with yellowing walls and soiled soapbox-sized tables. By day, couples rendezvous in its dark corners, and at night it is mostly empty. But the cafe on Tahrir Square has two things to recommend it.

title: Rain Dampens Campers, Not Spirits
description: Ira Bligen, 17 years old, would go only so far. He did not mind spending a rainy night in the woods with only a cot and wooden roof for comfort, he said, standing in a drizzle with his hands in his parka pockets. A weekend of camping, even in the rain, was a welcome change from the ''buildings, sidewalks and sewers'' he sees every day in the Bronx.

title: Steinbrenner Box Score
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dissidents in China Are Reported Arrested
description: Three of China's most outspoken dissidents were arrested on Thursday morning, shortly before they were to hold a news conference to call on the Government to release political prisoners, a Chinese with access to information in the Public Security Bureau said.

title: Sheila Cole Nilva: Gift Basket Maker
description: One career has not been enough for Sheila Cole Nilva. She has been a travel writer and a model, has done promotional work for swimsuits and bedspreads and has been in the antiques business. And because even one career at a time has seldom been enough, her careers often overlapped.

title: METALS IN SEWAGE MUST BE REDUCED
description: In an attempt at cleaning up New York Harbor, the Federal Government will order New York City to limit toxic discharges of copper and mercury from its 14 sewage treatment plants. It will be the first time the Government limits the maximum amount of a specific toxic substance in sewage-plant discharge.

title: THE TONYS VS. THE PULITZERS
description: ''The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama and was nominated for the Tony Award as best Broadway play, but if anyone thinks that winning the Pulitzer makes a play a shoo-in for the Tony, think again. In the 42 years since 1948, the year the American Theater Wing gave the first Tony Award for best play, only 15 works have taken both.

title: Cautiously, Chile Investigates Political Killings
description: Setting out to fulfill the promise of Chile's new President to mix truth with prudence, a commission of lawyers and human rights experts will begin next week to gather evidence on political killings and disappearances that occurred during the military dictatorship.

title: Juried Show: Best of a Good Lot
description: HERE it comes again, ''Art of Northeast U.S.A.,'' on view at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan. The 41st of these annual events, the show and its more than $5,000 in prize money attracted some 1,200 contenders, 90 of whom were selected by the critic Carter Ratcliff.

title: Mary G. Wells to Marry
description: Mrs. James L. Wells 3d of Doylestown, Pa., has announced the late-June wedding plans for her daughter Mary G. Wells and Henry M. Ogden 3d of Short Hills, N.J., Miss Wells, 30 years old, is also a daughter of the late Mr. Wells. A Cedar Crest College graduate, she is the director of admissions and a history teacher at the Vail-Deane School in Mountainside, N.J. Mr. Ogden, 29, a graduate of Ohio Wesleyan University, has a law degree from Seton Hall University and is an assistant prosecutor in the Union County Prosecutor's office in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Headliners;   All Dressed Up, and Looking Like a Governor
description: The truth about Viscount Cornbury, an 18th-century Governor of the colonies of New York and New Jersey, is in question again. This time, a dispute has flared between historians in New York and London about whether he was, as has long been claimed, a transvestite.

title: Pickup Crew Wins a Gold
description: A pickup crew from Northeastern University rewarded parents and patrons today by winning a gold medal at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta on Onondaga Lake.

title: Use of Drug Impinges On Integrity of Racing
description: During the last few years, I have been asked to explain New York's position on Lasix, which is banned 48 hours before post time. New York stands alone on that position.

title: A Presence That's Meant to Command
description: Gregory Peck is 74 years old now, but as the newly released OLD GRINGO (1989, RCA/Columbia, $89.95) illustrates, he remains a commanding screen presence and a credibly romantic figure.

title: Elaine Reader Is Wed To Stephen P. Arbeit
description: Elaine Reader, the daughter of Eleanor Kiley of Ocean Grove, N.J., and the late William H. Kiley, was married yesterday in New York to Stephen P. Arbeit, the son of Claire Arbeit of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late David Arbeit. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel officiated at the Sign of the Dove.

title: Healiners;   Smooth Landing
description: Just six weeks after resigning under pressure as chancellor of the California state university system, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds has been named chancellor of the City University of New York. The problem in California was the 45 percent raise that she and the system's trustees approved for her. The public response to her new $198,000 salary was so loud that the raise was cut to 4 percent, about what faculty and staff members received, and Dr. Reynolds said she would resign next fall. But the trustees urged her to leave sooner, and she did. CUNY officials said they had looked into the dispute and were not dissuaded by it. Dr. Reynolds, a zoologist by training, had a reputation for toughness at the California state university system, a network of 20 colleges that is separate from the University of California system. At CUNY, she will also have 20 schools. And a salary of $160,000.

title: Q and A
description: Sublet and Lease Renewal

title: Seeing Is Believing
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Bocca and Ferri Co-star In 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' has become a modern ballet classic in the 25 years since it was created for England's Royal Ballet. And it is likely that everyone who has seen the production has a distinctive memory of the first time, whether of a performer or bit of choreography or the overwhelming first impression made by Nicholas Georgiadis's sumptuous Renaissance sets and costumes and the sheer spectacle of the way this version unfolds to its Prokofiev score.

title: God, Humanity and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: For 7A Administrators;   12-Week Training
description: The course titles tell the story: ''Housing Abandonment,'' ''Tenant Organizing,'' ''Operation of the Housing Court,'' ''Record Keeping,'' ''Plumbing Systems'' and ''Narcotics Control.''

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Jersey City's Riverfront Revival Resumes
description: LEAD: EMPTY lots still punctuate the Hudson River riverfront in Jersey City, reminders of the flight in the 1950's of businesses from the once bustling manufacturing center. But the commercial revitalization of this gritty strip, which began nearly a decade ago, is getting a second wind.

title: The Great New Drive to Rescue Wang's Computers
description: Richard W. Miller wasn't frightened by difficult business situations. After all, his first job after finishing business school in 1970 had been at the Penn Central Corporation, which was going through what was then the largest bankruptcy proceeding in the nation's history.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

On the Docket: The Barrens v. Developers
description: LEAD: THE first phase of one of the largest mixed-use projects ever conceived for Long Island is expected to start construction this summer in central Suffolk County, despite a lawsuit by a group seeking to halt all development in the pine barrens until further environmental studies are made.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Temple;   Three Students To Be Fined In Racial Incident
description: Temple University will fine three students $100 each and place them on disciplinary probation for a year for their involvement in a racial incident on its North Philadelphia campus, officials announced Wednesday.

title: Chopped Liver in the Playoffs
description: The mentors of the Windy City Bulls and the Auburn Hills Pistons have repaired to their separate rooms in order to cudgel their brains like never before this season.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Weight Till Next Year
description: LEAD: MY palms are moist, I am bathed in cold sweat, the palpitations of my heart are throbbing in my ears and I am gasping for air. I am looking at myself in a bathing suit in a department store mirror.

title: Bad Route to Meeting People
description: There are a number of ways to meet nice people, and one of the worst is to have car trouble. I know, because I've met some particularly nice people that way.

title: Alice Zimmerman Marries David Mott
description: Alice Margaret Zimmerman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Weaver Zimmerman of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to David Morrell Mott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Sutherland Mott of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Donald Raymond Kehew officiated at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island, R.I.

title: CReators of 'Annie' Come Full Circle
description: NO one wanted ''Annie'' in 1976, until Michael Price, the executive producer of Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, said, ''Come up here and try it out.'' That's how Martin Charnin, who conceived, directed and wrote the lyrics for the legendary musical hit remembers its tentative beginnings.

title: Fledgling Cable Networks Are Poised for Flight
description: Television conventions tend to have their own loopy logic - this is, after all, show biz. The recent National Cable Television Association convention in Atlanta was no exception: The cable system operator in search of fresh programming could sample networks for bingo players, for science-fiction fans, for armchair barristers - not to mention armchair cowboys, to single out just a few of the new channels hoping to sign up customers.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Should Mets Do About Strawberry?
description: Send him to the Boss's make-believe Yankees. They deserve each other.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: It was a pleasure seeing Villa Lante featured in William Weaver's article (Travel, April 8). American visitors to the villa will be interested to know that it has longstanding connections with the United States. Three ladies who married into the Lante della Revere family in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were American. One of these American duchesses, Mathilda Davis, was a New Yorker. While perhaps I have a certain bias (as a descendant), it should be noted that all three helped insure the villa's survival during difficult times and always welcomed visitors.

title: The Region;   When Welfare Pays the Rent
description: CAN a family of three survive in New York City on $286 a month for rent? The city and state maintain that it can. That is how much they give to the typical welfare family, a single mother with two children, for basic shelter.

title:
COMMENCEMENTS;

Lehigh University
description: LEAD: The astronomer Carl Sagan addressed 1,161 graduates at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., yesterday.

title: Technology;   Trying to Make Batteries 'Green'
description: Every year, Americans buy over 2 billion dry-cell batteries for use in products ranging from flashlights to portable computers. Since most are not rechargeable, they soon wind up in the trash, from which they go to a landfill or an incinerator.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Purity vs. Politics
description: The novelist E. L. Doctorow was waxing lyrical the other day about literary men in politics like Vaclav Havel, President of Czechoslovakia, and Arpad Goncz, President of Hungary. Unlike professional politicians, he said, amateurs don't cling to office by twisting the truth. In fact, Mr. Doctorow declared, ''I know of no better qualifications for a president anywhere: a total integrity on the one hand, and a precious lack of political experience on the other.''

title: The Truth About Engineering
description: To the Editor:

title: The Seating Game On Metro-North
description: I enjoyed the ''Railroad Seating Primer'' on the Westchester Opinion Page of April 15.

title: Jeanne Woodlock Married To James Gillispie in Jersey
description: Jeanne Woodlock, a daughter of Margaret L. Woodlock of Crestwood, N.J., and the late John P. Woodlock, was married yesterday to James Gillispie, a son of Frank J. Gillispie and Barbara T. Gillispie, both of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. James Moore officiated at the Annunciation Roman Catholic Church in Crestwood.

title: Westward Ho, the Sackbuts
description: The early-music-festival scene in America has come to resemble a glacially paced transcontinental tennis match. In a biennial alternation of events, the West Coast (in even years) initially had difficulty mastering the East Coast's strong serve (in odd). But the West's return has improved drastically of late, and a booming forehand this summer may even the contest. Boston, long the undisputed champion of American early-music activity, now faces serious competition.

title: Bush and Baker
description: So two old friends get along well, like bawdy jokes, tease each other and enjoy killing fish and birds - so what? Why are there no hard questions? Nothing in the article suggests how Bush expects to become ''education'' or ''environment'' President without investing a dime in new Federal revenue. Or on what grounds it was decided that the loss of lives and property in Panama was justified in order only to capture a drug dealer and former Central Intelligence Agency asset. Or whether either man has any remorse for running the sleaziest Presidential campaign in this century.

title: OUTFITTING A HOST'S HAMPER
description: There is little I enjoy more than a picnic. What better way to celebrate that rare summer day than to head straight for the heart of it, setting off with a hamper and a handful of friends. But to inhabit the outdoors with comfort, you need a well-equipped picnic hamper. And while there are ready-made standard models available - the ultimate, perhaps, being the classic sold at Asprey in London for about $21,000, complete with caviar and champagne - they don't offer much personality. For several years now, I've been assembling my own, complete but never finished. It has picked up along the way all the funny pieces I could never quite fit into my schemes for life at home, like Russel Wright's plastic cups and saucers with their improbable real leaves pressed into the 1950's plastic. My hamper also harbors anything that I can't bring myself to discard.

title: Leslie Hotchkiss Weds in Vermont
description: In the garden of her parents' home in Chester, Vt., Leslie Ellsworth Hotchkiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winchester F. Hotchkiss, also of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to John Ewins Arndt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. S. Arndt of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Hal Miller, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: Claire A. Goodrich Weds Richard Van de Berghe Jr.
description: Claire A. Goodrich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Goodrich of South Windsor, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard L. Van de Berghe Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Van de Berghe of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Paul S. Johansson officiated at Emanuel Lutheran Church in Manchester, Conn.

title: Escalator Collapses in Subway, Injuring 14
description: At least 14 people were injured last night when an escalator at the 161st Street-River Avenue subway station serving Yankee Stadium in the Bronx partially collapsed, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Jody Lynn Misher To Wed Next Year
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Misher of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jodi Lynn Misher to Steven Robert Peikin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Peikin of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Playing the Game Against the Prevailing Sentiment
description: Despite the stock market's rally to new highs last week, so-called ''market sentiment'' is not very strong. In fact, there is still a high level of skepticism. In the contrary ways of Wall Street, this may actually be good news, say portfolio strategists, who believe that as long as investors remain skeptical prices can go higher. But when too many investors become optimistic, goes the theory, prices have nowhere to go but down. A weekly survey of investment advisory newsletters by Investors Intelligence, a research firm in New Rochelle, N.Y., found last week that the number of advisers who describe themselves as bears is still high. In the past, the cautious advisers often became more bullish, just as prices peaked. As long as these advisers remain cautious, the market could go higher, say portfolio strategists who monitor the market sentiment numbers. ''This probably means that we're not through with this rally,'' said Byron R. Wien, chief of portfolio strategy for United States stocks at Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Walter C. Reisinger, Brewery Executive, 66
description: Walter C. Reisinger, an executive of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, died of lung cancer on Friday at Jewish Hospital in St. Louis. He was 66 years old and lived in St. Louis, where the brewery is based.

title: With Babies on Board
description: They say that travel broadens a person, and I believe it. This may seem strange, considering that I have only gone beyond the continental boundaries of the United States twice in my life. Once I spent two weeks on the Caribbean island of St. Barts, which was a little like going to heaven. Once I spent two weeks in the Soviet Union, which was a little like going to Mars.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Songs for Myself
description: LEAD: HERE I go again. There's a catchy love song on the radio, just daring me to sing along. Not one to back down in the face of a challenge, I jump in on the chorus. But wait - it's Debbie Gibson. A few words into the first phrase and I'm done for. I just can't hit those notes, no matter how hard I try.

title: Changes Entice A Chinese Hurdler
description: His mother, Jiang Yu-min, was the Asian record-holder at 100, 200 and 400 meters. His father, Li Jing-ming, was the Chinese record-holder in the high jump at the mundane height of 6 feet 3 1/2 inches. His brother, Bo Feng, was the Chinese 200-meter champion.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 13 about the growth of computer networks misidentified a man using a computer keyboard and his company. He was Dr. Robert W. Root, a scientist for Bellcore.

title: Amy Wagner Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wagner of Scarsdale, N.Y., have anounced that their daughter, Amy G. Wagner, and Corey R. Shanus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol H. Shanus of Delray Beach, Fla., will be married later this month. Miss Wagner, a University of Pennsylvania alumna, teaches French and Spanish at Harrison (N.Y.) High School and is studying for a Ph.D. in Spanish at Columbia University, where she received master's degrees in Spanish and education. Her fiancee, a magna cum laude graduate of Penn., where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, received law and M.B.A. degrees from the University of Chicago. He is the president of the Sobert Realty Corporation in New York.

title: Guerrilla War in Guatemala Heats Up, Fueling Criticism of Civilian Rule
description: The three policemen sped past a Coca-Cola billboard here that advised them to ''have a safe trip.'' Moments later, guerrillas on a nearby hillock fired on the car, sending it tumbling down a 40-foot embankment into a stream.

title: Fixing Sliding Patio Doors
description: DURING warm weather, traffic through patio doors increases and doors that stick or are difficult to slide become nuisances. Fortunately, most problems with sliding patio doors can be fixed relatively easily.

title: Disney Studios Takes Care of Business
description: These are boom or bust times in Hollywood. Half a dozen smaller companies have collapsed in the last two years, and even some of the major studios are teetering on the brink of bankruptcy. On the other hand, studios lucky enough to latch on to a blockbuster like ''Batman'' or ''Look Who's Talking'' can see their profits soar to record levels.

title: Elizabeth Anderson Debs Is Married To Stephen C. Turner
description: In Connecticut Elizabeth Anderson Debs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Debs of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and Stephen Carmichael Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kimball Turner of Edgartown, Mass., were married yesterday at the Greenwich home of the bride's parents. The Very Rev. Paul Schneirla, an Antiochan Orthodox priest, officiated. Nicholas A. R. Debs attended his sister. Thomas Wiggin was the best man.

title: Review/Music;   Love Songs, Sad and Satirical, by Cantori de New York
description: The venerable musicologist Paul Henry Lang remarked recently, perhaps only half in jest, that someone should undertake a study of precisely what it is that choral conductors do with their batonless hands: all those arcane cupping and molding and waggling gestures, which presumably (though not always apparently) speak volumes to choristers. Whatever it may be, it is not indispensable, as Bart Folse demonstrated again on Thursday evening in performances with his 24-voice Cantori di New York at Merkin Concert Hall. Even in the first half of the concert, entirely a cappella, Mr. Folse wielded a baton, with happy results.

description: WASHINGTON

title: A NEW TWIST ON POTLUCK
description: An outdoor party FOR 140 friends - with 40 different dishes and lots of activities for children - can be held with little effort on the part of the hosts. We have been giving such a party at our home in Washington every year for the past seven years, and it is a proven success. A joint project, it is the one time our family entertains together.

title: Fishermen Detained In Looting of Eggs Of Endangered Birds
description: Federal agents have detained five fishermen and seized their trawler after dozens of eggs were plundered from the nests of endangered pelicans and sea gulls, wildlife authorities said.

title: The Nation;   How to Map The Best Places For Rare Species
description: Scientists in Idaho, in a hopeful application of satellite and computer technology, have produced a powerful new tool for helping states and the Federal Government preserve the nation's diversity of plants and animals.

title: Lisa Battalia Weds Stephen Anthony
description: Lisa A. Battalia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. William Battalia of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen P. Anthony, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Anthony of Concord, Mass. The Rev. John Replogle officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach.

title: Rex Harrison, a Leading Man With Urbane Wit, Dies at 82
description: Rex Harrison, the suave British actor who won a Tony in 1957 and an Academy Award in 1964 for his portrayals of Prof. Henry Higgins in ''My Fair Lady,'' died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old. The actor, who was knighted in July 1989, played a wide variety of roles during his long career in theater and films, but he was best known for his portrayal of the waspish professor of phonetics in the musical based on George Bernard Shaw's play ''Pygmalion.''

title: Headliners;   Different Direction
description: Joseph Papp wanted something new for the New York Shakespeare Festival, and he is starting with JoAnne Akalaitis. A director and a founding member of the experimental troupe Mabou Mines, she will have the title of artistic associate and can present and cast plays ''any way she likes,'' Mr. Papp said last week. The idea is to redesign the festival, which has a dwindling endowment. (Mr. Papp is also turning over the small theaters of the Public Theater complex to three young directors, George C. Wolfe, David Greenspan and Michael Greif.) Ms. Akalaitis is not a conventional choice. Apart from her association with Mabou Mines, an eclectic, combustible force in modern theater, she is known for infuriating Samuel Beckett by changing his stage directions for ''Endgame.'' But Mr. Papp said he wanted an ''esthetic sensibility'' unlike his own.

title: New Iran-Contra Grand Jury Hears North
description: Oliver L. North appeared before a newly empaneled Federal grand jury on Friday in the continuing criminal investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

Ronald Erbe, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Malley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stoddard Warden of West Barnet, Vt., graduated from the University of Vermont. She is a flight attendant with Trans World Airlines. Her father, who is retired, ran an insurance agency in West Barnet.

title: Markdowns On All Kinds Of Movies
description: Everywhere in video these days there seem to be rafts of older feature films available at lower prices. Typically, the movie companies - Warner, say, or MGM/UA - will put together a group of comedies, westerns, musicals, crime films or whatever and reissue them at $19.95 or so apiece.

On those nights, $3 will buy a teen-ager admission to the new Paradise Cafe, which welcomes youths who come to dance, mingle, watch movies and use the game room.

title:
New Jersey Opinion;

Trimmed With Lac And Dreams
description: LEAD: THE color is blush - a trifle paler than pink and rosier than white. It's gossamer light, as if woven by elves.

title: Headliners;   Smooth Exit
description: In Derek C. Bok's two decades as president of Harvard, he has become practiced in perhaps the most prestigious job in higher education, and the university has become a more settled place. The endowment has quintupled, Harvard and Radcliffe are peaceably merged, and the new ''core curriculum'' is not new anymore. So the 60-year-old Mr. Bok said last week that he would give up the job. In 1970 Mr. Bok, then the dean of Harvard Law School, was seen as conciliator for a university worn out by antiwar protests. By and large, he was. One hitch was the law school, where the faculty waged marathon ideological quarrels and Mr. Bok alienated some among the liberal faction. But there was much praise last week, including a comment by John Kenneth Galbraith, professor emeritus of economics, about Mr. Bok's ''amiable response to intrusive and even obnoxious professors.''

title: Kenneth Aretsky Weds Diana Lyne
description: Diana K. Lyne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Lyne of Boston, was married yesterday to Kenneth M. Aretsky, a son of Mrs. Sidney Aretsky of North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Aretsky. The Rev. Vernon Nichols officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: When 50 Labels Aren't Enough
description: In a typical month, Koch international, an Austrian-based music and media technology company that is becoming an increasingly active presence in the United States market, floods record shops with more than 100 new releases of compact disks, cassettes and even an occasional LP. As a distributor of some 50 labels from around the world, Koch regularly supplies collectors with such things as obscure Greek symphonies, Baroque English chamber music written in imitation of birds, or the showy piano music of Leopold Godowsky.

title: SURPRISE EXTENDS TO CITADEL COACH
description: Chal Port listened intently the other day as his counterparts from Stanford, Louisiana State, Mississippi State and Georgia discussed the roads their teams had taken to Omaha for this year's college baseball World Series.

title: Don't Lump Us All Into One Pile
description: Regarding Mary M. Jeffords article (''This Island Is a Really Good Place to Be From,'' Opinion, April 29) I take personal offense. I am 52 years old and have lived most of my life on Long Island.

title: What the Beauty And the Beasts Have in Common
description: In ''Pretty Woman,'' Julia Roberts shows off legs that begin somewhere above Augusta, Me., and are still going strong beyond Baja California. In fact, they are 44 inches from hip to toe - the measurements she gives in the movie. The legs of the four teen-age mutant ninja turtles, in ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' are a good deal shorter, stubbier and more rubbery, their feet two-toed. Yet magnificent legs are what the two films have in common. According to the May 23 issue of Variety, ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' has earned $114,032,497 in its first 52 days at American box offices, and ''Pretty Woman'' $109,624,898 in 59 days.

title: Helen MacIsaac Is Married
description: Helen A. MacIsaac, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren MacIsaac of Washington, was married yesterday at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in Amagansett, L.I., to Eric O. Kuhn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kuhn of East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Charles Haskins and the Rev. Donald Desmond, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Kuhn, 30 years old and a Barnard College graduate, is a vice president of Richard L. Hanley Associates, an investment consulting concern in New York. Her father is a professor of drama at Catholic University in Washington. Mr. Kuhn, 33, is the news editor and his father the art director of The East Hampton Star.

title: Miss Pray Is Wed To Arno Fischer

description: I never went to summer camp as a kid. My husband did, once; his most enduring memories are of bad food and bug bites.

title: FICTION
description: THE BISON: A Novel About the Scientist Who Defied Stalin. By Daniil Granin. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The ''Bison'' of this fact-based, eulogistic novel is the great Soviet geneticist Nikolai V. Timofeyev-Resovsky, who died in 1981. Daniil Granin, a Soviet writer who is now a member of the Soviet Parliament, openly admires his subject and assumes that readers are familiar with Timofeyev-Resovsky and numerous other personalities of his country's scientific community. Mr. Granin drops enormous numbers of names, leaving the uninitiated reader feeling excluded. Eventually, however, one can't help getting caught up in the gripping tale of Timofeyev-Resovsky's life, which began in czarist Russia and ended at the dawn of glasnost. (He was given the nickname Bison because of his physical heaviness and strength and his ''oxen stubbornness,'' and because he was a survivor of a bygone era, pre-Soviet Russia.) ''The Bison'' picks up speed when the brilliant young scientist leaves in 1924 to run a research institute outside Berlin; he stays for years and ends up spending the war there, on enemy soil. As Hitler rises to power, the Bison barely notices, partly because he is absorbed in his research and partly because he won't believe what is happening. But when he can no longer ignore the facts, he uses his high position to help save Jewish colleagues and turns a blind eye to the dangerous anti-Nazi activities of his son, Foma. Betrayed by an acquaintance, Foma is caught, sent to Mauthausen and executed. Back in the Soviet Union after the war, the father is arrested by Stalin's henchmen and shipped to a labor camp. The Bison's story is told in brief, engrossing anecdotes, flawlessly translated by Antonina W. Bouis. These segments join to create a vivid rendition of a crucial period in history, a portrait that is particularly stirring in light of recent events in Eastern Europe.

title: China's Future on Hold With a 'Gang of Elders'
description: In the middle of the crackdown against the democracy movement a year ago, Deng Xiaoping summoned the Government's leaders for a lecture that has turned out to be prophetic.

title: A Festival Where Chopin And Rock Mix
description: LEAD: Freiburg, on the edge of the Black Forest in West Germany, is, at first glance, a charmed time warp of a town, where the glories of the past are reverently preserved. From the elegant Renaissance Town Hall to the delicate spires of the Gothic cathedral, from the towers that form the corners of the ancient city wall to the cobbled squares, Freiburg exists in a reverie of medieval grace and imperial splendor.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: PETER JOKL;

Staying Fit 'Makes You Feel Good'
description: LEAD: THOUGH athletic wear is the height of fashion, most Americans are not fit. Only 40 percent of adults in this country say they exercise with any regularity, and only 20 percent do so at levels vigorous enough to produce cardio-respiratory benefits. Those are numbers should be improved, says Peter Jokl, president of the American Academy of Sports Physicians and the director of the Yale Sports Medicine Center in New

title: Groups Seek Jews' European Roots
description: MEMBERS of the Jewish Genealogical Society of Connecticut are tracing their roots, aided by old records - like a 1913 farm directory - and by new developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Some society members have been searching for decades, but more have only recently felt encouraged to look.

description: Although sequin-encrusted spandex has replaced taffeta and ponytails are as likely to grace the back of a young man's head as a young woman's, the gala festivities that mark the end of high school differ little from those held decades ago.

title: Ms. Warner to Wed William Simmons

description: IF a British country squire chose to settle in Connecticut, Washington, in the middle of Litchfield County, would be a good choice. Hardwood forests interspersed with towering hemlocks, sprawling farms and estates, are reminiscent of the English lake country.

title: 'Nannies Classes': When They Started
description: This letter is written in regard to the article, ''Nannies' Workshop Offers a Link Between School and Home,'' which appeared in the Westchester Weekly on April 29.

title: Deborah Ellis Is Married
description: Deborah A. Ellis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer N. Ellis of Madison, Wis., was married yesterday to Andrew W. Dwyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Dwyer of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at Riverside Church in New York. Ms. Ellis, who will keep her name, is the legal director at the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, in Newark. She graduated cum laude from Yale University. She and her husband, a Harvard University graduate, have law degrees from New York University. Mr. Dwyer is to become a clerk in August for Judge Dickinson Debevoise of Federal District Court in Newark.

title:
DINING OUT;

American Fare in Casual Fishkill Setting

In Dutchess County, the Fishkill area has a number of restaurants that will fill the bills of those seeking anything from Mexican to the hautest of cuisines.

title: Alison Friedricks Wed To Jonathan Alan Step
description: Alison Hope Friedricks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford A. Friedricks of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Alan Step, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Step of Indianapolis. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

description: The New York City Division of the American Cancer Society raised more than $600,000 Thursday night at a dinner dance in the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel. The evening honored Tony Bennett, the singer.

title: Connecticut G.O.P. Seems in Disarray
description: Battered by defections and internal bickering, Connecticut's Republican Party, which four months ago seemed confident in its ability to win its first gubernatorial election in 20 years, now appears on the brink of breaking apart.

title: Pistons Want Comforts of Home
description: Chuck Daly, coach of the Detroit Pistons, put it simply today.

title: Postings: Rye Brook Executive Park;   Learning Lessons Along the Way
description: In the eight years it has taken so far to build the Royal Executive Park in Rye Brook, N.Y., the market has taught the developers some important and expensive lessons. As a result, the final phase of the project will be rather different from the first.

title: CELL TRANSPLANT FOUND EFFECTIVE IN MUSCLE DISEASE
description: The first attempt in humans to correct the muscle defect that is at the heart of muscular dystrophy was a success, researchers reported yesterday.

title: AT HOME WITH ROBERT MOTHERWELL
description: This is my magic mountain,'' said Robert Motherwell, indicating his Greenwich, Conn., sanctuary of the past two decades - a converted carriage house that serves both as residence and studio. The artist who coined the term New York School for himself and the other Abstract Expressionists that made their mark on the art world 45 years ago now lives 32 miles from the heart of Manhattan.

title: A Midsummer Scottish Berry Binge
description: At the Dome restaurant, facing the main square in Blairgowrie, Scotland and just nearby Hodge's solicitor's office, it is possible to eat ice cream topped with Scotland's best raspberries, and to ponder the coincidences - and in this case the culinary rewards - of history. For in that solicitor's office a hundred years ago, James M. Hodge, forebear of the current head of the firm, took steps that permanently changed Scottish agriculture and cuisine and made the Tayside region -stretching westward from the North Sea and including the cities of Perth, Pitlochry, Blairgowrie and Dundee - a draw for travelers who think there is nothing more delicious than raspberries fresh off the vine. Unless, perhaps, it's freshly picked strawberries, gooseberries or blackberries (brambles when you are in Britain).

title: Golfers' Waiting Time Increasing
description: LEAD: WEEKEND crowds are approaching record numbers at Long Island's public golf courses, and waking up at the crack of dawn appears to be a luxury that golfers cannot afford if they want to tee off before noon.

title: Woman's 11-Year Battle on Eating Clubs Goes On
description: LEAD: AS a sophomore at Princeton University, Sally Frank was denied admission to its exclusive all-male eating clubs. That was in 1978, and today, after her well-publicized lawsuit, it seems that in the near future Princeton women will become full members of the clubs that once would not even let Ms. Frank in the door.

title: Ms. Denk to Wed Alan J. Romney
description: Ruth E. Schreyer-Denk of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susanne Romy Thelen Denk, to Alan John Romney, a son of Piedad M. de Cardenas Romney of New York and Dr. Harry Romney, who lives on the island of Majorca. A September wedding is planned.

title: S.E.C. Expansion
description: If the Southeastern Conference has his way, the 10-school conference will soon be adding at least two members, splitting into two divisions and holding a division playoff game to decide which football team goes to the Sugar Bowl.

title: Reaching for the Sky to Add a Room
description: STANDING atop the Plaza Hotel, with the leafy carpet of Central Park laid out 19 stories below, Lee Harris Pomeroy finds irony in the project he is about to begin - a $20 million reconstruction of the 83-year-old hotel's roof and top two floors into 14 penthouse suites.

title: Cara R. Kennedy to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Randolph M. Kennedy of Upper Saddle River and Sea Isle, N.J., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Cara R. Kennedy and Joseph C. Cuttone, a son of Ann J. Gallo of Mahwah, N.J., and Donato A. Cuttone of Grymes Hill, S.I. Miss Kennedy attended Vista College. Mr. Cuttone is a broker with Cuttone Inc., a New York stock brokerage headed by his father.

title: S. M. Rose, 77, Dealer And TV Car Salesman
description: Sam M. Rose, a Bronx car dealer who became well known in the New York area for appearing in his own local television commercials, died yesterday at the St. Joseph Medical Center in Yonkers after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Q and A
description: Baseball Road Trip

title: Works in Progress;   Kick Me
description: For the world cup finals, the quadrennial showcase of professional soccer that begins in Italy on Friday, 7,000 press credentials have been issued to reporters and photographers from 80 different countries. Perhaps four million fans are expected to witness the 24 national teams (including the United States', participating for the first time since 1950) vying for the world title. Countless millions will watch on television in 118 nations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: One thing that separates mere stamps from postal history is the evocativeness of an envelope or postcard. A stamp may have a handsome design, best admired in mint condition, or a readable cancellation that says something about when and where a stamp was used.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;   Costly Rehab Of the Past
description: The first section of rehabilitated apartments has opened at the 700-unit Alden Park development, part of a $66 million project that the developer says is the nation's costliest rehabilitation of a historic residential property. The location is between the communities of East Falls and Germantown, 20 minutes from Center City.

title: Dinner Guests At Camp David
description: Following is the official guest list for a dinner given by President and Mrs. Bush at Camp David, Md., tonight for President and Mrs. Gorbachev:

title: Lisa Gustin Weds P. D. Fitzsimmons
description: Lisa Gustin, a daughter of Ralph Livingston Gustin Jr. of Wellesley, Mass., and a stepdaughter of Mrs. z Gustin, was married yesterday at the Wellesley Congregational Church to Peter Day Fitzsimmons, a son of Thomas Fitzsimmons of Mansfield, Conn., and the late Virginia Fitzsimmons. The bridegroom's grandfather the Rev. Edward Day, a retired Episcopal priest, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Divine, a Congregational minister. Mrs. Fitzsimmons, a marketing consultant with John Hancock Financial Services in Boston, graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Smith College. She received an M.B.A. from Dartmouth College, as did her husband, a graduate of Harvard University. He is a manager in consulting services at Coopers & Lybrand in Boston. The bride's father is a retired lawyer and the bridegroom's father is a retired teacher.

title: The World;   In Isolation, The Burmese Vote, and Then Wait
description: THE person bearing the brunt of explaining the positions and policies of the National League for Democracy - the party that swept Myanmar's first multiparty elections in 30 years last Sunday, humiliating the military authorities - is a gentle 72-year-old named U Kyi Maung.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Union;   Space Problem: Trying to Fill 80 Empty Beds
description: The dean of students at Union College, Joseph Mammola, thought he had a plan to fill 80 empty dormitory spaces next year. The college would require all sophomores, in addition to freshmen, to live in college housing.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

Having a Retiree Underfoot, and What Can Be Done About It
description: LEAD: WHEN my husband announced he was going to retire I had visions of his stalking around the house watching me while I was on the phone, taking a nap, or gossiping with the neighbors at the mail-box instead of cleaning and cooking. How would I explain getting caught by an afternoon game show, which I had turned on just to entertain me while

title: Questions Nobody Asked
description: So many people had the chance to stand up publicly in Washington and put the questions to President Mikhail Gorbachev, but nobody did.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Summit in Washington;   Smiles, Golf Carts and 2 Lethal Footballs
description: The scene at Camp David this morning was tranquil and informal, if you did not count the 2 marines in fatigues frantically swabbing the landing pad, or the 14 marines in dress blues with rifles and Soviet and American flags, or the dozen sailors in dress whites standing at attention, or the swarm of security people, or the Soviet and American aides carrying the coded signaling devices for blowing up the world.

title: STALKING THE HYENA
description: EDGE OF EDEN

title: Postings: Report on a Chelsea Hybrid;   Condos Lag, Rentals Thrive
description: An unusual hybrid development in Chelsea - part rental, part condominium, part renovation, part new construction - is offering evidence of the sluggishness in New York's sales market. Almost 75 percent of the rental units have tenants, while only 30 percent of the condominiums have been sold, which has led to price reductions.

title: Academy To Link School And Work
description: LEAD: THAT businesses and schools must work together has been a common theme in education in recent years. For 70 ninth graders, that idea will become a reality this summer, and for the next three years.

title: Jail in California Is a Breakout Artist's Dream
description: Sheriff's Capt. Benny McLaughlin is having trouble keeping prisoners in his jail, one of the most overcrowded in California, but nobody is blaming the judicial system.

title: Capriati Gains Round of 16 in Paris
description: Jennifer Capriati, the reigning French Open junior champion, today continued to show why she has forsaken the junior ranks and defied chronology for bigger stadiums and stakes at the relatively tender age of 14.

title: Jill Lepard Becomes a Bride
description: At the Norwich (Vt.) Congregational Church, Jill Lepard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Lepard Jr. of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Thomas D. French, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. French of Andover, Mass., by the Rev. Mark Pickett. Mrs. French, 29 years old, graduated summa cum laude from Bowdoin College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received an M.B.A. from Harvard University, as did her husband, 30, an associate in the Boston management consulting firm of McKinsey & Company. He graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover and cum laude from Dartmouth College.

title: New Jersey Opinion;   8th-Grade Views on Society's Problems
description: As a class project, eighth-grade students at the John Adams Middle School in Edison chose topics from recent newspaper articles and gave their views in the form of letters to the editor. Their teacher is Linda Cutler, head of the English department. Here is a sampling of the students' opinions on society's problems and other issues.

title: Data Bank/June 3, 1990
Jill C. Luftig Marries Michael Mendelsohn
description: Jill C. Luftig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark D. Luftig of New York, and Dr. Michael G. Mendelsohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mendelsohn of Dix Hills, L.I., were married last evening. The bride's cousin, Rabbi Dennis Math, assisted by his wife, Cantor Ellen Math, officiated at the Equitable Tower in New York.

title: PLAYING HOST ON THE ROAD
description: Like innocents abroad, business travelers must navigate their way through a thicket of far-flung restaurants. When entertaining away from home, they bank on their own dining instincts, a few simple precautions and a little kindness from strangers to help them impress their business clients. Or at least insure a good meal.

title: Camera Shy
description: To the Editor: ''The How and Why of Turning Camera Shy'' by Martha Stevenson (Travel, March 11) reminded me of a visit to northern Thailand when my husband and I were approached by a guide for a Japanese couple our age with the request that they wanted to be photographed with us. I found it amusing to be the object and did not mind accommodating our peers of the East.

title: For the Much-Maligned Motel, *****
description: Two and a half years ago my wife and I decided to try living without a fixed address. We closed our house in Florida, packed all our hopes and dreams and socks and underwear into the trunk of our Buick Century, and set off in search of America.

title: E.P.A. Drops Waste Case in North Carolina
description: In a case watched closely by environmentalists and waste treatment companies, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has abandoned an earlier effort to revoke North Carolina's authority to regulate hazardous waste.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: No doubt the average amateur photographer has heard by now of Robert Mapplethorpe whose photographs have caused a nationwide commotion over the past year. Mapplethorpe's images sparked attacks on the National Endowment for the Arts and renewed efforts to crack down on ''obscene'' depictions of the human body.

title: Stop the World, Mexico Is Getting On
description: As usual, Carlos Salinas de Gortari is a man in a hurry - and with some tough decisions to make.

description: Suzanne Marek, a daughter of Zdenek R. Marek of New York and Jessica Ford Marek of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Quine Armstrong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Q. Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Christ Church in Greenwich.

description: YOU are what you buy, or, as a growing number of advocacy groups would have it, what you do not buy.

title: Francie Fischer Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. David S. Fischer of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced wedding plans for their daughter Francine E. Fischer and Mark R. Malina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Malina of Cheshire, Conn. Both are Union college graduates. Miss Fischer, 24 years old, is a financial analyst at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Mr. Malina, 26, with a law degree from Harvard University, is an associate at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. They will be married later this month.

title:
Northeast Notebook: New Bedford, Mass.;

A Waterfront Rehab Hotel
description: LEAD: Hopes are high here that the opening next spring of a four-story, 117-room Sheraton hotel in a renovated 86-year-old building will fill a void in this port city. New Bedford, with a population of 102,000, is an hour south of Boston.

title: A Word on Parks And County Policy
description: This is in response to a recent column, ''When Hatred Enters a Park, the Rats Cheer'' (Opinion Page, April 29), which addresses the issue of graffiti at Saxon Woods Park in White Plains.

title: Bensonhurst March Protests Acquittal in a Racial Killing
description: More than 350 demonstrators marched through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon to protest the acquittal on murder charges of a defendant in the racial killing of 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins, the police said.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Crystal Gazing

title: Doubts Remain After Lab Loses Nuclear Contract
description: More than a year after the Government alleged fraud at the major laboratory for analyzing radioactive and chemical contamination at the Hanford nuclear weapons plant, the laboratory has lost its contract.

title: Elizabeth B. Hix Marries
description: Elizabeth B. Hix and John T. Colby Jr. were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I. The Very Rev. Robert V. Wilshire officiated. Mrs. Colby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan R. Hix of Mill Neck, L.I., graduated from Skidmore College. She is an international operations coordinator at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. Mr. Colby, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Colby of Glen Cove, L.I., graduated from Syracuse University. He is the chief financial officer and secretary in New York of Doubleday Book Shops.

title: Drive to Counter Computer Crime Aims at Invaders
description: From Los Angeles to Atlanta, Federal and state law-enforcement agents have begun an intense battle against computer operators who break into government and business data systems.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: DO HORSES NEED LASIX?;

The Drug Is Beneficial to Horse's Well-Being
description: LEAD: Of all mammals, the horse seems to be the only one that bleeds from the lungs after exercise. Veterinarians estimate that between 44 percent and 75 percent of race horses suffer from exercise-induced pulmonary hemorrhage. Approximately 10 percent of them bleed from the nostrils while others are diagnosed by veterinarians who see blood in the trachea and upper respiratory tract with a flexible fiberoptics scope.

title: The World;   The Mideast Defies A Trend to Diplomacy
description: WHEN an Arab summit meeting ended here on Wednesday, the centerweight of Arab diplomacy seemed to have shifted perceptibly. The relative moderation of Cairo appeared to be yielding to the tough talking of Baghdad that has captured a mood of frustration and anger.

title: New Genetic Treatment Given Vote of Confidence
description: In a surprising turn of events, the first proposal to treat children with a severe genetic disease by inserting new genes into their cells has received an enthusiastic vote of confidence.

title: Fashion;   A Star-Studded Season
description: Consider the current state of fashion, and you realize just how good American designers really are. To put it mildly, the situation is unsettling. Store business ranges from tough to dismal. The cost of most clothing is exorbitant. Fashion itself is sort of standing still. Clearly, consumers are in no mood to embrace big style changes. After all, they have only recently accepted, in significant numbers, fashionably shorter skirts. Yet this turgid atmosphere actually points up the particular talent of America's designers. For they are - with rare exceptions - specialists in small changes.

title: Singapore Releases Lawyer
description: Teo Soh Lung, a lawyer who has been jailed for more than two years without trial since she was accused of taking part in a ''Marxist conspiracy'' to subvert Singapore, was released on Friday, but with limitations on her civic rights. The case of Miss Teo and 22 others arrested in 1987 has prompted much international criticism of Singapore's policy on human rights and its limitations on political expression. The release of Miss Teo leaves only Vincent Cheng, a church worker and the accused mastermind of the so-called Marxist conspiracy, still in detention.

title: Melissa Wilcox Married To David Bruce Kinyon
description: Melissa Helene Wilcox, a daughter of Barbara Wilcox of Norwich, Conn., and James F. Wilcox of Hartford, was married yesterday to David Bruce Kinyon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Kinyon of Lancaster, Pa. Msgr. James O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Norwich.

title: Richard W. Millar Is Dead at 91; Pioneer in the Aerospace Industry
description: Richard W. Millar, a major force in the development of Southern California's aerospace industry and former chairman of the Northrop Corporation, died Friday in a nursing home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: Cable TV Needs a Dose of Competition
description: Congress can best serve the short- and long-term national interest by permitting the telephone industry to compete in the cable television business. The alternative proposal, to re-regulate cable television is a second-best solution. And re-regulation would address only one facet of the issue - the concerns consumers have voiced about cable rates and service.

title: Gifted Children's Programs
description: Elizabeth Stone describes well the concerns about gifted education in the 1990's. One such concern is the limited number of programs.

title: Americans In Paris: Disparate Images
description: THE cinematic view of the American expatriate in Paris appears bounded by two extremes. One is the happy-go-lucky fellow who is looking for love that is here to stay (Gene Kelly in ''An American in Paris''). By contrast, witness the brooding and enigmatic loner who exudes lust (Marlon Brando in ''Last Tango in Paris'').

title: Coach Moves Up
description: After serving as an assistant coach of the United States baseball team that won a gold medal in the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, Ron Polk, the head coach at Mississippi State, has been named to lead the American team that will try for a repeat of the victory at the 1992 Games in Barcelona, Spain.

description: Your article ''Complaints Rising Against Lawyers'' (May 6) starts out by maintaining that ''More Long Islanders are complaining about lawyers than ever before . . . according to a state watchdog committee [the State Attorney's Grievance Committee for Long Island] .

title: Rabbi Joseph Asher, Synagogue Leader, 69
description: Rabbi Joseph Asher, the former senior rabbi of San Francisco's largest synagogue, Temple Emanu-El, died of cancer last Tuesday. He was 69 years old.

title: Ms. Hodin Is Engaged To Elliot Cooperstone
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Solomon Hodin of Scranton, Pa., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Barbara Eve Hodin and Elliot Sheldon Cooperstone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Cooperstone of Montreal.

title: Americans in Philippines Fear More Attacks
description: As the Philippines gets ready for a new round of talks on the future of the United States military installations, many Americans living here are bracing themselves for increasing anti-American violence, which in the last year has taken the lives of eight Americans.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Hark, Hark, Is That a Rare Bird?
description: LEAD: LIVING on the East End, it is hard not to be a bird watcher. What with the squadrons of Canada geese honking their way across the sky, osprey nests on telephone poles, the flash of a cardinal, blackbirds with the German flag on their wings, the aristocratic heron, the connubial swans, the squabbling gangs of ducks, it is all here.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Rental Apartments Thriving in Stamford
description: RENTAL apartments are popular in Stamford, where housing now lingers unsold for an average of 163 days. In the boom days several years ago it took only 30 days to sell a home, and prices have dropped 20 to 24 percent since then.

title: The Outdoor Play's the Thing
description: Earlier this spring, I received an invitation to the 60th anniversary performance of Merton Floats - Oscar Wilde's ''Salome'' - in the gardens of Merton College. It gave me quite a twinge. Over three decades ago, as an American at Oxford, I'd been an avid member - as actor, even as playwright - of the Merton Floats, the amateur theatrical group at the college. It is one of some 20 college theatrical clubs at Oxford. Float means ''a footlight'' - right, Dickensian English - in the plural, ''standing for the theatrical profession,'' since actors perform, of course, behind the floats.

title: Critics Question Planners' Study
description: LEAD: WHEN a plan for promoting tourism is presented to the Long Island Regional Planning Board later this month, it will be the fifth in a series of studies due to culminate in late 1991 with a strategic document intended to guide Long Island into the next century.

title: FASHION: On the Street;   Craze of Spring: Dots, Dots, Dots On Everything
description: No, this is not an eye test. It's merely this spring's instant fashion craze, polka dots. To be more precise, black and white dots, in various sizes, but mostly large, and in profusion.

title: U.S. Is the Leader in Decentralization
description: We are now entering an era in which our political allies - Germany and Japan - are our most formidable economic adversaries, and we do not know how to manage these changing circumstances yet, least of all in Washington.

title: Rainy Start for Dragon Races
description: Buddhist monks led the ceremonies this morning to open the 15th annual Hong Kong International Dragon Boat races, renacting the ritual aspects of the event that recall its 2,000-year-old history.

title: Susan V. Gerrity to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Gerrity of Loudonville, N.Y., have announced wedding plans for their daughter Susan V. Gerrity and Nathan A. Chase, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Chase of Clearwater, Fla. Miss Gerrity, 28 years old and a graduate of the University of Vermont, is a tour coordinator with the Vermont County Cyclers in Waterbury Center, Vt. Her father, the president of Saratoga (N.Y.) Raceway, raises horses in Kinderhook, N.Y. Mr. Chase, 27, attended the Vershire School and works at the Shed Restaurant in Stowe, Vt. His father is a partner in the law firm of Chase & Gay in New Port Richey, Fla. The wedding is to take place later this month.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Should Mets Do About Strawberry?
description: Management and fans have been frustrated with three seasons of minimal production from Strawberry. For someone who possesses some of the best natural talent in baseball, it seems that his problems revolve around attitude, or lack of it. Like fashion previews, fans are subjected to the appearance of the New Darryl each year. My feeling is that if $1.8 million a year does not motivate him, $3 million a year will certainly not. Trade him for the best available outfielder or catcher.

title: Parents Learn to Accent the Positive
description: A hush came over the crowded room of parents when the psychologist asked them to remember their best and worst bosses.

title: The Secrets of Gray Ranch
description: A field of blond grama grass three times the size of Manhattan whips in the desert wind, like a sheet on a clothesline, filling this valley 10 miles south to the Mexican horizon, where a mountainous cloud of spring rain has turned the morning dark. In its size and in the variety of life it supports, it is unlike any other grassland in North America, and yet here it is simply a ranch pasture.

title: Center to Offer Day Care To Mildly Ill Children
description: LEAD: A DAY-CARE CENTER for mildly ill children, said to be the first of its kind in the county, will be established this fall at the White Plains Hospital Center.

With a facility for dazzling multiple turns and vaulting leaps, Mr.

title: J. T. Phillips Wed To Ms. Southgate

Phillips of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. John F. Keane, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Joseph's Chapel in Magnolia, Mass.

title: 'Private' Lanai Is Private No More
description: For years, Lanai has been the most inaccessible and, in a certain way, the most alluring of the major Hawaiian islands. The smallest and least visited of the islands, it made few gestures to tourism. Visitors had only one modest 10-room hotel, few paved roads and one drab town. But those willing to brave rutted and dusty jeep tracks through pineapple fields found an isolated tropical paradise: deserted, pristine beaches and shipwrecks, red lava cliffs and deep gulches, mountains and tableland teeming with axis deer and pheasant, and magnificent views of nearby Molokai and Maui. Lanai, it seemed, was stuck in an earlier time, the Dole plantation era, before Hawaii was transformed by modern tourism and high prices - and many a knowing visitor preferred it that way.

title: Lake Balaton, Where Hungary Summers
description: Hungary has the largest freshwater lake in Central Europe: Balaton. Shaped like a 50-mile-long paprika, of the pointed piquant variety, Lake Balaton is about 60 miles from Budapest by way of the M7 highway and the same distance from the Austrian border.

title: Kathy Donohoe to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Douglas 3d of Orangeburg, N.Y., have announced wedding plans for their daughter Sandra L. Douglas and Todd K. Parker, a son of J. Ms. Douglas, 33 years old, is a legal secretary at the law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld in Washington. She and her fiance are graduates of Lynchburg College. Mr. Parker, 32, is a supervisor of ship-building operations with the Department of the Navy. He received a master's in public administration from Virginia comonwealth University. description: The cold war is dead and has been buried by George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev. But the cold war mentality, and undemocratic policies and practices designed to limit Americans' thoughts and associations that it engendered, live on. They, too, should be given a funeral.

title: Sydney Ullman, Former Administrative Judge, 79
description: Sydney Ullman, a retired Federal administrative law judge, died Thursday at a nursing home in Montclair, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

description: LEAD: The cruise control and radar detector set the speed, an electronic brain rations gas to the engine and calculates spark advance, idiot lights on the dashboard blink at even the suspicion that anything might be not entirely nice about oil pressure or brake fluid and a woman's recorded voice offers suggestions for using seat belts, turning on lights and making your monthly payments on time.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Should Mets Do About Strawberry?
