description: I think the Mets should trade Darryl Strawberry to the Phillies for Lenny Dykstra and Roger McDowell, or to the Giants for Kevin Mitchell.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Bedford, N.H.;

Condos Buck Slow Market
description: LEAD: A Local developer is moving ahead with a $50 million condominium housing development on the edge of a private golf course here despite the region's sluggish residential real estate market.

title: Marie Webster to Wed Thomas Loose in July
description: Marie Webster of East Conway, N.H., and Richard Webster of Intervale, N.H., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Tina Maureen Webster and Thomas Maxwell Loose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Loose of Painted Post, N.Y.

title: Burst of Freedom in Czechoslovakia May Split Czechs From the Slovaks
description: Seven months after the peaceful revolution that ended four decades of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia, the biggest political question is whether President Vaclav Havel can keep Czechs and Slovaks from going separate ways after free elections on June 8 and 9.

title: God, Humanity and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Phoebe Zeeman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Zeeman 3d of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced wedding plans for their daughter, Erica P. Zeeman and Mark T. Fitch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E Fitch of Leonia, N.J. Miss Zeeman, known as Phoebe, graduated from the New York Restaurant School and is a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, as is Mr. Fitch. They are to be married later this month.

title: A Politician's Life, From Militant to Mainstream
description: If, a generation ago, old guard Democratic leaders had been told that Bobby Rush, the militant leader of the Black Panther Party here, would rise to a position of power in the Illinois Democratic Party, they would probably have scoffed or shuddered.

title: Centralized Immigration Control Urged
description: Over objections from the Bush Administration, a Federal advisory committee will recommend creation of an independent Government agency to formulate immigration policy and to enforce laws now administered separately by three Cabinet departments.

title: 3-Way Race Focusing Campaign's Geography
description: PEOPLE who want to plan their summer vacations so they can rub elbows on the beach with a leading gubernatorial candidate - or avoid those pesky office seekers altogether - can take heart.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu;   A Preview of Summer in Pasta With Basil
description: The basil is looking better: the bunches are plumper, the leaves larger and with fewer black spots, the prices lower.

title: 2 Childhood Victims Recall Nazis' Terror
description: LEAD: HOW they grew up lightning fast in order to survive the madness of the Third Reich is the subject of two recent books by authors who live part time on the East End.

title: Hilary K. Colgate To Marry in Fall
description: Mrs. Howard Leach of San Francisco and John Kirtland Colgate Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Kirtland Colgate to Mark Jeffrey McInerney, a son of J. Barrett McInerney of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Marilyn McInerney. A November wedding is planned.

title: 'I AM ONE WITH THE MAD'
description: THE LOONY-BIN TRIP

title: Lauren Stevens to Wed Michael Bolen
description: The engagement of Lauren Elizabeth Stevens to Michael John Bolen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Bolen of Riverside, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Stevens of Woodbridge, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Tara Sherman Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. David H. Sherman have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Tara Lynn Sherman, and Dr. Anthony Alan Weiss, a son of Dr. Elizabeth Weiss of Riverdale, N.Y., and Dr. Marshall F. Weiss of New York.

title: Growing Up in the Richard Rodgers Household
description: LINDA RODGERS EMORY keeps a tiny framed note on the desk of her home here. ''Oh, how I envy you!'' it reads, in the handwriting of her father, Richard Rodgers.

title: Concerto Contest Names Winners
description: AFTER the gala concert last month that officially marked its 60th anniversary, the Westchester Conservatory of Music could rest on its considerable laurels, at least till next season. But not so: today at 3 P.M., the Conservatory Orchestra, directed by Elliot Magaziner, will be at Stepinac High School in White Plains to introduce and accompany the laureats of an all-Conservatory Concerto Competition.

title: God, Humanity and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Megan Craven and Lukas Guenthardt Are Wed
description: Megan Ann Craven, the daughter of Carolyn Morgan Palermo of Upper Grandview, N.Y., and the late Robert N. Craven, was married yesterday to Lukas Guenthardt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Guenthardt of Basel, Switzerland. Msgr. Arthur Campbell performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Church in Nyack, N.Y.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The Berkeley, Calif., grandmaster Walter Browne summed up his unimpressive performance in the Dortmund International Tournament in West Germany by remarking, ''I was playing solidly but made blunders at the end.'' His wife, Raquel, added that he had not shaken the bad cold he got in the previous competition, in Rekjavik, Iceland.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner;   A Taste of Sicily, or Maybe Milan
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some Italian restaurants that are open on Sundays.

title: Civvies for the American Military Economy?
description: As the cold war fades into history, policy makers are beginning work on trimming the military budget. But how easily can companies that serve the military convert their operations to civilian use? Seymour Melman, professor emeritus of industrial engineering at Columbia University and chairman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, and Lawrence Klein, Benjamin Franklin Professor of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania and a Nobel laureate, discussed the economic consequences of smaller military budgets with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.

title: What's Doing In;   Lisbon
description: One of the world's great port cities since Roman times, Lisbon is rediscovering its waterfront, and major efforts have begun to revive, expand and spruce up the neglected port area on the banks of the broad, moody Tagus River estuary. In modern times the stately Praca do Comercio, overlooking the river and framed by 18th-century arcaded government buildings was turned into a glorious parking lot. On either side of the square, extensive docks, wharves and warehouses were left to deteriorate and the riverside was totally bereft of hotels, restaurants or cafes.

title: Visa Rules for Performers Are Disputed
description: New Federal regulations intended to reduce the number of work visas granted on the basis of ''distinguished merit or ability'' are making it more difficult for new and less well-established performers from abroad to perform in the United States, music industry spokesmen contend.

title: LOVE AND RUMORS
description: BEHIND THE WATERFALL

title: Orchestra Blends 3,000 Years' Talent
description: SOME 60 musicians, ages 53 to 84, are scheduled to arrive in Mystic today. The members of the National Senior Symphony are coming from 24 states to rehearse for the orchestra's second annual concert, on Thursday. ''Three thousand years of musical experience will be on the stage,'' said the symphony manager, Mary Anne Stefanski.

title: Elsa Davern: Jewelry Maker
description: At jazz festivals and the private jazz weekends in Europe and the United States, unusual necklaces made of old beads and small artifacts have become a sign of recognition for women, likely to bring the question, ''Is that an Elsa?''

title: God, Humanity and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorist or Freedom Fighter? Pretoria Debates Whom to Amnesty
description: Robert McBride, an African National Congress guerrilla, sits on Pretoria's death row for planting a bomb in Durban that killed three whites in June 1986. Barend Strydom, a member of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, is there for shooting to death eight black pedestrians in Pretoria in November 1988.

title: Electronic Snooping: It's Not Just for Spies
description: So, what you've always longed for is a vehicle tracking system: it sprays a tracking fluid on the road that is virtually invisible to all but the vehicle in pursuit. Long no more: there's a new store in New York where you can purchase one for $595. (Father's Day, after all, is just around the corner).

title: FICTION
description: CRY SPY. By William Hood. (Norton, $18.95.) Alan Trosper, the hero of William Hood's previous novel, ''Spy Wednesday,'' is happily in from the cold and out of the Firm, the fictional United States intelligence agency for which he worked as a case officer. Trosper is just beginning to enjoy his new life in London with his new British wife when an old comrade-in-espionage contracts a rapidly fatal disease. Traces of a Soviet poison are found during an autopsy, and so, at the behest of his old employers, Trosper sets forth to find out who killed his friend and why. British intelligence is miffed at having an American ''cousin'' snooping around on British soil, and early on it is clear that William Hood himself presumes to trespass on literary territory mapped by another former intelligence man, John le Carre. Mr. Hood's novel is peopled with eccentrics of the spy trade and the narrative is far-flung and ambitious, ranging from Byelorussia in 1943 to London, Washington, Florence, Zurich, Vienna and Geneva in the preglasnost days before the fall of the Berlin Wall. Mr. Hood - who spent 30 years in American military intelligence, the O.S.S. and the C.I.A. - endeavors to show us these cities as agents see them, locales reduced to safe houses and offices where spy handlers fret. And he has knit a plot so intricate that readers may need some time to unravel it. Mr. Hood compels us to turn the pages, though his prose rarely rises to anything more than a serviceable level. Ultimately, ''Cry Spy'' disappoints; it ends clumsily, with characterization and plausibility falling away like bad cover.

title: NOTHING BUT CURVE BALLS
description: Nothing has come easy for Fay Vincent. Not even his ceremonial appearance at the belated opening day at Yankee Stadium.

title: Southern Art With a Sense Of Mission
description: ''Next Generation: Southern Black Esthetic'' is a loose, uneven, but important exhibition of works by 22 artists, many of them unknown outside the South. The selection was made by a curator outside the region, Lowery S. Sims of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, working from slides assembled by Southern curators, critics, artists and museum directors.

title: State Curbing Electronic Treasure Hunts
description: LEAD: METAL-DETECTOR hobbyists say their pastime is a relaxing electronic meditation that can yield pieces of history and retreive their neighbors' lost treasures. But state officials say the growing number of people who use radio-metal detection equipment poses a threat to the state's already endangered historical and archeological sites.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A FREE AND ORDERED SPACE: The Real World of the University, by A. Bartlett Giamatti. (Norton, $9.95.) The Renaissance scholar turned baseball commissioner, who died last year, examines the purpose of the university and the meaning of a liberal education in this series of essays, many of which were written while he was the president of Yale. When the book was published in 1988, one reviewer said that he ''contributes a fresh voice to the debate over higher education in America, writing not about what we ought to know, but about why it is important to know.''

title: SIMPLY FOR SIPPING
description: In summertime, when the livin' is easy, the drinking should be, too. Hearty wines, robust wines, complex wines - they are for long winter evenings, important dinners and serious guests. Summer is the time to drink wine, not think about it.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: JOYCE G. LEVIN;

When Children Return to the Empty Nest
description: LEAD: THEY have been referred to as ''baby boomerangs'' - those ''baby boom'' adult children who come back to their parents' home to live. In some instances, it is high rents that make it impossible for the adult child to leave home; in other cases there may be emotional reasons. But whatever the reason, making such an arrangement work can be a challenge.

title: The Executive Computer;   Who Would Buy Machines Without Disk Drives?
description: The Houston-based Compaq Computer Corporation is best known for its powerful desktop and floor-standing PC's. These are used by many businesses as ''servers'' for clusters of less-powerful machines connected on local area networks. In such a setup, one fast server with a large amount of hard disk storage is the repository of most, or all, files needed by a group of workers. Each worker on the network pulls the needed information from the server, processes it at a desktop computer - which in most cases does not need to be very fancy - then returns the files to the central server.

title: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions;   Babylonian Kings and Other Bits of Historic Exotica
description: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes.

title: Animal Shelter Asks City for More Aid
description: LEAD: CONNIE MOGULL, president of the New Rochelle Humane Society, was worried about the 1-year-old beige and black German shepherd-mix dog with the bleeding mouth. Confined to a 4-by-4-foot cage, he probably got excited just before feeding time and jumped against the fence, hurting himself, she said.

title: Miss Shino Weds G. L. Johnson 4th
description: Misao Shino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haruhiko Shino of Yokahama, Japan, was married yesterday to G. Leonard Johnson 4th, a son of Dr. Johnson 3d of Arlington, Va., and Jessie Reed of Hico, W.Va. The Rev. John Dexheimer performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Alpine (N.J.) Community Church.

title:
Your Own Account;

Getting Married, Again
description: LEAD: Wedding season is upon us. And 34 percent of today's weddings involve a bride or groom who has been married before, according to Bride's magazine. Yet financial planners say that many of these couples spend more time worrying about wedding bills than about how to merge their money styles and create a new, workable financial unit.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

To Dream the Impossible House
description: LEAD: LOUD rumbling calls me to the bedroom window of our condominium, and I see a rare sight: a moving van lumbers into the parking lot and awkwardly settles near an adjacent building. I remember that our neighbors Kathy and Peter are moving away today. Luckily, they have escaped being trapped in Bridgeport's glutted and slow-paced real-estate market.

title: Now Tries to Be Then in Land of Thunder Dragon
description: In a country like no other in South Asia, a country where icy peaks glitter in an unpolluted sky and protected pine forests still cover the mountain slopes, where rhododendrons bloom in the glens, a 34-year-old King armed with modern technology and an ancient culture is fighting to save the last Shangri-La.

title: Florio's School Plan Angers Bergen
description: Gov. Jim Florio's proposed law redistributing state school aid to local districts, and slashing $97 million from Bergen County's aid by the mid-1990's, has left Bergen's superintendents incredulous, indignant and gloomy.

title: Hers;   Pre-Wedding Syndrome
description: I'd reached that certain age when some studies said I had a better chance of being attacked by nuclear terrorists than registering for silver at Bloomingdale's.

title: A 64-Year Dream About Champagne
description: ONE of Gutzon Borglum's most ambitious bronze works was viewed with renewed reverence in recent days, not because of its 42 life-size military figures representing all of America's wars, but because of a rumor that champagne had been secreted inside more than 60 years ago.

title: Headliners;   Underachiever
description: In baseball, a long memory is not always useful. Neither is a good record. Davey Johnson, for instance, is now the New York Mets' former manager, after six seasons and a winning percentage of .588, because the last few weeks have been bad. In the broader view, they were only mediocre - just under .500 for the season - but the club's general manager, Frank Cashen, said the Mets were ''underachieving'' and left little doubt that he blamed Johnson's loose style. So Johnson was out on Tuesday, and on Wednesday Bud Harrelson, formerly third base coach, was manager. Meanwhile, Johnson was hinting that he would like a job with the Yankees, who are doing worse than the Mets. Loose or not, Johnson lasted longer than any other Mets manager and won a World Series and a division title. His teams never finished below second in the division, which looks good now.

title: Red Cross Takes Steps To Protect Liberians
description: The Red Cross today officially began protecting refugees in Liberia, as rebels advanced on the capital for a showdown with Government troops.

title: GIFTS THAT CAN CHANGE THE CLIMATE OF A MUSEUM
description: The art-world news from London, just two Sundays ago, concerned Heinz Berggruen, a 75-year-old art dealer who made his career in Paris between 1948 and 1980. From 1982 to 1988 he kept an apartment in the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Since then, he has lived in Geneva.

title: 5 Museums With a Feel for the Road
description: Last year, the Bridgewater Auto Museum in upstate New York closed its doors. It was housed in a white warehouse, a dim but sincere display of old cars that were parked and left to be looked at for 40 years, along with license plates, hood ornaments and a collection of power lawnmowers. The more valuable cars were kept behind chicken wire.

title: HELLO, COLUMBUS
description: THE HARP AND THE SHADOW

title: THE TOUGH GOT GOING
description: WHAT'S THAT PIG OUTDOORS?

title: WHEN THE RIGHT SNUFF BOX REALLY MATTERED
description: Queen Elizabeth condemned all forms of tobacco in 1584. Her successor, James I, attacked its use in a 1604 pamphlet, ''A Counterblaste to Tobacco,'' and sought to eliminate it by imposing higher taxes and attempting to restrict its cultivation. That their efforts were in vain can be seen in ''Powder Celestial: Snuff Boxes, 1700-1880,'' an exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art, through June 24.

title: God, Humanity and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Gregory Anrig Jr. Weds Miss Reid
description: Jeanne L. Reid and Gregory R. Anrig Jr. were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Jane Presler, an Episcopal priest, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Hard Line Taken
description: The American League president, Bobby Brown, imposed a three-day suspension on the Baltimore Orioles manager, Frank Robinson, for bumping an umpire. But if any National League managers or players think their president, Bill White, might be more lenient in such a situation, White wants them to think again.

title: Ranks of 'Reverse Commuters' Expected to Grow
description: To live in New York City and spend one's days working in a suburban office complex in New Jersey is still regarded as an unusual way of life. But if predictions by transportation analysts come to pass, by the end of the decade reverse commuters may have plenty of company as they cross the Hudson River against the traffic flow.

title: SUMMER STOCK
description: Soup's on'' can mean dinner, supper, lunch or - in Japan - breakfast is served. But with time in short supply for most cooks, soup increasingly is coming from a can, cube or metal packet. As a passionate proponent of soup, I am only too happy to speed its return to today's entertaining menus. Especially since soup, followed, say, by a fennel and radicchio salad with lemon dressing, thick crusty baguettes and fresh goat cheese, can make a gala luncheon or even a festive light supper on a hot day. And no matter how simple your dinner - cold poached fish, roast chicken, something from the grill - adding a sumptuous soup as a first course may turn the meal into an occasion.

title: BUSH AND BAKER
description: The article on George Bush and Jim Baker mentions a lack of ''passion'' in their governing style (''The Fabulous Bush and Baker Boys,'' by Maureen Dowd and Thomas L. Friedman, May 6). As far as I'm concerned, this country has concentrated too much on personal passions. Give me rational thinking any day! As the authors state so eloquently, ''Passion, symbols, bread and circuses - those are for political campaigns, not for governing.''

title: Holyfield Clearly Makes His Point
description: The ending was no surprise, less of one certainly than a prefight cameo appearance at ringside by Marla Maples, the supposed other woman in Donald Trump's life.

title: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: The Gorbachev's Will Get a Close Look at the America Beyond Washington;   San Franciscans to Give a Big Party
description: The T-shirt sellers are out in force, the gossip columnists are wondering why this C.E.O. was invited to meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev and that one wasn't, and the merchants at Fisherman's Wharf are hyperventilating about the boost to a sagging tourist industry.

title: Left-Handers and Right-Handers Are Tilting Team Rotations
description: Lee Thomas, general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, scans the walls in his office and checks the pitching staffs on the rosters of the other major league teams.

title: America's Cup '92 Dates
description: Challenger will meet defender in the first of a four-of-seven-race America's Cup match on Saturday, May 9, 1992, it was announced Friday.

title: Barry Crawford Wed To Gizella Callender
description: Gizella Anne Callender, the daughter of Gizella Parrish Callender of Lancaster, Pa., and Robinson W. Callender of Philadelphia, was married yesterday in Wellesley, Mass., to Charles Barrett Crawford, the son of Mrs. Robert R. Viscount of Woodbridge, Conn., and the late Charles Barrett Crawford. The Rev. Stephen J. White, an Episcopal minister, officiated at Wellesley College's Houghton Memorial Chapel.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a well with an expansion tank for the water. Does this tank require maintenance, and can you give me some idea of how it works?

title: SETTINGS FOR AN ALL-OCCASION MENU
description: Like a little black dress, a menu that adapts to almost any occasion saves both time and worry. The three plans for an outdoor meal given here not only offer this versatility, but allow doubling or tripling or even substituting ingredients. All the host needs to do is vary the presentation of the dishes slightly in order to serve them at a casual gathering, as a festive buffet or for a formal dinner.

title: College Students Teach Adults How to Read
description: LEAD: A SELECTED group of Westchester Community College students earned three units of college credit this spring while being trained to teach reading to illiterate adults.

title: 15 Towns Open Center For Household Poisons
description: LEAD: A DOZEN or so half-empty cans of oil-based paint have followed Charles C. Walden through 15 years and three homes. Together with containers of antifreeze and paint thinner, the cans took up a lot of room in the basement of Mr. Walden's home in Madison.

title: The Nation;   In Moscow, Yeltsin Has A Summit To Himself
description: IT truly was the far side of the summit here last week as Boris N. Yeltsin could be found leaning back in the Kremlin and waxing presidential, using some of the cold war bromide language about ''mutual understanding'' to talk of mercy toward his antagonist, who was in Washington. ''I am prepared to go a good part of the distance towards Gorbachev,'' Mr. Yeltsin said, delighting the nation's groundlings as he ascended to presidential office - President of Russia, the nation's heartland republic - and immediately began talking as Mikhail S. Gorbachev's equal.

title: Elderly Pair Arrested in Harlem Crack Case
description: A 73-year-old woman and a 68-year-old man were arrested yesterday after narcotics officers found crack, money and guns in their apartment in Harlem, the police said.

title: Gooden Sputters Again
description: Dwight Gooden is struggling and the Mets continue to look for answers, literally from head to toe.

title: Grim Reminder of World War II P.O.W.'s on Display
description: THE many years since the end of World War II have diminished some of Walter Furca's abilities, but not all of them. Not his ability to remember.

title: THE BASIC REPERTORY: ROOTS TO GROW BY
description: When Virgil Thomson began writing music criticism in New York half a century ago, he was appalled to find the repertory in the grip of what he termed the ''50 famous pieces.'' Furthermore, he discovered, the tyranny of these masterworks was made possible with the complicity of a handful of big-name performers and their managers, who profited by keeping music in a stagnant state. Artists like Toscanini and Heifetz, who Thomson felt could have sold the public anything they chose to play, betrayed music by feeding audiences a few familiar, easily digested standards.

title: Local Wines in a North Fork Setting
description: VISITING California's Napa and Sonoma Valleys means both a tour of the vineyards and enticing food at charming restaurants. The fine dining that usually follows the winemakers has not yet materialized on Long Island's North Fork. From Riverhead to Orient Point, two or three restaurants, at best, are worth the trip.

title: Summit in Washington;   Chevron and Soviets to Work Toward Oil Venture
description: The Chevron Corporation signed an agreement today that could open the way for a major expansion of its commercial activities in the Soviet Union.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: DANIEL P. GUIDO;

Suffolk's No. 1 Law and Order Man
description: LEAD: HE is, he says, a congenial individual, but there is something in the face of Suffolk County Police Commissioner Daniel P. Guido that suggests a harder side to this career police administrator, a man credited with ending the most-troubled period in the department's history since taking over in April 1988.

title: Some Subjects for Summiteers to Ponder On;   Revenge and Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Gifted Children's Programs
description: While the new theorists worry about how to structure curriculums for gifted programs and talk about nonsensical mots and plops, they should keep in mind the most significant element of successful programs: lots of bright, curious children challenging one another to new heights of achievement. Creative, energetic teachers who respond to and further stretch these gifted minds are the other component of successful gifted programs. As a student at Hunter College High School in the 1970's, I was offered ''innovative'' curriculums in math and the humanities; however, my sense is that the students and teachers were the reasons for its success. Let's devote our resources to developing and paying challenging teachers to teach our gifted.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 171 AND COUNTING

title: The Male Athlete and Sexual Assault
description: Once revered as much for his manly image as for his on-the-field performance, the male athlete is receiving increased scrutiny for his off-the-field behavior with women.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu;   Sushi With a Difference: No Raw Fish
description: When Katsu Toyota was growing up in Japan, the sushi parlor near his home served a dish that he describes today as steamed sushi.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a well with an expansion tank for the water. Does this tank require maintenance, and can you give me some idea of how it works?

title: Housing Auctions Find Niche in Slow Market
description: LEAD: PETER A. FLIHAN 3d of Tarrytown, who married yesterday, loves the idea of real estate auctions. ''The asking price of a condominium we were interested in was $243,000,'' he said. ''At the original price there was no way we could afford it. Our final cost at auction was $167,000.''

title: Police Filch Faxes to Snare a Gambling Ring
description: A tale of high-tech tactics in which the law-enforcement authorities out-faxed a major illegal-gambling ring emerged last week with the arrests of 43 people in New York City and the suburbs.

title: The World;   45 Years of Change, But the Same Names
description: 1942 - Japanese forces occupy Burma, a British territory.

title: A Time to Die
description: When she visits her husband in the nursing home, she apologizes to him. Ann is a nurse, and her husband was a carpenter, and when they came home from work in the old days, before the accident, she would tell him about the people on machines, the respirators and the feeding tubes. And he would say, ''If that ever happens to me, I want you to shoot me.''

title: Waterfront Renewal Turns to Greenpoint
description: A developer who built his reputation in Manhattan high-rise construction is embarking on the first major effort to redevelop the long-neglected East River waterfront in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: Bowers and Merena, Inc. will hold an auction on June 11 to June 13 in New York City to sell some remarkable examples of American numismatics. Among the items are a rare 1893 silver dollar from the San Francisco Mint.

title: BERLIN AFFAIR: A THRILLER
description: THE INNOCENT

title: Schools Getting Weather Radios
description: LEAD: WEATHER ALERT radios, which activate automatically in case of severe impending climatic conditions, will be distributed Thursday and Friday to superintendents of all Westchester school districts.

title:
ART;

Celebrating the 'Nancy' Strip for Its Clarity and Its Chuckles
description: LEAD: WHEN this writer was younger, the local newspaper found itself top-heavy with comics and polled its readers to find out the favorites. ''Nancy'' received just a trickle of votes but the strip was kept anyway because the paper decided that most of this moppet's fans were too young to write.

title: Meg Smith Becomes Fiancee of George Kimball
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. William Smith of Lexington, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Marilyn Ann Smith and George Jones Kimball, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Kimball Jr. of New York and Milbrook, N.Y.

title: Question Of the Week;   What Should Mets Do About Strawberry?
description: They should do what any major league franchise should: get rid of him. A .240 hitter who rarely delivers in the clutch, runs the bases like a minor leaguer and plays the outfield like Dave Kingman, is hardly likely to lead the way to another pennant. Strawberry arrived in the majors in 1983; if he hasn't reached his potential by now, the prospects are beginning to look dim.

title: Fargis Heads Riding Team
description: Joe Fargis of Southampton, L.I., winner of the $50,000 Devon Grand Prix here Thursday evening, heads the roster selected to ride for the United States equestrian team at the world championships starting in Stockholm July 25.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: UMass;   Using the Stage To Teach Students About Safe Sex
description: A mysterious figure clad in a gray trenchcoat and a black hat slips noiselessly into the yellow beam of a mock street light.

title:
The Executive Life;

Recharging the Batteries of Midlife
description: LEAD: To Judson Reis, it seemed as good a time as any to pay back the debt he felt he owed to the business world. Three years ago, the corporate finance department at Morgan Stanley & Company where he worked had hit a lull. As a managing director at the firm for 10 years, he had earned a six-month leave with pay.

title: A Lot's Amiss, But the Indexes Could Care Less
description: Just as all of Washington was celebrating the victory of capitalism over Communism, a symbol of capitalist excess surfaced last week at the most symbolic of places, where Monopoly is made.

title: Currency;   Gaining Ground on the Mark
description: The dollar rose against the West German mark again last week, topping 1.70 marks to the dollar briefly on Friday before slipping back to 1.6985. The dollar is now up more than 4 percent against the mark since the beginning of May. Some foreign exchange traders say that part of the mark's weakness stems from the belief that the West German Bundesbank is having more disagreements than usual over economic policy with the West German Government. In addition, there may be more dissension within the Bundesbank itself. Both strains, if true, could hamper the Bundesbank's efforts to make the economic unification of the two Germanys as smooth as possible. Meanwhile, the dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, finishing the week above the key 150 level.

title: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
description: In a letter to the editor (May 20), Laurence H. Tribe wrote that a quotation he ''never uttered'' had been ''incorrectly attributed'' to him in my article ''When Legal Titans Clash'' (April 22). The disputed quote was a reference by Professor Tribe to a colleague of his at the Harvard Law School, Alan M. Dershowitz: ''There are a lot of cases he has taken that I have refused.'' As I hope the article made clear, I hold both men in high esteem. In separate interviews, each of them expressed great respect for the other, as well as considerable differences of opinion. A review of the recording of my interview with Professor Tribe confirms the accuracy of the quotation.

title: Cabinetmaker Keeps Shaker Design Alive
description: LEAD: THE Shakers believed in a rare work ethic - applying hands to work and minds to God; beauty was not sought for its own sake. But Ian Ingersoll, a cabinetmaker who has been making Shaker-style furniture for 15 years, says he is driven by esthetics and challenged by the Shakers' intricate mechanics and pared-down design.

title: Nathalie Warriner and William Turecamo Marry
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, Va., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Nathalie T. Warriner, a daughter of Reuel E. Warriner Jr. of Laguna Beach, Calif., and Mrs. William W. Blunt Jr. of Dallas, to William R. Turecamo. The Rev. Richard Peard officiated. Mrs. Turecamo, 22 years old, is a senior at Boston University. She graduated from the Hill and Hotchkiss Schools. Mr. Turecamo, 33, is a son of Vincent C. Turecamo of Southampton, L.I., and the late Linn Biron. He graduated from the Buckley and Hotchkiss Schools and Princeton University and received a law degree from Fordham University. He is a vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Asset Management in New York.

title: PARSLEY: GOOD ENOUGH TO EAT
description: ''It's like parsley. If they take it away, no one's going to know the difference.'' - ''The Fabulous Baker Boys''

title: BRUSH ASIDE THE IDEA OF PAINTING CD'S
description: It only takes a little practice to believe impossible things. That's what the Queen told Alice in Wonderland. ''Why, sometimes,'' she said, ''I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.''

title: That Incredible, Shrinking Indy 500
description: The National Football League, which is trying to cut the average length of its games back to three hours, would love to have the problem that the Indianapolis Motor Speedway has.

title: Mercy Hospital Fought On Expansion Proposal
description: LEAD: MERCY HOSPITAL in Rockville Centre is planning a major expansion at the same time that an affiliated order of nuns, which owns property next to the hospital grounds, wants to sell 19 acres of woodlands to a condominium developer.

title: CRIME
description: Don't move to the suburbs, for crying out loud, if you're working on a serious love affair. Detective Chief Superintendent Geoffrey Bailey and Crown Prosecutor Helen West, those attractive and mature lovers we met in ''A Question of Guilt,'' come to this conclusion in Frances Fyfield's NOT THAT KIND OF PLACE (Pocket Books, $17.95). But not before life in the stultifying village of Branston knocks a few buds off their greening relationship.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: NERVOUS LAUGHTER
description: ''MASQUERADE'' AND OTHER STORIES

title: China's Long Wall of Silence
description: LEAD: It is one year since China's democracy movement was crushed in Tiananmen Square, and 10 years since its ''Democracy Wall'' movement was brutally suppressed. Will Chinese intellectuals once again allow 10 years to pass silently while the fire of democracy grows cold?

title: IF THE PROBLEM IS JIGGLING, THE SOLUTION IS NOW AT HAND
description: When a new VCR is launched, its manufacturer usually feels obliged to say that it represents an improvement. Such claims are often backed up merely by some added frill that has nothing to do with picture quality. Not so in the case of Panasonic's new PV-S4990. This model is one of the first home VCR's to include Time Base Correction, called TBC for short.

title: Time Warner Is Closer to a Cable Franchise Pact
description: Negotiators for New York City and Time Warner have narrowed their differences over the renewal of franchises for two Manhattan cable television systems that Time Warner operates, officials on both sides say.

title: Recycled Paper Is Not the Only, or Best, Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Moncrief Slaps Value of College
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Blueprint for a Better Propeller
description: Engineers at the Lewis Research Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Cleveland have been working for more than a decade on advanced high-speed propeller designs. One promising prototype now undergoing wind-tunnel tests features two counter-rotating propellers, built by the Hamilton Standard Company, that could operate on aircraft flying at speeds as high as Mach 0.85. Powered by turbofan jet engines, the propeller device has eight forward and nine aft blades. Their angles can be adjusted during operation to dampen noise and to achieve the highest ratio of thrust to engine output under different load conditions, ranging from takeoff to cruising to reverse-thrust operations during landing. According to NASA, counter-rotating propellers are up to 10 percent more efficient than single propeller designs.

title: World Markets;   The Making of a European Market
description: Rudiger von Rosen, executive vice chairman of the Federation of German Stock Exchanges, has been pushing for the development of a pan-European stock market. But, at the same time, his continuing interest in protecting his home market shows why this effort is fraught with difficulty.

title: Jane Owen Weds Alexander Brash
description: The Church at Point O'Woods, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jane Owen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Querengesser of Toronto, to Alexander R. Brash, the son of Mrs. Douglas R. Brash of Essex, Conn., and the late Mr. Brash. The Rev. Dr. Daniel M. Young, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Danielle DiGiacomo to Wed in the Fall
description: October wedding plans for Danielle DiGiacomo and David Kent Ganek have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank DiGiacomo of Paris. Mr. Ganek is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ganek of New York.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Georgia;   A Student Group Works to End Racial Incidents
description: Residents of a dormitory at the University of Georgia have organized to put a stop to racial harassment.

title: All Is Not Tranquil In the Machine Age
description: ONE of the ways in which we show mastery over our environment is by controlling wild animals in zoos. Machines also often seem like marauding animals raging back and forth across an otherwise civilized world.

title:
THE GREAT OUTDOORS;

OUTDOOR PLEASURES
description: LEAD: Whether you are planning to be a generous host or simply an inspired guest, here are 12 diverting ideas for making the most of entertaining in the outdoors, be it a stone's throw from the house, on the beach or deep in the countryside. Some suggestions are practical - an ice chest that converts into a seat, for example.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: NO GOOD LIFE GOES UNPUNISHED
description: FAMILY SINS & OTHER STORIES

title: IN SEARCH OF BRUCE LEE'S GRAVE
description: As an Asian-American born some 12 years before Shanlon Wu, I was surprised to read of his difficulty in finding Asian heroes in America (About Men: ''In Search of Bruce Lee's Grave,'' April 15). When Mr. Wu was a boy, Hiram L. Fong, a Chinese-American, and Daniel K. Inouye, a Japanese-American, were representing Hawaii in the United States Senate.

title: Nina Middleton Marries Lars Toomre
description: Eugenia Matthews Middleton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Middleton of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Lars Toomre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alar Toomre of West Newton, Mass. The Rev. John Luttrell performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Three Decades Ago, Another Visitor
description: Much has changed since Nikita S. Khrushchev barnstormed the country three decades ago, meeting American labor leaders in San Francisco, visiting an Iowa corn farm and touring a machine tool plant in Pittsburgh.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: First-quarter productivity figures are due out. Soviet and American high-technology leaders meet in Santa Clara, Calif., to improve trade relations, while officials meet in Washington to discuss sales by American food companies in the Soviet Union.

title: New Way to Tan: Slow and Healthy
description: Covering up on the beach is a wonderful idea, but it takes more than clothing to do the job completely. The face and other exposed areas of skin need to be protected in any outdoor activity. It is always advisable to apply sun screens, which have proliferated in recent years. Every cosmetic company today offers a range of products.

title: What It Takes to Survive on a Bicycle
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing Change
description: A new Gallup Poll confirms that people want the Mint to go on coining pennies, even though they're mainly a nuisance, and don't want a dollar coin, despite its genuine convenience. To a skittish politician, that says don't meddle. But the constructive message is that changing change takes leadership.

title: CHINA'S UNTOLD STORY: WHO DIED IN THE CRACKDOWN?
description: A year ago there was no more potent symbol of China's crackdown than the television image of the young man who halted a convoy of tanks near Tiananmen Square. And today, there is no better example of the uncertainties of what really happened than the confusion about that man's identity and fate.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended May 19

title:
New Jersey Opinion;

A Great Place To Retire
description: LEAD: IT was a traumatic move. After 25 happy years in our seven-room house in a small cul-de-sac street in Valley Stream, L.I., we - my sister, my brother and I - decided to sell and move to an adult residential community in central New Jersey.

title: Hispanic Playwright Follows 'the Dream'
description: WHILE driving in Huntington one day last year, Eduardo Ivan Lopez took a wrong turn. As he looked around, he had a sudden sense of deja vu.

title: When a Drive Leads to Court
description: The scenario goes something like this: Barreling down the highway in your new touring machine, you and your family and your pet sheepdog, Bosco, could not be happier. Suddenly, in the middle of the 200th refrain of ''Row, Row, Row Your Boat,'' your good cheer is broken by the wail of a siren. It's a state trooper, who pulls you off the highway for traveling too fast in a 55-mile-an-hour zone, directs you to follow him 15 miles down a country road, and deposits you in a sweltering, one-room courthouse where you wait all day for a justice of the peace to hear your case.

title: Randi L. Simowitz, Graduate Student, Weds Andrew W. Feinberg, Law Clerk
description: Randi Lynn Simowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Simowitz of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to Andrew William Feinberg, the son of Dean Lilienstern Feinberg Stein of Longmeadow, Mass., and Barry Feinberg of West Haven, Conn. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at Temple Beth Tikvah in Wayne.

title: FUTURES TRADING
description: I share the view expressed in Louis Uchitelle's article ''Futures Trading: Does Chicago Run Wall Street?'' (April 22) that the equities markets and the stock-index futures markets, are, in effect, one market, but I do not believe that one market demands one regulator. The leadership of the Treasury Department, which comes from Wall Street, may think so. The Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who would see his power expanded, may agree. But the head of the Federal Reserve Board, an undisputed market expert without a vested interest in either side of this issue, told a Senate Banking subcommittee early in April that he did not believe that the existing division of regulatory authority between the S.E.C. and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission had increased volatility in the securities markets. ''Nor,'' he added, ''in this regard is it a threat to the capital-formation process.''

title: 'Yes - and No - Prime Minister!'
description: For the past three months, Anglophiles have had reason to switch at 9 P.M. Sundays from ''Masterpiece Theater'' on PBS to C-Span, in order to catch ''Prime Minister's Question Time'' from the House of Commons.

title: A TOUCH OF SPICE
description: Chicken breasts, short ribs, bacon, a large spanish onion and head of cabbage lay on a worn-wood cutting board, evoking images of a 17th-century kitchen in a Dutch still life. This particular tableau, however, belongs very much to the present. It is in the home of Alberta Wright, the owner and chef of Jezebel, a popular Manhattan restaurant that has been a favorite of celebrities, critics and aficionados of Southern cuisine since it opened six years ago. On this sunny afternoon, Ms. Wright was busily preparing four dishes for a summer supper, a distinctive menu that included peanut butter soup, cabbage and shrimp over rice, white corn muffins and raspberry parfait. As she cut the meat, diced the onion and tore the cabbage leaves, her town house in the West 40's filled with the aromas of her travels - and the flavor of her imagination.

title: Sun-Worshippers Go Under Wraps to Catch the Rays
description: Noel Coward was among the first to warn us about the noonday sun. He was followed by scores of dermatologists and cosmeticians. Today more and more people are taking those warnings seriously and refusing to venture out into the sun unless they are slathered in sun block - or swathed in fabric. Beach cover-ups have become almost as important as swimsuits for summer at the shore or by the pool.

title: Broadway's Bounty: Dramas Brimming With Life
description: ''What kind of day has it been?'' That was the question with which William Goldman closed ''The Season,'' his classic journalistic study of one season (1967-68) in the life of the Broadway theater just as it slid into its most precipitous period of decline. Two decades later no one can say whether that decline has yet halted, but the 1989-90 New York theater season, on and off Broadway, has been one unexpectedly, perhaps inexplicably, bright day. Theater art, show biz glamour and, best of all, American plays about lives that intersect with the audiences' own have been in high supply during the 12 months that will be celebrated tonight, as tradition has it, at the Tony Awards show.

title: CELEBRITIES ONE-ON-ONE
description: In an era when vanity parades as substance and notoriety has become its own shallow reward, Roddy McDowall's DOUBLE EXPOSURE: Take Two (Morrow, $60) proves a reassuring reminder that some celebrity is still based on talent and accomplishment. This collection of Mr. McDowall's elegant photographs of 116 eminent subjects - culled primarily from the stage, film and music worlds - is amplified with commentaries by other celebrities. Predictably, most of these are valentines, but even so contain revelations. ''I suppose as much as I hated most of what he was and did, I somehow knew that he couldn't help it and I loved what was left,'' confides Blake Edwards about Peter Sellers. ''His critiques of films are subtle and can be very amusing, especially of the ones he hasn't seen,'' remarks David Hockney about Billy Wilder. Mr. Wilder, in turn, tells a priceless story recalling bittersweet difficulties directing Jean Arthur in ''A Foreign Affair'' and her phoning him 40 years later. Jane Fonda shares her view of Gregory Peck as ''a sensualist with a Lincolnesque demeanor.'' Other pairings include Helen Hayes on Ina Claire, Charlton Heston on Katharine Cornell, Bette Davis on Claude Rains, Neil Simon on Joan Rivers, Sir John Gielgud on Vivien Leigh, Jules Feiffer on Al Hirschfeld, Zubin Mehta on Beverly Sills and Ringo Starr on Mae West. Philip Dunne supplies the wisest pronouncement in his homage to Darryl F. Zanuck: ''Creators are judged not by their personalities but by their achievements.''

title: CHET BAKER'S HORN AND VOICE ECHO WITH PATHOS
description: The attention brought to a recently deceased musician inevitably inspires at least a brief flurry of activity around his or her slot in the record stores. The new releases have been particularly abundant in the case of the trumpeter and singer Chet Baker, who died at the age of 59 in 1988 and who was one of the most recorded artists in jazz. He didn't so much make records as permit others to make records of him. In addition, last year's ''Let's Get Lost,'' the visually stunning documentary equivalent of ''The Glenn Miller Story'' or ''The Fabulous Dorseys,'' has given his music enough exposure to turn the steady stream of releases into a deluge.

title: Who Won On Abortion Law?
description: CONNECTICUT'S new abortion law has been the most distorted and misrepresented piece of legislation to surfacefrom the 1990 session of the General Assembly.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Why I'm Not Moving
description: LEAD: TO move or not to move, that is the question. What are we waiting for? The millennium? A turnabout in the real-estate market?

title: Clean Water Enforcement Act Criticized
description: A Tough new law that imposes mandatory penalties for violation of the state's water pollution regulations is being criticized by public utilities officials and business and industry representatives. They say the law will ultimately cost taxpayers millions of dollars in fines and perhaps billions of dollars in waste-water treatment plant improvements that could be obsolete by the time they are in place.

title: Recycling Record At Blind Brook
description: The April 22 article ''Sorting the Garbage: How Well Is It Working?'' stated: ''At Lakeland High School there, students . . . started the county's only plastics-recycling program.''

title: Andrea Bond Is Wed
description: At Christ Church Cambridge, Andrea G. Bond, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Bond Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to John R. Wilson Jr., a son of Mr. Wilson and Brayton Wilson, both of Cleveland. The Rev. Eugene Goetchius performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Wilson, 24 years old, graduated from Dana Hall School and Lake Forest College; Mr. Wilson, 26, from Northwestern University. He is an investment banker with Kidder Peabody & Company in Chicago.

title: COFFEE, TEA OR A FIBBER MCGEE?
description: From the outset, we Americans have pursued a radical policy of laissez-faire when mixing drinks. Our Colonial forebears threw everything but the kitchen sink into their punches, flips, shrubs and sangarees. In the 19th century, celebrity bartenders would tour Europe and astonish the natives by shaking up blue blazers, Connecticut eye-openers, Alabama fog-cutters and lightning smashes. The stern imperatives of Prohibition produced such fanciful but now forgotten gargles as the whizz-doodle, the bee's knees and the Fibber McGee. H. L. Mencken once hired a mathematician to calculate just how many cocktails could be made at a first-rate bar. The total was 17,864,392,788. And still the tinkering goes on. ''I have myself invented eleven,'' Mencken wrote, ''and had nine named after me.''

title: BASEBALL: National League;   Giants Rally in 9th and 10th to Beat the Astros
description: Mike Kingery's run-scoring single with two out in the bottom of the 10th inning, his second run-scoring single of the game, rallied the San Francisco Giants to a 5-4 victory today over the Houston Astros.

title: Mall Builders See Growth Continuing
description: DESPITE falling retail sales, rising vacancy rates and problems at a number of major department store chains, a mall building boom is still under way in Connecticut.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The most important thing we're going to discuss today is to go over the planet and its hot spotss - in other words, to discuss regional issues. And of course we will pursue our general discussions in order to understand each other better.''

title: HOMELESS MAN SLAIN IN DISPUTE OVER A SODA
description: A homeless man was fatally stabbed by another homeless man late Friday night at La Guardia Airport after the two argued over a can of cherry soda, the police said.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: His First Cathedral

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Some Subjects for Summiteers to Ponder On;   Germany in NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Long Island City;   Citicorp Tower as a Harbinger for Jackson Avenue
description: WHILE most eyes in Long Island City, Queens, have been trained on the waterfront as the enormous Hunters Point commercial and residential project goes through municipal review, city planners have also been devising a framework for much greater development along the nearby Jackson Avenue corridor.

title: Advocates for Tenants in Mt. Vernon
description: EVERY time it rains, the ceiling in Diane Brown's Mount Vernon apartment leaks. The boiler in the Cortlandt Street building has been broken since March 31, leaving 50 families living there with no heat or hot water.

title: Polls in Peru Show a Tight Race Shaping Up
description: Peru's presidential race nears the runoff vote on June 10 with a near-tie in the polls between the two candidates: Mario Vargas Llosa, the novelist, and Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer.

title: Camps for the Elderly Prove as Durable as Their Guests
description: LEAD: WHEN Joseph Borzar first heard about Vacation Lodge, he had his doubts. A summer camp for the elderly sounded like a good idea, he said, but who knew?

title: 2 Charged With Random Killing of Harlem Doctor by Stray Shot
description: Two 20-year-old Harlem men were charged yesterday with the killing of a 60-year-old doctor who died when a stray bullet tore through his kitchen window early Friday and hit him in the chest, the police said.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: John E. Trafford;

Heading a Group Helping Municipalities
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey State League of Municipalities has been saying it for 75 years: whether one is an elected or appointed local official, ''We could make your job easier.'' John E. Trafford, the league's executive director, put it a little differently but just as invitingly: ''There is no need for any member municipality to go it alone.

title: The World;   Voting Isn't Helping in Guatemala
description: MORE often than not, President Vinicio Cerezo packs a pistol under his custom-made suits - a sign, he says, that he will defend his Government with his life. But for many Guatemalans, the gun is a bitter symbol of the carnage plaguing this country, and of the Government's failure to uproot the military's regimented control.

title: Jennifer Schultz Wed in Scarsdale
description: Jennifer Lockhart Schultz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lockhart Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bruce Allan Demaree, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Thomas Demaree, also of Scarsdale. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale.

title: GRAND CENTRAL BASKS IN A BURST OF MORNING LIGHT
description: A stunning thing happened the other day, which was the removal of the illuminated Kodak sign that had filled the east end of the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal since 1950. Actually, it was the removal of the huge curtain that had been erected to obscure the dismantling of the sign, which has been taking place gradually over the past couple of months. But now it is all finished, and Grand Central's concourse, surely the finest public room in New York City, can be seen in a state closer to its original than at any time in more than a generation. The greatest surprise of all is the view through the vast arched windows at the east end of the concourse, a view that has been blocked for years, as well as the avalanche of morning light that now cascades in from that direction. Who could ever have imagined that you would be able to see the United Nations Secretariat Building from within Grand Central Terminal?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: A Play About Paris
description: ''The Last American in Paris,'' a theater piece in English and French, will be performed through next Sunday at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., Exit 28 of the Hutchinson River Parkway. Performances are at 8 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday and 7:30 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets: $20. Information: (914) 251-6200.

title: Japanese Fare With Views of the Sound
description: WATERFRONT dining is at a premium in Connecticut, reason enough to savor the experience of Sapporo in Stratford. The Japanese restaurant, which faces Long Island Sound at the mouth of the Housatonic River, is at the very end of Sniffen Lane; Milford Point is directly across the water.

title: Summit in Washington;   Meanwhile, Back in Moscow, the News Is Bad
description: Domestic issues ranging from economic reform to political opposition have shaped Soviet press coverage of the Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting in Washington.

title: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: The Gorbachevs Will Get a Close Look at the America Beyond Washington;   High Technology and Diary Cows in Minnesota
description: The grass along the freeways is freshly mowed, there are Soviet flags and signs everywhere, and out near suburban Rosemont, on the way to Richard Brand's dairy farm, the Dakota County highway department has painted a fresh yellow stripe down the middle of State Road 3.

title: Police Kill Queens Man Paroled for Robbery
description: A Queens man on parole was shot and killed by police yesterday in South Ozone Park after he pointed a gun at four officers who had been chasing him, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Style Makers column on May 20 about Judith Niedermaier, a display designer in Chicago, misstated her role in creating mannequins shaped like wooden clothespins for the Fendi boutique in New York.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing;   In Kingston, the Waterfront Lives On
description: The Rondout Creek waterfront is a gateway to the Hudson River, just as it was back in the early 1800's, when Kingston was the home port of a thriving barge industry transporting coal, cement and bricks to New York City. A few old buildings remain as reminders of Kingston's industrial past, but today the waterfront area, at the confluence of the Rondout and the Hudson, reflects its attraction today for tourists, with marinas, river cruises, antique shops, galleries and restaurants.

title: Ideological Fireworks as Usual At Bavaria's Passion Play
description: The traditional German greeting ''Gruss Gott!'' (''God be with you!'') could hardly be more appropriate anywhere this year than on the streets of this Bavarian village, where 2 of the 4,900 inhabitants are alternating in the role of Jesus Christ and many of the other men in town have sprouted biblical beards for the 20th century's latest and last version of the Oberammergau Passion Play, performed mostly at 10-year intervals since 1634.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE OSBORN RETIREMENT COMMUNITY;

One Adam and 142 Eves in This Garden
description: LEAD: THE residents of the Osborn Retirement Community here say their newest member is the sort of person who fits right in: genteel, intellectual, impeccably mannered. There is just one major difference: The new resident is a man.

title: Review/Theater;   If the Song 'My Hero' Seems Silly, It Was Supposed To!
description: ''My Hero,'' by far the most famous song from Oscar Straus and Stanislaus Stange's 1909 operetta ''The Chocolate Soldier,'' is one of the most wildly romantic ballads to have survived as a standard from the early part of the century. In a paroxysm of dreamy fantasy, the narrator of this overheated waltz actually proclaims, ''Thou art divine,'' to the image of a lover who is not present. Rarely in pop have romantic and religious fervor been more thoroughly blended.

title: Who's That Behind the SUNY Curtains?
description: WHEN the Flying Karamazov Brothers appeared at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase, among the things they found in their dressing rooms were boxes of tea, both Earl Grey and English Breakfast; bottles of fruit juices, assorted sandwich and salad makings, flowers and good wishes. All supplied by the theater's volunteer group, the Prompters.

title: The Bank of Tokyo Responds
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Kendrick to Wed B. P. Kaufman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. E. Kendrick of Columbus, Ind., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Susan C. Kendrick and Benjamin P. Kaufman, a son of Mrs. Robert C. Rosenberg of New York and Harold Kaufman of San Francisco.

title: SOMETHING IS OFF-KEY IN TIMBALI
description: THE MUSIC PROGRAMME

title: Miss Lee Weds Dr. Young Kim
description: Christina Sunmi Lee, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Yong Sik Lee of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Young Han Kim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jong Hyuk of Fairlawn, N.J. The Rev. Alan Hape, a Methodist minister, officiated at Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SODA JERK

title: Lesley Topping, Producer, Weds
description: Lesley E. Topping, a daughter of Seymour and Audrey Topping of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Randolph M. Ostrow, a son of Robert and Eleanor Ostrow of Newfane, Vt. Rabbi Judith Lewis officiated.

title: Gorbachev, in U.S. Heartland, Dangles Visions of Fortunes in Soviet Trade
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told America's business and agricultural leaders today that they need not fear investing in the Soviet Union while that country undergoes economic reform.

title: Tuna Industry Working to Save Porpoises
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Ballet;   A Guest Star and a Principal Bring Life to a Spectacle
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' is a sumptuous theatrical spectacle. But because it is weighty and choreographically slow-moving, it can easily turn ponderous. Two fine artists helped bring it to life when American Ballet Theater presented it on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: If You Show Us Up Then You Go Down
description: TIM DRUMMOND fires a pitch over Mel Hall's head. Greg Harris plants a pitch in Kevin Elster's back. Ken Patterson buries a pitch in Jeffrey Leonard's ribs.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page Reporter's Notebook article yesterday about the Camp David talks between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev mistated the year in which President Carter used Camp David as the site of Egyptian-Israeli peace talks. It was 1978, not 1979.

title: N.B.A. Final Series Worth the Wait
description: With 10 seconds remaining in the most important game of his life, Buck Williams felt as if he were staring down the barrel of a rifle. Tom Chambers had the ball, he was isolated one-on-one against Williams, and he was preparing to make his move toward the basket.

title: Key Sections From the Bush-Gorbachev News Conference
description: Following are statements by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday at a news conference and excerpts from the question-and-answer session that followed, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through a translator.

title: Chinese Are No. 1 In Dragon Boats
description: The men's team from China today reclaimed the Cathay Pacific Cup, symbolic of dragon boat supremacy, in the final race of the 15th annual Hong Kong International Dragon Boat Festival.

title: Books of The Times;   Who Killed Director? Was There a Cover-Up?
description: A Deed of Death

title: For NBC, 'Party's Over' at Its Affiliates Meeting
description: For the first time in five years, NBC is facing questions about its leadership in the industry at the annual convention of the managers of its affiliated stations.

title: Carol C. Dadakis Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Coleman Dadakis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine S. Dadakis of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Thomas McKeever, the son of Mrs. Paul B. McKeever of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. McKeever. Msgrs. Thomas P. Guinan and John J. Foley, the uncle of the bridegroom, officiated at the Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EMMA SOAMES has joined WILLIAM SHAWN, GRACE MIRABELLA, ANDRE SCHIFFRIN and ANTHEA DISNEY in the ever-growing group of editors to be dismissed by S. I. NEWHOUSE JR. Ms. Soames, who until last week was editor of Tatler, was dismissed during a five-minute meeting with two executives of Conde Nast Ltd., the magazine group's international company.

title: An Inventor of the Microchip, Robert N. Noyce, Dies at 62
description: Robert N. Noyce, an inventor of a computer chip that revolutionized the electronics industry and gave rise to the high-technology era, died yesterday at Seton Medical Center in Austin, Tex., after suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: Troop Cutback Would Limit Spread of AIDS;   Lift Haitian Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter C. Reisinger, Brewery Executive, 66
description: Walter C. Reisinger, an executive of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, died of lung cancer on Friday at Jewish Hospital in St. Louis. He was 66 years old and lived in St. Louis, where the brewery is based.

title: A Field Of Controversy
description: IT is as much a part of the panoply of baseball as spring training, hot dogs and the seventh-inning stretch, and, like those cherished traditions, this one seems destined to endure.

title: At Yellowstone Park, 1988 Fires Echo in Debate on Rangers' Role
description: The snow is melting rapidly on the mountainsides, the bears have risen from their winter sleep and park rangers are praying for rain.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Dr. Melissa Scheer Weds
description: Dr. Melissa R. Scheer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Scheer of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Michael B. Finkelstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Finkelstein of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Charles Feinberg officiated at the Valeur Mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Dr. Scheer, who will keep her name, is a resident in radiology at Montefiore Hospital. She is a graduate of Wesleyan University and New York Medical College. Dr. Finkelstein, who is to become the assistant director of Lenox Hill Hospital's department of medicine next month, is a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he also received an M.D. degree.

title: Gandhi, Shaken by Defeat, Seeks a Comeback
description: Rajiv Gandhi, who won the biggest election victory in Indian history in 1984, only to be decisively rejected by voters five years later, is now fighting his most important political battle: to survive as leader of the opposition and bring back a battered Congress Party.

title: Budget Crunch
description: THE Southwestern Athletic Conference won't have Prairie View A&M to kick around anymore.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-17

title: HONG KONG HONORS BEIJING'S VICTIMS
description: More than 100,000 people, most of them dressed in the mourning colors of white and black, took part today in a march to honor pro-democracy demonstrators who were killed in the army crackdown in Beijing last June 4.

title: Villanova Track Coach Will Handle 2 Teams
description: Villanova University, hoping to return to its glory days in men's track and field, has promoted Marty Stern, its women's coach for the last six years, to head both the men's and women's programs. The announcement will be made Monday in Villanova, Pa.

title: 4 Hurt When Airliner Crashes in Alaska
description: An airliner with four crew members but no passengers aboard slammed into a fog-shrouded hillside and broke up Saturday, injuring all four.

title: One of the Greatest Shows on Earth
description: As if the senses are not overwhelmed by the ordinary treasures of Italy -the silky wines, antiquity all about - now comes one of the premier athletic events on the planet. Brace yourself. The World Cup of soccer is a quantum leap from Super Bowls, Final Fours and other American curios, like the oddly named annual denouement of baseball, the World Series. Some say not even the Olympics is so big an event.

title: Side by Side at the Summit
description: George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev put pen to paper over the weekend to draw an end to the cold war. They pledged deep cuts in nuclear and chemical arms. And Mr. Bush offered most-favored-nation trade status for the Soviets - a sign of his willingness to meet Mr. Gorbachev's urgent economic and political needs.

title: Ellen S. Ilivicky Is Married to Dr. Ira L. Siegman
description: Ellen Sue Ilivicky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ilivicky of Baldwin, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Ira Lowell Siegman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Siegman of Syosset, L.I. Rabbi A. David Arzt and Cantor Avraham Albrecht officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Julie Mariash Is Wed To Charles D. Noble
description: Julie Mariash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Mariash of Pine Brook, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles D. Noble, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Noble of St. Augustine, Fla. Judge Robert G. Fogelson of the Montville Township Municipal Court officiated at the Smoke Rise Village Inn in Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Tutu Tells Wesleyan Its Help Paves the Way for Liberation
description: In a commencement address, Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican Archbishop of South Africa, praised Wesleyan University today for supporting the black liberation movement in his country and particularly for backing economic sanctions against its white Government.

title: Reviews/Music;   The Kid Creole Beat, Minus Latin Influences
description: Kid Creole and the Coconuts have always been better at syncopation than career timing. August Darnell's band was treating rock concerts as song-and-dance revues before most pop stars were doing the same. And before ''world beat'' became a marketing category, he lived up to the Kid Creole name by merging Caribbean and North American dance music. On Friday night at the Ritz, the dance routines by the band's three-woman chorus line, the Coconuts, were suaver than ever. But the music had severely cut back its pan-American borrowings.

title: Time Speaking With a New Voice
description: While the pundits have been sitting around wondering what effect the Time-Warner merger would have on the integrity of Time magazine, a funny thing has quietly been happening at the magazine itself.

title: Immediate Move by Fed Not Expected
description: Despite mounting evidence that the economy is expanding at an even more sluggish pace than the tepid 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, many credit market analysts do not expect the Federal Reserve Board to begin efforts to stimulate growth until later in the summer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Television Contact and Comfort In an AIDS Hospice
description: ''I think your time will be soon,'' a counselor says to an AIDS patient. ''I hope so,'' the patient replies.

title: Now, a Tricky Observation
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, has offered a new meaning for NATO: ''Navies, Aircraft, Tanks, Obsolete.''

title: Lisa A. Sharf Marries Eric Green in Boston
description: Lisa A. Sharf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Sharf of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and New York, was married in Boston yesterday to Eric A. Green, the son of Craig A. Green of Marshall, Ind., and the late Diane Cox Green. The Rev. Katrina R. Finley, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: The Teacher Who Refuses To Give In To Paralysis
description: For 11 years, Susan Schwartz was a vigorous teacher who breathed life into her lessons by pacing across her classroom, pausing to scratch an illustration on the blackboard, raising and softening her voice. Then, seven years ago, she developed multiple sclerosis.

title: WORDS OF RESPECT
description: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded their second summit conference today with warm talk of amity, but with little progress toward resolving their most divisive disputes over Germany and Lithuania.

title: Father's Vanishing Act Called Common Drama
description: For all the talk about the new American father, those Cosby-like dads who are just as involved in diapers and day care as any mom, the reality in many families is quite the opposite: the disappearing American father, who leaves his children, emotionally and financially.

title: Review/Music;   'Tauromagia,' a Flamenco Portrayal of Bullfighting
description: Manolo Sanlucar's composition ''Tauromagia,'' which had its American premiere at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, is considered to be a major work by this Spanish flamenco guitarist and composer, who performed it with a group of seven other musicians.

title: Ready (or Not) and Waiting, Italians Hail a Miracle
description: When the Naples soccer team won the Italian national championship three years ago, its fans went predictably wild. They danced. They yelled. They drove around town honking their horns.

title: Sydney Ullman, Former Administrative Judge, 79
description: Sydney Ullman, a retired Federal administrative law judge, died Thursday at a nursing home in Montclair, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: China to Deal In Futures
description: China will open what it says is the first futures market in a socialist country this summer, an official newspaper reported today.

title: Hundreds March in a Protest at Beijing University
description: Defying a huge display of police force, hundreds of Beijing University students marched around the campus in the pre-dawn hours this morning to mourn the democracy protesters killed precisely one year earlier.

title: In Florio's Old Stumping Grounds
description: Until an intense young New Jersey Assemblyman named Jim Florio won New Jersey's First District Congressional seat in 1974, no Democrat had held it since before the turn of the century.

title: Recreation Properties To Be Sold
description: Some of the country's best-known golf resorts and developed communities will be put up for sale this week by the Landmark Land Company.

title: On Television, at Least, Still Larger Than Life
description: The advance publicity for the reappearance of Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the United States promised a show that had gotten bad reviews out of town. The star, heading a company that included enough drum beaters and spin artists to staff every television news program in the nation, was hopefully returning to the stage and screen of past triumphs. As ABC's Peter Jennings observed shortly before the curtain went up, ''It seems ironic to some that Mr. Gorbachev comes to the United States to hear applause.''

title: Israel Answers Soviets, Denies Plans for Settlers
description: Israel reiterated tonight that it has no plans to settle Soviet Jewish immigrants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Miss Heller Weds Dr. N. S. Heftler
description: Jennifer Heller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Heller of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Noah S. Heftler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Heftler of East Hills, L.I.Chief Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: NEVADA MURDERER IS PUT TO DEATH
description: Thomas Baal, who killed a woman in a robbery because she had given him only $20, was executed by lethal injection early today after opposing his parents' legal effort to keep him alive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nintendo's Review
description: Nintendo of America has narrowed the review for its $15 million advertising account to the Leo Burnett Company and the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, advertising executives said Friday. The incumbent is McCann-Erickson.

title: California Race Is Becoming Symbolic for Women
description: When the race for the Democratic nomination for governor of California ends on Tuesday, it seems likely that the result will turn, more than anything else, on sex. The candidate leading in the polls is a woman who has emerged in the minds of female Democrats as a strong symbol of their aspirations for political equality and power.

title: Troop Cutback Would Limit Spread of AIDS;   For Case Management
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARNOLD PALMER and other owners of the Bay Hill golf club in Orlando, Fla., are being sued by a Japanese company that had offered to buy the club for $46 million. The company, WDI Systems Inc., wants its $3 million deposit back, The Associated Press reported.

title: L.I. Youth, Suspect In Student's Killing, Is Held in California
description: A 17-year-old Long Island youth was arrested in Los Angeles yesterday and charged with slaying a fellow student two months ago in the victim's home in Herricks, L.I., the Nassau County police said last night.

title: A Wheel of Misfortune in Mets' Loss
description: When the Mets put an end to the Davey Johnson era last week, one reason given was that there was no longer ''a fire in the belly.''

title: Business Scene;   Offsetting the Rise Of Labor Costs
