description: Once the Soviet Union gets the lowest possible tariffs from the United States and access to American Government credits, Moscow will start repaying $674 million of World War II Lend-Lease debts to the United States, an agreement appended to the newly signed Soviet-American trade agreement says.

title: Ex-Kodak Executive To Head Kinder-Care
description: When J. Phillip Samper found out in December that he had lost out in the competition to become the Eastman Kodak Company's next chief executive, he surprised many people by immediately announcing that he would leave the company. But it has not taken him long to land a top position.

title: Jack Henry Abbott, the 'Lawyer,' Objects
description: Jack Henry Abbott, the murderer and jailhouse author who has been sued for civil damages by a victim's widow, began his defense yesterday by acting as his own lawyer, but with his every move in the courtroom shadowed by armed officers.

title: Vehicle Imports in Japan
description: Sales of imported vehicles in Japan rose 21.4 percent in May from a year earlier, to 16,325, a record for the month and the 77th straight monthly increase from the month a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. But May sales were down from April, when 20,141 imported vehicles were sold. Sales of imports in Japan are minuscule compared with the number of Japanese cars sold overseas.

title: LEADER OF LIBERIA REFUSING TO QUIT
description: With rebel columns bearing down on the capital, a group of prominent Liberian religious leaders has urged President Samuel K. Doe to resign and create a transitional Government. But Mr. Doe rejected the demand with a scornful tirade, several participants in the meeting said today.

title: Personal Health
description: While many people work hard to counter the drying effects of winter on their skin, warm weather actually harbors far more threats.

title: Review/Ballet;   His First and Latest Works Open Robbins Festival
description: A Festival of Jerome Robbins's Ballets opened Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with the deceptive simplicity that colors many of the more than 60 works choreographed by Mr. Robbins since 1944.

title: Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers sifted through, and ultimately shrugged off, a series of potentially negative developments.

title: A Setback For Albany: Agency Cuts Credit Rating
description: Three weeks after the Legislature adopted a budget that political leaders insisted was sound, a major credit agency, Moody's Investors Services, dealt the state a stinging setback today, lowering its long-term credit rating one notch.

title: Parker Van Zandt, 96, Aviator and Developer
description: J. Parker Van Zandt, who founded Scenic Airways at the Grand Canyon and established what is now Phoenix's main airport, died of complications of pneumonia on Sunday at a retirement home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 96 years old.

title: NBC, Citing Nielsen, Sees A $200 Million Ad Shortfall
description: Acknowledging that it had lost ground competitively and economically over the last year, NBC said today that it faced a $200 million shortfall in advertising revenues because of lower prime-time ratings and problems with the ratings system.

title: Fielder Belts 3 Homers As Tigers Beat Indians
description: Cecil Fielder became the first Detroit player to hit three home runs in a game twice in a season, powering the Tigers over the Cleveland Indians, 6-4, tonight.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Czechoslovakia Detains Ex-Communist Party Leader and 4 Others
description: The man who led Czechoslovakia as Communist Party chief for two years until the party was overthrown in the peaceful revolution in November was seized today for interrogation in ''criminal offenses,'' including his role in the Soviet-led invasion in August 1968.

title: MBIA Offers Common Shares
description: MBIA Inc., the holding company of the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, one of the leading municipal bond insurers, is offering 5.75 million common shares at a price of $36.25 a share through Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Spend Fairly for Schools. Then What?
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court's remarkable decision on poor school districts deserves national notice for reasons of justice and elemental decency. The state legislature will now have to spend as much on poor districts as on rich ones. But eliminating spending inequities is only a starting point. A quality education for all students cannot be conferred even by model court decisions or assured even with money. It will have to be worked for, district by district.

title: Viola Gets 9th Victory as Mets Edge Expos
description: Even Dwight Gooden considers it far-fetched: Two months after the delayed start of the baseball season, five of the Mets' six starting pitchers own a collective record of 8 victories, 20 defeats and many raised eyebrows. The sixth, fortunately, is Frank Viola. And he stopped the show again last night.

title: Beijing Frees 97 Held in Protests To Try to Ease Domestic Tension
description: China announced today the release of 97 people who had been involved in last year's pro-democracy movement, including two student leaders, in a move that diplomats described as an attempt to ease domestic tensions and win favor in Western countries.

title: From Voyager 1, a Space Snapshot of 6 Planets
description: Looking back on the scene of its triumphant travels in the last 12 years, the Voyager 1 spacecraft has snapped a sequence of pictures showing six of the nine known planets in orbital array like tiny diamonds on a background of black velvet.

title: The Unlikely Deal for MGM
description: When Giancarlo Parretti, a garrulous Italian businessman who says he plans to build the world's most powerful entertainment company, announced a tender offer for the MGM/UA Communications Company three months ago, there was widespread skepticism about whether the deal would be completed.

title: CHINA WEIGHS SALE OF GAS CHEMICALS
description: The United States has received intelligence reports that China is considering the sale of chemicals to Libya that can be used to make poison gas, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Vuitton Off Moet Board
description: In the final round in a 15-month bout between rival clans making up the French luxury group LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the last representatives of the Vuitton family were voted off the board today.

title: Troupe Devoted to Obscure Operas
description: L'Opera Francais de New York, a shoestring company that specializes in infrequently performed French operas, might not have been established if a promised conducting job had not fallen through.

title: Mets Dismiss Trade Rumors Of Strawberry to Yankees
description: In a time of turmoil for both teams, the Mets declined to ruffle their relations with the Yankees yesterday when they dismissed rumors of a major trade involving Darryl Strawberry as ''irresponsible speculation.'' But they did acknowledge that they had been talking to the Yankees about a lesser deal that apparently would have involved Bob Geren and Dave Magadan, although even those talks were said to be ''in neutral.''

title: 24 Doghouses to Bark About
description: BUDGET overruns, late delivery and ambitious designs often land architects in the doghouse. These doghouses, however, might not be such bad places to be.

title: Fernandez Weighing Lawsuit on Formula For State School Aid
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that he was contemplating legal action against the state to reduce disparities between school aid to New York City and the rest of the state.

title: Calendar of Events: The Subject Is Roses
description: Roses, Roses, Roses June is the peak for rose blossoms, and the Queens Rose Society is sponsoring a free show on Saturday from 1 to 5 P.M. at Our Lady of the Snows Church, 258-15 80th Avenue (Union Turnpike), Glen Oaks, Queens; information: 718-347-6070.

title: An Empire at Risk - Trump's Atlantic City;   Debt Forcing Trump to Play for Higher Stakes
description: For Donald J. Trump, the 43-year-old entrepreneur who built his business empire during the 1980's with borrowed money, the stakes are highest, and the game hardest, along the sandy Boardwalk of Atlantic City.

title: Drexel Plan Has Creditors Skeptical
description: The creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. voiced strong skepticism yesterday about the firm's reorganization plan, questioning whether Drexel's management should supervise the liquidation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the New York State Democratic nominating convention referred incorrectly to Ralph J. Marino, a Republican who is State Senate majority leader. Mr. Marino supports abortion rights but opposes Medicaid funds for abortions. The article also misidentified Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, who has decided against running for re-election. Her state is Vermont, not New Hampshire.

title: Small as a Bug on Radar, Stealth Is in Budget Sights
description: Still trying to build support for the Stealth bomber, the Air Force said today that the aircraft would appear no bigger than an insect to an enemy radar operator.

title: India-Pakistan War: It Could Be Nuclear
description: LEAD: If India and Pakistan go to war over Kashmir in the months ahead, it would be the first major military conflict in history between two states with ready access to nuclear arms.

title: Stocks Continue Down As Dow Retreats 13.35
description: Stock prices continued falling yesterday, for the second straight day, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 13.35 points to close at 2,911.65.

title: Foreign Investment Dip
description: Foreign direct investment in the United States last year was $64.6 billion, down from $72.7 billion in 1988, but well above outlays in earlier years, the Commerce Department said this week. It said in a preliminary report that British concerns continued to lead in direct investment, with purchases worth $22 billion last year. Japan was second with $14.9 billion. They were followed by Australia, with $4.5 billion in purchases; Canada, $3.9 billion; the Netherlands, $3.3 billion; France, $3.1 billion, and West Germany, $2.5 billion.

title: George Girard, 83, Queens Pastry Maker
description: George Girard, a pastry maker whose shop, La Vie en Rose in Long Island City, Queens, supplied prominent restaurants and airlines for a quarter-century, died on May 22 at his home in Long Island City. He was 83 years old. Mr. Girard died of heart disease, his son Pierre said yesterday.

title: Dan Turner, AIDS Lecturer, 42
description: Dan Turner, a playwright, actor and composer who waged an eight-year battle against AIDS and lectured on how to live productively with the disease, died on Monday at a San Francisco hospice. He was 42 years old.

title: Washington Talk;   Frank, It's Clear, Isn't Yet Done For
description: If the prognosticators were to be believed, by now Representative Barney Frank should be finished politically.

title: Hewlett-Packard, Mentor in Deal
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Mentor Graphics Corporation signed a three-year contract under which Mentor will purchase up to $400 million worth of HP/Apollo work stations, servers and other computer hardware, software and services.

title: Basing Pay On Results Gets Support
description: PAYING advertising agencies based on how well the products they advertise perform in the market is ''an idea whose time has come,'' according to a new study of marketers and their agencies.

title: GUERRILLA HIDEOUT IS RAIDED IN LIMA
description: Two pairs of thick eyeglasses left on a writing desk, medicine bottles on a bed stand and a bookcase filled with Maoist and Stalinist literature indicate that the mastermind of Peru's Shining Path rebellion recently stayed at a split-level house on a quiet middle-class street here.

title: The Year That Ended On June 6
description: In the centuries to come, when historians search the archives for the events of the year 1990, they will be surprised to learn that it ended on June 6 instead of Dec. 31.

title: Accounts
description: * Anderson-Little/Richman Brothers, a division of Woolworth Corp., to Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, with a budget of $10 million.

title: Easier Living for the Aged or Disabled
description: THE two-story, three-bedroom house in this Prince Georges County suburb of Washington is notable for not being conspicuous. It seems inspired by ''Ozzie and Harriet,'' but it is perhaps the best mainstream example of ''adaptable housing,'' designed to meet the needs not only of the general population but also of the disabled and the elderly.

title: New Charge Barred in Howard Beach Retrial
description: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case ruled yesterday that the prosecution could not expand the charges against three defendants who face a retrial.

title: For Each Abortion Side, Comfort in Primaries
description: The emerging power of the abortion rights issue was demonstrated anew in Tuesday's primaries as abortion rights supporters won a crucial victory in the Iowa Democratic primary for governor.

title: Measles Wave Calls for Drug, Not Just Vaccine;   Shared Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislators Rebuff One-Year Extension For U.S. Arts Panel
description: Republican and Democratic members of the House panel that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts refused today to go along with the Bush Administration's recommendation that the endowment be reauthorized for one year without any restrictions, rather than the usual five years.

title: Business Wary of Gorbachev Pitch
description: Although American business leaders were heartened by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speeches in the last week on economic reform in the Soviet Union, they warn that a series of obstacles still prevents them from investing in a big way in that country.

title: Messier Wins the M.V.P. Award
description: Mark Messier of Edmonton stepped out of Wayne Gretzky's shadow tonight by winning the Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League's Most Valuable Player, an award dominated by his former teammate in the 1980's.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 24 about violence by young children in New York public schools described a teacher who was assaulted by a 9-year-old boy. The teacher, Joan Zale, was quoted as having said: ''I used to think I could make a difference in these kids' lives. After the attack I thought, 'Why am I knocking myself out when most of them will end up at Rikers Island?' ''

title: Court Bars F.C.C. Rule On Data Sent by Phone
description: A Federal appeals court reversed two decisions yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission had made concerning the regulation of computer information services provided over telephone lines.

title: Q.&A.
description: Paint-Protecting

title: Lafleur: One More Time
description: Guy Lafleur said yesterday in Quebec that at the age of 38 he will play one more National Hockey League season with the Nordiques and then retire, permanently this time.(AP)

title: Moody's Finds Risk In Albany's Budget
description: After assessing the New York State budget adopted three weeks ago, Moody's Investors Services lowered the state's long-term credit rating by one notch.

title: Pregnant Women Can Gain More And Skip Vitamins, a Panel Says
description: Pregnant women who eat balanced diets do not need extra vitamins and can safely gain more weight than previously recommended, according to guidelines released today by the Institute of Medicine.

title: Police Hold Tokyo Broker
description: The president of an unlicensed financial futures brokerage was detained today on suspicion of swindling 12 billion yen, or about $78.7 million, from 2,000 investors.

title: Soviet Thaw With Seoul: What Is Real Depends on Whom You Listen To
description: Within moments of the end of his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday, the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, was broadcasting a message of victory back home, declaring that ''the cold war ice on the Korean peninsula has now begun to crack'' and predicting the imminent establishment of diplomatic relations with Moscow.

title: Brooklyn Judge Drops Charge Against Grocer
description: The assault charge against a Korean grocer whose store has been boycotted for more than four months was dismissed yesterday, but prosecutors said they would continue to investigate the incident. The boycott is expected to continue.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East Europe's Nuclear Plants Stir West's Safety Concerns
description: After closely studying nuclear plants in Eastern Europe, West European scientists have concluded that the reactors fall far short of Western safety standards and in many cases should be radically modified or closed.

title: Computer Retailer in Japan Deal
description: Businessland Inc., a large computer retailer, announced today that it had formed a joint venture with several Japanese companies to sell personal computers and work stations in Japan. The new venture, to be called the Businessland Japan Company Ltd., has headquarters in Tokyo.

title: States Turn to the Courts for Water As the Rain-Starved Missouri Falls
description: To hear them talk, both the people who live upriver and those who live downstream on the Missouri River Basin are prepared to be completely reasonable. All they want, they say, is their rightful share of the mighty river's water and its benefits.

title: Jets Re-sign McNeil
description: Freeman McNeil, the Jets' career rushing leader with 7,146 yards gained on 1,605 carries over nine seasons, yesterday signed a series of one-year contracts. Last season, a serious ankle injury sidelined McNeil, the Jets' No. 1 selection in the 1981 draft out of U.C.L.A. He played in only 11 games, picking up only 352 total yards on 80 carries for the season. Before his abbreviated season, McNeil had led the team in yards rushing for eight years in a row.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON will be released from St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., today or tomorrow. A spokesman for the hospital said yesterday that tests had shown no abnormalities for the 31-year-old singer, who was admitted Sunday after suffering chest pains.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Tuesday about Harold J. Corbett of the Monsanto Company misstated his action.

title: The Secret Is the Brows
description: It takes 45 minutes to transform Pat Carroll into Sir John Falstaff.

title: TAX REVOLT FADES AS CALIFORNIANS VOTE AN INCREASE
description: More than a decade after they led a revolt against taxes and spending, California voters turned around in elections Tuesday and approved higher gasoline taxes, a looser limit on state spending and more than $4 billion in bonds.

title: A Big Dream Comes True for Stump Merrill
description: Carl (Stump) Merrill is many things, but first and foremost he is a baseball man.

title: 18 Years, 18 Times: Yanks Once Again Replace a Manager
description: Bucky Dent's short and unproductive reign as Yankee manager ended suddenly today when Dent was dismissed with his team in last place. In a strange twist, the move came in the city where Dent enjoyed his greatest triumph as a player.

title: Review/Film;   A Documentary Chat With Abbie Hoffman
description: Students of American parody will not want to miss ''My Dinner With Abbie.'' It steals its title from the Wallace Shawn-Andre Gregory ''My Dinner With Andre'' but, in every other way, it is a send-up of the Barbara Walters Finishing School of Television Journalism.

title: People
description: * Susan Caughman has been named vice president of consumer marketing for the Time Inc. Magazine Company.

title: Leslie P. Barker, Physician, 88
description: Dr. Leslie P. Barker, a physician who founded the dermatological service at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan in 1942, died of colon cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: A Gandhi Crusades Against a Befouled India
description: Maneka Gandhi woke up the other day thinking about polluted water and onion patches.

title: Judge Rejects Broad Testing For Drug Use
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has declared unconstitutional a New York City Transit Authority policy in the mid-1980's that mandated testing for marijuana use for all employees and job applicants.

title: Rev. Vincent J. Hart, Educator, 91
description: The Rev. Vincent J. Hart, a former president of St. Peter's College in Jersey City and a former director of development at Fordham University, died on Tuesday at the St. Ignatius Retreat House in Manhasset, L.I., where he had been retreat master since 1969. He was 91 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Utility's Bonds To Yield 9.67%
description: The Southern California Edison Company, a subsidiary of the SCE Corporation, is offering $200 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds due 2021 through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers Inc., which won the issue through competitive bidding.

title: 'Meet Me' to Close
description: ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' a musical based on Sally Benson's ''Kensington Stories'' and the 1943 film, with music and lyrics by Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street. Directed by Louis Burke with book by Hugh Wheeler, the show will have run for 253 regular performances and 16 previews.

title: U.S. to Clean Radium Sites In Three Towns
description: After seven years of local uncertainty and fear, Federal officials said today that they would spend more than $250 million to remove radium-contaminated soil from around and under as many as 400 houses in Glen Ridge, Montclair and West Orange.

title: B.S.B. Wins Best Foods Jobs
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates yesterday won the advertising account for Mazola corn oil products, made by the Best Foods division of CPC International. The agency's corporate cousin, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, resigned the account in April.

title: At Bronx Zoo, a Damsel In Distress Is Rescued
description: The Bronx Zoo introduced Rapunzel to her public yesterday, but this Rapunzel is distinguished not by blond braids but by the coarse reddish-brown hair that protects her 1,725 pounds.

title: Kemp Urges Tightened F.H.A. Insurance Program
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development said today that the Government's mortgage insurance program for single-family homes was losing about $350 million a year and could be insolvent by the end of the decade without immediate changes.

title: Bridge
description: By tomorrow there will be two undefeated teams surviving in the prestigious Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship.

title: Western Wind, When Wilt Thou Blow?
description: LEAD: IF alarm clocks and videocassette recorders can be set, why not fans? For those who enjoy going to sleep in a breezy room but don't want a fan on all night, the Tatung fan can be set to turn itself off. It has an eight-hour timer and oscillates at three speeds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It makes me look so old.''

title:
Currents;

English Get Proper Spot To Ring Up
description: LEAD: THE English are quite attached to their red telephone booths - old cast-iron structures that offered character and privacy.

title: As Memory and Music Faded, Oregon Woman Chose Death
description: Three years ago, her husband says, Janet Elaine Adkins began to notice slips in her memory and her ability to play the piano music she loved.

title: Evolution in Europe;   40 REPORTED DEAD IN SOVIET CLASHES
description: The Kremlin reported today that at least 40 people had been killed in three days of growing ethnic rioting and Soviet troop countermeasures in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia.

title: New U.S. Fund Picks Salomon
description: The United States Overseas Private Investment Corporation announced yesterday that it had selected Salomon Brothers to serve as the financial adviser to a new fund that will invest in Eastern Europe.

title: Vasily V. Kuznetsov Dies at 89; A Soviet Vice President and Envoy
description: Vasily V. Kuznetsov, a former First Vice President of the Soviet Union and a delegate to the United Nations, died Tuesday in Moscow, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 89 years old. The immediate cause of his death was not given.

title: Truck Disrupts Traffic On Verrazano Bridge
description: Brooklyn-bound traffic on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was disrupted yesterday for three hours during the evening rush when a private sanitation truck struck an overhead beam on the lower level on the Staten Island side of the bridge, the police said.

title: Wine Tax Should Match That on Liquor and Beer
description: To the Editor:

title: Class of '90On the Family
description: TO the college class of 1990, how does the future look when it comes to balancing careers with family life?

title: Pervasive Racism and Boycott of Korean Stores
description: To the Editor:

title: Warsaw, Faulted by Walesa, Declares Market Conversion Complete
description: Under renewed criticism from Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, the Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki declared today that Poland had converted its economy to a Western-style market system in just five months, but that the price was high and that it was time to ease up on austerity.

title: London Bank Plans to Move
description: The Abu Dhabi-controlled Bank of Credit and Commerce International said today that up to 500 British employees would lose their jobs in a reorganization that includes the transfer of its headquarters to Abu Dhabi from London.

title: Group Predicts Big Rise In AIDS for New York
description: One in 25 New York City adults will become sick from the AIDS virus within the next 10 years, creating tremendous burdens on the local economy and health-care system, a national health organization said in a report yesterday.

title: Medellin Journal;   In the Capital of Cocaine, Savagery Is the Habit
description: Viewed from the window of a commuter helicopter, Medellin offers much of the provincial charm long associated with Colombia's second largest city.

title: JAIL POINDEXTER, PROSECUTORS URGE
description: Government prosecutors have urged a Federal judge to sentence John M. Poindexter to prison for misleading Congress with a ''diet of lies'' about the Iran-contra affair, according to sentencing papers made public today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: The Challenge to Designers
description: To The Home Section:

title: Belmont Stakes a Weak Main Event
description: The 122d Belmont Stakes is just one of seven stakes races over four days at Belmont Park this week. Given the weakness of Saturday's main event this year, the other races seem even more interesting than usual.

title: Talking Deals;   Pressure to Sell On Savings Units
description: LIKE the Landmark Land Company, which recently put its vast real estate portfolio up for sale, other California savings and loan associations are now trying to sell their properties to comply with new Government regulations.

title: Wasserstein Names Adviser
description: The Wasserstein, Perella Group Inc., the mergers and acquisitions firm, said on Tuesday that it had named Franco Reviglio senior adviser.

title: Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Is No Matter of Certainty
description: Many medical experts said yesterday that it seemed precipitous for an Oregon woman to commit suicide at the age of 54 after being told that she suffered from Alzheimer's disease.

title:
Currents;

'Decaying Venice Veneer'For a Corporate Identity
description: LEAD: ONE might expect a corporate-identity consulting firm to have distinctive offices. And the Venice, Calif., offices of Keith Bright & Associates, designed by Franklin Israel, a Los Angeles-based architect, do not disappoint.

title: Dying, Dr. Kevorkian's Way
description: To Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who made it possible, the death by lethal injection of Janet Adkins this week was one more volley in his battle to make euthanasia ''a positive experience.'' To others, it seemed a lot more like an execution.

title: The Krzyzewski Talks
description: Mike Krzyzewski, Duke's basketball coach, met in Washington yesterday with Red Auerbach, the president of the Celtics, to discuss the team's coaching vacancy.

title: Knicks' Ewing Chosen To All-N.B.A. Squad
description: After finishing second to Akeem Olajuwon in the voting for center on the all-National Basketball Association team for the last two seasons, Patrick Ewing of the Knicks finally topped his talented rival from Houston and became the only newcomer on the 1989-90 team announced yesterday. Ewing, who averaged 28.6 points, 10.9 rebounds and 3.99 blocks while shooting an average of .551 from the field, joined repeaters Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers and Michael Jordan of Chicago, the guards, and Charles Barkley of Philadelphia and Karl Malone of Utah, the forwards.

title: Review/Jazz;   Drumming With Dramatics
description: The drummer Roy Haynes is after drama. He will smack his snare drum and cymbal simultaneously, stopping a few hearts in the audience, or he will just play his bass drum. He'll change rhythm patterns every bar or so, or he'll raise the volume abruptly until the band can barely be heard. At Condon's on Tuesday night, one band member was late, and Mr. Haynes dressed him down onstage, creating tension.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Interpreters' Lot: Hours of Tedium and Moments of Precision
description: Did Mikhail S. Gorbachev say on Friday that centrally controlled economic planning was ''a vice,'' meaning immoral - or, did he say it was ''a vise'' constricting growth?

title: When Karan Handles It, Fur Can Look Like Silk
description: IT'S casual, sophisticated and technically advanced. Donna Karan's latest fur collection, her fifth for Birger Christensen, is clearly her best yet. It focuses on furs made like blankets or chair throws, no more bulky than an afghan.

title: Perfuming A Fund Drive
description: A BLUE speckled egg with an orange beak emerging from it and a clear-glass apple with a red stem are among perfume bottles on display in the fragrance department of Bloomingdale's through tomorrow.

title: Federal Judge Rules Rap Album Violates County's Obscenity Law
description: The rap album ''As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' by the group 2 Live Crew was declared obscene today by a Federal judge who cited its graphic sexual lyrics.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Equicor Official Gets Top Health Network Job
description: LEAD: Ronald W. Moreland, an insurance and benefits executive who ran the $1 billion Western operations of Equicor, an employee benefits company, has been named president and chief executive of Managed Health Network Inc., a Los Angeles company that provides mental health and employee assistance programs.

title: Measles Wave Calls for Drug, Not Just Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Wins New Jersey Primary
description: Senator Bill Bradley, who won an easy victory in the New Jersey Democratic primary in his bid for a third term, will face a little-known Republican candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, in the November general election.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Seeks Europe Security Group Shift
description: In an effort to parry Soviet hopes to have the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe rather than NATO take the leading role in shaping a new Europe, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today offered his own ideas of how the 35-nation organization should evolve.

title: Close to Home
description: IT was hot one Saturday in early May, hot enough for us to carol ''summer's here'' and for me to wear a dress so light the merest breeze could set it floating. But on Sunday the cold came in again, along with a driving rain, and we weren't talking about summer any longer. We weren't even talking about spring.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Warsaw Pact Under Fire
description: On his way to Moscow to attend a meeting of the leaders of the Warsaw Pact, Prime Minister Jozsef Antall of Hungary called today for the abolition of the military alliance by the end of 1991 and, more immediate, for the elimination of those parts of the treaty that violate the ''sovereignty'' of its seven member countries.

title: INSIDE
description: China, Libya and Poison Gas

title: Administration To Weigh Plan For Military Cut
description: White House and Congressional negotiators resumed their budget talks today, with the first indication that the Bush Administration is prepared to offer a plan for reducing military spending.

title: Armstrong Suits
description: Armstrong World Industries and the Belzberg family have dropped all lawsuits stemming from their hostile takeover fight in a settlement that makes the Canadian family $4.4 million richer. Under the agreement, Armstrong said, the Belzberg group will limit its holdings of Armstrong stock for 10 years to no more than 50,000 shares. The family, whose investment vehicle is the First City Financial Corporation, agreed not to interfere the business of the interior furnishings company.

title: On Deconstructivism
description: To The Home Section:

title: Topics of The Times;   Beggaring the Beggars
description: Victorious in court over subway beggars, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority did something bureaucratic and insensitive. It filed an accounting of court costs, ordinarily the first step toward collecting them from an opponent. Startled by protests, the M.T.A. then withdrew the filing, saying it never intended to extract $1,425.90 from the losing side.

title: Review/Television;   'Seinfeld,' A Comic As a Comic
description: Jerry Seinfeld is still another comedian attempting to transform the essence of his stand-up act into a weekly television series. Bill Cosby succeeded. So did Roseanne Barr. Jackie Mason didn't. Currently in the midst of a limited run on NBC, Thursdays at 9:30, ''Seinfeld'' comes tantalizingly close to making it.

title: An Artful Falstaff Who Transcends Sex
description: It is the morning after, and Sir John Falstaff is sitting in a corner coffee shop not far from Capitol Hill, sipping decaffeinated coffee and munching a strip of bacon.

title: The Public Voice - Amplified
description: Voters in California this week needed to know a little bit about a lot of things - mountain lions, chiropractic and trial procedures, to name only a few. That made the measly 39.5 percent of the electorate who actually went to the polls part of a dubious national trend - instant popular government.

title:
Currents;

Architect Clearly Takes His Own Advice to Heart
description: LEAD: ''AN apartment with a view of Central Park should be all glass,'' said William Gleckman, a New York architect. In adding two new levels to the top floor of a building on West 58th Street to make a pair of triplex apartments, he has wholeheartedly practiced what he preaches.

title: Metro Matters;   Turning Boycott Of Greengrocer Into Green Power
description: For almost five months, a chorus of shrill chants has defined the boycott by a group of blacks against a Korean-owned greengrocer on Church Avenue in Brooklyn. Meanwhile the real story behind the boycott was quietly unfolding around the corner.

title: Joe Loss, Band Leader, 80
description: Joe Loss, a band leader who was one of the kings of the ballroom dance era, died of kidney failure today in a London hospital, his publicity agent said. He was 80 years old. Mr. Loss's soft-spoken manner and easy-to-dance-to music won him millions of fans, including the British royal family, who frequently engaged his big band to play at royal affairs.

title: American Sentenced by Bonn for Espionage
description: A West German court sentenced a former United States Army sergeant today to life in prison for selling Soviet-bloc agents ''mountains of highly secret materials'' that could have undermined Western defenses in the event of war.

title: Keep American Art Within Our Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: On Bearding The Iris: Color
description: A COUPLE of miles from my house there's a garden I usually contrive to drive by at this time of year. I don't know the owners, but the character of their horticultural passion is clear, even at 35 miles an hour in a passing automobile.

title: Donations in U.S. Climb, but Worries Linger
description: Americans gave $114.7 billion last year in philanthropic gifts, an increase over last year, but fund-raisers remain worried about the continuing adverse impact of 1986 tax laws.

title:
Currents;

A Touch Of Rome For Tokyo
description: LEAD: IT is not easy for new buildings to stand out in densely packed Tokyo. But the Wall does.

title: Review/Jazz;   An Up-to-Date Big Band
description: For almost 10 years, Toshiko Akiyoshi has maintained an unusually challenging role in jazz as a pianist who leads a big band playing a repertory made up solely of her own compositions and arrangements. Since she organized her band in 1973, the ranks of major big-band leaders have dwindled with the deaths of Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Thad Jones, Mel Lewis and Gil Evans, leaving Miss Akiyoshi as one of the few beacons still lighting up this area of jazz.

title: New Manager Might Help if He Can Hit and Pitch
description: The last time the Yankees and the Mets changed managers during the same season, Yogi Berra left the Mets and Billy Martin began the first of his five terms with the Yankees. The Yankees hired Martin to replace Bill Virdon on Aug. 2, 1975; the Mets dismissed Berra four days later.

title: Subway Lifts Ban on Strollers
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that starting on Monday token sellers would not enforce a longstanding ban on open baby carriages in the subway.

title: Woman Admits She Lied After a Slaying
description: Testifying for the third day at her murder-conspiracy trial, Karin Aparo conceded today that she had lied to the police after her mother was killed and had lied to the former boyfriend who committed the slaying.

title: Money-Fund Yields Down
description: Yields of taxable and tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

title: Justice Agency Warned on Inquiry of Loans to Iraq
description: State Department officials say they have cautioned the Justice Department over the agency's investigation of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank accused of making more than $2 billion in unauthorized and unreported loans to Iraq.

title: Kirghizia; At A Glance
description: The People

title: Warmth and Ice
description: The Washington summit talks did not reveal a great deal new about George Bush, but they did tell us a lot about Mikhail Gorbachev - certainly more than he intended.

title: Brent Staples Is Appointed To Times's Editorial Board
description: Brent Staples, first assistant metropolitan editor of The New York Times, is moving to the newspaper's editorial board to write on politics and culture. His appointment, effective this summer, was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor.

title: Upjohn Selling South African Unit
description: The Upjohn Company agreed to sell its 100-employee South African vegetable-seed operation, Asgrow S.A., to local management. But an Upjohn spokesman, John P. Lambrechts, said the company was not pulling out of South Africa and would continue operating its 150-employee Upjohn Ltd. pharmaceutical and animal health products business there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Already banned at Stanford University and the University of California at Berkeley, the Grateful Dead have now been banned in Columbia, Md.

title: Review/Theater;   Arrogant Academic With a Midlife Crisis Has a Disastrous Day
description: Since there is no new Simon Gray play in sight at the moment, the Manhattan Theater Club has imported a reasonable facsimile of one, ''Prin,'' by another British writer, Andrew Davies. Like Mr. Gray's ''Butley,'' ''Prin'' recounts a disastrous day in the midlife crisis of an arrogant, self-destructive academic. Its cast includes American specialists in the Gray canon, Remak Ramsay (''Quartermaine's Terms'') and John Christopher Jones (''Otherwise Engaged''). John Tillinger's genteel production, from the wood paneling and Gothic spires of John Lee Beatty's set to the incidental touches of Benjamin Britten choral music, will leave Anglophiles longing to be in England now that New York's summer humidity is here.

title: Lectures on the Sistine
description: A look at the restoration under way in the Sistine Chapel at the Vatican is to be given today at 5 and 8 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. The cleaning of the Michelangelo frescoes is to be discussed by Dr. Walter Persegati, the secretary general of the Vatican Museums. The restoration project, now in its final stage, has been under way since 1980. Admission is $10 ($5 for students and the elderly). Information: 874-5210.

title: Bank Lending Said to Slow; No Credit Squeeze Is Seen
description: Three top Federal regulators said today that there had been a slowdown in bank lending but no credit squeeze. And they said that any slowdown should not be attributed to excessively harsh treatment of banks by examiners.

title: Hurled Roll of Papers Hits Quayle on Head
description: Vice President Dan Quayle was struck in the head today with a rolled-up collection of papers thrown by a man who shouted to him as he got into his limousine near the Capitol.

title: A Women-Only College Is Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.I.C. Rejects Bid
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it had declined an unsolicited offer for its 26 percent stake in the Continental Bank Corporation of Chicago. The F.D.I.C. became a Continental shareholder after rescuing the former Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1984.

title: Helms Change Added to Disabled Rights Act
description: The Senate voted 53 to 40 today to support an amendment to a bill barring discrimination against the disabled that would allow employers to shift workers infected with AIDS and other contagious diseases out of food-handling jobs.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Nicholas W. Danforth, Investment Counselor, 85
description: Nicholas Williamson Danforth, a retired investment counselor, died of a heart attack on May 30 at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 85 years old.

title: Sometimes, It Really Is A Bit Like Football
description: During the United States' 2-1 loss to Switzerland on Saturday, several American players were hammered fairly hard. The team's leading scorer, Bruce Murray, in particular, had a difficult time as the man marking him seemed more interested in kicking his legs than the ball. On one play, the Swiss defender conked Murray with his forehead.

title: Joseph C. Bevis, 80, Among First To Examine U.S. Public Opinion
description: Joseph C. Bevis, a pioneer in the public opinion and market research industry, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Tuesday at Martin Memorial Hospital in Stuart, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Stuart.

title: White House Panel Says U.S. Can Fight Pollution and Grow
description: The White House's Council on Environmental Quality says the progress of the last two decades shows that the nation can have both economic growth and environmental quality.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Dukakis Triumphs . . .
description: LEAD: For the past 17 months, President Bush has done what would have been unthinkable during his relentlessly negative 1988 Presidential campaign: he has adopted almost verbatim major policy ideas from the campaign of Michael Dukakis. In other words, he has embraced ideas he once ridiculed so successfully when proposed by the ''liberal Governor from Massachusetts.

title: Older Pass-Throughs Called Stronger Than New Ones
description: Analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. noted that moderately seasoned pass-through securities now offer a better value than new pass-through issues, a recent research report shows.

title: Tyson Works Out
description: Mike Tyson's first public workout for his June 16 fight against Henry Tillman drew about 1,000 fans, who waited yesterday for the former heavyweight champion who was more than an hour late for the workout in the sports pavilion at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev. Tyson will fight for the first time since losing his title Feb. 10 against James (Buster) Douglas.

title: Battling Back From Knee Surgery, Muster Gains Paris Semifinals
description: Every morning, Thomas Muster of Austria walks two blocks toward center court from the apartment he is renting near Roland Garros. He selected the apartment in order to be very close to the object of his desire, the French Open championship.

title: 2 Campeau Units See Smaller Losses
description: In a sign that the retail divisions of the Campeau Corporation were improving faster than expected, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores are expected to report narrower losses for the fiscal first quarter ended April 30 compared with the year earlier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, appointed Richard M. Scroggins senior vice president for corporate real estate and general services and also named him chairman of the company's environmental protection committee.

title: SHUTTLE MUST GO TO REPAIR HANGAR
description: The space shuttle Columbia will have to be returned to a hangar to repair a fuel leak, indefinitely delaying its launching, the space agency said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President FERNANDO COLLOR de MELLO of Brazil made a hot television appearance yesterday. He was to set fire to a mound of seized cocaine and marijuana, to promote his anti-drug campaign. Instead, the gas-soaked pile exploded in flames as Mr. Collor dropped a torch on it. He then covered his face and ran back.

title: Jackson Urges Barry to Seek Plea Agreement
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson called on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today to work out a plea greement with prosecutors on the 14 drug-related charges he faces, including an agreement not to seek re-election.

title: M.T.A. to Run TV Ads To Gain Subway Riders
description: If you watch television today you are likely to hear the following lines from a new set of commercials.

title: Topics of The Times;   Ethical Update
description: A decade ago, the Senate Judiciary Committee agreed to frown on nominees for the Federal bench who belong to clubs that engage in ''invidious discrimination,'' including racial or religious exclusion. A few nominees have since been confirmed only on condition that they quit such clubs. The policy has needed updating to include sex discrimination, and to make clear that last-minute resignations look fishy; any lawyer with judicial ambitions ought to quit such clubs now.

title: New Findings Tie Cut in Smoking To Drop in Heart Disease Deaths
description: New findings from a large heart study support the belief that reductions in smoking and other health risks have contributed importantly to a sharp decline in deaths from heart disease. Researchers using data from the Framingham Heart Study, which has followed patients for more than 40 years in Massachusetts, estimated that nearly a third of the decline in coronary deaths may be a result of reductions in blood cholesterol levels, blood pressure and cigarette smoking. Their findings are being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Primary Results: Setting the Stage for November
description: Results are not final.

title: Dr. Harry L. Segal, 90, Physician and Teacher
description: Dr. Harry Louis Segal, a gastroenterologist and educator, died of pneumonia on Monday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 90 years old and lived in Brighton, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester.

title: Japanese Warrants Surge, But Many Investors Lose
description: Japan is justly famous for its many natural hot springs, which seem to bubble from nearly every cleft rock in this mountainous land. But never has there been a more bountiful gusher than the financial wellspring known as the Japanese market for stock warrants.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Systems Inc., Mountain View, Calif., provided Xerox Corp. with licensing rights to Adobe's Postscript language interpreter. Postscript is an industry-standard language that supports computer systems and electronic printing and publishing products. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Pic 'N' Save Corp. Wins Injunction
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation said a Federal District Court had granted its request for a preliminary injunction enjoining Girard Partners L.P. from pursuing its proxy fight until it discloses more information about its partners.

title: Review/Theater;   Two Disparate Women Who Find a Sisterly Tie
description: In Marsha A. Jackson's ''Sisters,'' two disparate women are snowbound on New Year's Eve on the 20th floor of an office building in downtown Atlanta. For dimly stated reasons, they decide not to challenge the elements. Instead, they try to stretch the audience's credulity. Repeatedly, the question arises why the two women do not leave the building. The tie that binds them there is Ms. Jackson's contrived play.

title: Joseph Tomassi Jr., 67, A Specialist in Mergers
description: Joseph J. Tomassi Jr., an industrial executive and a specialist in mergers and acquisitions, died on Monday at his home in Milford, Conn., at the age of 67. His family attributed his death to heart failure.

title: Canada's Latest Identity Crisis
description: Once again, Canada is agonizing over a problem as old as the nation itself - the uneasy marriage between its English and French cultures. Antagonism has reached another crisis. There is even talk of Canada breaking apart. That seems unlikely, but the tension creates unwelcome uncertainty in America's closest ally.

title: Loss No. 1 for Merrill And No. 32 for Yanks
description: Stump Merrill's first day as the new Yankee manager could have easily been just another day at the ball park for Bucky Dent.

title: Parent & Child
description: AFTER six years of living with her husband and stepchildren, Kris Warhol said she finally feels like she is a real mother. A few hours earlier she had appeared before a Hennepin County judge in downtown Minneapolis as the final step toward adopting her two stepdaughters, age 11 and 14.

title:
Currents;

Serving a Revolution, With Cream or Sugar
description: LEAD: AFTER the Russian Revoution, Nicholas and Alexandra no longer needed monogrammed plates for state dinners, and a lot of blank pieces of porcelain were left behind in the imperial Porcelain Factory.

title: Restored Plaza Hailed (but Turn Down That General!)
description: When water spills from the pedestal supporting the goddess Pomona atop the Pulitzer Fountain on Fifth Avenue this morning, a dry spell of almost 10 years will end, and Grand Army Plaza, a sort of urban courtyard for some of the city's most elegant commercial and residential establishments, will be reborn.

title: An Adweek Executive Joins Hearst Magazines
description: Hearst Magazines announced several personnel moves yesterday, including the hiring of David W. Bentley, the senior vice president and publishing director of Adweek, as director of corporate advertising sales.

title: Physician Fulfills a Goal: Aiding a Person in Suicide
description: For weeks before he first allowed a patient to use his homemade suicide device, Dr. Jack Kevorkian said, he scouted southeastern Michigan for a clinic, church or funeral home that would allow him a haven in which to perform the procedure.

title: 2d Activase Approval
description: Genentech Inc. said today that the United States Food and Drug Administration had granted approval for the marketing of its cardiovascular drug Activase for the treatment of obstruction of the arteries of the lungs. The drug, a tissue plasminogen activator, is already licensed as a treatment for heart attack patients. ''We believe that the effectiveness of Activase has the potential to make it as important in the treatment of pulmonary embolism as it has become in the treatment of heart attacks,'' Genentech's president, G. Kirk Raab, said.

title: Home Improvement
description: ROOM air-conditioners perform better and last longer with simple cleaning and maintenance twice a year: before the cooling season begins and midway through the summer.

title: Books of The Times;   The President's Husband and His Near-Fatal Puns
description: First Hubby

title: Japan Picks U.S. Design For Phones
description: The Japanese Government chose American technology yesterday as a nationwide technical standard for its next generation of cellular telephones.

title: If a Hat Makes You Hang Your Head
description: ALTHOUGH custom hatters are a thing of the past in New York City, Worth & Worth tries to retain some of the old-fashioned service. The shop will steam-clean and reshape hats, free of charge, while you wait.

title: THE 1990 ELECTIONS
description: Nine months after she nearly dropped out of the race for governor of California, Dianne Feinstein emerged today not only as the Democratic nominee but also as the party's new symbol, a charismatic centrist figure who many in the party hope will bring wayward Democrats and independents back into the fold.

title: Seagram Net Declines 4.6%
description: The Seagram Company said today that its profit fell 4.6 percent in its first quarter.

title: Mayor of Oakland Backs Football Deal And Loses Election
description: Support for the return of professional football, which seemed a safe political issue, has cost Lionel Wilson his job as Mayor of Oakland, a city that grieved when the Raiders quit town nine years ago but rose up in protest recently at the prospect of their coming back.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three young reporters got the Livingston Award in New York yesterday. This is the ninth year MOLLIE PARNIS LIVINGSTON, the fashion designer, has given the awards to journalists under the age of 35. They went to PETER GUMBEL of The Wall Street Journal, TOM ASHBROOK of The Boston Globe and MICHELE NORRIS of The Washington Post. Each got a citation and $5,000.

title: Puzzles Whose Pieces Fit Young Imaginations
description: When children play with Bright Ideas puzzles, the brightly colored wooden pieces often wind up outside the frames as shapes for free-form designs, people and animals. Dan Wetmore, the founder of the Bright Ideas puzzle company, likes it that way.

title: Parishioner Finds Suspect in '82 Church Theft
description: When the Rockland County woman walked into the J. C. Penney store in Taos, N.M., a few weeks ago, she thought it had to be her church's missing treasurer. He had a beard, which was new, but when they had traded a bit of chitchat about Rockland, she was sure.

title: Thomas Draws Raves For 4th-Quarter Effort
description: A panel of judges was asked today to rate the most memorable games in Isiah Thomas's career in the National Basketball Association.

title: Taylor Seeks New Deal
description: Negotiations are under way between Lawrence Taylor and the Giants to sign the All-Pro linebacker to a contract extension or a new pact.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Bar Export of Banned Pesticides
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee approved legislation today to bar American chemical companies from exporting pesticides that are banned in the United States.

title: Name Change Set For Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation announced it would change its name to Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. The Houston-based concern, once the nation's largest airline company, owns Eastern Airlines, which is currently in bankruptcy proceedings, as well as Continental Airlines.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chicago Journal;   A Source of the Blues Gathers Tributes Anew
description: In the 1940's and 50's, scores of black musicians with nothing but their dreams and harmonicas left the bayous of the South to work the nightclubs and street corners of Chicago's South Side.

title: In Peru's 'Holy War,' Strange Allies
description: With polls leading up to the presidential runoff election Sunday showing a dead heat, Mario Vargas Llosa, who says he is an agnostic, may benefit from support from an unlikely source: the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   More Nielsen Data On Minority Viewers
description: Nielsen Media Research will bolster its efforts to report data on television viewing by minority audiences. Nielsen, a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet, has agreed to expand its National Audience Demographic Report to include black households and about 20 black demographic categories. It will also include more marketing information, like estimates of the size of local minority populations, in its local market reports.

title: Marshall Field Chief Seen Coming to Saks
description: Philip B. Miller, chairman and chief executive of Marshall Field & Company, will become co-chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue and eventually be named its chairman and chief executive, financial and retailing executives said yesterday.

title: Washington at Work;   Attorney General Calm Despite Storm at Justice
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is getting a lot of criticism these days, but no one can accuse him of that vintage Washington sin of holding on too long to a damaged assistant. He shunted aside two key members of his ''Pennsylvania mafia'' with icy detachment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 8, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Soviet Official Urges Shift in Exchange Rate
description: The Soviet currency's official exchange rate should be changed next month to reflect market conditions, Finance Minister Valentin Pavlov said in an interview published today.

title: California Sets Phone Rules
description: The California Public Utilities Commission issued new regulations on Wednesday for the cellular telephone industry in the state.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about ''The Bohemians'' misstated the address of the Cooper Square Theater. It is at 50 East Seventh Street, not West Seventh.

title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend
description: TODAY

title: Dinkins and the Council Reach a Tax Agreement
description: The Dinkins administration and the New York City Council agreed yesterday on the mix of higher taxes they would seek from Albany to balance the city's budget, including a personal income tax surcharge of $355 million, instead of the $300 million the administration originally proposed.

title: Mets Get Shot at Pirates and Miss
description: The Mets finally got their shot at the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates last night but, even with Dwight Gooden on the firing line, they could do nothing to change the strange standings of the season.

title: Mandatory Sentences in Drug Cases: Is the Law Defeating Its Purpose?
description: The case before Federal District Judge William W. Schwarzer last fall made him weep as he sat on the bench.

title: Henry Russek, 78, a Cardiologist Known for Stress Research, Dies
description: Dr. Henry I. Russek, a cardiologist who conducted early studies of the relationship of occupational and emotional stress to heart disease, died on May 30 at Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: First Woman in Top A.B.A. Job Quits
description: Jill Wine-Banks, the first woman ever to serve as executive director of the American Bar Association, resigned abruptly yesterday. The move ends her stormy tenure of almost three years as the bar group's chief administrator.

title: Universal's Park Opens in Florida
description: Universal Studios' $630 million movie theme park formally opened today as more than two dozen entertainers attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony. The 440-acre park includes working movie sound stages and tourist attractions featuring scenes from popular movies.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 17 about problems in the field of psychiatry misidentified the editor in chief of The Psychiatric News. He is Dr. John L. Schwartz. A related chart misstated the number of psychiatrists in the United States. It is about 40,000, not 36,000.

title: Robert Aaron Mayo, Priest, 53
description: The Rev. Robert Aaron Mayo, a priest in the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: Review/Ballet;   Robbins Over the Years: Fresh Amid the Familiar
description: The two-week event that is being called A Festival of Jerome Robbins's Ballets by the New York City Ballet promises few surprises in terms of repertory.

title: Argentina Pays Debt Interest
description: Trying to improve relations with its foreign creditors, Argentina met today with leading banks in New York and made a $40 million interest payment.

title: Keep Our Library Doors Open to All Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   For Murphy And Nolte, A Sequel
description: The difference between ''48 Hours,'' made in 1982, and the new ''Another 48 Hours,'' a sequel, is the difference between Eddie Murphy the young television actor making a terrifically engaging movie debut, and Eddie Murphy the 1990 supernova, the star of seven films that have earned more than one billion dollars at box offices around the world. Money talks. It also preens. It takes its time. It does no more work than it has to.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Johnson Leaving as No. 2 at Fed
description: Manuel H. Johnson, an important voice of conciliation on the Federal Reserve Board and a leading expert on international finance, announced today that he would resign from the board in August when his term as vice chairman expires.

title: Demian Acquavella, Dancer, Is Dead at 32
description: Demian Acquavella, a dancer with Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and Company and other troupes, died of AIDS on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 32 years old.

title: Myron A. Wick Jr., Executive, 75
description: Myron A. Wick Jr., former chairman and chief executive officer of Dominick & Dominick, the investment banking house, died on Wednesday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times;   Observations on Failures in Passion and Intimacy
description: Like Life

title: Dying by the Thousands;   Light in Ethiopia?
description: The most pitiable victims of Africa's oldest war are three million Ethiopians trapped on battlefields and facing starvation. But Ethiopia's tough President, Mengistu Haile Mariam, is not faring well either. So it was certainly a breakthrough for decency, and perhaps for peace, when Presidents Bush and Gorbachev agreed at the recent summit meeting to combat famine and help end the war.

title: Ex-Tennis Star Heads SmithKline Drug Unit
description: Jan Leschly, who was a top-ranked professional tennis player in the late 1960's, was named yesterday as chairman of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C.'s worldwide pharmaceuticals business. He will head the largest of the British-based company's four divisions, one that accounts for 50 percent of sales and 60 percent of profits.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Nintendo's Account
description: Nintendo of America, the video-game company, yesterday selected the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding as its advertising agency. The other finalist was the Leo Burnett Company; the incumbent was McCann-Erickson. Nintendo said the account would bill $35 million, although an executive at McCann said the company had never spent more than $15 million. Donald R. Coyner, Nintendo's advertising manager, cited Foote, Cone's work for Levi Strauss as evidence that the agency can market to youth.

title: Justice Confused
description: Weird things are happening down at the law firm of Recusal, Entrapment & Fluttering, formerly known as the U.S. Department of Justice. Some suspect it is a plot by the current Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, to make Ed Meese look good by comparison.

title: Our Towns;   Let Nature And Sweet Tarts Be Your Teacher
description: Every year, first graders in the East Brunswick schools take a field trip to the town park, where they learn about nature from sixth graders. It's always a pretty big deal. Many have never met an actual sixth grader. ''No, I never have,'' said Sarah Kao. Plus, first graders have a lot to learn. They admit it. ''We don't know anything,'' said Sean Clark.

title: Contamination at 3 Labs Casts Doubt On Results Pointing to Cold Fusion
description: Three top laboratories whose work supported low-temperature nuclear fusion said yesterday that their experiments had used palladium metal that was contaminated with tritium, a byproduct of fusion.

title: Line Between Villain and Victim Blurs As Barry Takes Case to Capital's Blacks
description: On the morning the trial began, Kathy Hughes opened her radio talk show with the 27th Psalm: ''The Lord is the strength of my life; of whom shall I be afraid? When the wicked, even mine enemies and my foes, came upon me to eat up my flesh, they stumbled and fell.''

title: Drexler Is Confident As Blazers Go Home
description: The Portland Trail Blazers believe they are a team of destiny. And after tonight's 106-105 overtime victory, they are a major step closer to reaching their destination.

title: U.S. Holds Ex-G.I. On Spying Charges Tied to Bonn's Case
description: Federal agents arrested a former soldier today on spying charges in Tampa, Fla., the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Can Money Alone Fix Urban Schools?
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruling on public-school financing places two constitutional orders on state government, to equalize spending between the poorest and wealthiest districts and to create urban programs far broader than suburban offerings.

title: Trump Aide Denies Talk Of Sales
description: The executive in charge of Donald J. Trump's three casinos denied today that Mr. Trump was seeking buyers for any properties and sought to dispel reports of poor casino performance, managerial dissension and widespread layoffs.

title: Oil Is Spilled in New York Harbor And First Mate on Tanker Is Held
description: A British-flag oil tanker ran aground yesterday morning while docking on the New Jersey side of the Kill van Kull in New York Harbor, spilling about 260,000 gallons of fuel oil into the waterway.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Systems Inc., Palo Alto, Calif., a software company, licensed its Postscript software technology to Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Wider Race Gap in Writing Skill Is Found
description: The gap in writing ability between white and minority students is even greater than previously indicated, according to the results of a nationwide test released today.

title: COMPUTER PROJECT WOULD SPEED DATA
description: A group of private companies, universities, research laboratories and Government agencies is planning to develop an advanced computer network in which data would be transmitted at speeds 700 times faster than possible now. The plan is to be announced today by the National Science Foundation. It would be the first comprehensive effort in the United States to advance the technologically critical area of computer networks and is being called an important model for cooperation between business and government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Fairchild Publications has started a tennis business magazine, Tennis Merchandiser. Terence Moffatt is the editor, and Diane Langhorst is the advertising manager.

title: Motorola To Announce New Phone
description: Motorola Inc. applied yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to test and market wireless personal telephones in Chicago and Atlanta.

title: Glenn Abernathy, 68, Political Scientist, Dies
description: M. Glenn Abernathy, who taught at the University of South Carolina for 35 years, died of a stroke on Tuesday while visiting a son in Richmond. He was 68 years old and lived in Columbia, S. C. Dr. Abernathy retired in 1986 as the Olin D. Johnston Professor of Political Science at the university.

title: U.S. Delays On Iraqi Bid
description: The Bush Administration has delayed a decision on Iraq's request for an additional $500 million in loan guarantees from the Commodity Credit Corporation until the conclusion of an Agriculture Department investigation into possible irregularities, including kickbacks, involving Iraq's purchase of American agricultural commodities.

title: Piano Recital
description: Jodie Gelbogis DeSalvo is to play Busoni's arrangement of the Bach Chaconne, Beethoven's Sonata No. 31 (Op. 110), Prokofiev's Sonata No. 6 (Op. 82) and the world premiere of Keith Pruitt's Sonata for Piano at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: Miss Reger Wed To Howard Crash
description: Patricia Reger, an interior designer, and Howard Crash, an investment banker, were married yesterday at the ''21'' Club in New York by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattlebaum.

title: Insurer Insolvencies: Next Mega-Crisis?
description: LEAD: Unless appropriate regulatory and enforcement actions are taken, the nation could face a crisis in the insurance industry rivaling the thrift debacle. The parallels are disturbing.

title: Lawyers Ask Judge to Spare Poindexter From Prison-Term
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter asked a Federal judge today not to imprison the former national security adviser for his crimes in the Iran-contra affair, asserting that he had already suffered enough.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Upper Columbus Avenue Street Fair, Columbus Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 86th to 96th Streets from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Restaurants
description: Bice

title: John Alexander, 71, A Newark Pediatrician
description: Dr. John W. Alexander, a pediatrician and educator who helped develop the first neonatal intensive-care unit in Newark, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his house in Orange, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: Colony of Film Stars Votes to Become a City
description: Malibu, the famed colony of the stars, is now the 87th city in Los Angeles County Residents voted by 3,797 to 708 on Tuesday to incorporate into a city that will stretch 20 miles along the California coast and one mile inland into the foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains, where many of the celebrities have their homes.

title: Ethnic Warfare Grows in Soviet Asia, With Toll at 48 in One City
description: Ethnic warfare in Central Asia continued to grow today as mobs roamed the capital of the republic of Kirghizia demanding that the local government resign and armed militants reportedly massed on the Uzbek border.

title: Iacocca Says He Will Stay At Chrysler's Helm Past '91
description: Seeking to allay concerns among investors, dealers and employees that a leadership vacuum could develop at the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca said today that he would stay on as chairman beyond December 1991.

title: Market Place;   Some Managers Shunning Stocks
description: As the Dow Jones industrial average flirts with 3,000, many market watchers are wondering whether a group of professional investors will be forced by their clients to join the rally and spend their huge sums of cash, thus pushing stock prices even higher.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Other Illicit Traffic
description: Antiquities smuggling can be seen as an unacknowledged twin of the narcotics traffic. Each trade has its pushers, middlemen and addicted customers. There is even a curious geographical overlap. The soils of Latin America, the Middle East and Asia richest in ancient art are in many places highly suitable for cultivating the coca leaf, marijuana and opium poppies.

title: Abbott Argues Actor He Killed Didn't Suffer
description: Jack Henry Abbott, the imprisoned killer and author who is being sued for the death and suffering he caused when he killed an aspiring actor in the East Village, maintained yesterday at a court hearing that his attack on the young man was so quick that there was no suffering.

title: Free Bus to 3 Museums For 'The Decade Show'
description: There is a free Saturday bus service for visitors to the most dispersed art exhibition in New York, ''The Decade Show: Frameworks of Identity in the 1980's.'' The three participating museums are the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, and its neighbor across the street in SoHo, the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art, 584 Broadway.

title: A Cuomo Away, but Not Far, From Albany
description: At 24, Andrew M. Cuomo ran his father's first successful campaign for governor. At 25, he moved into an office in the Capitol and joined the ruling elite of state government. He spent his days, and many of his nights, with a telephone in one hand and a cigarette in the other, plunging from one political conflict to the next.

title: Yankees Get 1 Hit; Merrill 2d Loss
description: His career as a big league manager is two games old, but Stump Merrill has already seen the worst of times with the Yankees.

title: Durenberger Hearings May Focus on Intent
description: Noting that Senator Dave Durenberger had so far not disputed the facts of the case that has been made against him by the Senate Ethics Committee, the panel's ranking members suggested today that their inquiry might now focus on whether any wrongdoing was deliberate or inadvertent.

title: The Strawberries Are Ready! Are the Pickers?
description: The pick-it-yourself strawberry season has arrived on farms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: After No Choice, Czechoslovaks Now Have Many
description: Czechs and Slovaks will put a formal end to 42 years of imposed rule Friday and Saturday with two days of parliamentary elections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANK SINATRA spelled his last name backward and has put it, along with a very youthful picture of himself, on jars of spaghetti sauce. Last week, the sauce, made by Artanis Foods International, hit the shelves in California and will work its way eastward by October.

title: Mary Headlee Markham, Otolaryngologist, 81
description: Dr. Mary Headlee Markham, an otolaryngologist in Manhattan for almost 50 years, died Wednesday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after suffering a stroke. She was 81 years old and until March had lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. PLANNING SALE OF ARMS TO SAUDIS
description: The Bush Administration has announced plans to sell $4 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia, including light armored vehicles, antitank missiles and improvements for Awacs electronic surveillance aircraft.

title: U.S. Issues Rise in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly in light trading yesterday, as interest rates remained locked in a tight range.

title: Pic N' Save Truce With Dissidents
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation reached a truce with Girard Partners L.P., a dissident shareholder group trying to gain control of its board. The parties said Pic 'N' Save's annual meeting would be postponed until Aug. 15 and neither would solicit proxies or consents before July 15. The pact allows Pic 'N' Save, based in Dominguez, Calif., and its investment bankers to concentrate on finding bidders for the company, which could include Girard.

title: Jackson and Barry Meet on Call For Plea Bargain on Drug Counts
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and the Rev. Jesse Jackson met over lunch today to discuss Mr. Jackson's suggestion that Mr. Barry offer not to seek re-election as part of a plea agreement with Federal prosecutors.

title: 2 New York Officials Sue to Overturn Ban On Positions in Party
description: Two New York City borough presidents filed suit yesterday to challenge a provision of the new city charter barring many elected and appointed municipal officials from holding political party office.

title: Review/Ballet;   2 Sets of Partners in 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' calls for as much dramatic as danced interpretation. It is not a question of chewing the scenery, or even of gestural interpretation, but of full commitment to these now stereotypical star-crossed lovers. That point was made, in two different ways, when American Ballet Theater presented the MacMillan-Prokofiev classic on Tuesday and Wednesday nights at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN and MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS will team up as artistic directors of the new Pacific Music Festival, to be inaugurated June 26 in Sapporo, Japan. The three-week festival is modeled after the Tanglewood Festival, where both conductors have studied, taught and performed.

title: Oklahoma St. Routs L.S.U. on Way to Finals
description: With two days remaining until the national championship game, the 53d College World Series, distinguished early on by sloppy play and big innings, has shaped up as a showdown among two traditional powers and one newcomer.

title: Why Applaud Art Auctions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Loss of Tropical Forests Is Found Much Worse Than Was Thought
description: Tropical forests, which play a vital role in regulating the global climate, are disappearing much more rapidly than previously estimated, an international research group said today.

title: Lewis in New York
description: Carl Lewis, the first entrant in last year's inaugural New York Games, will return to the event July 29 at Columbia University's Wien Stadium, Fred Lebow, the executive director of the meet, announced yesterday.

title: Economic Scene;   How a Trade Pact Could Aid Soviets
description: The trade agreement signed by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Washington summit meeting still has high hurdles to clear before it takes effect.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a chart yesterday showing election results omitted a figure in some copies for the Democratic nominee for the Senate from North Carolina. Harvey Gantt won the nomination with 57 percent of the vote.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, the diversified travel, financial and information services company, appointed Randy L. Christofferson senior vice president for strategic planning.

title: House Votes To Override Amtrak Veto
description: The House of Representatives today overrode President Bush's veto of legislation continuing the Federal subsidy of Amtrak, the passenger rail line, but Senate action was delayed until next week as Republicans attempted to rally support for the veto.

title: Out of Black Africa, Varied Perspectives Of Life and the Arts
description: THIS is a weekend for the African explorer, and you don't have to go by way of the Cape of Good Hope, either. In art, in dance and in music, the many cultures and esthetics of the big continent on the downtown side of the Mediterranean will be making a splash in Manhattan.
