title: North Korea Faults Roh and Gorbachev
description: North Korea indirectly lashed out at President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea today for what it said was his ''shameless, flunkyist'' meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in San Francisco on Monday. It also rebuked Moscow in milder terms for embarrassing Pyongyang by meeting with its archenemy in the United States.

title: LAW:At the Bar;   The fetish of footnotes, or the folly of trying to eradicate the profession's enduring weeds.
description: It was supposedly Noel Coward who once complained that encountering a footnote was ''like going downstairs to answer the doorbell while making love.'' Or was it John Barrymore, and was his choice of verbs more pungent? For further information, see footnote 23 in ''Footnote#1 Skulduggery#2 and other Bad Habits#3,'' by Arthur D. Austin of Case Western Reserve Law School.

title: Auctions
description: Dotty Pottery

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Margery Gladstone has been appointed associate publisher of Lear's magazine.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: East German Visa Card
description: East Germans will be able to apply for Visa credit cards in the autumn, the Berliner Stadtbank A.G. said on Wednesday after joining the international Visa card network. The Visa board of directors for Europe, the Middle East and Africa accepted the bank as a member at Visa's annual meeting in Berlin. Berliner Stadtbank will be the first bank to offer plastic cards to East German citizens.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Randall Rothenberg Serious Plans Of Saatchi's New Leaders
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company is planning to open agencies in Hungary and East Germany and is exploring the possibility of making its Campbell-Mithun-Esty agency in the United States a part of a small international advertising network, the company's chief executive and its group financial officer said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: KOHL, AT HARVARD, REAFFIRMS BORDER
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany reiterated today that the border between Germany and Poland would remain ''inviolable'' after his country reunites with East Germany.

title: Review/Circus;   Clowns Who Fly and Flies Who Clown
description: At Circus Oz, almost everyone, no matter how daring, intends to be funny: jumpers, gymnasts and aerialists who crowd a trapeze so that they become as close-quartered as straphangers on a subway car during rush hour. In this Australian circus, clowns can fly.

title: Icahn Loses USX Contest
description: The USX Corporation said today that its shareholders had rejected the proposal by the takeover specialist Carl C. Icahn to spin off the company's steel division.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 504 money market mutual funds decreased by $804.80 million, to $380.73 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds decreased by $475.30 million, to $92.14 billion. The assets of the 241 general-purpose funds were up by $1.01 billion, to $130.30 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.34 million, to $158.28 billion, the institute said.

title: High-Tech Embargoes On Eastern Bloc Eased
description: The United States and its major industrial partners agreed to ease strictures on high-technology exports to the Warsaw Pact, with even broader access for Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and East Germany.

title: Du Pont Offers $1.85 Billion In Zero-Coupon Securities
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is offering $1.85 billion in zero-coupon convertible discount notes with final maturity of June 14, 2010, through the First Boston Corporation as sole manager. The size of the issue was originally to have been about $1.3 billion.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Man Ray's New Incarnation

title: Don't Test Mandela on Israel
description: Nelson Mandela is on his way to Geneva to meet with leaders of half a dozen mainstream American Jewish organizations who are asking him to clarify his position on Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Fortissimo, Forsooth

title: Another Thriller As Blazers Tie Series
description: Two free throws by Clyde Drexler tonight with 2.1 seconds left in the five-minute overtime enabled the Portland Trail Blazers to edge the Detroit Pistons, 106-105, in a 3-hour-14-minute struggle of heroics and changing leads.

title: Review/Photography;   Using the Camera as a Guide and Tool in Painting
description: Since its invention, photography has served painters as an illustrational aid, helping them convey expressions, gestures and movements too fleeting for the naked eye. In a few cases - Edgar Degas is the most obvious example - photographs have provided cues for composition as well.

title: Creditors to Fight Drexel's Plan for Revamping
description: A committee of unsecured creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that it would oppose the investment firm's reorganization plan.

title: Ex-Church Official, Denying Theft, Tells Of $300,000 Profit
description: A former New York church treasurer accused of disappearing eight years ago with church funds said today that he had left abruptly because he was the target of industrial espionage, not because he had stolen anything.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Return of the Founder

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Newspaper Ads Down
description: Newspaper advertising spending for the first quarter of the year fell by three-tenths of a percent, to $7.296 billion, compared with the first quarter of 1989, according to preliminary estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. While retail advertising rose by 2.7 percent, to $3.835 billion, classified advertising dropped by 6.4 percent, to $2.495 billion.

title: KEY RATES
SOUTH AFRICA ENDS EMERGENCY DECREE IN 3 OF 4 PROVINCES
description: Addressing a major obstacle to full-scale negotiations with the African National Congress, President F. W. de Klerk announced today that national state-of-emergency regulations in effect for the last four years would be lifted in all but one of South Africa's four provinces.

title: Neta Lohnes Frazier, Children's Writer, 100
description: Neta Lohnes Frazier, an award-winning writer, died Saturday. She was 100 years old.

title: Krzyzewski to Stay?
description: Mike Krzyzewski has decided to remain at Duke as basketball coach, declining overtures to become coach of the Boston Celtics, according to a newspaper report.

title: Review/Film;   Myths of Race and Sex In a Breezy Examination
description: The smoothly self-congratulatory hero of ''How to Make Love to a Negro Without Getting Tired'' is a black Haitian writer living in Montreal and concentrating most of his energies on sexual conquests. Devoting himself exclusively to adoring white college-girl types, whom he and an African roommate privately refer to as Miz Literature, Miz Suicide, Miz Tickle-Tickle and so on, this writer, called Man (Isaach de Bankole), sometimes reflects upon racism. Sometimes he makes bitter fun of the way whites allow racial stereotypes to distort their perceptions of blacks. Most of the time, though, he thinks exclusively about trying to score.

title: Slaney to Run Outdoors
description: Mary Slaney plans tonight to run her first outdoors race on the track since 1988. She will attempt to qualify for next week's national championships in the 1,500 meters.

title: In Rocking East Village, The Beat Never Stops
description: NEW YORK is a city of differences; in the East Village, those differences are just a little louder. The street life is livelier, the hairdos are spikier, the short skirts a bit shorter than in other neighborhoods. People in the East Village wear their differences proudly. There are more tattoos, more black leather, more white T-shirts and more guitars than anywhere else in Manhattan. There are fewer suits and ties there, too, so to wear a suit and tie is to be different. And in the East Village, to be different is to fit right in.

title: 'Piano Lesson' Remarks And Artistic Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: James L. Green, Urologist, 70
description: Dr. James L. Green, a urologist who was a founding physician at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Floral Park, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Now, NATO Is in Search of a New Self
description: NATO Foreign Ministers meeting here agreed today that their alliance was going to have to begin defining itself more as a partner of the Soviet Union than as an enemy, a senior American official said.

title: Texas Researchers Develop 4 Gene-Altered Calves
description: A team of scientists here has produced the nation's first genetically engineered calves, a new milestone in using advanced genetic technology to alter food-producing animals.

title: Filling the Body After Nourishing the Soul
description: The East Village, for all its renown as an incubator for new ideas in music, art, film and theater, does not have a reputation as a hotbed of gastronomy.

title: Lower Business Spending
description: Spending by businesses to expand their production is expected to rise at an annual rate of 5.5 percent in 1990, down from an estimated 7.9 percent increase estimated two months ago, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Warsaw Pact Pronounces the End Of Ideological Conflict With West
description: The Warsaw Pact members today pronounced an end to the notion of the West as ''ideological enemy'' and agreed to study ways of transforming the pact into a democratic alliance to better stabilize Europe.

title: Nynex Plan Spurs 4,000 Retirements
description: The Nynex Corporation said about 4,000 managers had taken advantage of a special retirement incentive program that ended last week. The company said 2,100 managers retired from its New York Telephone Company unit, 900 from the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, 600 from the Nynex Service Company and the rest from other operations.

title: Dorothy Weeks, 97, A Physicist Who Led In Variety of Careers
description: Dorothy W. Weeks, a physicist whose professional career spanned nearly six decades, died of a stroke on Monday at Newton Wellesley Hospital in Massachusetts. She was 97 years old and lived in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Northwest Air Sees Revenue Shortfall
description: Northwest Airlines is facing a shortfall in expected revenues this year and has asked managers to come up with $34 million in cuts. ''This is not unusual,'' an NWA Inc. spokesman, Doug Miller, said. ''This company goes through budget reviews all the time.'' The projected shortfall, $80 million, totals 1 percent of the airline's 1989 budget, he said.

title: Review/Art;   Themes of Vuillard: Naturalism to the Daring
description: In ''The Intimate Interiors of Edouard Vuillard,'' an exhibition of 74 paintings, 32 prints and drawings by the French artist at the Brooklyn Museum, artistic radicality is couched in familial tenderness.

title: Criteria Upheld On Adjustments For the Census
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday upheld Commerce Department guidelines for deciding whether the 1990 census should be adjusted to compensate for any undercount.

title: Norman Withdraws
description: Greg Norman, who has played in the last two Buick Classics and nearly won one of them, has withdrawn from this year's tournament at the Westchester Country Club, June 21-24.

title: Review/Ballet;   Fashion Merger: Dance, Dollars And a New Scent
description: A ballet helped send a new perfume onto the market on Monday night when Christian Lacroix, the French fashion designer, introduced ''C'est la Vie,'' his first perfume, at a reception at the Palladium. What made the occasion choreographically noteworthy was that it included a powerful performance of Maurice Bejart's ''Bolero,'' with Sylvie Guillem, a guest star from the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: Nationwide Arts Day Supports Endowment
description: Joining hundreds of cultural organizations around the United States yesterday in support of the National Endowment for the Arts, the Metropolitan Museum of Art draped paintings in black, Carnegie Hall gave a sidewalk percussion salute and Mayor David N. Dinkins helped explain what Arts Day U.S.A. was all about.

title: Science Careers Are Attracting Few Blacks
description: Nearly 9,600 Americans earned Ph.D.'s in the natural sciences and engineering in 1989. Only 133 of them were black. As small as that figure is, it was an improvement on the 1988 total of 124, and it matched the highest previous figure, reached in 1978.

title: ESP? Camels? It's Time to Play
description: The leading clairvoyants in Yaounde, the capital of Cameroon, were recently polled by a local newspaper to determine the fortune of the national team in the 1990 World Cup finals. None offered an opinion.

title: Farm Credit Bonds To Yield 8.807%
description: The Farm Credit System Financial Assistance Corporation yesterday priced $325 million in 8.80 percent bonds due 2005 at a price of 99 30/32, to yield 8.807 percent, through 25 securities dealers and dealer banks.

title: New Russian Orthodox Head
description: An ethnic Estonian considered a strong backer of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms was elected the new Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church and its following of tens of millions today. Metropolitan Alexi of Leningrad and Novgorod won election in a secret ballot, said Anna Generalova, a church spokeswoman. A church council of 330 members chose him as successor to Patriarch Pimen, who died May 3.

title: The Captain Who Stays Anonymous
description: In most countries, Mike Windischmann would be a legend. In the United States, he is a man who may want another job in a few weeks.

title: Dow Falls 14.32 Points, To 2,897.33
description: The stock market fell yesterday for the third consecutive day, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 14.32 points, dropping below the 2,900 mark that it had hurdled so smartly last Friday.

title: Some Babes in Uniform For House Ruth Built
description: One day after he selected another new manager to take over his skidding team, George Steinbrenner promised more changes for the Yankees, probably within days.

title: Violence, as American as Apple Pie
description: To the Editor:

title: Read California's Rumbles
description: California, no stranger to earthquakes, produced two political tremors on Tuesday that are likely to reverberate nationwide. The voters who led a revolt against spending and taxes 12 years ago approved a sharp increase in gasoline taxes and loosened restrictions on spending. They also named Dianne Feinstein as the Democratic candidate to run for governor in the fall.

title: New Civil Rights Bill Doesn't Mean Quotas
description: To the Editor:

title: Conagra In Deal for Beatrice
description: In a surprise announcement, Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Beatrice Company for $1.34 billion in a combination that would create the nation's second-largest food company.

title: With Dance And a Play
description: A typically rich mix of performance art and dance is being offered this weekend by Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. The cheeky but venerable home for the arts has become one of the city's major sites for avant-garde theater. Audiences have three very different events to choose from, in two funky, cozy theater spaces.

title: Review/Theater;   Bleak Comedy of Grotesquely Piggish Male Views
description: Though Jules Feiffer is always thought of first as an iconoclastic political cartoonist, it is his words for film and theater that really get people hopping mad. It's still possible to find fans of Feiffer cartoons arguing about whether ''Carnal Knowledge,'' his 1971 movie about eternally adolescent American men, was mysogynist, or whether ''Grown Ups,'' his 1981 play about an imploding Jewish American family, was an act of Jewish anti-Semitism. The anger is hardly likely to subside with ''Elliot Loves,'' the bleak and unsatisfying comedy that Mr. Feiffer and his ''Carnal Knowledge'' collaborator, the director Mike Nichols, have brought to the Promenade Theater.

title: Private Clubs May Be Bigger Barrier for Nominees
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee moved today to warn lawyers that if they aspire to become Federal judges or senior Justice Department officials, they should not belong to clubs that exclude women, blacks or other minority members.

title: Bankers Trust Sells Notes Due in 2000
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation priced $200 million in 9 1/2 percent subordinated notes due 2000 yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: TV Weekend;   End of the Run for Garry Shandling
description: At the top of Showtime's comedy lineup tonight, at 10, is the final episode of ''It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' which, perhaps not so coincidentally, was pulled not too long ago from the Fox Broadcasting Sunday-night schedule. The comic has no need to pout, as is his wont. On the Showtime pay-cable service, ''It's Garry Shandling's Show'' compiled a total of 72 episodes over four seasons. Good show. The shambling Mr. Shandling has parlayed a keen eye and ear for life's daily foibles into a performance persona that his fans find gently ingratiating. Some, though, have been heard to say they find that same persona irritatingly inert. As far as the Shandling career is concerned, the yeas clearly have the momentum.

title: Shift in Senate Control Gave Us McCarthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Say Risk From Asbestos Is Higher Than They Had Thought
description: In a rejoinder to some scientists who have recently argued that asbestos in buildings poses little hazard to health, other scientists contended yesterday at an international asbestos conference that the threat was even greater than had been thought.

title: For Children
description: SHOWS, NATURE, MUSEUMS

title: Animals' Advocates Seen as 'Terrorists' By Health Secretary
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services today portrayed animal rights activists as ''terrorists'' and said raids on laboratories and similar tactics used by some of them jeopardized disease-curing experiments.

title: Where to Go to Get Them
description: Here is a list of pick-it-yourself strawberry farms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, prepared by the Departments of Agriculture in New York and Connecticut and the Cooperative Extension Service in New Jersey.

title: Graduates Are Urged To Aid Poor
description: George Friedman, a philanthropist and former executive director of the ''I Have a Dream'' foundation, which pays for the college educations of underprivileged students, urged graduates of Brooklyn College to give back something to those who are less fortunate.

title: Senate's Leaders Move to Salvage Crime Measure
description: A major anti-crime package that includes a provision banning the manufacture and sale of some semiautomatic weapons suffered a serious setback today amid swelling opposition from both gun control opponents and civil liberties groups.

title: U.S. Investigation Of Norton Merger
description: The Federal Government will investigate whether the proposed merger between the Norton Company, an American manufacturer with military contracts, and a French company raises national security concerns. Executives announced the $1.8 billion merger between Norton and France's Compagnie de Saint-Gobain this spring, thwarting a hostile bid made by BTR P.L.C., a British company, for Norton, based in Worcester, Mass.

title: At the Movies
description: Donleavy on Film

title: Democratic and Republican Leaders See Way to Trim Conventions
description: Leaders of the Democratic and Republican Parties joined today to offer a horse trade of a singularly modern sort: They would shorten the Presidential nominating conventions if the television networks would provide free air time for the candidates to speak to the voters when they are paying most attention, in the fall.

title: Major Chip Advance Is Reported by Hitachi
description: Hitachi Ltd., one of Japan's biggest electronics companies, said today that it was the first to reach a long-sought milestone in microelectronics: the development of a working prototype of a memory chip that can store more than 64 million bits of information.

title: AIDS Vaccine Shows Promise
description: An experimental AIDS vaccine given to eight human volunteers started the production of immune cells able to seek out and destroy AIDS-infected cells in blood samples from three of them, researchers said today.

title: Pathe Delays Completion Of Its MGM/UA Takeover
description: The Pathe Communications Corporation did not complete its takeover of the MGM/UA Communications Company yesterday and instead extended its tender offer to June 15.

title: Times Reporter Wins $15,000 Library Award
description: Thomas L. Friedman, the author of ''From Beirut to Jerusalem,'' is the recipient of the Helen B. Bernstein Award for Excellence in Journalism, which is given annually by the New York Public Library. Mr. Friedman, a two-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize for international reporting, was bureau chief for The New York Times in Beirut and Israel. He was honored for his book, which was published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Henkel Cosmetic, to Tracy-Locke in Los Angeles, for its Fa brand of toiletries.

title: G.M. AND MOSCOW IN $1 BILLION PACT
description: In a move that could foreshadow closer ties between the Soviet Union and American companies, the General Motors Corporation signed a $1 billion agreement in the Soviet Union today to sell auto parts to the largest Soviet car maker.

title: Nagasaki Journal;   With the Hugest Splash, the Japanese Go Cruising
description: A while back Shoji Fukushima took a break from his job at the giant shipyard dominating the harbor here and signed up for one of those luxurious Caribbean cruises that haggard-looking Japanese executives see advertised on commuter trains as they are crushed toward their offices every morning.

title: Investigator Delivers Steinbrenner Report
description: John Dowd, the Washington lawyer who conducted baseball's investigation of Pete Rose, delivered the report of his investigation of George Steinbrenner to Commissioner Fay Vincent in San Francisco yesterday.

title: No-Lick Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC Meeting Called Possible
description: A top official of Indonesia, considered a moderate member of OPEC, said today that it was possible the organization might hold an emergency meeting because of plunging oil prices.

title: Teen-Age Duel: Seles Too Much for Capriati
description: In what turned out to be a one-sided battle between two prominent members of the Swatch generation, 16-year-old Monica Seles used her double-whammy ground strokes to subdue 14-year-old Jennifer Capriati, 6-2, 6-2, today in the semifinals of the French Open.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McCabe's New Agency Promotes Miami Heat
description: The Miami Heat basketball team, which had previously handled its own advertising, has turned to Ed McCabe and his new agency, Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners, for additional marketing help. ''We would not have changed our posture had it not been for Ed,'' said Patrick Speer, the Heat's vice president of corporate affairs.

title: U.S. Jews Go to Geneva To Meet With Mandela
description: A delegation of American Jewish leaders left for Geneva last night to meet with Nelson Mandela before his arrival in New York on June 20 for a 10-day visit to the United States.

title: U.S. to Relax Standards On High-Tech Exports
description: Responding to political change in Eastern Europe and intense lobbying from Western companies, the United States and other major industrial powers agreed today to a sharp reduction of controls on high-technology exports to Warsaw Pact nations.

title: On Stage
description: Ron Silver's Tony Speech

title: Meyer M. Kailo, 73; Rose From a Clerk To a Housing Aide
description: Meyer Mitchell Kailo, a career civil servant for the City of New York, died on Monday at the West Boca Raton (Fla.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and had homes in Boca Raton and Suffern, N.Y.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Burkhardt & Christy's Spot for Sony Tapes
description: Because audio tape is a product whose quality varies little from brand to brand, most advertising for the product relies on image. Burkhardt & Christy's first campaign for Sony audio tape, which starts next month, is no exception.

title: In the Water
description: The pool at the Manhattan Plaza Health Club, 482 West 43d Street, will be filled with dancers and their Hula-Hoops and other props in a water show presented by Water Works. The show, ''Crosscurrents,'' is to be performed at 9 tonight and at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Tickets are $10. Information: 459-4154.

title: Cable TV Bill Is Backed
description: A Senate committee voted today to restore Federal regulation of cable television rates and service, after hearing scores of complaints from cable customers nationwide about high rate increases and poor service. The bill was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee by an 18-to-1 vote and sent to the full Senate. It gives the Federal Communications Commission authority to regulate rates for basic cable services, including local station broadcasts, to insure the rates are reasonable. Premium services, like movie channels, which cost more, would not be included.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Tropical deforestation is an unparalleled tragedy. If we don't reverse the trend soon, it will be too late.''

title: Benefit Programs Emerging As Big Hurdle to Deficit Cuts
description: White House and Congressional budget negotiators turned from military to domestic spending today in their search for a way to slash about $50 billion from the Governmment's deficit for the next fiscal year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Anti-Drinking Effort Aimed at Teen-Agers
description: The Advertising Council and the Harvard Center for Health Communication have announced a project to combat alcoholism among teen-agers. The effort will build on the campaign of public-service ads the council announced two weeks ago.

title: A Truant Officer Children Love to See
description: Jonathan Fuzzell is only a kindergartner, but he has already fallen behind at Public School 94 in the north Bronx. His teacher, Susan Kessler, says Jonathan is sweet, determined to learn and an outstanding artist. But he has missed 50 days of school.

title: Sports People: TRACK AND FIELD;   Beatty to Be Inducted Into Hall of Fame
description: The National Track and Field Hall of Fame will take in four new members this year. In an announcement yesterday in Indianapolis, site of the hall, the new nominees were singled out: Jim Beatty, the first man to break the four-minute mile indoors; Charles Dumas, the first to high jump 7 feet; Doris Brown Heritage, winner of 14 United States distance titles and five world cross-country events, and Rick Wohlhuter, a two-time Olympian and former world record-holder at 880 yards and 1,000 meters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three youths convicted of painting anti-Semitic graffiti on a high school in Westchester County got a letter from JAMES A. MICHENER on the shame of racism. Their sentence had included reading a chapter on a Nazi concentration camp from the author's book ''Poland.''

title: Side Issues Maintain Lead on Eve Of Belmont
description: There were no surprises as the expected nine 3-year-olds were entered yesterday morning for the 122d Belmont Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park. The mood surrounding the draw, though, reflected the peculiar character of the final leg of the Triple Crown this year.

title: Aide to Bush Assails Cuomo On Drug Plansi
description: William J. Bennett, the President's national drug policy director, issued a blistering attack on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's drug policies today and asserted that the White House has no fear of a Cuomo Presidential candidacy.

title: Agassi to Face Svensson
description: In the men's semifinals Friday, the most controversial player left in the French Open draw, third-seeded Andre Agassi, will face Jonas Svensson of Sweden, a meditative player who has career victories against Boris Becker and Ivan Lendl, but who has had trouble stringing victories together.

title: Shock Greets Banning of a Rap Album
description: Civil liberties experts and First Amendment lawyers expressed shock yesterday over a Federal judge's finding in Florida that a rap album by the Miami-based group 2 Live Crew was obscene under the Supreme Court's 1973 criterion of contemporary community standards.

title: Mariners' Johnson Retires 20 in Row
description: Randy Johnson said he pitched as well today as he did last Saturday when he pitched a no-hitter. The results weren't quite as good, but the 6-foot-10-inch left-hander wasn't complaining.

title:
Waterfront Housing;

Coney Island Complex Being Converted
description: LEAD: A 734-unit rental apartment complex in Coney Island on the border of Brighton Beach, which is being converted into condominiums under a non-eviction plan, is one of 17 in the city whose owners have pulled out of the Mitchell-Lama housing program. Three upstate projects have also left the program.

title: Wasserstein, Perella To Acquire Maybelline
description: Wasserstein, Perella Partners L.P. said today that it would buy the Maybelline Company for $300 million, after a deal for the beauty-products concern collapsed.

title: Dying by the Thousands;   Darkness in the Sudan
description: What does it take to get the United States Government to express revulsion and horror?

title: Consumer Debt Rise Is Slower
description: Consumers took on debt at a sharply lower rate in April by putting off purchases of new cars, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Delay in Dredging of PCB's
description: An attempt to delay cleanup of PCB's from the Hudson River was vetoed from the new $50 billion state budget today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The veto of the PCB measure included in the budget permits the Environmental Conservation Department to go ahead with plans to dredge contaminated sediment from the Hudson and develop a landfill for it in Washington County. Under the Cuomo administration plan, PCB's scooped from the Hudson would be buried at that landfill and eventually destroyed.

title: Correction
description: A chart yesterday listing the Yankee managers hired during George Steinbrenner's ownership including incomplete records for three managers in some copies and, as a result, misstated the overall record.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about Wagner's ''Parsifal'' at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. appeared under an incorrect dateline. The festival is in Charleston, S.C., not Charlotte.

title: Fight the Philistines
description: A small band of religious zealots and right-wing political opportunists is trying to show the world that America is an intolerant Puritan country, contemptuous of artists. Are the rest of us going to take that in silence, wringing our hands, or are we going to stand up and fight?

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Arms Sale to Saudis

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday listing the Yankee managers during George Steinbrenner's ownership included incomplete records for three managers in some copies and, as a result, misstated the overall record for the Steinbrenner era. A corrected chart appears today on page B15.

title: Article 069790 -- No Title
description: Gerald Greenwald will get at least $9 million to give up his post as vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation and become head of a union effort to buy the UAL Corporation, people familiar with the buyout proposal said yesterday, confirming a published report.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about Peter M. Brant, who was sentenced to prison for tax evasion in Bridgeport, Conn., was published in error. It showed a different Peter Brant - Peter N. Brant, who was sentenced in 1988 to eight months in prison for insider trading.

title: Canada Premiers Near Accord
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces reached agreement early today on a package of measures that clears the way for adoption of the Meech Lake constitutional agreement.

title: Transamerica Deal For Nova Financial
description: The First Interstate Bancorp signed a definitive agreement to sell Nova Financial Services, a San Diego-based consumer lending operation, to the Transamerica Corporation for about $108 million in cash. First Interstate said it would record a pretax gain of about $90 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON was released Thrusday night from St. Johns Hospitial and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif., after chest pains he suffered were traced to bruised ribs. The 31-year-old entertainer, who checked into the hospital Sunday, suffered from costochondritis, or cartilage inflammation of the front part of the ribs, according to his physician, Dr MARK ZATZKIS. Mr. Jackson apparently suffered the injury during his regular Sunday two-hour solo dance session in a bedroom of his Los Angeles home.

title: Penguins Eye Bowman
description: Scotty Bowman, the top-winning coach in National Hockey League history, is being considered for a job with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Anne Bahr Weds R.E. Thompson
description: Anne L. Bahr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Bahr of Elberon Park, N.J., was married yesterday in Edinburgh to Ronald E. Thompson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson of Madison, Conn. Katrina Hoy, Queen's Register for the District of St. Andrew, performed the ceremony at the Queen's Registry.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 16 about a dropout prevention program in New York City misstated the amount spent by the Board of Education per participant. It was $800, not $8,000.

title: Yanks Get New Look But Same Old Result
description: The Yankees, a team trying to change on the run, made more changes today. But the results had a familiar, sad ring as the Orioles defeated the Yankees, 5-4, in 10 innings. The loss was the Yankees' seventh in a row and 12th in 13 games.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday on the California election erroneously described Dianne Feinstein as ''pro-life.'' As the context made clear, she favors the right of women to choose an abortion.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Danaher Corp., Washington D.C., a manufacturer of tools and transportation products, announced its acquisition of Easco Hand Tools Inc., Hunt Valley, Md. for $125 million.

title: Issue of Race Rules on test For Mayor
description: Mayor James L. Usry, running for a third term, wears a button that says ''Do the Right Thing.'' His campaign literature, distributed only in black wards, urges people to vote for him because of ''the color of my skin'' and because, he says, the Lord wants him to ''make life better for you - my people.''

title: What Good Are Pupfish and Periwinkles?
description: LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. recently suggested that society must choose between economic growth and protecting endangered species. Citing the dispute over a proposed observatory that threatens the endangered Mount Graham red squirrel in Arizona, he asked, ''Do we have to save every subspecies?

title: Baker Seeks to Avoid Breaking Off P.L.O. Talks
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d indicated today that the Bush Administration was trying to do all it could to avoid breaking off the United States-P.L.O. dialogue because that would mean an end to the current peace process.

title: Ames Chain Closing 188 More Stores
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. yesterday took its biggest cost-cutting step since its April 25 bankruptcy filing by announcing the closing of an additional 188 stores. The chain had reported earlier that 33 would be closed.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Six Brokers Are Disciplined
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said it disciplined six brokers for violating exchange rules.

title: Herbert Blueweiss, Publisher, 67
description: Herbert Blueweiss, executive publisher of a men's wear and textile industry newspaper and an officer with Fairchild Publications Inc., died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and his death was attributed to an apparent heart attack by a spokesman for the family.

title: For Communists in Bulgaria, A Ballot With no Guarantees
description: The election season in Eastern Europe, which began last March in East Germany, is ending in Bulgaria with what amounts to a referendum on the fate of the last ruling Communist Party in the Warsaw Pact outside the Soviet Union.

title: Schweitzer Deplored Lab-Animal Suffering
description: To the Editor:

title: Tar Balls From Oil Spill Wash Up Along Beaches in Three Boroughs
description: Gooey fist-size tar balls began washing ashore yesterday on several New York beaches as the impact of a 260,000-gallon oil spill on Thursday slowly spread from the site of a tanker accident in the Kill van Kull.

title: Getting Closer in Pretoria
description: President F. W. de Klerk has taken a new and vital step toward peaceful resolution of South Africa's racial problems, ending emergency rule in three of its four provinces effective today. Pretoria is now within sight of meeting the African National Congress's preconditions for beginning formal negotiations, and Washington's conditions for ending sanctions.

title: Paying for Electric Power by the Time of Day
description: A growing number of consumers are paying a price for electricity based on the time of day they use it.

title: Bensonhurst Leaders Will Join Demonstrators in Unity Drive
description: Leaders of the heavily Italian-American Bensonhurst area in Brooklyn and those who have been demonstrating over the racial slaying of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black teen-ager, said yesterday that they would work together on a citywide effort to heal racial divisions.

title: Cuomo Weighs Move to Drop Tobacco Stocks
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said this week that he is studying whether the state should ban the investment of state pension funds in tobacco stocks, an idea that he said has ''incredible appeal.''

title: Pier 1 Finds Success Beyond Brass
description: The recent push by Pier 1 Imports Inc. into Manhattan caps a four-year overhaul that has transformed the company from a retailer of inexpensive imported goods into one selling moderately priced home furnishings for successful young professionals.

title: As Farm Meets Suburb, Sides Clash
description: Among the defendants who will appear in Cook County Criminal Court on Monday to answer charges of rape, theft, drunken driving and other crimes against society will be Ray Dettmering, a young farmer.

title: News Summary
description: International#2-5

title: Review/Theater;   Artists' Home of Legend
description: People come and people go, but most of all, people stay. This is the Chelsea Hotel, the legendary West Side home of writers and artists, a building fallen from its former glory and surviving in memories conjured up by newer, younger residents and by the few who have been left in place. The play, Nicole Burdette's ''Chelsea Walls,'' at the Naked Angels theater, is filled with energy and theatrical imagination.

title: The Russian Question
description: Another period of sudden, dramatic change is beginning in Europe, or rather the implications of last year's upheavals are spreading even before they have been absorbed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: About 100,000 people sat down to play bridge last night, not a very unusual occurrence except that they were all dealt the same hand and they were all on top of things, like the Eiffel Tower and the Empire State Building and other towers in 90 countries. The hand was predetermined in Paris by the actor OMAR SHARIF, a top-ranked player.

title: New Disputes Threaten Pact on U.S.-Japan Trade
description: Negotiations between Japan and the United States to conclude a major trade agreement before an economic summit meeting in Houston next month may be derailed by a struggle within the Japanese Government and resistance to American demands for more specific commitments, people on both sides of the talks said today.

title: Taxi Commissioner Ignores Livery Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the likelihood of new appointments to the New York City Board of Education misidentified a current member, Dr. Gwendolyn C. Baker. She is national executive director of the Y.W.C.A. of the U.S.A.

title: Krzyzewski Stays
description: After a week of talks with top officials of the Boston Celtics, Mike Krzyzewski announced yesterday he had turned down an offer to coach the Celtics and would continue, as he has for the last 10 years, to coach Duke University.

title: Rep. Studds Is Beaten on Washington Street
description: Representative Gerry E. Studds was beaten by two teen-agers on a street corner here Thursday night, his office said today.

title: KEY RATES
'She Took the Lonely Cause of Equality'
description: LEAD: They buried Cecil Roberts, 76, last week in Birmingham, Ala., as she had wished, in her bright red pajamas. On the lapel were the words every Southerner calls a real Democrat: ''Yellow Dog.''

title: On Big Bang, Einstein Outranks Aristotle
description: To the Editor:

title: Peoria Unites to Aid One of Town's Own, Hostage in a Jungle
description: After Scott Heimdal, an American who was working at a mining company in Northern Ecuador, was abducted in that country April 28 and taken to Colombia by Colombian guerrillas, his captors demanded $1.2 million ransom.

title: Doctors Describe New Blood Substitute Test
description: Guatemalan and American researchers announced yesterday that they had completed the first human safety trials of a new blood substitute, devised from an extract of cow's blood.

title: Affirmative Action Bears Great Moral Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonald's Plans Nutrition Data
description: The McDonald's Corporation said it would post complete nutritional information - including fat and sodium levels -on all of its products at its restaurants by the end of July. McDonald's drew fire this spring from Phil Sokolof, an anti-cholesterol crusader from Omaha, who took out full-page ads in newspapers across the country pleading with McDonald's to cut the fat in its hamburgers.

title: Killer Cross-Examines the Widow Suing Him in Her Spouse's Death
description: Jack Henry Abbott introduced himself in court yesterday to the widow of the man he stabbed to death nine years ago and then asked her:

title: NUCLEAR MISSILES ON SOME BOMBERS TO BE WITHDRAWN CONCERN ON SAFETY CITED
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney today ordered the Air Force to remove hundreds of short-range nuclear attack missiles from bombers in 10 states until safety studies are completed.

title: Michael Raffetto, Radio Actor, 91
description: Michael Raffetto, a radio actor who played Paul Barbour, the eldest son on ''One Man's Family,'' during the 1930's and 40's, died on May 31. He was 91 years old.

title: Electricity Price Plan Is Backed
description: A New York State court, in a decision disclosed yesterday, upheld the authority of the Public Service Commission to price electricity based on power saved, rather than power used. The approach is an attempt by regulators to reduce air pollution and cut power costs.

title: Two Military Contractors Plan Layoffs
description: Texas Instruments Inc. and the General Dynamics Corporation, a pair of leading military contractors, plan to lay off at least 1,500 in Texas because of expected military budget cutbacks.

title: A Livery Driver Is Shot to Death On Bronx Street
description: A 35-year-old Bronx livery-cab driver was shot in the head and killed yesterday, apparently for his wallet, the police said, and a man described as a frequent customer of the cab company was later charged with the crime.

title: Thomas Sheridan, 60, Robert Kennedy Aide
description: Thomas R. Sheridan, a trial lawyer who was a special assistant to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy in the 1960's, died of a heart attack on Thursday at St. Vincent's Medical Center. He was 60 years old.

title: Beliefs
description: Not long after his cause emerged victorious in Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel went to the Manhattan residence of John Cardinal O'Connor to receive an award from the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a group concerned with religious freedom. While Mr. Havel met there privately with a number of New York's religious leaders, reporters milled about outside, trying to scrape together whatever they knew about Mr. Havel's religious beliefs.

title: Dow Falls by 34.95 in Fourth Straight Loss
description: The slide in stock prices extended to a fourth day yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply, dropping 34.95 points, to 2,862.38. The blue-chip index is now down by 72.81 from its historic high on Monday and off 38.69 from last Friday's close.

title: Two Warring Shiite Factions In Lebanon Meet on Conflict
description: Representatives of Lebanon's rival Muslim factions held their first face-to-face peace talks in 16 months today, and said they were discussing ways to end three years of conflict for leadership of the Shiites.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Some Other Big Upsets
description: Cameroon's victory over Argentina, the defending champion, in the opening game of the World Cup today put the African nation in the same giant-killing club as the United States, North Korea and Algeria.

title: Graf and Seles Rematch
description: In a rematch of the German Open final that Monica Seles won last month, top-seeded Steffi Graf will be matched against the 16-year-old from Yugoslavia in the French Open women's singles final Saturday.

title: Evolution in Europe;   NATO Overture to a Rival
description: One day after the Warsaw Pact announced that it no longer viewed NATO as an enemy, NATO agreed to extend an olive branch to the Soviet bloc, saying that it wanted to join with it in a partnership that would insure that the Soviet Union and its allies would not be isolated in Europe.

title: Cable Bill Faces Hurdles, Despite Panel Approval
description: The likelihood that the cable television industry will undergo some form of re-regulation gained momentum this week as the Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill that would let the Federal Communications Commission set guidelines on the fees cable subscribers pay to receive broadcast and public access channels.

title: In Rap Group's Album, Graphic Sexual Lyrics
description: The rap album ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' by 2 Live Crew, is a record loaded with graphic descriptions of sex, genitals and sodomy. Using a variety of rhythms, including reggae, house music, hip hop and rock, members of the group revel in the sort of creative obscenity heard in locker rooms, telling stories about sexual encounters with women and giving descriptions.

title: Alfredo Poveda, 64; Led Junta in Ecuador
description: The last military dictator of Ecuador, Adm. Alfredo Poveda Burbano, died of a heart attack on Thursday in Miami, relatives in Quito said today. He was 64 years old. Family members said Admiral Poveda died at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami, where he had gone for treatment. His remains are to be returned to Ecuador for burial, the family said.

title: Milton J. E. Senn, 88, Pioneer in Child Psychiatry
description: Dr. Milton J. E. Senn, a pioneering expert in child psychiatry, died of bladder cancer yesterday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: Ms. Rosenbloom, Lawyer, Married
description: Beth A. Rosenbloom and James S. Sigler were married last evening at their home in Watertown, Mass., by Rabbi Albert S. Goldstein.

title: Delta Air Seeks Hong Kong Link
description: Delta Air Lines said it had asked the United States Department of Transportation to designate the airline to serve Hong Kong,. Delta said it would inaugurate service to Hong Kong no later than six months after Hong Kong and British authorities granted Delta the necessary operating permit.

title: Goodwill Team Named
description: The Athletics Congress announced yesterday its selections for the United States men's marathon team that will compete in the Goodwill Games in Seattle, July 20 through Aug. 5. Chosen on the basis of performances turned in between Sept. 30, 1989, and March 18, 1990, were Budd Coates, Jerry Marsh and Mike Keohane.(AP)

title: Old-Time Magic Makes Appearance for Mets
description: For one evening at least, the Mets found the old-time formula and found that it still works.

title: 14 Paintings Found 2 Years After Theft On Upper East Side
description: Acting on a tip from an informant, the police have recovered 14 of 19 paintings stolen from an art gallery on the Upper East Side more than two years ago.

title:
Books of The Times;

Charges of Bungling Before Airline Bombing
description: LEAD:

title: Premark-Sike Tie
description: Premark International Inc., a maker of consumer and restaurant products, said it had completed its $201 million offer for the Sikes Corporation, a maker of ceramic tile. Premark said it had purchased 10.3 million class A shares of Sikes under its tender offer of $16.40 a share, which expired on Thursday, and it had also bought all class B Sikes shares.

title: No Use of Suicide Device
description: A judge ordered Dr. Jack Kevorkian today to stop using his suicide device until prosecutors decide whether to charge him for letting an Alzheimer's patient kill herself with it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What were these people thinking when they moved to the country? It's not like these farms snuck up on them.'' - Ray Dettmering, an Illinois farmer, responding to neighbors complaining about his plowing at night. [6:1.]

title: Questions Outpace Contenders
description: Can Unbridled win the Belmont Stakes without Lasix? And what will be proved if he does?

title: Nick Kerbawy, Sports Executive, 77
description: Nick Kerbawy, a former general manager of the Detroit Lions and the Detroit Pistons, died of cancer Thursday. He was 77 years old.

title: Report Warns of Decline Of U.S. Electronics Industry
description: In a study that could cause the White House some discomfort, the Commerce Department warned today that the $200 billion-a-year American electronics industry, long considered a bellwether of the country's competitiveness, is losing its edge in the world market and may be eclipsed in this decade by Japan and newly emerging producers like South Korea.

title: Pistons Put the Game on the Line
description: It's a cardinal rule in basketball that when the game is on the line you don't put your opponent there.

title: Review/Ballet;   Robbin's-Eye View of Bach And Astaire
description: A Festival of Jerome Robbins's Ballets is the descriptive name the New York City Ballet has given its panorama of choreography by a longtime resident genius, and the two-week event, initially, seemed as subdued as it title.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Last Hugo Aid Office Closes
description: Nearly nine months after Hurricane Hugo pounded South Carolina, the Federal Emergency Management Agency shut down its last disaster field office today. The office, in North Charleston, was opened two days after the storm smashed ashore Sept. 21, causing an estimated $5.9 billion damage and claiming 29 lives in the state. In all, the agency and the Small Business Administration have spent $675 million helping South Carolina recover from the storm.

title: An Executive Spin on Eastern's Pitch
description: What Lee A. Iacocca did for the Chrysler Corporation in the 1980's, Martin R. Shugrue hopes to do for Eastern Airlines in the 1990's. The court-appointed trustee, nervous and clutching two packs of Camels, began taping television commercials here this week in an effort to convince the public that his company deserves another chance.

title: The Stuff Of Legends: Stan, Ted
description: Not long ago, Ted Williams was invited to stop by tonight's dinner celebrating Stan Musial's induction into the Brooklyn Dodger Hall of Fame.

title: Lynn R. Callin, Physician, 82
description: Dr. Lynn R. Callin, a physician, died of complications of open heart surgery yesterday at the Southwest Regional Medical Center in Fort Meyers, Fla. He was 82 years old and had moved to Fort Meyers from Rochester in 1982.

title: A Chapel in Florence Reveals Its Wonders Anew
description: When a promising artist named Michelangelo was studying the human form, he came here to the Brancacci Chapel to sketch frescoes that had been put there decades earlier by one of the first geniuses of the Renaissance, Masaccio.

title: Evolution in Europe: East Berlin Journal;   A First U.S. Visit, and Maybe a Last
description: For Lothar de Maiziere, the idea that he is about to be the first East German leader to visit the United States is not really that extraordinary.

title: Recording Ruled Obscene Brings Arrest
description: Armed with a Federal judge's finding that the lyrics of a best-selling rap music record are obscene, the authorities today arrested a record store owner who had continued to sell the album.

title: Florio's Puzzling 'Vision' for New Jersey
description: When you put together a puzzle, no one piece gives you the whole picture. But piece by piece the puzzle becomes clearer, until the picture is complete.

title: Inside
description: 14 Stolen Paintings Found

title: Jerome Metzner, 79, A Professor of Biology
description: Jerome Metzner, who taught biology in New York City for more than 30 years, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Lido Beach, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: Up, and Down, With Donald Trump
description: What's the right word, arrogance or audacity?

title: Corrections
description: A map of Czechoslovakia yesterday, with a chart about elections there, reversed two regional labels.

title: Patents;   Lasers Used In Reversing Gum Disease
description: An ophthalmic surgeon in New York City who is a leading authority on the use of lasers in eye surgery, obtained a patent this week on a method for using low-powered lasers to reverse gum disease.

title: A New Yorker Seeks a Consensus on a National Black Museum
description: Dozens of letters have arrived at the Smithsonian Institution in the last few months for Claudine Brown.

title: SHAMIR ANNOUNCES A NEW GOVERNMENT OF THE RIGHT WING
description: With his final deadline only hours away, Acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir announced tonight that he had succeeded in forming a new Government, the most conservative ever in Israel.

title: Carters Guilty In Using a Dump On Staten Island
description: Two owners of waste companies were convicted yesterday of illegally dumping thousands of tons of medical waste, asbestos and other hazardous materials at a landfill in Port Ivory, S.I.

title: 49ers, er, Giants Rout Falcons, er, Braves, 23-8
description: The rookie Rich Parker drove in seven runs and Will Clark hit two three-run homers as the San Francisco Giants set team records for runs and hits tonight in a 23-8 rout of the Atlanta Braves.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Britain Blocks European Move on Pollution
description: Britain and three other countries blocked moves by the European Community today to set the year 2000 as a deadline for stabilizing carbon-dioxide emissions, which are thought to be contributing to the earth's warming.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ex-Sergeant Charged With Role In Selling Secrets to Warsaw Pact
description: The Government charged in Federal court in Tampa, Fla., today that a former Army sergeant was part of a spy ring that provided valuable military secrets to Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union for which he may have been paid between $2.2 million and $5 million.

title: Ethnic Slayings Are Reported in Liberia
description: Hundreds of Liberians are believed to have been killed in recent days in a surge of ethnic-related violence, Western diplomats and witnesses say.

title: Jose Figueres Ferrer Is Dead at 83; Led Costa Ricans to Democracy
description: Jose Figueres Ferrer, the Costa Rican leader who helped install democracy in his homeland in 1948 and was President three times, died yesterday of a heart attack, his physician said. He was 83 years old and lived in San Jose, the capital.

title: Medtronic to Join With Bio-Medicus
description: Medtronic Inc. and Bio-Medicus Inc. agreed to merge in a transaction that would swap 3.1 shares of Bio-Medicus's common stock for each share of Metronic stock. The agreement calls for Medtronic stock to be priced between $77.50 and $92 a share at the time of the merger. Its shares dropped $3.375 today, to $76.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bio-Medicus rose 62.5 cents, to $23.75, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Keeping Cars Cool
description: Now that the weather is warm and getting warmer, the Automobile Club of New York, an affiliate of A.A.A., recommends having a professional check your car to prevent overheating.

title: On World Soccer Stage, a Stunning First Act
description: Amid the deafening roar of nearly 74,000 spectators, Cameroon upset the defending champion, Argentina, today in the opening match of the World Cup soccer tournament. The result was one of the most stunning in the event's 60-year history.

title: Window of Hope for New York Schools
description: Who's to blame for the failings of New York City schools? A mayoral commission points an accusing finger at the central Board of Education. Now there is a window of hope. Staten Island's Borough President, Guy Molinari, has announced his new appointee to the board, and several other appointments are expected. They can make a dramatic difference - if they recognize the need to work from a citywide perspective.

title: Burned Boy a Step Away From Home
description: David Opont, the Brooklyn boy who was set on fire three months ago after refusing what he thought was drugs, was released from a Manhattan hospital yesterday and transferred by helicopter to a clinic in Queens for extensive rehabilitation therapy.

title: Patents;   Bicycle Lock Avoids U-Shaped Vulnerability
description: Robert Denison, owner of a chain of bicycle stores in New York City, has patented a double-looped lock that he said overcomes the inherent vulnerability of U-shaped locks to being cracked by thieves.

title: Shepard Clough, 88; Professor and Writer Of European History
description: Dr. Shepard B. Clough, who retired after 42 years as a history professor at Columbia University, died on Thursday at Northeast Vermont Hospital in St. Johnsbury. He was 88 years old and lived in East Peacham, Vt. His son Peter said Dr. Clough (pronounced cluff) had died after a stroke.

title: CONSUMER WORLDS: Guidepost;   Poisonous Plants
description: It's time to beware of poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac. All three belong to the same genus of plants and have a sap that oozes oleoresin. Mere contact can cause serious dermatitis. Ortho Poison Ivy and Poison Oak Killer, available at garden centers and hardware stores, is an effective control. Nonselective herbicides get rid of poison sumac. Never burn these plants because the poison is carried by smoke and inhaling it can damage the lungs.

title: Eastern Air Recalls Pilots
description: Eastern Airlines has for the first time recalled pilots who stayed off the job until the end of the Air Line Pilots Assocation strike, the company said today.

title: Chip Maker Signs Pact With Soviets
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said it planned to make computer chips and other electronic devices for the Soviet Union in an unusual licensing agreement that will give the company Soviet chip-making technologies. Cypress signed a letter of intent with the International Center for Informatics and Electronics of Moscow.

title: Center at Tanglewood Commissions Overtures
description: Five American composers have been commissioned to write overtures for the Tanglewood Music Center's 50th anniversary this summer. The A.T. & T. Foundation has given the center $50,000 for the commissions.

title: U.S. Has Jurisdiction Over Noriega, Judge Rules
description: In a setback today for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's defense on drug-trafficking charges, a Federal district judge here rejected his challenges to American courts' jurisdiction.

title: IN MIDWEST, BUSH SELLS HIS SUMMIT
description: Sounding defensive at times and triumphant at others, President Bush has stumped the Midwest the last two days, carrying his own analysis of last week's summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev away from his critics in Washington and into what a White House aide called ''the real America.''

title: Giving Death a Hand: Rending Issue
description: The announcement by a Michigan doctor that he helped a 54-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease to kill herself this week is likely to goad many Americans into confronting and discussing an issue that has rarely seeped to the surface of public discourse: whether and when physicians should help seriously ill people take their own lives.

title: Cuomo's Real Race
description: Four years ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was swept into a second term by the biggest landslide in New York State history. He defeated his opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, by a margin of more than 2 to 1, and carried 57 of the state's 62 counties.

title: Your Money;   Burden of Loads On Mutual Funds
description: Loads, as mutual fund fees are known, are aptly named. They can certainly weigh down a fund's return to shareholders.

title: Bridge
description: At most tournaments only a minority of players are fighting for major titles. The majority are engaged in lesser events, either because they are not qualified to play in the top echelon or because they prefer a fair chance of prevailing among their peers to a poor chance of besting the experts.

title: Double-Deck the Roads At Kennedy Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: D. & H. Railway
description: A bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., has approved the purchase of the Delaware & Hudson Railway Company by CP Rail, a unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd., for $25 million. In announcing the approval, Pennsylvania's Governor, Robert Casey, said the sale would improve business at the port of Philadelphia. The deal is still subject to several conditions, including settlement of contracts with D.&H.'s unions and approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Begat by Puritanism
description: The reproductive organs, always politically troubling in America, are even more so these days. Consider the womb. Hardly a day goes by without a news story about the womb. It sometimes seems nobody in the entire country is willing to grant the womb any relief from politics.

title: Review/Music;   For Otto Luening at 90, an Evening's Choral Tribute
description: The 90th-birthday party the Goodman Chamber Choir gave for Otto Luening at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening was wonderful, once it finally got rolling. For reasons made only more obscure in prefatory remarks by the director, Andrea Goodman (something about poetry and music and American nationality), the first half of the concert consisted of works by Amy Marcy Beach and George Whitefield Chadwick.

title: Patents;   Upjohn Denies Charge Of Fraud on Minoxidil
description: An attorney representing doctors who are being sued for infringing a patent on minoxidil, the hair-growing compound, asserted this week that the Upjohn Company obtained its key patent through fraud.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Czechoslovaks Voting in Holiday Mood
description: Czechs and Slovaks cast their votes today on the opening day of the first free elections since 1946.

title: Car Leasing Gains New Popularity
description: Spurred by rising car prices and a sharp reduction in the tax deduction for interest payments, more people are leasing automobiles for long terms. Dealers, banks and leasing companies are all offering long-term contracts - and individuals are following corporations in snapping them up.

title: Failed Memories and Vanished Witness Follow Killing in a Market
description: It has been three weeks since Ernest Abdul Mateen, a father of nine from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was shot and killed in midafternoon in a crowded open-air vegetable market in Canarsie.

title: Opposites Attract: Agassi and Gomez in Final
description: There is no comparing anyone to Andre Agassi, at least not with his permission. He is very much his own invention and amalgamation, from the hairdo he kind of shares with Dweezil Zappa to the ground strokes he kind of borrowed from Zorro to the Las Vegas panache with which he punctuates every syllable and gesture.

title: A.C.L.U. and Gay Groups Vow Legal Test on Immigration Policy
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and homosexual groups said today that they would take legal action to stop Federal immigration and health officials if they try to bar self-declared homosexuals from entering the United States to attend an AIDS conference this month in San Francisco.

title: North Stars Hire Clarke As General Manager
description: Howard Baldwin always thought it would be ideal to build a team around Bobby Clarke. He also thinks Clarke is the ideal man to build a Stanley Cup team. So yesterday, Baldwin, the Minnesota North Stars' president, hired Clarke as the team's general manager.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Maybe this is what I'll give Barbara for her birthday present,'' PRESIDENT BUSH said yesterday in Des Moines as he accepted a gift box of six pork steaks from the National Pork Producers Council. BARBARA BUSH's 65th birthday yesterday was obviously on the President's mind, as he mentioned it several times during political fund-raising events in Iowa and Nebraska. But if the First Lady had a cozy family dinner in mind when the President returned last evening from his two-day trip, she would have to wait. Mr. Bush just about had time to get ready for a state dinner in the White House for Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Russian Republic Asserts Its Laws Have Primacy Over Kremlin Rule
description: The Parliament of the Russian Federation directly challenged central authority over the largest and richest Soviet republic today by asserting that Russian laws take precedence over Soviet laws.

title: CHRONICLE
description: INES DE LA FRESSANGE, who personified Chanel style as KARL LAGERFELD's top model and muse until she parted company with the designer in a public dispute last fall, is to be married today in the town hall at Tarascon, France, near Arles. The bridegroom is LUIGI D'URSO, 38 years old, who is in charge of press relations for CIT, the Italian railway company.

title: Plans and Costs Expand To Fix Subway Stations
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that it plans to greatly expand its program for modernizing dilapidated subway stations.

title: Italians Hoping For Fans' Support
description: It was the reception the Italian national team should have gotten a month ago in Florence: 5,000 fans, welcome signs, singing and chanting, flags and banners draped about the packed streets and squares of this tiny town just a half-hour outside Rome.

title: About New York;   The Doctor Is In (Row F, Seat 12); Now Sing Ahhhh!
description: In these bedraggled times, that old New York swagger has grown elusive. Yankee Stadium is just a ballpark in a bad neighborhood where a last-place team bumbles along. The British have bought Madison Avenue and the Japanese most everything else.

title: New York Agencies Push Huge Queens Development
description: In a plan that is being pressed with unusual urgency at City Hall, three public development agencies in New York City and several prominent business executives are trying to build a small new city along the East River in Queens.

title: Barbara Baxley, 63, Who Acted In Theater, Movie and TV Roles
description: Barbara Baxley, a stage, film and television actress, was found dead Thursday in her Upper West Side apartment. The medical examiner's office said the apparent cause of death was a heart attack. She was 63 years old.

title: Evolution i Europe;   Judge Rules P.L.O. Is Liable In Raid on the Achille Lauro
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Thursday that the Palestine Liberation Organization could be sued in United States courts for the October 1985 attack on the Achille Lauro, an Italian passenger liner assaulted by commandos in the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Youth Hijacks Soviet Airliner To Sweden, Then Surrenders
description: A Soviet airliner with 121 people aboard was hijacked by a teen-ager carrying a fake grenade and was forced to land at an airport north of here early today, the police said.

title: Titan 4 Launches Secret Military Payload
description: A Titan 4, the nation's largest rocket, was launched here early today with a secret military payload.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Uzbek Leader Pleads for Moscow's Aid on Unrest
description: The President of Soviet Uzbekistan said today that ethnic violence was spreading to his republic from neighboring Kirghizia and he asked Moscow to help stop skirmishes from degenerating into full-scale conflict in Central Asia.

title: Gloomy Report on the Health of Teen-Agers
description: America's teen-agers are plagued with an array of physical and emotional health problems that make them less healthy than their parents were at the same age, a national commission said today.

title: With Air-Conditioners
description: When temperatures push past 90 and stay there, air-conditioning is often the only relief. But while you cool off, your neighbors may be hot under the collar about the noise your air-conditioner is generating.

title: Ads That Misguide Consumers on AIDS Are to Be Prohibited
description: New York City will ban advertisements that misleadingly imply that nutrients and vitamins sold as immune boosters can prevent or cure AIDS, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Western Union Stock-Sale Step
description: The ITT Corporation and a group of 31 banks have registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 22 million common shares of the Western Union Corporation.

title: State Dept.'s Excellent Information Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Needed: A Tough Exec for Two States
description: Running the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is one of the most challenging executive jobs in government. The Port Authority's operations are vast and so is its impact on the region's economy. It oversees airports, commuter rail systems, bus terminals and bridges; runs container ports and the World Trade Center, and deals with airline executives and commuters. It pays for all its own operations.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Upper Columbus Avenue Street Fair, Columbus Avenue will be closed today from 86th to 96th Streets from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Affirmative Action Bears Great Moral Costs;   One Standard for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote Backs Bid For Genentech
description: Shareholders of Genentech Inc. approved a plan today for Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, to pay $2.1 billion for a controlling stake in the largest United States biotechnology company.

title: New Kidney for Easley
description: Kenny Easley, the former Seattle Seahawk safety, was in good condition yesterday after receiving a new kidney at the University of Washington Medical Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Wednesday about primary elections around the country misstated the number of blacks who have served in the United States Senate. There have been three, all Republicans; the article omitted Blanche Kelso Bruce, a Reconstruction-era Senator from Mississippi who served from 1875 to 1881. The article also misidentified one Senator; he was Hiram Rhodes Revels, who represented Mississippi in 1870 and 1871. It also misstated the length of service of the third, Edward W. Brooke. He represented Massachusetts from 1967 to 1979, not 1969 to 1979. c

title: Review/Music;   Jose Carreras At Carnegie, For a Cause
description: A year ago, the Spanish tenor Jose Carreras returned to the American recital stage after an apparently successful battle with leukemia, and it was on behalf of the Jose Carreras Foundation Against Leukemia that he sang a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

title: India Rejects Talks With Pakistan Over Kashmir
description: India today rejected a suggestion from Pakistan that talks be held this month between high Foreign Ministry officials, ending a week of speculation that there is some immediate hope of reducing tension over the issue of Kashmir.

title: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Bonds Ease
description: Prices of long-term Government securities eased yesterday, but the market in shorter Treasury maturities was essentially unchanged in unusually lackluster trading. One reason was the absence of any significant economic news.

title: Review/Music;   Julia Fordham's Reflections About Love and Pain, Etc.
description: Among the dozens of performers who have been inspired by Joni Mitchell's confessional albums of the 1970's, Julia Fordham comes closest to capturing some of the stream-of-consciousness immediacy conveyed by Ms. Mitchell's finest records.

title: WHERE WALL STREET MEETS POLICE BEAT
description: We put our money on the line every day, but the police put their lives on the line every day,'' says Albert Fried Jr., the managing partner of Albert Fried & Company, a Wall Street investment bank. Fried is the chairman of The Centurion Foundation, established in 1986 primarily to support New York City's men and women in blue.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: Americans are frustrated by the fact that there is little scoring in the game, and fans cannot appreciate a 1-0 strategic, defensive match (unless they're chess aficionados). It is worse than college basketball before the shot clock.

title: Bridget Venus Weds
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Bridget A. Venus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael T. Venus of Sparta, N.J., was married yesterday to Henry M. Bonner Jr., a son of Mr. Bonner of Southport, Conn., and the late Anne C. B. Bonner. The Rev. John G. Hartnett officiated. The bride, 26 years old, will keep her name. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, she is an account executive at the Grace & Rothschild advertising agency in New York. The bridegroom, 26, a law student at the University of Connecticut, is a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Wesleyan University.

title: There's More to Bohemian Music Than Dvorak
description: Mention Czechoslovak music to the average American concertgoer, and the immediate association no doubt will be Dvorak's lilting strains. A few may remember Smetana's ''Moldau,'' and even fewer Janacek's name.

title: Burlington, Vt.;   Old Doctrine Finds New Use
description: An Ancient but seldom-used legal concept that Vermont courts cited to squelch a railroad's waterfront development proposal has started to come into more general use as an anti-development tactic.

title: Less Maple Syrup Produced In New York State This Year
description: Warm weather in March led to a 23 percent drop in maple syrup production in New York this year, despite an increase in the number of maple-syrup farmers, the State Agricultural Statistics Service said this week.

title: Hearings Near, Durenberger Stumps
description: As he kissed babies, glad-handed passengers and chatted up the crew aboard Northwest Airlines Flight 323 from Washington Friday night, Dave Durenberger acted as if he were still the most popular politician in Minnesota, not a man struggling to salvage his personal reputation and his seat in the United States Senate.

title: Animals in Distress on Rise As Habitats Fall to Developers
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH development on Long Island throughout the 1980's provided many homes for humans, the winged and four-legged inhabitants of the woods and wetlands have not fared as well.

title: Mets Defeat Pirates On Way to Revival
description: The Mets took another step on the road to respectability last night when they subdued the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates for the second successive time, and they did it with more of the old-time virtues of no-nonsense pitching and power.

title: In a West Bank Town, a Quiet Dialogue Between Settlers and Palestinians
description: At 2,700 feet this Jewish settlement stands aloft, unique not only for its red-tiled townhouses and green lawns, but mostly because its inhabitants initiated talks with the Palestinians of the cheerless Arab villages and towns whose vineyards come right up to the settlement's fences.

title: They're Just Wild About Trail Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Books On the Block
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Limbocker Wed in Newport
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Hilary duPont Limbocker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Derek L. Limbocker of New York, and Anthony Dick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Lorne Coyle performed the ceremony.

title: For Overloaded Eyes and Ears, Bite Makes Right Bite Makes Right
description: A FRIEND OF MINE LIVED FOR years without television, virtually uncorrupted by knowledge of either its technology or its products. But he was no fool when ABC's ''Nightline'' summoned him to tape an interview not long ago; he prepared several convincing sound bites, the standard verbal unit of the electronic media. Two of his carefully sharpened sound bites made it onto the air, whereupon his mother phoned to tell him, ''You looked wonderful, dear, but you didn't really say anything, did you?'' ''Of course not,'' he replied. ''That wasn't the point.'' The point, perhaps, is that in America today, bite makes right. If it sounds like a ''sound bite,'' the ideally compact and colorful remarks by ''talking heads,'' for which television journalists strive tirelessly and around which news pieces are usually constructed, then it must be meaningful (except, naturally, to vigilant relatives). The term has entered the general language with a vengeance, where it lends comments about the media a casual knowingness. Another friend, normally a stranger to television shoptalk, surprised me by saying, as we watched a Government official on a recent network news piece, ''That was a good bite.'' But he was only illustrating the widespread mounting reverence for short form over substance.

title: Ashley Richards Wed in Virginia
description: Ashley Louise Richards, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wayne Richards of Albany, Ga., was married yesterday to Jonathan Thomas More Reckford, a son of Kenneth J.
