Reckford of Chapel Hill, N.C., and the late Mary Stevens Reckford. The Rev. John D. Burley, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Falls Church in Falls Church, Va., assisted by the Rev. James C. Peterson, a Baptist minister.

title: The Long Campaign for a Perfect Prom
description: Esther Truzman, the class secretary, fiddled with her notes and spoke up: ''The club has to be a nice space. A lot of clubs, you walk in and they're so blah. Hot Rod last year was nice, but the music wasn't so hot.''

title: Marie Whelan and Patrick Dolan Wed
description: The marriage of Marie Dignam Whelan and Patrick Daniel Dolan took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford Village, N.Y. The Rev. Martin A. Dolan, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Swedish Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless in America
description: One of the most incongruous snapshots of America's homeless men and women can be taken daily at about 4:30 in the afternoon on one of the two large lawns that flank the entrance to City Hall on Main Street in Santa Monica, Calif. The neatly trimmed grass, the blue canopy and Art Deco mosaic tiles over the front doors of the white, two-story building just two blocks from the serene Pacific, is an odd setting for a soup kitchen. Private volunteers of Family Assistance Involving the Homeless, or Faith, serve 250 or 300 people a hot supper and dessert. Several park rangers stand around in case of trouble, but on this sunny, cool afternoon the line moves quietly along the perimeter of bright green grass toward the tables of food. Wearing down jackets and windbreakers (one or two men are in suits) and carrying knapsacks, duffel bags or black plastic garbage bags, the homeless seem mostly in their 20's or 30's; some are black, some white; men far outnumber women. A middle-aged street woman dressed in layers of clothing feeds her toy poodle vegetables with a teaspoon; its doghouse is a mobile home - a carton wedged at the front of a shopping cart piled high with possessions.

title: Leslie Troy Wed To Walter Tsui
description: Leslie B. Troy, the daughter of Joan B. Troy and Michael C. Troy, both of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday in Durham, N.C., to Walter W. Tsui, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tsui of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Hong Kong. The Rev. Charles T. Midyette 3d officiated at St. Philip's Episcopal Church.

title: The Beltway and the Globe
description: Now that Communism is in retreat, need Americans care all that much about NATO or the messy third world? Not really, argues Irving Kristol, a panjandrum of neo-conservatism, in The Wall Street Journal. He is saddened, for example, by turmoil in Liberia but sees no reason why it ''should even be within the purview of American foreign policy - or why The Times should be devoting so much space to it.'' High time, he says briskly, to devote more attention to national interests.

title: In The Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Millburn $160,000

title: Fare of the Country;   Fresh From Ohio's Amish Ovens
description: IF not for precise directions, it would be easy to speed past the hand-lettered, wooden sign posted for Miller's Farm Bakery on U.S. 422 between the small farm communities of Welshfield and Parkman in northeastern Ohio. When heading up the dirt drive to the large white clapboard farmhouse, it would also be easy to feel a bit like an intruder, especially for an urban visitor. But all it takes is one look at Nora Miller's spread: a table filled with thick-crusted loaves of tall white bread cooling in their plastic wrappers, rounds of fat and sticky cinnamon buns and peach, apple and blackberry pies lined up in a neat row, and any awkwardness is quickly forgotten.

title:
ART;

From Exuberant Abstraction to Detailed Realism
description: LEAD: AS the sole juror of the Huntington Township Art League's 35th annual Long Island Artists Exhibition at the Heckscher Museum, the painter Nell Blaine chose from more than 750 entries.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a concrete basement floor with a one-inch trench around the perimeter. For years, this floor has had a hairline crack about five feet long that goes from one corner out toward the center. The crack has widened to about a sixteenth of an inch, and there seems to be a new hairline crack that goes about eight feet past this. The floor gets little traffic; the only thing that has changed is that an exercise machine is now in the basement. Could this have caused the added cracking?

title: WestHELP Wins Approval For Sites in White Plains
description: THE Board of Legislators reached a milestone last week as it approved the last of the three Westhelp housing projects that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke had hoped would serve as a catalyst for community assistance to the homeless.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a typographical error, an article on April 29 about Mozart in Vienna misstated his age at the time he was ordered kicked down the stairs at 7 Singer Strasse. As a reader has recently written to point out, he was 25, not 15.

title: COMPANY SHOWS FACE THE MUSIC
description: The hand-lettered sign on the door of a nondescript office in downtown San Francisco read, ''Please Wait Til Called.'' A dozen bankers stood nervously in line outside the door, gripping their attache cases. Inside, Ellen Marshall, an assistant vice president of First Interstate Bank of California, was singing: ''Ah-mare-i-ka, Ah-mare-i-ka, God shed His . . .'' From his seat at the piano, composer-lyricist Morris Bobrow interrupted. ''Can you take it higher?'' Marshall stiffened, leaned back and let fly in a voice reminiscent of Ethel Merman with just a hint of Patti LuPone: ''. . . grace on theeeee.''

title: Susan I. Jacobson to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Simon Jacobson of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced 1991 wedding plans for their daughter, Susan I. Jacobson, and Dr. Edward D. Fein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Fein of Brooklyn. Miss Jacobson, 24 years old, graduated from Washington University and is studying for an M.B.A. at New York University. Her fiance, 26, is a resident internist at Mount Sinai Hospital. He is a graduate of Brandeis University and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

When a Child Walks Away
description: LEAD: MY face has never appeared as a lost child on a milk carton to be casually scrutinized over corn flakes, but it easily could have if what I did when I was a little girl growing up in the 1930's had been done in these less gentle times. In fact both of our faces - mine and my best friend in those days, Eric McDougall, who was as attractive as Etan

title: HIS TURN: WHITE HOUSE SPOUSE TELLS ALL
description: FIRST HUBBY

title: Second Honeymoon in Niagara Falls
description: WHEN my wife and I got married, we had only the briefest of honeymoons - just a couple of days in a small, rundown Fire Island cottage lent to us by a friend who had rented it for the season. So it was with a sense of happy surprise that on our 24th wedding anniversary we found ourselves driving past Niagara Falls en route to visit my wife's brother in Toronto.

title: Firsthand Look At Sore Arms
description: To the Sports Editor: rrMalcom Moran's ''The Tender Years and Sore Arms'' (The New York Times, May 27), was so on target. Never have I seen a group of men do more harm to the game of baseball than overambitious high school coaches intent on winning at any cost.

title: Emigre Dreams of Dachas in America
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH his portfolio is filled with photographs of the hotels, hospitals and apartment complexes that he designed as an architect in the Soviet Union, Arkady Dreyser says he is content for the time being with the modest painting contracts and home-remodeling projects that are keeping his family afloat while they adapt to their new life in Stamford.

title: Corrections
description: The festival listings in the Summer Arts supplement of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday misstated the information telephone number for the New York City Opera. The correct number is (212) 870-5570.

title: Biddle Duke to Wed Idoline Scheerer
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Scheerer 2d of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Idoline A. Scheerer to A. Biddle Duke Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke of New York and Southampton, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Elderly Volunteer for Latchkey Plan
description: LEAD: CHILDREN in an after-school latchkey program here are getting lots of hugs and patient listening from elderly volunteers. Some even compete on the basketball court with a 72-year-old grandmother, who can toss some mean shots.

title: Schools Try 'Heart-Healthy' Meals
description: LEAD: PUTTING foods together in the right combination can mean a ''heart-healthy'' meal, the American Heart Association says. And to prove its point, the association has come up with the Winning Combination meal.

title: Iron Mike or Straw Mike? Tyson Is Replying
description: The lingering image of Mike Tyson is of a fighter, once regarded as invincible, on his knees groping almost comically for a displaced mouthpiece that is about to become secondary to the imminent loss of his heavyweight title.

title: THE MOVIE'S CREATORS USED THE STRIP TO TEASE
description: Where do people dress in orange hats, green shirts, red pants and blue coats? In the comic strips; and now, thanks to ''Dick Tracy,'' in the movies. Not only are the film's characters and story line drawn from Chester Gould's original cartoons, but its look is, too. The reason is simple: ''I wanted to be 7 years old again,'' says Warren Beatty, the film's producer, director and leading man.

title: Ruth Redmond Wed To William D. Bloom
description: Ruth E. Redmond, a daughter of Claire Driver Redmond of West Orange, N.J., and John R. Redmond of Convent Station, N.J., was married last evening to William D. Bloom, a son of Charles Bloom of West Orange, and the late Marie Bloom. The Rev. Thomas Setzer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J.

title: Review/Music;   Opera Francais Company Presents a Cherubini Rarity
description: The fledging Opera Francais de New York made its leap into orchestrally accompanied, fully staged productions Friday night at Florence Gould Hall, with generally auspicious results. Certainly the chosen vehicle, ''Les Deux Journees'' of Luigi Cherubini, was well worth encountering.

title: Blaine Hammer Wed To Allen T. Levenson
description: Blaine A. Hammer, a daughter of Martin L. Hammer of New York and Ronnie S. Hammer of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Allen T. Levenson, a son of Paul H. Levenson of Framingham, Mass., and the late Rose H. Levenson. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated at Temple Israel in Westport.

title: Andrea Kaplan Plans Wedding
description: Andrea Robin Kaplan and Andrew Robert Peikon plan to marry in September. Ms. Kaplan is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kaplan of Lawrence, L.I. Her fiance is a son of June Peikon Sturz of Bayonne, N.J., and the late Isaac Peikon.

title: October Wedding For Mimi Fisher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Fisher 3d of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have made known the October wedding plans for their daughter Mary Florence Fisher and John Francis Hickey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hickey of Denver.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The most enduring international postal system is celebrating the 500th anniversary of its founding. Known to collectors as Thurn und Taxis, it was founded in 1490 by Franz von Taxis, ruler of a Germanic duchy who traced his roots to northern Italy. The royal house that ran the system survives, but the service ended more than a century ago.

title: A SHOT IN THE DARK
description: A DEED OF DEATH

title: Grand Opera In a Colorado
description: AFTER Central City, Colo., completes its festival in honor of Lou Bunch, the ebullient madam who catered to the tastes of miners in the late part of the last century and into the early part of this one, , the city mothers light up their Victorian opera house and let the music of Mozart, Verdi and Copland prevail.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on May 13 about a New Orleans guide for wheelchair users, called ''Rollin' by the River,'' misstated its availability. It is $1 at the office of the Advocacy Center for the Elderly and Disabled (210 O'Keefe Avenue, New Orleans, La. 70112) or $2.25 by mail; it is not free.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: COMPANIES

title: Correction
description: A report in the Headliners column last week about Davey Johnson and the New York Mets misstated the day on which Bud Harrelson took over as manager. It was Tuesday, May 29, the day Mr. Johnson was dismissed.

title: Turning Short-Lived Fads Into Steady Growth
description: Strolling into his debut fashion show in 1987, Rick Fayer had little more than an idea for a new pair of pants. He was a fashion designer with no name recognition, no track record and not even enough money for a display booth.

title: A FATHER'S PAWN
description: I was very hurt to see Fred Waitzkin's article ''A Father's Pawn'' (May 13). The negative publicity that it has given my son, Gata, will add yet another obstacle to his difficult way to success in the chess world. That way is already blocked by envy on the part of many American and Soviet emigre chess players who resent the competition from Gata.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

New Uses and Tenants for Old Buildings
description: LEAD: IN today's tough real estate market, commercial developers and building owners are having to find new uses for old properties, which often means converting them.

title: With Southern Baptists Gathering, Dissension Arrives From the North
description: The pastor of Bergen Baptist Church here is opposed to abortion, believes that the Bible is the infallible word of God and each Sunday invites visitors to step forward and ''give your life to Christ'' while the congregation sings ''Amazing Grace.''

title: Why Gorbachev Frets;   In Europe, Peace Comes easier Than Peace of Mind
description: IN separate meetings over the last week, NATO and the Warsaw Pact each agreed that it had met the enemy, and found that he no longer existed. But how to replace the balance of terror that kept Europe at peace, if divided, for four decades now that the cold war has been declared over - or at least ending - is not as easy as it sounds: Alliances usually need enemies.

title: Arts Festival Will Offer 98 Events
description: LEAD: RUTGERS SUMMERFEST, which started four years ago as an experimental summer arts festival but succeeded beyond all expectations, will return in an expanded format this season, with 98 events from this month through August. Having educational and performance components, the festival includes music, dance, theater, visual arts and film.

title: BARBARELLA'S PROGRESS
description: CITIZEN JANE

title: SOME CUSTOMERS ARE ALWAYS WRONG
description: At first glance, it was a scene to gladden a retailer's heart. In the men's department of a Dayton Hudson store in a suburb of Minneapolis, a well-dressed, 20-year-old man strolled toward the register, bearing four Ralph Lauren shirts and a sweater. But with $500 worth of merchandise on the counter in front of him, the sales clerk rang up only two of the shirts, for a total of $159. No money changed hands. The clerk simply bagged all the shirts and the sweater and handed them to the customer, who quickly headed for the exit.

title: When You're Older and Out of Work
description: THERE is a dark side to capitalism. Take the experiences of the 20 educated, skilled, out-of-work executives who recently participated in a job-search workshop program in an effort to find jobs.

title: Miss McMullen Becomes a Bride
description: Caroline Lovell McMullen, the daughter of Mrs. David Rule Pyott of Alexandria, Va., and the late Richard Park McMullen, was married in Alexandria yesterday to David Van Scoyoc Hemphill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James T. Hemphill of Johnstown, Pa. The Rev. Mark Anschutz officiated at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Edward Campbell 4th, Entertainer, 33
description: Edward Campbell 4th, an actor and dancer who made his Broadway debut in the musical ''Black and Blue'' and performed in it until last April when illness forced him to retire, died of AIDS on Friday in a private hospice in Los Angeles. He was 33 years old.

title: Social Events
description: Party at the Seaport

title: Election Buoys Bulgaria's Ethnic Turks
description: After decades of harassment and an official campaign of forced cultural assimilation, Bulgaria's ethnic Turkish minority appears set to re-emerge from this country's political underground in Sunday's multiparty election.

title: A Conflict Develops Over a Musical
description: NOBODY made a fuss over ''The Rothschilds,'' the musical, when it opened on Broadway in October 1970. But now that the show has been having two coincidental productions - one at the Forum Theater Group in Metuchen, the other off Broadway at the Circle in the Square - the artistic director of the Forum, who believes that theaters should share and share alike, is fretting over being forbidden to extend the musical's engagement beyond tonight's performance.

title: AN INTRIGUING NETWORK FOR THE PROXY WARS
description: Near the end of UAL's melancholy annual meeting in Chicago on April 26, an elderly gentleman requested the microphone. What had been done, he asked, to persuade ''Mr. Coniston'' to increase his offer to buy the airline at $203 a share?

title: Missing the Issues In Child Custody
description: The headline ''Who Gets the Children? There's No Easy Answer'' for Janice Cohn's and Gary Skoloff's article on custody of children in divorce (Opinion page, April 29) tells legions about the key problem. The authors' language ''gets'' hints of property rights, and it is in this mentality that the Legislature, driven by the matrimonial attorney lobby, seeks to perpetuate the problem.

title: First Steps Toward Cleanup Are Offering Hope On Sound's Future
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, when Terry Backer was earning his living fishing out of Norwalk Harbor, he often saw raw sewage in the water there and in other ports along Long Island Sound. In the wake of repeated sewage spills, the state was closing offshore shellfish beds with growing frequency. Around the same time, Mr.

title: THE LOVE SLAVE
description: GALLOWGLASS

title:
COOKING;

GOOD EATS, BAD FOLKS
description: LEAD:

title: Susan Carpenter Weds Mark Hill
description: Susan E. Carpenter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund M. Carpenter of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark R. Hill, a son of Patricia A. Hill of Waukegan, Ill., and Joe R. Hill of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop officiated at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: 'NEVER FORGET THAT YOU HAVE SEEN HIM'
description: LEAD: LAWRENCE OF ARABIA

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: Yes. Just look at the increase in soccer clinics, soccer camps, the number of young participants in leagues both in summer and fall, and the number of periodicals devoted exclusively to soccer. The recent exhibition game by the U.S. soccer team at Yale Bowl drew over 30,000.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: And the Winner Is...

title: Campus Life: Syracuse;   Students Fight For the Right To Be the Orange
description: For 40 years Lambda Chi Alpha fraternity brothers have closely guarded the right to wear the Syracuse University mascot uniform, the Syracuse orange. But in a new agreement between the fraternity and university officials, the orange will have a new identity this fall.

title: Hilary Lea Weds Matthew Bernard
description: Hilary Martin Lea and Matthew Lionel Bernard were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. John W. Bishop. The bride is a daughter of Charles L. Lea Jr. of New York and Avice Stevens Lea of Greenwich. Mr. Bernard is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Bernard of Greenwich.

title: Rhoda Han-Pu Woo Weds
description: Rhoda Han-Pu Woo and Mark D. Wainger were married yesterday at the Sonesta Beach Hotel in Southampton, Bermuda, by the Rev. Michael Davis, an Episcopalian. The bride, 31 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Tse-Chien Woo of Pittsburgh. She graduated from Yale University and received an M.B.A. from New York University. She is the director of marketing at Global Advanced Technology, a financial research and software company in New York. Her husband, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jim Wainger of Cranford, N.J., is the co-founder and chief technical officer of the company. He graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and has a master's degree in applied science from N.Y.U.

title: Emily Lifland to Wed T. B. Michaud
description: Judge and Mrs. John C. Lifland of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Emily Jean Lifland to Thomas Beaulieu Michaud, the son of Anna G. Michaud of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Clarence L. Michaud. A September wedding is planned.

title: Will Success Spoil Moscow's Underground?
description: For nearly half a century the artists of the Moscow avant-garde lived on the fringe of society. Denied studio space, prohibited from showing their work in public and even from buying canvas, paints and brushes, the Moscow underground subsisted as something of a masonic sect, committed to the principle of free expression, and fighting to prevent the Soviet regime from implementing the same sort of centralized, monolithic control over the arts that it exercised in most other facets of Russian life.

title: C.I.A. - Costly, Inept, Anachronistic
description: Of all the rusting relics of the cold war, none lingers on with more irony, more resistance to its growing anachronism than the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: AN ABORTION BAN GAINS IN LOUISIANA
description: The Louisiana House is preparing to take up a bill that would create the strictest abortion law in the country, banning all abortions except to save the life of the woman.

title: Bryant Gumbel, Forecast for 'Today': Cloudy
description: Richard Nixon is sitting stiffly cross-legged in an interview area on the set of ''Today,'' NBC's beleaguered morning news program, his hands clasped tightly in front of him, nervously staring straight ahead. Behind the cameras, where Nixon can't see him, Bryant Gumbel, the ''Today'' anchor, is waiting for the end of the newscast being read at the anchor desk. ''I can't sit down with him yet,'' Gumbel says. ''Nixon has a terrible stage whisper.'' Sure enough, in the closing seconds of the news, as Gumbel moves to take his place next to the former President, Nixon extends a hand enthusiastically and says, loud, ''Well, how are you?''

title: UNEASY ABOUT THE GERMANS
description: As an Indian-American, born and raised in Bombay, and having lived mostly in Chicago since 1969, I cannot say that I have been directly affected by the authoritarian element in the German psyche - but I have been directly affected by its artistic, scientific and philosophical elements through the works of Luther, Beethoven, Goethe, Brahms, Wagner, Kant, Rilke, Mann and Hesse, among others.

title: Corrections
description: The Art View column in the Arts and Leisure section today, about the Venice Biennale, refers incorrectly to the artist Jenny Holzer, as did an art review on May 28. She is the first woman to be the sole participant in the United States pavilion, not the first woman represented there.

title: Arrested Retailer Plans More Sales of Album
description: A owner of a South Florida record store who was arrested on Friday for selling a rap music album that has been ruled obscene, said today that he would order a new shipment of the recording and sell it next week.

title: Jacqueline Lupichuk Weds
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in East Islip, L.I., Jacqueline M. Lupichuk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Lupichuk of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary W. Skubik, a son of Mr. and Mr. Henry Skubik of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Gennaro DiSpigno officiated. The bride, a graduate of Rutgers University and its law school, is an associate in the law firm of Richard A. Miller in Ronkonkoma, L.I. Her husband, a graduate of Dowling College, is a pilot with Continental Airlines.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Coins of the Nelson Bunker Hunt collection form a fascinating record of changes in the Roman Empire. The different silver and gold coins along with several medals document the rise and fall of emperor after emperor, their wives and favorites. In some cases the coins even depict some of the great buildings of Rome.

title: Miss Watchman Weds T. F. Burchill 4th
description: Sarah Link Watchman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Surtess Watchman Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Burchill 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burchill 3d of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. George Busler officiated, assisted by the Rev. Raymond Schroth, a Roman Catholic, at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Sepp Ruschp, 81; Skier Who Brought Sport to U.S. Is Dead
description: Sepp Ruschp, an Austrian-born skier who helped develop skiing in the United States as a recreational and competitive sport, died Friday at his home in Stowe, Vt. He was 81 years old.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Tough Review

title: Currency;   The Dollar Keeps to a Steady Course
description: The dollar was generally steady last week against both the West German mark and the Japanese yen. It closed the week at 1.6980 marks to the dollar, down slightly from the 1.7005 at which it began; it was also down slightly against the yen, ending the week at 153.50, down from 152.40 at the start. Although the dollar pushed slightly above the 1.70 marks point, the trading range was narrow and the market lacked the momentum to sustain a big advance. Currency traders said that the lack of important economic data last week and the anticipation of a slew of trade and economic figures this week caused many traders to postpone taking large positions. Concerns over German monetary union and political unrest in the Soviet Union also helped to keep trading even.

title: Exploring New Venues in Graphics
description: LEAD: DESCRIBING the contemporary printmaking scene, John Ross is brief and to the point.

title: Mamaroneck Pursues Affordable Apartments
description: LEAD: A 53-ROOM motel in Mamaroneck where the county once housed homeless families will be torn down and replaced by a low-rise complex of 55 affordable-rent apartments, under a plan approved by the Town Board.

title: Young Jazzmen Revive A Style Be-Bop Banished
description: When Be-Bop made its way onto the American scene in the 1940's, it did more than introduce a new musical and cultural language. It also banished, for nearly 40 years, a way of playing that's slowly beginning to make its way back into jazz.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Festival Beginning 61st Season
description: MUSIC MOUNTAIN, which says it is the oldest continuing summer chamber-music festival in the United States, returns for its 61st season this afternoon, in Gordon Hall, the resonant all-wood auditorium just outside Falls Village.

title: Focus: Time Shares;   Owners Call New Florida Law Unfair
description: A LAW passed by the Florida Legislature last July to eliminate abuses in the time-share resale market is coming under fire from unit-owner representatives as too restrictive. It requires any person who lists, advertises, promotes or sells time shares to have a real estate license, and although individual time-share owners are not affected, critics say it makes it harder for them to resell their shares.

title: 18 Are Injured in Bus Crash on Thruway
description: A chartered bus with 18 people on board crashed on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway early today. All 18 were injured, the state police said.

title: Hull Re-Signs
description: The St. Louis Blues ended months of negotiations by re-signing Brett Hull, the highest-scoring right wing in National Hockey League history, to a multiyear contract yesterday.

title: New Jersey Motor Vehicles Plans to Close on Saturdays
description: The New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles' 50 local agencies and 35 inspection stations will be closed on Saturdays beginning July 2 unless legislators and Gov. Jim Florio find money to keep them open, a division spokesman, Arthur Smith, said on Friday.

title: Tarrytowns Celebrate History and Diversity
description: IN ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' the ill-fated Ichabod Crane rhapsodized over ''the ample charms of a genuine Dutch country tea table,'' feasting on ''the doughty dough-nut,'' the ''crisp and crumbly cruller'' and roast chicken, among a host of other delectables.

title: Backstage, Bands on the Run Have Cleaned Up Their Acts
description: In the mid- to late 1970'S, when Aerosmith was one of hard rock's most popular and powerful bands, the scene backstage at their arena concerts reflected the excesses of a very rich, very spoiled group of musicians. The band members were known to be heavy drug users. At every show they demanded a Thanksgiving-style roast turkey, which usually went untouched, as well as several cases of Budweiser and assorted bottles of liquor. Right before they went onstage, each member drank a shot of Bacardi 151-proof rum.

title: No Headline
description: At no time since he burst upon the scene as a New York City developer and then as an Atlantic City casino operator has Donald J. Trump seemed in more financial trouble than in the last few weeks. The 43-year-old entrepreneur has been closeted with his bankers amid concerns that he lacks the cash to make timely payments on his huge business debt. In New Jersey, worried gaming regulators have undertaken a broad review of his holdings and financial condition.

title: Gone Fishin' at Belmont
description: A man wearing a cap that read ''Wishin' for Walleye'' was at Belmont Park before the first race yesterday, leaning on the rail, and reading the form chart with a certain scientific interest and a circling pen. It was fishing, to be sure, but in a different kind of stream.

title: Iranian Jews Revise Synagogue Proposal
description: LEAD: A GROUP of Iranian Jews, twice denied permission to build a synagogue in Great Neck, will try again on Thursday, submitting plans for a smaller building and more parking.

title:
COOKING;

Foodies' Bible
description: LEAD: In the early 1960's, when most of us were ignorant of ethnic cuisines other than our own, Craig Claiborne, then the food editor of The New York Times, gave us not only new foods to eat, but food for conversation as well. ''The New York Times Cook Book'' was our first guide to becoming foodies. The original book, conspicuously ahead of its time, anticipated our national passions for Cajun, Asian and Mediterranean cuisines.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Eastern Offers New Tickets For Old Ones

title: West Comes Alive in A Ghost Town
description: LIFE in the West's rough-and-tumble mining camps didn't get much harsher than in Bodie, Calif., a treeless, wind-whipped site some 8,500 feet above sea level on the east slope of the Sierra Nevadas. The lure of gold brought hard-rock miners, drifters and toughs to a town that once boasted a population as high as 10,000 at its peak in the early 1880's.

title: Oil From Spill Cleaned From S.I. Beach
description: Cleanup crews removed about 1,000 pounds of oil clumps from Midland Beach on Staten Island yesterday as more than 300 Coast Guard and private workers continued their efforts to remove the gooey oil that spilled from a tanker into New York Harbor on Thursday.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Clearwater's Revival Returns to Valhalla
description: MUSIC MOUNTAIN, which says it is the oldest continuing summer chamber-music festival in the United States, returns for its 61st season this afternoon, in Gordon Hall, the resonant all-wood auditorium just outside Falls Village.

title: Humble Beginnings
description: Most fans know that the top players in the National Basketball Association come from a galaxy of perennial big-time college basketball powerhouses: schools like U.C.L.A., Indiana, North Carolina, Georgetown and Indiana.

title: Arsenic Detected in System of a Former Hostage
description: Arsenic was found in the system of a freed hostage, Frank Reed, shortly after his release from 44 months in captivity, hospital officials said Friday.

title: The Nation;   Waiting for the Lightning Or Anything, to Strike Voters
description: MIDWAY through the primary season, this election year has the look of a half-hearted Broadway revival. To be sure, there are some intriguing new stars, but the script is familiar and the audience is often disengaged.

title: WHAT WE DON'T KNOW
description: I enjoyed Christopher Hitchens's article about E. D. Hirsch, and I agree that we need a common body of shared knowledge (''Why We Don't Know What We Don't Know,'' May 13). In his penultimate paragraph, the author mentions advertising slogans as the only memorable things in the 1984 political campaigns. This, I think, is a point that deserved further comment.

title: Brazil Court Ruling Curbs Fight on Inflation
description: President Fernando Collor de Mello, fighting an increasingly uphill battle against inflation, has suffered his biggest political defeat so far with a Supreme Court ruling that effectively trims presidential powers.

title: Georgia Pitches Its Way Past Oklahoma State
description: Had someone predicted before this afternoon's championship game that Oklahoma State would be limited to one run and five hits, chances are he would not have been taken seriously by anyone at Rosenblatt Stadium.

title: Allergy Sufferers, Keep the Tissues Handy
description: THE Island's trees have been pollinating since March, grass pollen and mold spores are now in the air and thousands of allergic Long Islanders are suffering from runny noses, itchy eyes, blocked sinuses and asthma.

title: Lifestyle;   The Making of a College Cult
description: For money and sometimes for fun, Mark Leyner writes advertisements for products like artificial saliva. ''I say that it's pleasant tasting,'' said Mr. Leyner, an affable 34-year-old with a deadpan manner, ''and that it's the most effective remedy for chronic dry mouth.''

title: Letters on Travel;   Glasgow
description: To the Editor: Craig R. Whitney has been misled by troublemakers (''Good Grief, It's Glasgow,'' Travel, May 20). ''Auld Reekie'' is a derogatory description applied to Edinburgh not Glasgow. I ought to know. I was born in Glasgow.

title: The Framers Had Muskets in Mind, Not Semiautomatic Rifles
description: To the Editor:

title: Sisters Torn Apart by the Holocaust
description: OCCASIONALLY, the story that a play tells transcends its plot, characters and quality of production. The audience fills in pauses in dialogue with personal or familial memories that expand whatever is unfoldling on stage.

title:
The Executive Life;

A Spiritual Healer For the Workplace
description: LEAD: One former general manager at the Wagner Mining Equipment Company in Portland, Ore., was a brilliant engineering executive. But he had one fatal flaw - an obsessive need to control. ''He would constantly fly off the handle and give confusing orders,'' recalled Paul Middelhoven, vice president of engineering.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration on May 27 with the Practical Traveler column was misattributed. It was by Barbara Samuels.

title: Edward Embury, 84; Designed Zoo in Park
description: Edward C. Embury, an architect who designed the Children's Zoo in Central Park among other recreational, educational and residential projects, died on Wednesday of emphysema at the Winchester (Va.) Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Berryville, Va.

title: Baptism of Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: What's New at Frisbee U.
description: Hampshire College was born 20 years ago this fall in an apple orchard in western Massachusetts. As the many journalists who described its infancy were wont to say, the school had a silver spoon in its mouth and a frisbee in its hand. It was a college that gave no grades, had no departments, and didn't offer tenure to faculty. Academically, students were free to do whatever they wanted. The year it opened, Hampshire was one of the hardest schools in the country to get into.

title: Dr. Deborah Rubin to Wed Dr. Howard Herrmann
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter Rubin of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Deborah M. Rubin, to Dr. Howard C. Herrmann, a son of Mrs. Fred Herrmann of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr. Herrmann. An August wedding is planned.

title: Headliners;   Differing Views
description: She said in resigning that her tenure had been ''an exciting time,'' and Jill Wine-Banks, until last week the executive director of the American Bar Association, had something there. In her three-year administration, Ms. Wine-Banks, who first achieved fame as a Watergate prosecutor, was criticized for favoring a chauffeur-driven limousine and storming out of a meeting when turned down for a raise in her salary, which eventually reached $225,000. But the membership was especially exercised when it was disclosed in early 1989 that Ms. Wine-Banks's attorney had been designated a special prosecutor to seek sanctions against a veterinarian who had unsuccessfully treated her pet Dalmatian. That led Eugene Thomas, a former A.B.A. president, to urge her removal, writing to bar group leaders that Ms. Wine-Banks ''does not understand the use of power and lacks a sense of decorum and propriety.'' But the group's president, L. Stanley Chauvin Jr., said she had done an ''outstanding'' job. Ms. Wine-Banks agreed, saying the charges of abuse of power were ''total baloney.''

title: Fairfield Sports League Adapts to Fewer Pupils
description: LEAD: SINCE its inception in 1961, the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference has emerged as a skilled and influential league, with 14 high schools competing in 22 sports. Now the league faces growing problems, chiefly declining enrollments, which sometimes led to inequitable competition.

title: Data Bank/June 10, 1990
Anne G. Walsh Is a Bride
description: Anne G. Walsh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Walsh of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Resurrection Roman Catholic Church to Steven B. Bopp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Bopp of Northfield, N.J. The Rev. Daniel J. Fitzpatrick officiated. The bride, a graduate of Dickinson College, is an assistant investment representative at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The bridegroom, a magna cum laude graduate of Dickinson and a member of Phi Beta Kappa, is a management intern at the Bankers Trust Company in New York.

title: Near Prospect Park;   40 Condo Units on the Block
description: Forty condominium units in Brooklyn are to be put on the block this afternoon by a company that last month auctioned off most of the apartments in another condominium project just two miles away. The latest auction involves a development called Windsor Place by the Park, 128 Prospect Park Southwest at Terrace Place in the Windsor Terrace neighborhood. The four-story building has 69 apartments, of which 25 had been sold and four had been under contract before the auction.

title: A Fresh Air Fund Romance, 30 Years Later
description: When Elba Rosa was 15, her aunt sent her to the country to keep her away from the boys in their Lower East Side neighborhood.

title: India Reports Drug Smuggling on Burmese Border
description: Drug traffickers in Burma and Thailand are stepping up their use of the lightly patrolled Indian-Burmese border to funnel heroin out of Southeast Asia and to the West.

title: BLASTS AND FIRE HIT TANKER IN GULF
description: Three explosions rocked a Norwegian oil tanker carrying more than 38 million gallons of crude in the Gulf of Mexico off Galveston early today, setting off a fire and killing at least two crew members.

title: U.S. Is Inspired by Cameroon
description: After a week of calm, productive preparation for its first match of the World Cup finals Sunday in Florence against Czechoslovakia, the United States team has received a fresh bolt of energy from an unlikely source.

title: Lisa McNamara Plans To Marry Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Carey Hogan Jr. of Shelburne, Vt., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hogan's daughter Lisa McNamara to David A. Hughes Jr., a son of Sarah Hughes and David Hughes, both of Tucson, Ariz. A July wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Speak Clearly, Woodtsock, And I'll Understand
description: LEAD: PEOPLE tell me I have a hearing problem and often add helpful suggestions like ''Why don't you get a hearing aid?'' or ''Why don't you have that operation I heard about?'' or ''Get your ears cleaned.'' They never mention the Woodstock factor. The doctor confirms that I have lost perception of the higher frequencies due to nerve damage, but I still hear most things well.

title: Kuwait Vote Seen as Essential to Democracy
description: Kuwaitis vote on Sunday for a new assembly portrayed by the Government as necessary for the future of democracy in the Persian Gulf state but condemned by opposition leaders as unconstitutional.

title: Ethnic Protesters Attack Troops, Soviets Say
description: Soviet television reported tonight that militants in the Soviet republic of Kirghizia had fired on troops and attacked trucks as tensions mounted further in the Central Asian region.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: For John Guare A Return to Roots In the Comic Style
description: On Oct. 18, 1983, an unusual news item appeared in The New York Times. On four occasions a teenager calling himself David Poitier talked his way into the homes of prosperous Manhattan couples. David would claim to be a friend of the couple's children and a fellow student at college. He would say that he had come to New York to meet his dad, the actor Sidney Poitier, but that his father would not be arriving until the following morning. The youth would then say that he had just been mugged. The couples responded like good samaritans, offering food, money and sometimes a bed for the night. The only problem was that nothing ''David Poitier'' said was true.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Where Twain Had a Tree House
description: A welcome escape for the nature-starved New York City dweller lies on a hill in the quiet, tree-lined neighborhood of Riverdale in the Bronx, across Independence Avenue from the house where Don Corleone and his family lived in ''The Godfather.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Time to Cook Up a Pot of Self-Esteem
description: LEAD: I CONFESS I was one of those women who sometimes complained about the endless daily rounds of family meals and the planning and shopping that almost inevitably fall upon the wife, even in a fully employed household. Only now, with a divorce and the departure of children for college, do I realize how much of my identity and self-esteem used to be tied up in my role of a cook.

title: HOW A 30'S STIFF BECAME A CHARMER FOR THE 90's
description: Though in many ways wooden and expressly two-dimensional, the figure of Dick Tracy has an enduring attraction. Right now, we see his face everywhere. We can eat off it, lean back on it, walk the dogs in it and wipe the dishes with it. Come Friday, we can see a feature film in which Warren Beatty produces, directs and plays the title role and Madonna warbles away in the role of an archetypal temptress.

title: The Cookie Monster Makes Policy
description: A not-so-funny thing happened to Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner on the way to the White House, where he was to deliver America's new national transportation policy. The policy got eaten up by a Cookie Monster named Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Katherine Eresian Weds
description: Katherine A. Eresian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Eresian of Chevy Chase, Md., was married there yesterday at the Woodend Audubon Naturalist Society to David C. Chenok, a son of Philip Chenok of Greenwich, Conn., and Ann Chernow of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Kenneth MacLean, a Unitarian, officiated. The bride, 29 years old, graduated from Harvard University and received an M.B.A. from Yale University. She is the San Francisco coordinator of planning for the Kaiser Health Plan. Mr. Chenok, 30, graduated from Georgetown University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. from Yale. He is the chief analyst in the office of the Deputy Mayor of San Francisco.

title: Gansler Says He'll Stay
description: Bob Gansler, the coach of the United States team, was shocked and agitated this morning after reading a published report saying that he intended to resign after the World Cup competition. ''There's no truth to that at all,'' he said. The report, from Agence France-Presse, said Gansler had announced his intentions before Cameroon beat Argentina in the opening game in Milan on Friday.

title: In a Bad Year, N.R.A. Sounds Alarm
description: There is talk of war here. Not just the kind that lobbyists wage (though plenty of that, too), but the real thing: a possible foreign invasion.

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Spills and Wildlife

title: Chess
description: The goings-on in chess often flout prediction, as was shown once again by the performance of Aleksandr Belyavsky in the Mephisto-SKA International Tournament, which took place in Munich from April 27 to May 11.

title: Headliners;   Tony Collector
description: Tommy Tune had a nice evening when the Tony awards were given out last weekend. The director-choreographer won two of them for ''Grand Hotel,'' one for direction and one for choreography, and the play won three more. It was not the first for Mr. Tune, who took the rather unlikely vehicle of tap dancing to great fortune on Broadway. He has also won Tonys for ''My One and Only,'' which he choreographed with Thommie Walsh and starred in with Twiggy, and for ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine.'' His first Tony, in 1973, was for his role in ''Two for the Seesaw.'' Mr. Tune (his name really is Tune, though a few generations back the family was Tunesmith) started his dance training as a 5-year-old in Houston. And as a director, he once said, he sees everything as ''one gigantic, never-ending musical number.'' For all the accolades that went to ''Grand Hotel,'' with its swirl of 1920's steps, Mr. Tune said he was a little surprised at five Tonys. The three he did not win went to Michael Jeter for best actor in a musical, Santo Loquasto for costumes and Jules Fisher for lighting.

title: Jennifer C. Shikes Becomes a Bride
description: Jennifer C. Shikes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Shikes of New York, was married yesterday to David L. Haines, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Haines of Schenectady, N.Y. The Rev. Richard A. Taber performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Salisbury, Conn.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Nancy Klein to Wed Jordan Ira Bailowitz
description: The engagement of Nancy Sue Klein to Jordan Ira Bailowitz, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bailowitz of Fort Lee, N.J., has been announced by Miss Klein's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman I. Klein of Baltimore.

title: New Brooklyn Bishop Leads Prayers at Abortion Clinic
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn led more than 500 parishioners in a prayer vigil outside a women's clinic in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday morning to protest abortions being performed there.

title: IN FOR REPAIRS: AYER'S IMAGE
description: ''HEY, GUYS, WAIT A MINUTE!'' SHOUTS JERRY J. Siano, chief executive of N.W. Ayer. Sitting sideways on a chair, his legs thrust out under one of the metal arms, Siano is watching the mock-up of a television spot roll across a video monitor. The ad is part of a presentation that Ayer will be making for the Dexatrim over-the-counter diet pill account. But Siano is unhappy with a chart that is meant to show weight loss after several weeks on Dexatrim. As usual, he is not slow to express his opinion: ''I know what's wrong with this. Let's get the words 'Pounds Lost' to pop up at the end.'' A young copywriter nods agreement, adding, ''Yeah, so it becomes a button.''

title: Cheryl Neel Noble Becomes a Bride
description: Cheryl Neel Noble, a lawyer, and Edward James Mendelson, a professor at Columbia University and the literary executor of the estate of W. H. Auden, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia by Judge Richard M. Palmer of Family Court in Brooklyn.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a concrete basement floor with a one-inch trench around the perimeter. For years, this floor has had a hairline crack about five feet long that goes from one corner out toward the center. The crack has widened to about a sixteenth of an inch, and there seems to be a new hairline crack that goes about eight feet past this. The floor gets little traffic; the only thing that has changed is that an exercise machine is now in the basement. Could this have caused the added cracking?

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE ELMSFORD FIRE DEPARTMENT;

A Village Says Thanks to Its Volunteer Companies
description: LEAD: IN their daily lives, the men and women in the Elmsford Fire Department are white- and blue-collar workers, hard-driving professionals and folks enjoying retirement, people who work with their hands and those who sit behind desks. When the alarm sounds, however, or when there is a drill, a muster or a meeting, they are all firefighters, bonded by the job to each other and the community they serve.

title: After 3 Weeks, Dominican Vote Still Unsettled
description: Three weeks after national elections, this country still awaits the results of a presidential contest in which a margin of well under one percent separates the two leading candidates.

title: Alarmed at Turn in Israel, Arabs Forecast War
description: Arab and Palestinian commentators responded today to the formation of a new, right-wing Israeli Government with forecasts of war, reflecting a mood across the region that blends apprehension, anger and a deepening hostility toward the United States, Israel's main supporter.

title: Miriam Makeba Plans Return to South Africa
description: Miriam Makeba, the black musician dubbed ''Mama Africa'' by her fans, is expected to return home to South Africa on Sunday.

title: SUITCASE MUSIC TRANSPORTS PEOPLE AND VICE VERSA
description: Skipping town is an old summertime urge. Even in ancient Rome, those who could afford it headed for their seaside villas when the weather got hot; and in the backwoods of New England, where this column is written, cabins and cottages are now filling up with summer people from the cities.

title: Dare We Mention Socialism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Readied For Auto Insurance
description: NEW JERSEY drivers, who have long clamored for a major reconstruction of the state's ailing and expensive insurance system, may soon get the changes they have been waiting for.

title: Letters o n Travel;   Reading
description: To the Editor: It seems unlikely that Andrea Barnet (''Literary Logistics,'' Travel, April 8) had ''the pleasure of reading Willa Catha'' on the Golan Heights or anywhere else without noticing the spelling of Miss Cather's name.

title: U.S. Rights Groups Fault U.N. Panel's Growth
description: American human-rights monitoring organizations are warning that the main United Nations group charged with enforcing respect for human rights in the world is likely to become less effective as a result of last month's decision to increase its membership and give all 10 new seats to third world countries.

title: The Forgiving Municipal Bond Market
description: Is it a hard time for debtors? Not in the municipal bond market.

title: Darien's 'Grease' Catches The Mood of a Decade
description: ONE is bound to get just the right measure of fun from the Darien Theater production of ''Grease,'' the 1970's view of the inanity of the 1950's. 'Grease' is a useful footnote to the nostalgic craze for a decade of intellectual and political snoozing.

title: Gorbachev, Though Besieged, Isn't Defeated;   Why We Should Help
description: To the Editor:

title: BETTING THE FARM ON BIOTECH
description: The sun beats down on green fields of corn that have never seen chemical insecticides or weed killers. Over the ridge, docile Holsteins are producing more milk on less feed than has ever before been possible, and piglets are growing into lean adults at uncommon speed. The air is free of dust from eroding topsoil and a stream drains the gentle slopes, its waters as sweet and pure as a mountain spring. Supermarkets are jammed with the bounty of a skillful, careful farming that is as safe as it is productive.

title: Gourmet Takeout Finds a Niche Among Young Professionals
description: LEAD: IN these days of two-career and single households where expense is less an object than time and energy, carry-out cuisine is a strong trend. Taste buds honed by travel and restaurant dining coupled with health consciousness have made more demanding customers for the new wave of takeout shops around the state.

title: Hit Men Have Guns, Will Direct
description: Leave it to the hardest-working film students of the future to determine just what ''Bird on a Wire,'' ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' and ''Saturday Night Fever'' have in common. Or what underlying qualities ''Cadillac Man'' shares with ''No Way Out,'' ''Cocktail'' and ''The Bounty.'' Only the most dedicated among them will be able to analyze the bonds linking ''Die Hard,'' ''Die Hard II'' and ''The Hunt for Red October'' with ''The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' which stars Andrew Dice Clay. And those who can sort out the stylistic differences among ''Robocop,'' ''Robocop II'' and ''Total Recall'' will go to the head of the class.

title: Dancing In the Street
description: It was already a national holiday, so the 10 million inhabitants of the Republic of Cameroon hardly knew how to celebrate on Friday when the West African nation's soccer team defeated the defending champion, Argentina, in the opening round of the 1990 World Cup. They found a way. As soon as the game was over, Cameroonians, who had been given the day off to follow the match on radio or television, poured out of their homes in exuberant, and sometimes raucous, celebration.

title: The Ritual of Sunday Brunch: A Sampling of County Spots
description: LEAD: DINERS reluctant on a sunny Sunday to follow winter's routine of remaining locked indoors with the newspaper and a bleak cup of coffee, can head out to celebrate the new-minted air and sunshine with that leisurely ritual called brunch.

title: Other Factors In Assaults
description: To the Sports Editor: rrIn regard to Gerald Eskenazi's article (''The Male Athlete and Sexual Assault,'' The New York Times, June 3), it seems to me that three important contributing factors were omitted.

title: Heavy Rains in Ohio Force Thousands to Flee
description: Heavy rains forced the temporary evacuation of up to 10,000 people today, including 2,000 living near a man-made lake whose retaining wall is in danger of collapse, the authorities said.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Special Menus for Special Fathers
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants particularly suited for Father's Day next Sunday.

title:
Style Makers;

Kenneth D. King, Milliner
description: LEAD: Elton John's album ''Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters'' hangs in Kenneth D. King's studio as proudly as any painting in a museum. That is because the singer posed for the cover photograph resplendent in a purple hat, trimmed with orange braid and turquoise beads, designed by Mr. King.

title: COLD WAR CROSSINGS: A QUIZ
description: The struggle between intelligence forces of East and West began years before the Berlin wall went up in 1961, and that conflict inspired many espionage novels. But the wall, as deadly fact and evocative symbol, engaged a whole new generation of writers, and it seemed as though it figured in all spy novels and thrillers for a while. Now that the wall is coming down, we're free to indulge in a bit of nostalgia. Here are some of the best-known fictional references and crossings. Who is the writer? What is the book, and when was it published? Answers on page 39.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Following the Banner of Good Will
description: LEAD: THERE have been heated debates recently involving strong emotional sentiments about our national flag and the rights of individuals to challenge that symbol of patriotism. In all countries, the flag represents a communal identity, and at an early age children are made aware of it. The flag is at all official ceremonies, in public places, schools, parades and international sports events.

title: No One Can Avoid Exposure to Radiation
description: One has to give the residents of West Sayville who oppose the installation of the National Weather Service's new weather radar installation (''Warning Sounded Over Weather Radar Station,'' April 22) the benefit of the doubt that they are generally concerned for their health and are not zealots. In exercising their rights of opposition they also have the responsibility to become informed, and the scientific community has the responsibility to educate.

title: Not Only Does He Act The Part, He Wrote It
description: On Wednesday at the Roundabout Theater, Charles Grodin the actor opens in ''Price of Fame,'' a comedy by Charles Grodin the playwright. Throughout much of his career Mr. Grodin has been both performer and writer. Here he tells how one calling led to the other.

title:
ART;

Defining Parameters of Hispanic Sensibility
description: LEAD: THE frenetic title, ''New York Spanics, Giving Some - Taking Some'' heralds a finely paced look at a range of art by artists of Hispanic origin who live throughout New York City. The exhibition at the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery has as its curator Renny Molenaar, director of the Black and White in Color Gallery in the

title: Campion at Age 13? In Tennis, It's a Long Shot
description: The professional debut of Jennifer Capriati at 13 and the success of Monica Seles at 16 have sent shock waves into the world of junior tennis. Parents watching the French Open and other pro tournaments are wondering if they should quit their jobs and move to a training center in Florida, and kids are questioning their futures in the game.

title: Adventures in Cooking;   Tippy Canoe And Eating, Too
description: Reading the diaries i kept on backpacking trips in the Pacific Northwest, I find glowing descriptions of glacial cirques, alpine tundra, perilous mountain passes and wretched meals. A typical dinner: freeze-dried chicken with instant rice and gravy. Dessert: instant butterscotch pudding, chilled in a nearby stream. Gastronomically speaking, backpacking is not my sport of choice.

title:
Cumberland, Md.;

Pinning Hopes On Recreation
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of this rural western Maryland community are hoping that a $48 million conference center and golf course will breathe new life into their depressed economy.

title: GARDENING
description: After much puzzling over the question of whether there are generic differences between American and British garden writing, I find that a growing hunch about the answer is confirmed in several of this spring's crop of books. British writers tend toward the impersonal, apparently assuming that the only reliable point of similarity between themselves and readers of very diverse tastes and backgrounds is their common interest in gardening. (No one who reads Vita Sackville-West's lapidary essays on gardening will suspect that she had a personal life at all, much less one as rich and erotically complex as hers.) British writers say little about themselves, probably because they feel that doing so would be of scant general interest, and they say even less about their friends, possibly because they are sensitive about invasions of privacy in a very tight little island.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Stay-at-Home Mother Offers No Apologies
description: LEAD: I WAS amused by the negative reaction on the Wellesley College campus to the selection of Barbara Bush as their commencement speaker. On one hand, I can understand how she must represent the antithesis of the students' ambitions, and yet I was hoping that college campuses had gone beyond teaching the early feminist doctrine of career as defining one's self worth.

title: No Headline
description: DRUGS, violence and death may be all too familiar on the streets of Hartford, but hope is there, too. That is what art students at Weaver High School say in ''The Streets of Hartford: An Exhibition of Provocative Art and Information.''

title: Headliners;   Day in Court
description: It is too late for Bridget Mergens Mayhew to have her high school Christian Bible club, but she has a Supreme Court decision bearing her name. Mrs. Mayhew, now 23 years old, was a senior at Westside High School in Omaha when she and other students were denied school sponsorship of their club. School officials reasoned that to give the group recognition, and the same modest perks enjoyed by such after-school groups as the chess and scuba clubs, would violate the First Amendment prohibition against government aid to religious organizations. But the students, in the role of plaintiffs, said the officials violated the Constitutional right to the free exercise of religion, as well as the freedom of speech and assembly. Their case later became a test of a Federal statute, championed by the religious right, guaranteeing religious groups the same access that other student groups have to public schools. Last week, in Board of Education v. Mergens, the Supreme Court upheld the law in an 8-to-1 vote. Mrs. Mayhew said later that ''it's a source of strength to be able to share your faith.''

title: Bush and Kohl Discuss Moscow's Concerns
description: After meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, President Bush said Friday night that ''we're making progress'' in easing Soviet fears about a united Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Kohl agreed that Moscow has ''understandable interests'' in the military future of Europe.

title: Lynne Loposer to Wed Robert Weber in 1991
description: The engagement of Lynne Louise Loposer to Robert Matthew Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weber of Hartsdale, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dan Loposer of Jackson, Miss. The wedding is planned for next year. Miss Loposer, 29 years old and a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin, is an advisory financial analyst at the International Business Machines Corporation in Somers, N.Y. Her father, a professor of computer science at Jackson State University, retired as a senior planner at I.B.M. in Austin.

title: Time For Children
description: ''I talk to them often, but do not like to beat my children - the world will beat them enough.'' - Elihu Burritt, 19th-century reformer

title: Walking in Hardy country
description: RETURNING to my native England recently, after many years in New York, I was moved to revisit Dorset, my home county. I was drawn by some rereading of Thomas Hardy, the Dorset poet and novelist I thought tiresomely old-fashioned when I was a teen-ager, but now seems wonderfully evocative and human; like revisiting the art of the Hudson Valley school after too much immersion in abstract Impressionism.

title: AFTER PROTECTION A TIME FOR RISKS
description: LEAD: For 40 years I've been trying to explain to my American friends that they misinterpret Japan. I haven't made much progress. The first challenge is explaining what any Japanese civil servant understands perfectly well: despite the country's economic miracle since World War II, Japan has not had an economic policy; it has had a social policy.

title: SPEED UP CHANGE, SOVIET AIDE URGES
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's personal economic adviser has disavowed the Government's plan for a gradual transition to a market-oriented economy, and instead proposed a series of presidential decrees to move the country more rapidly toward a free market.

title: Truman's 'Police Action'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rail Workers Back to Work After Picketing in 6 States
description: Under court order, striking railroad workers in six states dismantled their pickets on Friday and went back to work for CSX Transportation Inc.

title: Shelby P. Tison, Banker, Is Wed
description: Shelby Pamela Tison, the daughter of Paul Tison Jr. of Corte Madera, Calif., and Patricia Richardson Badig of Mahwah, N.J., was married yesterday to Jarvis Cromwell 2d, a son of Joan Van Pelt Cromwell of New York and Roger J. K. Cromwell of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell officiated at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: U.S. Grant to 2 Czech Parties Is Called Unfair Interference
description: An American attempt to foster democracy is being denounced here as unfair interference favoring the political parties closest to President Vaclav Havel.

title: Cuomo Neglected To Cite Lilco Deal
description: The article by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (''Helping the Island Helps the State,'' May 6) mentions the amounts of money that the state is spending on high-tech industries, research and transportation to help the Island's economy. But it neglects to mention the much larger amount that will be removed from the Island if the Governor's deal with Lilco sticks.

title: Lifestyle;   Graduates' Wish Lists and Gift Givers' Actualities
description: For many parents, college is so expensive these days that they consider it a gift in itself. So searching for the perfect gift for the high-school graduate gift is often overshadowed by the demands of preparing for freshman year or finding that first job.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Those who think that the spirit of photographic invention has fled from the United States to Japan should pay a visit to Joe Saltzer's darkroom, a scant hour's drive north of New York City. You won't find the latest hybrid 35-millimeter camera there, but you will see some of the best designed and easiest to use darkroom tools ever developed.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ARTS 'JUBILEE'

title: Seafaring Cook Shares Her Secrets
description: COOKING can be perilous enough on dry land, but Elizabeth Wheeler, of Rowayton, can turn out formidable feasts strapped into the galley in the throes of rolling swells.

title: Works in Progress;   Steeped in History
description: On Aug. 10, 1628, THE VASA, A three-masted, 64-gun Swedish warship, capsized and sank on its maiden voyage in the waters outside Stockholm, a blow to King Gustaf II Adolf - the family dynasty, begun by Gustaf I in 1523, was known as Vasa - whose nation was about to enter the Thirty Years War. The ship remained at the bottom of the ocean for more than three centuries. In 1956, a historian and archeologist, Anders Franzen, located the ship and initiated its raising, which was completed in 1961. Since then, the Vasa - the only identified 17th-century ship remaining in the world - has been displayed at a temporary site in Stockholm. After long delays, construction of a permanent museum began in 1986; it opens to the public next Saturday.

title: A DEATH IN THE ART WORLD
description: NAKED BY THE WINDOW

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Those Were the Days, Those Were the Days
description: LEAD: COMING of age on the South Shore - or -Remember when -

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Grilled Ginger-Mustard Lamb With Orzo
description: Orzo, the Greek rice-shaped pasta, appears to have become the newest pasta fad. It has a wonderful texture that is both slippery and firm. And even if you never ate it as a child, it still falls in the category of comfort food.

title: Ossining Is Angry Over Loss Of Bridge
description: A PROJECT of the State Department of Transportation designed to let modern rail carriers use the Hudson line is nearly complete, but at least one unexpected problem has not been settled.

title: Fashion;   Cool Summer Whites Can Also Turn Up the Heat
description: A symbol of purity and innocence, white can also be wanton. This summer's white-hot looks include lace bodysuits and leggings that tease the imagination, and figure-hugging cotton-Lycra skirts and tops that look great against the skin.

title: Italy Edges Austria
description: Seventy-eight minutes of crisp, aggressive soccer were rewarded tonight for the hometown fans when Italy scored a goal to beat Austria, 1-0, in the Italians' first game of the World Cup finals.

title: UNEASY ABOUT THE GERMANS
description: Arthur Miller tells us that he is concerned about the German problem but is still supportive of unification (''Uneasy About the Germans,'' May 6). He concedes that there is no way to assure ourselves that the Germany of the 1990's will not return to the politics of internal repression and external aggression once the constraints of the cold war are loosened. He concludes that ''If Germany remains implicitly on trial for a long time to come, release must come through good works and a demonstrated devotion to democratic ideals and practice.''

title: Lewis Enters Mobil
description: A year after he boycotted the Mobil Track and Field Championships because of a feud with The Athletics Congress, Carl Lewis plans to compete at the 1990 championships this week, but not because he and T.A.C. have patched things up.

title: The Nature of Peter Mattiessen
description: PEter Matthiessen may be the world's most hard traveling writer. He has steamed by freighter from Brooklyn to the head of the Amazon, trekked over 17,000-foot-high passes to the Tibetan plateau, bounced by lorry around East Africa - and each time he has returned with a book. On all continents he has gone in search of pristine places and societies untainted by Western culture. Faced with the exotic, Matthiessen is a compulsive note-scribbler. Whether writing natural history, travelogue or fiction, he bathes readers in a wash of particulars, establishing the dense reality of an unfamiliar place.

title: LORD OF THE 'RING'
description: It is five hours into richard wagner's ''die Walkure,'' the second opera in his massive ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' tetralogy. In one of the most dramatic moments in the entire 17-hour ''Ring'' cycle, Wotan, the king of the gods, sung by James Morris, has just banished his beloved daughter Brunnhilde from Valhalla for disobeying him.

title: Editor of Street News Steps Down
description: The founder of Street News, under attack from former staff members, has resigned as the paper's editor in chief, saying he hopes his departure will permit the paper to continue publication, friends and a board member said on Friday.

title: Stony Brook Plans a New Festival Mix
description: LEAD: IN some ''serious'' theatrical circles, mixing little-known, but acclaimed, experimental ''artistes'' with well-known rock stars playing Shakespeare might be considered selling out.

title: Julie Williams Is Wed To Daniel B. Murphy
description: Julie Hunt Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Fox Williams of Savannah, Ga., was married there yesterday to Daniel Bryn Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Bernard Murphy Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. George M. Maxwell performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: A Cafe Reopens: Lunch Returns to the Prairie
description: When Louisburg's last cafe closed its doors in 1988, Keith Hansen and John Lund and the other men who farm the rich, rolling prairies of western Minnesota found themselves confronting a new and lonely challenge: lunch.

title: Miss Gorewitz Is Engaged
description: Marian E. Gorewitz and Mark L. Kleinman are planning a July wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Freide Gorewitz of West Nyack, N.Y., and Rubin L. Gorewitz of New York, have announced. Miss Gorewitz, a magna cum laude graduate of Ramapo College with a master's degree in creative writing from City College, teaches English at Pomona (N.J.) Junior High School. Mr. Kleinman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kleinman of Liberty, N.Y., graduated from Sullivan County Community College. He owns Mark of Excellence Hairstyling in Liberty.

title: Dance Festival Opens New Season at Duke U.
description: The American Dance Festival is featuring major American choreographers and new choreographers from abroad in its new season, American Masters Plus, which opened Thursday and runs through July 21 at Duke University in Durham, N.C. This is the schedule: Erick Hawkins (today); Eiko and Koma (Tuesday and Wednesday); Martha Graham (Thursday to next Saturday); Ann Carlson (June 19 and 20); the Black Tradition with revivals, performed by the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company and the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble (June 21 to 23), and the African-American Dance Ensemble, with a premiere by Donald McKayle (June 26 and 27).

title: Is the Governor A Long Islander?
description: As someone who is employed on Long Island and resides in Queens, I agree with Governor Cuomo that Long Island is a critical economic part of New York State.

title: UGLY DEBATE ENDS AS PROVINCES SIGN ACCORD ON QUEBEC
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and the premiers of Canada's 10 provinces signed a package of measures tonight to clear the way for a constitutional accord to keep Quebec a part of Canada.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campus Life pages on May 27 about Sarah Lawrence College referred incorrectly to selection standards for the Joseph Campbell professorial chair. Drawn in rotation from several disciplines, scholars appointed to the chair will be specialists in the peoples and cultures of Africa, Asia, Native America, Latin America or the Middle East. The chair is not limited to minority scholars.

title: A CROWBAR FOR CARLA HILLS
description: The office of the United States Trade Representative is housed in a 19th- century building that once served as Union Army headquarters. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant occupied the spare, high-ceilingedroom that now is the office of Carla A. Hills, the nation's chief trade negotiator.

title: The Trouble With Tinkering
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Name of Ecology
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:;   Harding
description: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

title: 'I SHOULD HAVE KNOWN BETTER'
description: In March 1988, after meetings with the American representatives of Australia's Hooker Corporation, I became president of Bonwit Teller, the specialty store chain. Two months later I sat down for the first time with the top management of the Sydney-based real estate developer that owned the chain. There were four of us that day in New York, everyone jovially shaking hands and patting backs. Cigars were lit, and flowing, imaginative things were said. But at one point during those amiable hours, a shadow darkened my thoughts. Something was missing in our talk of a glowing future.

title: Mutual Funds;   On the Road With Grace Pineda
description: Grace Pineda, daughter of a Filipino diplomat, lived in France, Switzerland and the Philippines before her family settled in the United States. Here she studied Russian, one of four languages she now speaks, and later earned a graduate degree in international business from Fordham University. She has specialized in the Pacific markets since 1982, when she got her first money management job and was assigned to watch a promising spot called Japan.

title: On Language;   Cosmetological Chartist
description: Be careful of parenthetical remarks; these asides can get you into unexpected trouble.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Not Just Friends, Old Friends
description: LEAD: OLD friends. That is what we are. Not the, ''Yeah, we go way back'' kind of friends. I mean great friends. True friends. Friends of the heart. I mean old friends.

title: Technology;   The Phone Company Untangles Its Lifelines
description: Simple diagrams of how a local telephone call reaches its destination usually show a line from the customer to a telephone company switch, and then another line from the switch to the desired party.

title: Across the Wide Prairie By Wagon Again
description: THE Flint Hills Overland Wagon Train trip begins ''just past the drive-in,'' in the high school parking lot, of the tiny town of Rosalia, Kan., about 40 miles from Wichita. Although the Santa Fe Trail ran diagonally across the state some 40 miles to the northwest, the organizers of the modern-day trail ride chose Rosalia because the 50-mile-wide stretch of bluestem or tallgrass prairie land of south-central Kansas surrounding it, called the Flint Hills, is the only unplowed tract of true prairie remaining in the United States.

title: Rachel Cartmell Marries James Ault Jr.
description: Rachel Davies Cartmell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Madison Cartmell Jr. of Manchester, N.H., was married yesterday to James Mase Ault Jr., the son of Bishop and Mrs. Ault of Fogelsville, Pa., and Haines Falls, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Church of All Angels in Haines Falls by the bridegroom's father, a bishop in the United Methodist Church.

title: Data Update
No Benefit Seen In Longer School Year
description: As a college professor and the parent of a young child, I have some serious reservations about Assemblyman William J. Pascrell Jr.'s proposal to lengthen the school year Opinion page, May 6).

title: Agassi and Gomez Ready
description: Andre Agassi, the flamboyant Las Vegan, and Andres Gomez, the mild-mannered Ecuadorean, insist they'll square off in the French Open final Sunday afternoon as absolute equals. Agassi said the abundance of experience Gomez possesses in Grand Slam events, 27 appearances, and on this surface, 15 titles on clay, was immaterial. ''As far as the experience thing, it's his first Grand Slam final as well as mine,'' Agassi noted.

title: Keeping Norton in the Family
description: On May 27, The New York Times published an article by John Cahill, chief executive of the British conglomerate BTR P.L.C. A month earlier, one of the state's oldest and best manufacturers - the Norton Company - fended off BTR's takeover attempt with the help of timely state legislation.

title: The Region;   The New Math Of Rich and Poor
description: AS a tide of lawsuits seeking more equity in the financing of public schools spreads across the country, a court ruling in New Jersey last week underscored a seemingly intractable struggle.
