It pits the protectors of local control of the schools against advocates of absolute equality in the money that poor urban systems and affluent suburban districts can spend to educate their children. For New Jersey, it was the second landmark decision on the issue in 17 years and it may not be the last word.

title: Miss Kittredge Wed to R. P. Wastrom
description: Jennifer Ann Kittredge, a daughter of Mrs. David Brayton Kittredge of Charlotte, Vt., and the late Mr. Kittredge, was married yesterday to Richard Paul Wastrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dale Wastrom of Upper Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. Mark Bolles officiated at the Congregational Church in Charlotte.

title: Lena Wu to Wed M. V. McConnell
description: The engagement of Lena Wu to Michael V. McConnell has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James T. Wu of Salt Lake City. Mr. McConnell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent M. McConnell of New York. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a concrete basement floor with a one-inch trench around the perimeter. For years, this floor has had a hairline crack about five feet long that goes from one corner out toward the center. The crack has widened to about a sixteenth of an inch, and there seems to be a new hairline crack that goes about eight feet past this. The floor gets little traffic; the only thing that has changed is that an exercise machine is now in the basement. Could this have caused the added cracking?

title: Looking Ahead
description: TUESDAY: First meeting of an S.E.C. advisory committee to aid the development of securities markets in Eastern Europe.

title: Susan A. Anton to Wed James Clancy in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark J. Anton of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan A. Anton to James P. Clancy, a son of Dorothy Clancy of Morristown, N.J., and Richard Clancy of Boston. An October wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth Latane Ware Weds A. M. Brown Jr.
description: Elizabeth Latane Ware, the daughter of Guilford D. Ware of Norfolk, Va., and the late Nancy Smith Ware, was married yesterday to Archibald McDowell Brown Jr., the son of Mrs. Wootton Walker and Mr. Brown, both of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. A. Heath Light, Bishop of the Diocese of Southwestern Virginia, performed the ceremony at Christ and St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Norfolk.

title: Evening Hours
description: New York City itself was the backdrop for three recent parties.

title: 'Grease' Played Straight in Darien Production
description: EVEN though you're bound to get just the right measure of tutti-frutti fun from the Darien Dinner Theater production of ''Grease,'' it's hard to resist the temptation to take a sober view of the historicity of an innocuous musical.

title: Havel's Movement Seen Winning Majority Control in Parliament
description: President Vaclav Havel's citizens' movement, which swept the Communists from power last November, completed its victory today by winning majorities in both houses of Parliament in Czechoslovakia's first free elections since 1946, official forecasts indicated.

title:
DINING OUT;

In Tarrytown, but Only on Weeknights
description: LEAD: AFTER having been closed three months for major renovation, Tappan Hill is open once again, more beautiful than ever, and this time under the aegis of the county's talented caterer Abigail Kirsch. Most of the splendid rooms and terraces, including an oudoor ''chapel'' for wedding ceremonies - all with smashing views - are reserved for private meetings and celebrations of all sorts and sizes.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Clock Tower as a Mask;   Conversions With T.L.C.
description: A British real estate company run by a Scottish family has been quietly investing in New York City properties that its owners feel ''need tender loving care'' and developing them in diverse ways for long-term gain. The latest project of the Western Heritable Investment Company of London and Glasgow is the conversion of an old factory at 307 East 53d Street near Second Avenue into a small office building with an upscale aura.

title: Mindy Gerber Is Married
description: Mindy Gerber and Comdr. Charles Harry Barber 3d, U.S.N., were married yesterday at the Homestead in Hot Springs, Va., by Judge James H. Michael Jr. of Federal District Court in Charlottesville, Va. Mrs. Barber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gerber of Charlottesville, attended Hamilton College. She is a freelance producer of television commercials. Commander Barber, a son of Janet Forester Barber of West Chester, Pa., and the late Mr. Barber Jr., is the director of sailing at the United States Naval Academy. A graduate of Franklin and Marshall College, he received an M.S. in administration from George Washington University and an education specialist degree from the University of Virginia.

title: Seles Stuns Graf to Capture French Open Title
description: The girl with the biggest grunt in the game and tennis strokes lifted from the blueprints in her father's physics textbook swiftly and noisily rendered a rainy afternoon in Paris historic today.

title: Letters on Travel;   Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Having spent a marvelous week in Prague with my wife in July 1988, I read with interest Jane DeLynn's piece (''The Tape Is Still Red in Prague,'' Travel, April 15). I was curious to learn what, if anything, had changed insofar as a tourist was concerned. Not enough, it seems.

title: Review/Concert;   Early Music By Aurora
description: Aurora, a classy New York-based early-music quartet, concluded a three-concert series at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, 99th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, with a French-flavored 18th-century concert on Wednesday night.

title: John E. Stambaugh, Professor, 50
description: John E. Stambaugh, a professor of classics at Williams College, died on Wednesday at his home in Williamstown, Mass., after a long illness. He was 50 years old.

title: Letters on Travel;   Luggage Codes
description: To the Editor: Kenneth Lahn of New York (Letters on Travel, April 1) wrote about the confusion of luggage codes. In actual fact, there should be no confusion whatsoever, assuming the passenger knows where he/she is going.

title: DIED 30 B.C., STILL GOING STRONG
description: CLEOPATRA

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: JULY 4, 1873, was a summer day at the height of the Victorian era. In London, the Shah of Persia visited the architectural wonder of the age, the Crystal Palace. In Long Branch, President Ulysses S. Grant arrived at his elegant seaside cottage for the Independence Day holiday. And in Jersey City, the Rev.

title: Letters on TRavel;   Car Rentals
description: To the Editor: In reference to car rentals in Europe (Practical Traveler, April 1), you refer to Kemwel Company as a broker for ''many overseas rental companies.'' Kemwel is also referred to in many Pan Am ads as the supplier of cars in their promotions.

title: IS THE BBC LOSING ITS GRIP ON QUALITY?
description: Alan Bennett's ''Talking Heads,'' a series of dramatic monologues currently being broadcast Sunday nights at 10 on Channel 13, is precisely the sort of television that adds to the luster of the British Broadcasting Corporation's reputation for quality television. The overall BBC schedule still tends to be just as ordinary and mediocre as its American counterparts, but the occasional highs continue to stand rather gloriously by themselves.

title: Noreen R. Weiss Is Wed to Derek J. T. Adler
description: Noreen R. Weiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Weiss of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., was married yesterday to Derek J. T. Adler, the son of Florence Cousins of Palm Harbor, Fla., and Lee Adler of Climax, N.Y. The Rev. Orlanda R. Brugnola officiated at the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn in Brooklyn Heights. The bride, 26 years old and keeping her name, is an associate with the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. She graduated summa cum laude from Pennsylvania State University and cum laude from the Fordham University School of Law. Mr. Adler, 29, an associate with the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, graduated from Columbia University and received a law degree from Fordham and an M.S. in urban affairs from Hunter College.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Why does it happen? It's a combination of things, but the principal one is simply sending out wrong signals. It's rarely done deliberately because this kind of situation usually only occurs between friends, or with the innumerable people who aren't friends but are somewhat more than acquaintances. What it boils down to is communicating a message that is accurate in detail but, because one salient fact is omitted, leaves the other person with the wrong impression, based on the assumption that what's not spelled out is, nevertheless, understood.

title: AT MERRILL, A FRUSTRATING HUNT FOR PROFIT
description: As their limousines streamed toward Arizona's CamelbacK Mountain on a Friday in February, en route to Merrill Lynch & Company's junk bond conference, few of the 800 guests could have missed the various ironies surrounding the event. For one thing, there was the conspicuously lavish site of the conference, a 130-acre spread called the Phoenician Resort; it seemed strikingly at odds with an announcement just 12 days earlier that Merrill had taken a $470 million writedown during the fourth quarter of 1989. Then there was the curious fact that this flashy celebration of junk bonds was taking place just as the red-hot market for the high-yield securities was flaming out. And finally, there was a sense of deja vu, as Merrill's C.E.O., William A. Schreyer, announced, ''We aim to become No. 1 in the high-yield market.'' Not many months before, he had shut down businesses in New York and London for which he had once proclaimed a similiar goal.

title:
Philadelphia;

Restored Mill Renting Well
description: LEAD: RENTING has been brisk at the first phase of the rehabilitation of a historic textile mill into a 328-unit apartment complex in the city's East Falls section, about 10 minutes northwest of Center City. Of the 101 units in the first phase, 44 have been taken since renting began in late April.

title: Is a Mall Really 'Home'?
description: I found an inconsistency in Mary M. Jefford's article (''This Island is a Really Good Place to Be From,'' April 29) very interesting. She describes wanting to go ''home'' after a visit to Long Island and its status-seeking populace, where people have everything yet are somehow sour on life. Three paragraphs later she writes of going to the ''hometown mall'' and meeting a bejeweled woman who complains of the cold as she gets out of her Porsche.

title: The Guys in White Hats from Sony
description: In 1989, the Materials Research Corporation, which I founded, was faced with a critical challenge: raise capital or probably fail. The capital we finally raised came from Japan. We are now a wholly owned subsidiary of Sony U.S.A.

title: Seafood With the Tang of the East End
description: LEAD: BETH HARRIS, the writer, with John Haessler, of ''The Wainscott Seafood Shop Cookbook,'' learned at an early age how to cook fish. ''We grew up around the water,'' said the 37-year-old native of East Hampton, who lives in the same Springs house she was born in.

title: Tech Notes;   The Next-Generation Computer?
description: First there was the desktop personal computer, then the laptop. Now there is the walk-through PC. The what? It's not really a computer at all but a two-story working model of a PC with a 108-square-foot monitor and a 25-foot operational keyboard. It was built as an exhibit for the Computer Museum in Boston, to show how computers work, will open there June 23 and then tour the country. Inside it, visitors will be able to walk through a giant mock-up of random access memory chips, see 6-foot spinning disk drives, look at microprocessors enlarged 600 times and touch interface boards. The exhibit simulates the flow of data through a computer's many parts as it runs a simple geography program that pinpoints distances between any of 300 cities around the world.

title: About Men;   Wet Behind The Ears
description: I'd left my childhood in the murky waters of the Westhill High School pool. The school's administration had invested a great deal of money installing the pool and, in order to justify the expense, swimming class was deemed mandatory for all freshmen. It seemed logical that only freshmen should be forced to submerge themselves in the frigid waters for a few minutes each morning, then creep through the courtyard, hair soaking wet, to the next class. Wet hair was Westhill High's scarlet letter. Freshman! it screamed, loud and clear.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: In response to the question, may I say that in my small town more kids are playing little league soccer than baseball and the high school has an excellent team. The colleges in my small state - the University of Vermont in particular - have good teams and great support from fans. When Sports Illustrated ran an article on the United States goalie, Tony Meola, it was sold out at our local store. I had to go to the library to read it.

title: Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann Is Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ihler Grimmelmann of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Miles Oakley Bidwell Jr., the son of M. Oakley Bidwell of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, and the late Frances Jones Mott. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: Numbers Crunch;   Getting a Mental Grip On The Dimensions of The Savings Disaster
description: ONE of the more curious aspects of the savings and loan debacle is how much money has been lost and how little anyone seems to be upset about it. ''Twin Peaks'' appears to have generated more intense national discussion.

title: Dawn M. Haase Is Bride of James C. Stephens 2d
description: Dawn M. Haase, the daughter of Mary Salerno of Westport, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James C. Stephens 2d, a son of Simone S. Stephens of Westport and Clay G. Stephens 3d of New York. The Rev. Floyd George, a minister of the Federated Church of Westport, officiated at Camp Dudley in Westport.

title: School Aid Ruling: The Court And Society
description: WHEN the New Jersey Supreme Court last week declared the state's 1975 school-financing law unconstitutional as it applies to 28 of the state's poorest districts, it became the first state court in the nation to revisit the issue of school financing.

title: Douglas Sent Offer by King
description: The promoter Don King sent a letter today to representatives of Buster Douglas offering the heavyweight champion $20 million plus 50 percent of the gross revenue in excess of $34 million to fight Evander Holyfield.

title: Mosaic Postcards From Paradise
description: IT'S a brick building, not as big as a private home, not apt to catch the eye of a casual visitor. The windows are small and narrow, and the roof is so low that the building might be mistaken for a public restroom by anyone who fails to notices that it's shaped like a Latin cross.

title: The Elite No Longer Meet, So a Landmark Heads for Auction
description: MANY a political deal was made behind the scenes at the Parkview Hilton in Hartford, with hopes for office realized or dashed. Cabinet officials, vice presidents and presidents were among the hotel's visitors. But now it is to meet the same fate as two of Connecticut's other landmark meeting places: the auction block.

title: DECISIONS, DECISIONS
description: He is tall and handsome, and on this cold, rain-whipped morning in Manhattan he is having the time of his life.

title: Hilary A. Weston Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Josh S. Weston of Montclair, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Hilary Ann Weston and Capt. Alexander Walter Joel, U.S.A., the son of Sunja Joel of Washington and Dr. Clark Joel of La Paz, Bolivia.

title: PEACE PLAN ALIVE, SHAMIR MAINTAINS
description: With two days to go before Israel's new Government is submitted for formal parliamentary approval, Acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir began rebutting criticism today that the right-wing coalition will be unable to move Israel toward peace with its neighbors.

title: An Updated Menu in a Venerable Setting
description: IN an industry of ebb and flow, Scribner's is a tribute to the staying power of owner managership. The chef-owner, Scribner Bliss, and his wife, Beth, have kept the 16-year-old seafood restaurant on course with the consistent high performance that made it notable in the first place.

title: Ms. Dodson Engaged To Eric I. Greenberg
description: The engagement of Kathleen Dodson, a daughter of Naomi Dodson of Evanston, Ill., and the late Richard J. Dodson, to Eric I. Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Greenberg of Peekskill, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's mother. The wedding is to be next year.

title: The Polysided Views of Ives's Personality
description: Did Charles Ives, the revered pioneer of American music, secretly revise and redate manuscripts of his older compositions to promote the legend of his originality? That has long been the suspicion of some music historians, following a clue first dropped by his onetime disciple Elliott Carter in 1939 and dilated upon 30 years later in an oral-history interview. The question seems simple enough. However, reaching a verdict in this complicated case, as anyone who has ever served on a jury might attest, may not be so simple. Evidence has a way of changing shape and hue, according to the eye of the beholder and the time of day or night in which it is perceived.

title: Review/Dance;   Gregory as Ax Wielder in 'Fall River'
description: American Ballet Theater's revival of Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend'' on Friday night for the first time since 1980 was treated as the major event it is.

title: Ashley E. Davis and David J. Prend Are Married
description: Ashley E. Davis, a daughter of Peyton C. Lewis of Washington and William P. Davis of Dallas, was married yesterday in New York to David J. Prend, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Prend of Stockton, Calif. The Rev. John A. Buehrens officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Zambian Culture In a Crafts Shop
description: AS a founder of Zintu, the leading crafts store in Zambia, Gwenda Chongwe has had her share of the kind of serendipitous adventures travelers in Zambia must learn to love.

title: Showdown Looms On Bill to Compel More Recycled Newsprint
description: LEAD: WHEN Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin convenes a hearing tomorrow morning on a bill that would compel newspapers to hasten toward greatly expanded use of recycled newsprint, publishers and newspaper spokesmen are likely to tell him they are already moving that way as fast as they can.

title: Jane West Weds Steven Welker in Connecticut
description: Jane Hamilton West, the daughter of Maria McDonald West of Darien, Conn., and the late Herbert Buell West, was married yesterday to Steven Richard Welker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Welker of Somers, N.Y. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Anne Kimball at St. Luke's Church in Darien, assisted by the Rev. Allan Bartlett Jr., a cousin of the bride.

title: Ruth S. Feldstein To Wed in August
description: The engagement of Ruth Sara Feldstein to Dr. Asa Joel Nixon, the son of Tamara Nixon and Dr. Daniel Nixon of Miami Beach, has been made known by Ms. Feldstein's parents, Shirley Feldstein and Dr. Donald Feldstein of Teaneck, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Campus Life: Radcliffe;   Students Organize Campaign to Build A Women's Center
description: Administrators from Harvard University and Radcliffe College will meet this week to review documents submitted by student advocates petitioning for a women's center to be built in or near Harvard Yard.

title: Cuomos and Kennedys Sit on Both Sides of the Aisle
description: At the bridegroom's quarters at the Sheraton Carlton Hotel, most of the morning was spent trying to pin the tail on the Governor.

title: Miss Young Weds J. S. Reynolds Jr.
description: Margaret Randolph Young and Julian Sargeant Reynolds Jr. were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Joseph Clark Grew performed the ceremony.

title: Matthew P. Connolly Weds Maura A. Cronin
description: Maura Ann Cronin, a daughter of Neil R. Cronin of Hyannis, Mass., and the late Irene Heinsohn Cronin, was married yesterday to Matthew Powers Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Connolly of Weston, Conn. The Rev. Gildon Stillings officiated at the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Harwich Port, Mass.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion: On the Street;   A Leisure Look For Midweek, Even at the Office
description: Shorts are no longer just for days off. They are now a smart and sophisticated alternative to skirts and pants at the office or for some serious shopping in the big city.

title: Talking; Co-ops;   Boards' Powers Sustained
description: THE opportunity for a shareholder in a New York cooperative to challenge a decision by the building's board of directors or for a condominium unit owner to overrule the board of managers has been sharply curtailed by an April decision of the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court.

title: Gorgeous Bits Of Vocabulary
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Rosse Weds Dennis E. Foster
description: St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Orange, Va., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lesley A. Rosse and Dennis E. Foster. The Rev. Robert Marston officiated, assisted by Msgr. Edward Foster and the Rev. Dennis Worzalla, Roman Catholic priests who are uncles of the bridegroom.

title: Dollars, Dragons and Del Rey
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended May 26

title: Nancy Illman Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Illman of Massapequa, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Caralyn Illman and Eliot Nelson Meyers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Meyers of Cincinnati. Miss Illman, 23 years old and a graduate of Harvard University, is an account executive at Omni Development and Marketing Ltd., a consumer products company in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 25, graduated from Harvard and its law school and expects to start as an associate with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy in September.

title: Taking the Train to Escape the Q Bridge
description: ANN AND ROBERT JOSE of Old Lyme like to drive together to their jobs in New Haven, he to Connecticut National Bank and she to Connecticut Savings Bank. But Mrs. Jose's classes two nights a week have disrupted their schedule. Rather than drive separately, as they have been doing on those two days, Mr. Jose took the new Shore Line East commuter train home one night. Then a second night. And by Friday of the first week, he and his wife took the train together and left both their cars home.

title: Despite More Aid, School Officials Are Wary
description: LEAD: THREE weeks after the State Legislature announced the 1990-91 education-aid package for local school districts, many Westchester school administrators are still trying to decide whether they should shake or bite the hand that feeds them.

title: The Nation;   Greyhound Takes the Road to Bankruptcy
description: PUTTING the nation's only coast-to-coast bus company into bankruptcy was far from Fred G. Currey's thoughts when he led a debt-loaded buyout of Greyhound Lines Inc. three years ago. But last Monday he filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, freezing payments on debts of $540 million, after Citicorp and some other large creditors took steps toward repossessing as many as 1,000 of Greyhound's 3,800 buses.

title:
The Nation;

Blacks Debate the Cost of Affirmative Action
description: LEAD: Two years ago, at a seminar on higher education sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus, a young man who obviously didn't know better breached etiquette by posing a discomfiting question.

title: Getting the Most Out of a Shade Problem
description: POSSIBLY the greatest challenge any gardener has to contend with is too much shade. Full sun is easy for planters. But when a property is covered with leafy canopies, gardening can be tricky.

title: OBJECTS OF HIS DESIRE: ONE COLLECTOR'S CHINA SYNDROME
description: The color-splashed and richly figured Chinese ceramics on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Aug. 26 are a highly personal document of more than 2,000 years of stylistic developments in pottery. The vessels and figures, which date from the Han Dynasty (206 B.C. to A.D. 220) through the Ching Dynasty of the 19th century, are from a collection amassed over 50 years by Stanley Herzman, a New York collector and clothing manufacturer.

title: SAIGON SWAP
description: MESSAGE FROM NAM

title: A Soviet Violinist Is Adopted By Pupils as 'Their Very Own'
description: THE gym was decorated with banners proclaiming Soviet-American friendship. Chairs for special visitors proclaimed the importance of the occasion. A group of 200 hushed third through sixth graders, well-prepared for their guest of honor, waited cross-legged on the floor for the assembly to begin.

title: A Changed Biennale Remains the Same
description: The latest Venice Biennale opened to the public several days ago, and the mediocre result that has become almost predictable revives a familiar question: Has this most august of international art exhibitions outlived its usefulness?

title: Correction
description: An article on May 27 about racial tensions on college campuses misstated minority enrollments at several colleges and misattributed the figures. According to fall 1989 enrollment figures published by the Connecticut Department of Higher Education, 10.2 percent of the undergraduates at the University of Connecticut are minority students. For Trinity College, the percentage is 13.4 percent; at Yale, it is 22.8 percent.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: Unfortunately, no. For these reasons:

title: Re-regulate? Not on Your Life;   Triumphs on the Road, on the Phone, in the Air
description: Small towns howl about losing bus and rail service. Travelers complain about rising air fares and congested airports. Cable television users resent soaring rates, and many people occasionally pine for the days when Ma Bell cared for their every telephone need. The widespread elimination of Government regulation in the Carter and Reagan years has hit some Americans hard.

title: Michele Payson To Wed in Fall
description: October wedding plans for Michele Payson and Dr. Mark Rosenfield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mashe Rosenfield of Liverpool, England, have been announced by Ms. Payson's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Payson of Great Neck, L.I.

title: CONNECTICUT Q&A: HUNTER HASTINGS Marketing in 90's Needs New Strategies
description: CHANGING attitudes of consumers combined with the splintering of broadcast and print media has displaced advertising as the best way to market a product, says Hunter Hastings, a senior partner of the Ryan Management Group, in Westport.

title: Style Makers;   Francine McMillan, Designer of Party Favors
description: A few years ago Francine McMillan, a business executive in Manhattan, got hold of some bubble pack, those air-filled plastic bubbles used to insulate packages. She took it home, kicked off her heels and started popping the bubbles with her feet.

title: How the $8 Billion Space Station Became a $120 Billion Showpiece
description: America's planned space station, sold to Congress in 1984 as an $8 billion project, will actually cost at least $120 billion when operating and other expenses are counted, and even then it will not meet what has become the Government's top objective in space.

title: Headliners;   Two Heads
description: For a generation paleontologists have known that the Piltdown Man of England was a counterfeit, a couple of bones deftly patched together to suggest a large-brained prehistoric ancestor. But who assembled him? The list of usual suspects reads like a parody of an Agatha Christie cast: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, fossil buff; Dr. Arthur Smith Woodward, paleontologist at the British Museum; Charles Dawson, country lawyer; Dr. Grafton Elliot Smith, anatomist; Lewis Abbott, jewel counterfeiter, and Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, priest and philosopher. Now there is also Sir Arthur Keith, museum conservator of the Royal College of Surgeons. In a new book, ''Piltdown: A Scientific Forgery,'' Prof. Frank Spencer of the City University of New York says Dr. Keith, who had hypothesized the early evolution of an enlarged human brain, hatched the plot with Mr. Dawson, helping to doctor the human skull fragment and orangutan jaw that Mr. Dawson later ''discovered'' in 1912. Some experts still doubt that the case can be solved - which, after all, would ruin a pastime for paleontologists.

title: Surprise Charges Upset Condo Buyers
description: Apartment buyers in the expensive new Belaire condominium in Manhattan's Upper East Side got the news in April that their monthly common charges were going up 16 percent, and when the annual meeting of owners convened last month, many were in a mood to argue.

title: TV Policy Irks Basketball Fan
description: A FUNNY thing happened to the Hartford basketball viewer this season: He was almost denied broadcasts of both Boston Celtics and New York Knickerbockers games. Behind this peculiar outcome lay the antiquated and illegal territorial restrictions of the National Basketball Association.

title: Go and Go Runs Away With the Belmont
description: Go and Go, an Irish colt who was flown to New York from Dublin on Wednesday, thrashed what was left of the American Triple Crown crop when he scored an 8 1/4-length victory over Thirty Six Red yesterday to win the 122d Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Review/Dance;   Shang's 'Rituals' in Renaissance Setting
description: Ruby Shang's ''Urban Rituals'' evoked both the court festivities of the Italian Renaissance and the pomp of the French Baroque era. The work was performed by Ruby Shang and Company, Dancers, Thursday night in a mansion at 972 Fifth Avenue (at 78th Street) that was designed by Stanford White in an Italian Renaissance style in 1906 and that is now the headquarters of the Cultural Services of the French Embassy.

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1989 Christmas issue.

title: Wedding Planned By Anne Weiner
description: A September wedding is planned by Anne R. Weiner and Alan M. Rifkin, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Weiner of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced. Mr. Rifkin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Rifkin of Worcester, Mass.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PUTNAM CELEBRATED

title:
GARDENING;

ROSES AND CONCRETE
description: LEAD: This crisp, comprehensive handbook starts off with a vignette: Linda Yang is riding in a New York City taxicab. She's bringing home a sack of manure, and the indignant cabby, horrified at his cargo, screams at her, ''That's crazy - you can't really garden in the city!'' Ms. Yang goes on cheerfully to dispel that and a host of other myths about city gardening, adding a wealth of practical, proven information along the way.

title: Overstating Ink Toxicity?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MERRY SOUL AT 82
description: THE PLEASURES OF AGE

title: Park Leasing Plan Faces Suffolk Test
description: LEAD: A PLAN to grant long-term licenses allowing private businesses on the publicly owned parklands of Suffolk County will face its first major test this week. Two measures to block the plan until it is studied further will be considered by the County Legislature.

title: Saddling Up at a Dude Ranch
description: BUFFALO BILL CODY was still taking his Wild West Show on the road and Billy the Kid was fresh in his grave when cattle ranchers in the Rocky Mountains first started accepting paying guests, or ''dudes,'' as the visitors from back east came to be known. Much of the Old West is gone but this tradition has prospered.

title: Damage Seen From January Oil Spill
description: Five months after more than half a million gallons of oil spilled from a leaking pipeline into the Arthur Kill, environmentalists and conservationists say that many of their worst fears about damage to the fragile marine and bird life there are being realized.

title: 'Gremlins 2' Required a Whole Team of Mischief Makers
description: Walking into the office of the director Joe Dante at the Burbank Studios is like walking into the room of a 12-year-old movie brat. Posters from his favorite films - ''Son of Dracula,'' ''Invaders From Mars'' and ''Tomb of Ligeia'' - are plastered on the walls. The bookcase at the back of the room is overflowing with Gremlin toys, Gumby dolls, skeletons and a space helmet.

title: TRAVEL
description: I've been reading the latest batch of travel books. Which means I've been reading an awful lot about snow-capped peaks set against limitless blue skies and how such sights inspire awe, reverence and a renewed desire to preserve the wilderness. In book after book, I've been bombarded with fine, soulful sentiments. I've been dragged along like a tourist being guided through a succession of splendid cathedrals: this is a magnificent treasure, the litany goes, as landscape after landscape is unreeled. And every last one of them is threatened by our way of life, our greed, our heedlessness. What I've been getting is a lot of scenery and sermons.

title: A Hackley Teacher Fights Dismissal
description: THE founder of the well-known music conservatory program at the Hackley School, a private day school here, has been accused of misconduct and incompetence and asked to leave the school this month, but she is contesting the dismissal.

title: Informed Weeping
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Soccer Gain More Popularity In the U.S.?
description: Sure. When baseball, football and basketball cease to exist and/or the United States team wins the World Cup. ''Don't touch the ball, use your head!'' Please, no mas. Let this silly, boring ''game'' die a peaceful death.

title:
Your Own Account;

Changing the Insurance Game
description: LEAD: The rule was once very simple: Buy term life insurance, rather than whole life, and invest the difference. But that may no longer hold for baby boomers who are having children when they are in their late 30's and early 40's.

title: Shannon Shuman Weds C. M. Herzfeld
description: Shannon Stock Shuman, the director of international trade services at the law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, was married yesterday to Charles M. Herzfeld, the director of defense research and engineering in the Office of the Secretary of Defense, both in Washington. The Rev. William R. Wooten performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Sierra Club Gratified By Estate Purchase
description: The 6,500-members of the Sierra Club were quite gratified by Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin's Earth Day announcement of the purchase of the 1,400 acre Hampton Hills estate.

title: ADIRONDACKS BAN CALLED UNLIKELY
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation says he doubts that the Governor will endorse a plan to impose a one-year moratorium on permits for most new construction in the Adirondacks.

title: Institutions Should Pay
description: To the Sports Editor: rrRegarding Gerald Eskenazi's article on sexual assault:

title: Margaret Kyle Marries
description: Margaret S. Kyle was married yesterday to Frank T. Iorio at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Donald W. Poole. Mrs. Iorio, 29 years old, is the daughter of Susan P. Kyle of Rye and Donald W. Kyle of Scarsdale, N.Y. She graduated from Skidmore College and is an account executive at Carrafiello, Diehl & Associates, an advertising agency in Irvington, N.Y. Mr. Iorio, 30, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony F. Iorio of Ossining, N.Y. A graduate of Pace University, he is a district sales manager for Act III Communications in New York.

title: Liza Hathaway Is a Bride
description: Liza Phillips Hathaway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grant Hathaway Jr. of Ruxton, Md., was married yesterday to E. Brent Matthews, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Franklin Matthews of Towson, Md. The Rev. William P. Baxter Jr. officiated at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Garrison Forest, Md. Mrs. Matthews graduated from the Purnell School and the Maryland Institute of Art. The bridegroom graduated from St. Paul's School in Brooklandville, Md., and is entering his final year at Towson State University.

title: Promise Into Peril: The Kirby Fight
description: It all began with a letter that ended, ''With Kindest Regards.'' Sent in the spring of 1986, the letter caused long-simmering family frictions to erupt in a battle over an obscure charitable foundation. Since then, the Kirby family feud has turned into a tale of sibling rivalry played out on a billion-dollar stage.

title: Campus Life: Grinnell;   Program Allows Underprivileged A Chance to Learn
description: ''I felt lucky to be in this adoption,'' said 11-year-old Jesus Avila, a fifth-grader at Moulton Elementary School in Des Moines. ''I thought I wasn't going to college.'' That is until he and 48 classmates were adopted by Grinnell College, the first academic institution to sponsor a class under the ''I Have a Dream'' program underwritten by Eugene Lang, a New York business executive.

title: Randi Getz Plans to Marry Paul Tessitore in January
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart I. Getz of Massapequa, L.I., have announced that their daughter, Randi I. Getz, and Paul V. Tessitore, the son of Marie Tessitore of Massapequa and Vincent Tessitore of Spring Hill, Fla., are to be married next Jan. 26. Ms. Getz, 28 years old, graduated from Columbia University. She is a copywriter at the Sadler & Hennessey advertising agency in New York. Her father is a advertising sales representative for The New York Times. Mr. Tessitore, 28, graduated from Adelphi University and is an assistant manager in Hewlett, L.I., for the Long Island Lighting Company. His father owns the International House of Travel in Tarpon Springs, Fla.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Joyce London Mohamoud;

Helping Parents Avoid Child Abuse
description: LEAD: ACCORDING to a report released in April by the State Division of Youth and Family Services, the number of reported cases of child neglect and abuse almost tripled from 1982, the first year for which statistics are available, to 1989. In 1989, 58,404 cases were reported; of those, 21,311 were substantiated by an investigation.

title: She's Not Cher, but Pretty Close
description: LEAD: ''I WAS so in love with her, so in awe of her,'' said Audrey Cassel of River Vale as she reminisced about a childhood preoccupation with the entertainer Cher while Ms. Cassel was growing up, as she put it, as ''a chunky little kid with a big nose,'' on Long Island. Ms. Cassel said she would often imitate her idol by throwing back her hair and, tongue to upper lip, fix her friends with the bored, vampy stare that distinguishes the star.

title: Gorbachev, Though Besieged, Isn't Defeated;   Shades of the Czars
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;

It's Just Vaudeville, But It Has a Plot, Too
description: LEAD: ''Love Life,'' described as a ''vaudeville musical,'' originally opened on Broadway on Oct. 7, 1948, with music by Kurt Weill and book and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner. A revival by the American Music Theater Festival will open tonight at 7 at the Walnut Street Theater in Philadelphia and will run through

title: Riley May Resign
description: Is he or isn't he? Only Pat Riley, the Los Angeles Laker coach, and Jerry Buss, the team's owner, know for sure, according to Riley, whether he will be stepping down after nine seasons. But if Riley does decide to leave the Lakers, the team's general manager, Jerry West, already has a short list of possible replacements, including Mike Dunleavy, a Milwaukee Bucks assistant.

title: Style Makers;   Carol Cohen, Raincoat Designer
description: Carol Cohen specializes in coats that are as dramatic as they are rainproof. Her first collection for the Sanyo Fashion House, where she has been the head designer since last August, are not for the faint of heart or the meek in style, though they are exceedingly practical.

title: Pausing on Mars, Arnold Ponders His Success
description: The souvenir posters that go from floor to ceiling in Arnold Schwarzenegger's colorfully modern office tell the tale of what by now is clearly a major event in pop culture history. They show the primevally muscled, don't-mess-with-me, ultratough (though, in real life, entirely gentle and congenial) Mr. Schwarzenegger in one or another of his elemental, menacing poses.

title: The Region;   The Latest Plan for the Adirondacks Leaves Adirondackers Skeptical
description: WITH dozens of majestic peaks, 31,000 miles of rivers and streams and millions of acres of forested wilderness, New York's Adirondack Park is often referred to as the largest park in the lower 48 states. Indeed, the area encompassed within the Adirondacks Park's boundary - larger than Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, Glacier and Olympic National Parks combined -qualifies for the designation.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

With Everyone's Help, a Garden Is Restored
description: LEAD: When good gardeners get together, good things can happen. At Lyndhurst, the Tarrytown, N.Y. estate of the railroad magnate Jay Gould and many other prominent 19th century persons, a Victorian rockery is coming back to life.

title: Q and A
description: Clogged Ears on Descent

title: Fielder Is Taking His Fast Start in Stride
description: It was shortly after 3 P.M. on a warm and humid afternoon Friday when Cecil Fielder emerged from the cool of the clubhouse into the milky sunshine of Tiger Stadium to begin his long day on the job.

title:
DINING OUT;

Unusual Ideas About American Food
description: LEAD: IT'S been a long time since we saw the sort of descriptive menu excesses practiced at Palmer's restaurant in the Nassau Inn at Princeton. A menu is supposed to tell diners what is available, but does anyone really want to know if the tomatoes are from Vineland or the crab cakes from Long Beach Island?

title: FOR BARRY'S JURY, QUERIES AND MORE
description: Most of the excitement this week surrounding Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial has occurred outside the courtroom, with the legal proceedings overwhelmed by rampant speculation over whether he will reach a plea arrangement with Federal prosecutors.

title: 'Real Allusions' Show Offers a Crew of Surrealist Riddlers
description: IN the late 20th century, there is the obsession with technology on the one hand and the cult of the childlike on the other. Not so long ago, the two seemed to be in opposition, but now it looks as if they go hand in hand.

title: Philippines Says 2 Robbers, Not Rebels, Killed a Marine
description: The authorities said today that two robbery suspects have confessed to killing a United States Marine officer who the police originally thought was slain by Communist rebels.

title: Safety Seats for Infants Winning Favor in the Air
description: Despite many pressures, the Federal Government is still nowhere near a decision on a rule requiring that children under the age of 2 be strapped into portable safety seats for airplane takeoff and landing. But while the cost-benefit analyses go on and deadlines are extended, parents seem to be accepting the wisdom of this step; safety seats are increasingly used on planes for both ticketed and unticketed infants.

title: Jacqueline Elliman Becomes a Bride
description: Jacqueline Munroe Elliman, a daughter of Lawrence M. Elliman of St. Helena, Calif., and Judith Sperry Beavers of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Gerard Leonard Jr., the son of Mrs. Martin Winkler of Jericho, L.I., and the late Mr. Leonard. The Rev. David Fountain officiated at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If daffodils did not bloom profusely, they may need dividing; now while the leaves are visible, dig up and separate thick clumps of bulbs; replant them and water well, but the foliage must remain above ground to ripen naturally. Protect roses with a fungicidal spray to prevent development of black spot, a fungus disease that spreads rapidly. Cut to the base, faded iris stalks. Protect fruit trees again with an all-purpose spray formula.

title: Ms. Friedman to Wed Judah Shechter
description: September wedding plans for Amanda Beth Friedman and Judah Aryeh Shechter have been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Friedman of Toms River, N.J. Mr. Shechter is a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Jack Shechter of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Assessing the 10-Year-Old Facade Law
description: TEN years have passed since Local Law 10 was enacted to protect pedestrians in New York City from falling masonry. Over the decade, not only has it achieved its primary public-safety aim, but it also has preserved the integrity of many building facades.

title: A FATHER'S PAWN
description: I found Fred Waitzkin's profile of Gata Kamsky and his father disturbing. I have observed this odd pair at several large chess tournaments and have wondered about their curious relationship. How sad to have my suspicions about them confirmed - that this father is robbing his son of a childhood to further his own dream of glory.

title: A FATHER'S PAWN
description: Your article touched me. Gata Kamsky and I are the same age. My family comes from Russia and I, too, have felt my father's hand trying to push, or, rather, lead me through life.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our house has a concrete basement floor with a one-inch trench around the perimeter. For years, this floor has had a hairline crack about five feet long that goes from one corner out toward the center. The crack has widened to about a sixteenth of an inch, and there seems to be a new hairline crack that goes about eight feet past this. The floor gets little traffic; the only thing that has changed is that an exercise machine is now in the basement. Could this have caused the added cracking?

title: Rains Bring In Large Morel Crop
description: HEAVY rains this year have led to a good morel season. It started in mid-April and is expected to last through July. Those fragrant mushrooms are highly prized. Their delicate but pungent flavor produces the same ecstatic reaction on the part of those who eat them as do truffles or the best caviar.

title: Organic Farmers Seek Seal of Approval, Naturally
description: LEAD: DON TAYLOR has been using organic growing methods on his Danbury farm for 15 years. This year, he will make it official. Under a certification program sponsored by the Natural Organic Farmers Association of Connecticut, Mr. Taylor's 20-acre operation will undergo voluntary testing for pesticide residues.

title: Campus Life;   Thesis on Civil War Sites Finds Ear in Congress
description: From start to finish, Georgie Holder Boge's senior thesis has been a little different. Miss Boge's interest - a land-use study of Civil War battlefield sites -gave her reason to log only a few hours in the Princeton University library but lots of time on the road and at the sites themselves.

title: Special Today:
description: The Business World/Mag. Pt.2

title: 40 Years Ago, an Obscure Cup Team
description: The 1950 United States World Cup story should be considered ancient history, but every four years the record is replayed.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: LESLIE BORCK JAMESON;

Self-Help Is Just a Support Group Away
description: LEAD: FEISTY Females in Your Forties, Equal Rights for Fathers, the Westchester Lyme Disease Support Group, New York Pain Busters, the Dream Group, Inventors, Emotions Anonymous and, of course, Alcoholics Anonymous. These are just a few of more than 270 known self-help groups in the county. While each group's focus is specific, members have in common the belief that people with similar problems - whether they are medical, psychological, business or whatever - can help each other.

title: Heather Willson Marries
description: Heather Noel Willson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marlon E. Willson of Alexandria, Va., was married there yesterday to David A. Freeman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Freeman Jr. of Mobile, Ala. The Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz officiated at Christ Church Episcopal. Mrs. Freeman, 28 years old, graduated from Sweet Briar College; Mr. Freeman, 28, from Washington and Lee University. He is a vice president of J. P. Morgan & Company in New York.

title: Not Just An Ordinary Man
description: Rex Harrison thought of himself simply as an entertainer, not as an artist with inner genius. As an embodiment of that perception, he consistently delighted audiences during his seven decades in his profession, while occasionally challenging himself in roles he was at first hesitant to undertake. Sir Rex, who died on June 2 at the age of 82, was in fact an underrated actor and an interpretive artist of the first rank. He will be remembered as the ultimate Henry Higgins and as one of the most charming of leading men - and he was equally debonair in person.

title: Harvard's Power Too Much for Yale
description: On the finish line it was Harvard again, again and again today against Yale in their 125th annual regatta.

title: A THIN PAPER TRAIL IN NORIEGA INQUIRY
description: Despite an unceasing search to find physical evidence of drug dealing by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, disappointed American officials say they have found almost no documents so far that conclusively prove General Noriega trafficked in drugs.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Gorbachev, Though Besieged, Isn't Defeated
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen DiTolla to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. DiTolla of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Kathleen Mavourneen DiTolla and Donald Michael McCarty, a son of the late Gladys E. and M. David McCarty.

title: Audubon Hearings: 'Listen to the Sound'
description: LEAD: WHEN C. J. Marino was a boy, Long Island Sound was so clean that his mother boiled spaghetti in water taken from it in Westbrook, Mr. Marino recalled. Since then, the Sound ''has only gotten worse and worse,'' said Mr. Marino, 82 years old. ''I hope to see it clean by the time the good Lord takes me.

title: Kerith L. Sheehan Becomes a Bride
description: Kerith Leah Sheehan, the daughter of Mrs. Robert T. Sheehan of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Sheehan, was married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn to Marvin Stanley Putnam Jr., a son of Janice Crawford Putnam of Bangor, Me., and Mr. Putnam of Portland, Me. The Rev. David B. Hoopes officiated. Mary J. Hutchinson was the maid of honor, and Charles Bausman was best man.

title: Patent Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Zerline Goodman To Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack Goodman of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Zerline Lehman Goldman and Michael Andrew Rothenberg, a son of Dr. Eleanore Dubin Rothenberg and Stanley Rothenberg, both of New York.

title: In The Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Malverne $147,000

title: Liberia's Government Plans to Hold Peace Talks
description: The Liberian Government said today that it had agreed to hold peace talks with rebel forces in an effort to end the nearly six-month-long civil war.

title:
BLAIRSTOWN JOURNAL;

Anger Over Taxes Turns Into Action
description: LEAD: WHEN Gov. Jim Florio's education budget proposal was made public in March, it was apparent that homeowners were going to be hit hard in the checkbook - again. The record 17 percent shortfall in funds for school aid was a shock to all the state's school districts. But, with the remaining funds to be distributed through a formula that penalized districts with higher property values, the rural communities have cried foul, and

title: 4 Towns Told to Boil Water
description: A power failure at a chlorination plant led authorities to advise about 344,000 residents in Jersey City, Hoboken, Lyndhurst and West Caldwell to boil drinking water as a precaution.

title: The World;   Sound of Hands Shaking Wakes Asia
description: AFTER fretting that it was being left out of the changes transforming Europe, Asia received its first bracing encounter with the global diplomacy of the 1990's last week as a Soviet leader met a South Korean President for the first time. The hastily arranged visit in San Francisco handed President Roh Tae Woo a diplomatic windfall and gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a chance to maneuver in a region he has largely ignored until now.

title: Baltimore Bomber Foils the Yanks
description: If the Yankees thought their plight could not get any uglier, any more embarrassing, any more hopeless, they were wrong.

title: Victors In the Cold War
description: Max Schmeling looked up from the floor of the boxing ring, saw Joe Louis still standing there and said:

title: In Tennis, Love and Hate
description: AS I stand here on the base line, racket at the ready, peering across the net at my good friend Craig, I am wondering how to avoid ingesting the fuzzy yellow projectile that he is about to launch in my direction.

title: Mary Balderston Wed in Rochester
description: Mary McKinney Balderston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Balderston 3d of Rochester, was married there yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Richard Andrew Somerby, a son of Mrs. Peter L. Wastrom of Stamford, Conn., and Richard A. Somerby of Hartsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Wainwright officiated. Mrs. Somerby, 29 years old, graduated from Miss Porter's School and St. Lawrence University. She is the assistant director of the William Beadleston art gallery in New York. Her father is the chief executive of the Chase Lincoln First Bank of Rochester. She is a granddaughter of the late William Balderston, who was the president and chairman of the Philco Corporation.

title: Review/Music;   Trombone Gets Its Moment In an Avant-Garde Program
description: A concert of avant-garde music for trombone, alone and in flocks, might seem arcane. But a hardy band of avant-garde trombone fanciers rallied to attend Rob Bethea's concert on Monday night at the Washington Square Church.

title: Score in Thrifts Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychologists Address 'Burden of Being Male'
description: LEAD: AN executive sits at his desk staring at the paperwork he needs to complete and thinking about the deals he is working on. He knows he should be on the train home, but he stays another hour, and then another. His wife, meanwhile, has just returned home from her job; the children need help with their homework; there are dishes to be washed and laundry to be folded, and the husband knows he should help with those tasks.

title: Headliners;   The Suicide And the Doctor
description: THErr ''suicide machine'' that a victim of Alzheimer's disease used to administer her own death last week was the main instrument in Dr. Jack Kevorkian's main cause. ''They'll all be after me for this,'' said the retired pathologist, who devised the intravenous machine in his two-room apartment outside Detroit. He said he was determined to help other terminally ill people die.

title: Adelman Keeps Blazers Confident
description: Imagine a coach leading his team to the National Basketball Association championship series in his first full season on the job.

title: Michelle Jordan Becomes Bride
description: Michelle Jordan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George William Jordan Jr. of Carmel Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to David Allison Carpenter, a son of Kenan Casteen Carpenter of Winston-Salem, N.C., and Dr. Harry Mitten Carpenter of Coca, Fla. The Rev. Andy Strachan, a Baptist minister, officiated in the home of the bride's parents.

title: Wall Street;   Revisionist Research on Proxy Dissidents
description: Another proxy season has ended, and closely followed, high-stakes contests at Lockheed and USX bolstered an impression that managements still have the upper hand in a showdown. But now a study from the Analysis Group, a Belmont, Mass., company that studies corporate voting policy, shows that dissident investors are not as powerless as they are thought to be. The report tracked 17 of the season's biggest contests: three were won by management and three by dissidents. The study's authors, John A. Pound and Lilli Gordon, contend that the score changes if eight other cases, in which dissidents accomplished only some of their objectives, are included. Dissidents racked up complete or partial victories in 11 out of the 14 cases where there has been resolution. The review of the record indicates a surprising beneficiary: D. F. King & Company, a large firm that specializes in proxy solicitation, sided with more dissidents than any of its competitors - and had the best record of the bunch, with six partial or complete wins and four losses.ALISON LEIGH COWAN

title: Long-Magical Charm Is Wearing Out
description: My first encounter with Saab's 900 Turbo was not a case of love at first sight. For one thing, the car looked like nothing else on the road. For another, it was different in the way that it approached almost everything.

title: Outdoors;   Looking to Books For Angling Tips
description: Those who began sport fishing during the past 20 years have had an astonishing variety of instructive books at their disposal.

title: Ms. Rosenauer Becomes Bride
description: Kathleen V. Rosenauer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adolf Rosenauer of Reno, was married yesterday to Dr. Horace F. Henriques 3d, a son of Claire W. Henriques of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. Henriques Jr. of Buyck, Minn. The Rev. John J. Cantwell officiated at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Tahoe City, Calif.

title:
World Markets;

A Reality Check for the 'East Fantasy'
description: LEAD: Since the Berlin Wall opened last November, West German stock trading has been dominated by a phenomenon called Ostphantasie, or east fantasy.

title: What's Doing In;   Zurich
description: Switzerland's largest city has lately become a prime gateway to Europe because of its no-nonsense efficiency, with never a strike or an unscheduled work stoppage, its clocklike communications with all other areas of the Continent, its financial services and its affluent cosmopolitanism. In the warm months Zurich even manages to smile, although twinkling bonhomie isn't usually considered an outstanding trait of its citizens. Americans, at any rate, will encounter friendliness.

title: Managing;   The Need for Cooperation
description: Sandra L. Helton, Corning Inc.'s assistant treasurer, coveted the excellent return on equity that Merck & Company, a pharmaceutical and chemical corporation, enjoys. Merck envied the track record that Corning, which makes such things as optical fibers and consumer products, has established for successful joint ventures. So last year Ms. Helton invited Merck's chief financial officer and treasurer to Corning, N.Y., for a brainstorming session.

title: Don't Trust Humpty Dumpty
description: To the Editor:

title: Arabs Plan a Move in U.N. to Aid Palestinians
description: In an attempt to isolate Israel and the United States in world opinion, Arab countries plan to convene the United Nations General Assembly in emergency session this month to seek an international force to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories against Israeli security troops.

title: ROUND ONE: ELECTIONS IN BULGARIA
description: THE VOTING Two rounds of secret-ballot voting will be held to fill the 400 seats in Bulgaria's unicameral Grand National Assembly. In its next session, the Assembly will function both as a constituent assembly and a legislature.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on May 27 with an article about Conner Peripherals Inc. misstated revenues for Apple Computer Inc. in its first and third years of operation. The first year was 1977, and revenues were $770,000. In Apple's third year, 1979, revenues were $47.9 million.

title: Children Disprove the Notion That Caring Is a Forgotten Value
description: MOVE over, cynics, a good and caring generation is back. All that talk about the me-me generation, about yuppies who care only about themselves, their possessions and their move up in finances, position, influence and acquisitions - all that is history. Start paying attention to the evidence that shows that helping others and contributing to society are the values that have made it through again. These are qualities that persist because we nurture them and pass them along, one generation to the next.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1989. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings.

title: A CROSSOVER LIFE
description: ALMOST LIKE A SONG By Ronnie Milsap with Tom Carter. Illustrated. 259 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: A Composer Whose Time Never Seems to Come
description: In 1965, while taking part in the centennial celebration of Carl Nielsen's birth, Leonard Bernstein indulged in a bit of prophecy. He said the world was ready at last to accept the Danish composer as the equal of his celebrated Finnish neighbor, Sibelius.

title: International Clowning In a One-Man Show
description: IN a crisis, they send in the clowns. As a theatrical variation on circus lore, the George Street Playhouse, unable to win the right to produce the world premiere of a new play, had no show for its end-of-the-season slot. So it sent in a clown: Geoff Hoyle in his one-man divertissement, ''Feast of Fools,'' which was seen off Broadway in March. It runs here through next Sunday.

title: For New Luxury Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Dream Come True For Irish Trainer
description: Dermot Weld was looking not at all unhappy to be standing around with his black loafers caked with mud. It was, after all, the mud of a winner.

title: Fashion;   Long Skirts That Sigh With the Summer Breezes
description: Yard-long skirts are catching breezes around town. The freshest versions of skirts that graze calves or billow about the ankles offer a casual alternative to snug miniskirts, and they are anything but dowdy.

title: GLOBAL DEALS: THE FAUX PAS FACTOR
description: When United Technologies Sikorsky Aircraft began negotiations to sell two dozen helicopters to the Chinese government early in 1985, Marion P. Spigener bore the title of customer relations representative. But by the time a top-level Chinese delegation arrived that July to seal the deal at Sikorsky's headquarters in Stratford, Conn., Spigener was sporting a new title: chief of protocol.

title:
TO START WITH ...;

ZAPPA ZAPPED AS TRADE REP
description: LEAD: From the start, it sounded as surreal as a Kafka novel. Within weeks of assuming power in late December, Czechoslovakia's new Government selected a singular trade emissary: Frank Zappa, an American best known as an absurdist 1960's and 70's rock-and-roll music auteur, the creator of such albums as ''Weasels Ripped My Flesh.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Lots Joining Residences on Auction Block
description: LEAD: WITH increasing frequency, developers trying to cope with the sluggish residential marketplace are turning to auctions to clear inventories of single-family homes and condominiums. Now a Bergen County builder has added a new twist to the concept: He is putting homesites on the block. On July 22, the builder, the Lebel Companies of Paramus, will auction 75 improved lots, ranging from a quarter of an acre to slightly more than an acre, at three of the new single-family home subdivisions it has under way in the county.

title: It Wasn't Tom Sawyer, But Huck Finn
description: Lou Ann Walker refers (''My Career as Huck Finn at the Picket Fence,'' May 6) to the fence-painting episode in ''Tom Sawyer'' as a story which she believes parallels a recent episode in her life during which she painted her own fence. The error we perceive in her analogy occurs when she admonishes passers-by who call her Tom Sawyer rather than Huckleberry Finn.

title: 'Mad Dads' of Omaha Take On Gangs and Drugs
description: John Foster decided that something new needed to be done here to combat drugs and violence after his son, a 20-year-old college student, was beaten up last year by youths who thought he belonged to a rival gang.

title: JUST FIND A MILLION READERS AND SUCCESS WILL SURELY FOLLOW
description: Summoned to New York in May to pitch my new novel, I managed, between interviews, to meet my wife for a quick drink in the upstairs bar at Sardi's. There were two women seated nearby. One of them complimented my wife on her appearance and then turned to me. ''I know you,'' she said. A Canadian born and bred, I contrived to lower my eyes modestly. ''You're one of the old-timers,'' she said. I shrugged. ''Who were you?'' she demanded.

title: The Executive Computer;   Planning for Summertime Is Not Always a Picnic
description: Electrical fluctuations that seem relatively mild, causing a display screen to flicker or shrink for less than a second, can batter the delicate circuitry inside the computer. In most cases, built-in power regulators absorb the fluctuations and keep things humming along smoothly. But in some cases, power spikes and dips can cause physical damage. Hard-disk drives are especially vulnerable.

title: Correction
description: An art review on May 6 about the show ''Constructed Reality'' at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts misstated the role of Anne Hoy. She wrote the catalogue but did not organize the show. A recent letter from the gallery's director, Ann Williams, has pointed out that the exhibition was organized by Joan Good, Benita Wolff and Perijane Zarembok.

title: Tracing the Complexity of Indian Art and Its Wide Influence
description: THE buxom little figure illustrating this review is identified as a celestial musician and, despite its leonine legs, a centauress, too. An 11th- to 12th-century carving from Bangladesh, it is in ''Leaves of the Bodhi Tree: The Art of Pala India and Its International Legacy,'' a show that comes to the Newark Museum from the Dayton Art Institute in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Too Silly To Be Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories Are Made of This
description: PERRY COMO memories abound in Port Washington. Sheldon Tarakan was singing his.

title: MINDING THEIR OWN BUSINESS
description: As the decade's first batch of college graduates enters the working world, many will be eager to hit the ground running - as long as it is their own piece of ground. In a nationwide Roper poll, college students rated operating one's own business as the best way ''to get ahead,'' when presented with a list of choices that included working for a large corporation or the government.

title: 640 Graduate at U. of Chicago
description: Six hundred forty seniors received degrees yesterday at the University of Chicago's 417th commencement.

title: Carleton College
description: Carleton College presented degrees to 478 students yesterday at its 116th commencement ceremony.

title: UP TO NO GOOD IN HOLLYWOOD
description: AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN

title: Sarah Edwards Becomes Bride
description: Sarah Chamberlin Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Edwards of Essex, was married yesterday to Robert James Feeney Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Feeney of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Kenneth D. Thomas officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex, Conn.

title: And It Was Once a Corner Pizza Parlor
description: FEEL like a hearty meal in the old neighborhood? There is no need to go to Arthur Avenue in the Bronx or Little Italy's Mulberry Street. Rather, head for Lincoln Avenue in Roslyn. There, on an unlikely suburban street, is Antonio's. You can return to your roots along with a shirt-sleeved crowd complete with babies and grandparents.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Indian Shrimp With Apples
description: This shrimp dish might have been aptly named Curried Shrimp, but whenever something is called curry and there is no curry powder in it, someone invariably calls and asks if the curry was inadvertently omitted.

title: White Sox Executive Illustrates How to Follow a Game Plan
description: Players snickered at Larry Himes when, as the rookie general manager of the Chicago White Sox, he checked their feet to see if they were wearing socks with their loafers. If they weren't, he fined them.

title: A BORN-AGAIN FRANKLIN INSTITUTE BANISHES STODGINESS
description: The Transition is one of the most startling in Philadelphia: to go from the domed neo-classical hall of the original Franklin Institute to the vibrant atrium of the museum's just-opened Futures Center is not only to move from old to new but also from static to dynamic, from formal to relaxed, and from sumptuous to sleek. The $72 million Futures Center, which opened last month, is a combined exhibition hall, domed-screen Imax theater, and video-equipped lecture hall, all built around a central atrium; together these facilities add roughly 90,000 square feet to this venerable science museum, and they change its identity completely.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Next year is likely to be the changing of the guard for the United States in World Championship competition. In the past 10 years American players, mainly from Texas and the West Coast, have won six world team titles, finished second three times and been out of the money only once.

title: Article 272390 -- No Title
description: A record out-of-court settlement of $80.5 million has been reached in a lawsuit stemming from a 1985 fire that leveled a huge warehouse here.

title: C.I.A. TIE REPORTED IN MANDELA ARREST
description: The Central Intelligence Agency played an important role in the arrest in 1962 of Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader who was jailed for nearly 28 years before his release four months ago, a news report says.

title: A Flurry of Red Cards Hits the World Cup
description: At long last, most Americans have something to relate to at the World Cup of soccer. Not only is a squad of Yanks playing Czechoslovakia in Florence today, but a more drastic version of baseball's dreaded Balk-o-Mania has broken out.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Times Square Novelty;   North of Duffy Sq., a Butler-on-Every-Floor Hotel
description: THE Latin Quarter. Cotton Club. Coca-Cola. Castro Convertibles. With its hot nightclubs, dazzling signs and sprawling showrooms, the block at the northern end of the ''bowtie'' formed by Broadway and Seventh Avenue was always an important part of old Times Square. The developer Jeffrey Katz is betting that a $220-a-night hotel with butlers on every floor will suit the new Times Square, as well.

title: CHURCHILL HAD A SENSE OF HUMOR
description: DON'T SHOOT, IT'S ONLY ME

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Is There Any Way to Stop the Blockheads From Taking Over?
description: LEAD: IN the upper-right periphery of my vision, I saw a row of green smokestacks, and for a split second I thought I was on the New Jersey Turnpike at the exit for Elizabeth, perhaps one of the ugliest places in the Western Hemisphere.

title: THE BEST-SELLER BLUES: HARD LESSONS FROM A COSBY BOOK
description: In May 1986, the flanks of buses plying the streets of Manhattan sported jaunty advertisements proclaiming, ''Congratulations, it's a book!'' The happy event they signaled was the arrival of the latest offspring from the publishing house of Doubleday - a compendium of the wit and wisdom of the television paterfamilias Bill Cosby on the subject of ''Fatherhood.'' It was a miraculous birth, indeed: in the United States alone, the book proceeded to go through 30 printings in record time, selling 2.5 million hard-cover copies along the way. Even more astonishing was the small matter of what is called ''contributions to overheads and profits'': figures obtained from former employees reveal that the Doubleday coffers grew between $15 million and $16 million richer courtesy of that one slim volume.

title: Wrangling in Wyoming On the T Cross Ranch
description: ''ANYBODY up for a cattle drive tomorrow?'' asked the ranch owner as guests and wranglers lingered at the table after dinner planning the next day's adventures. ''My neighbor is driving a herd up to summer pasture a half-day's ride from here,'' she said, ''so if anyone's interested, be at the corral right after breakfast.''

title: The World;   With Luck and Ingenuity, Ethiopian Aid Gets Through
description: WHEN the rains failed in northern Ethiopia last year and the civil war reached new levels of destruction, with thousands of casualties inflicted each month, the specter of skeletal children and mass starvation loomed again, recalling the suffering of 1984.

title: Amazing Space;   Flights of Fantasy
description: Forget, for a moment, about practicalities. And about the perennial problems of living efficiently in the 20th century.

title: The Nation: Los Angeles Ruling;   A Shot at the Action For Hispanic Citizens
description: TWO important events in California last week illustrated the gap between the ethnic makeup of the country's largest state and its politics.

title: COOKING
description: Suddenly and for no apparent reason, on a recent azalea-brightened late spring day, I started to think about barbecued ribs, spicy-sweet and moist, and was captured by the thought of them.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 10, 1990
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 2 2 8 SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from many parts of the world encounter their often unexpected destinies during a get-together in a small Scottish town. 3 4 16 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 4 3 5 DRAGON, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) In 1993, Dirk Pitt moves fast to save America from a Japanese extremist. 5 5 4 THE GOLDEN ORANGE, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow, $19.95.) Murder and chicanery amid the yachts and mansions of California's Orange County. 6 7 5 AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Manners, morals and murder in Los Angeles's high society. 7 6 13 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) On her 33d birthday, the private eye Kinsey Millhone finds herself on the hit list of a killer she once tracked down. 14 12 10 MASQUERADE, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A New Orleans heiress encounters a masked man during a carnival in Nice. 15 14 9 THE EVENING NEWS, by Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Life as lived by two competitive television correspondents. The political pundit and baseball buff describes the craft of the game. 2 7 2 DAVE BARRY TURNS 40, by Dave Barry. (Crown, $16.95.) Reflections on the crises of middle age by the syndicated humorist. 3 2 20 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Morrow, $21.95.) Prognostications for the next decade. 4 3 20 BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. 5 5 83 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays. 6 6 38 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. 7 8 31 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $19.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's. 8 4 7 IN THE ARENA, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The 37th President reflects on his public career and private life. 9 11 18 HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the body's endocrine and immune systems. 10 1 FATHER SON & CO., by Thomas J. Watson Jr. and Peter Petre. (Bantam, $22.95.) The autobiography of the man who succeeded his father as head of I.B.M. 11 10 6 FLASHBACKS, by Morley Safer. (Random House, $18.95.) The observations of a journalist on revisiting Vietnam 25 years later. 12 12 16 WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) The memoirs of a former Presidential speechwriter. 13 14 6 LEGACIES, by Bette Bao Lord. (Knopf, $19.95.) Reflections on the Chinese experience during the past quarter-century. 14 * 1 DON'T SHOOT, IT'S ONLY ME, by Bob Hope with Melville Shavelson. (Putnam, $19.95.) The comedian reminisces about more than 50 years in show business. 15 15 112 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 16 * 13 12 MEANS OF ASCENT, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $24.95.) Lyndon Johnson's seven-year pursuit of a seat in the Senate, won in 1948 by 87 votes. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 26 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 2 2 69 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 3 3 179 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work, revised and updated. 4 4 23 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 5 5 16 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business.

title: Mothers: Tired of Taking the Rap
description: INfant colic,'' i remember a child psychopathology professor in graduate school casually asserting one day, ''develops when mothers are having problems with their maternal role.'' The professor was unmarried and had never mothered, but I copied the comment down. If an experienced child therapist connected colic to a maternal deficit, I had no reason to question her. Most of us in the class were young and childless, though there was one student who had two young children. And one had had infant colic. I remember her face flushing as she leaned over to whisper to a woman seated next to her, and then her hand going up. ''My child had colic,'' she said. ''It had nothing to do with my feelings.''

title: Same Time, Different Place
description: To the Editor:
