description: As this country prepares for the final round of its first multiparty parliamentary elections in more than four decades, scheduled for Sunday, a broad political chasm separates supporters of the renamed Communist Party and backers of the anti-Communist opposition.

title: Late Gain of 7.67 Puts Dow at Record High
description: The stock market yesterday weathered the uncertainties of its ''triple witching hour,'' a weak bond market and disparate economic reports as the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a last-minute gain of 7.67 points to set a record high in strong volume.

title: 2 Lead By 2 Shots In L.P.G.A.
description: The winds were higher during the afternoon in the second round of the Atlantic City Classic today and the scores followed suit.

title: RESULT PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Thursday about Jerome Robbins's ''Watermill'' at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center misidentified the male dancer in the duet. He was Brian Reeder, not Robert Lyon.

title: In Consumer's World: Air Bags, Pill Bottles
description: Auto makers are planning to put air bags in more models - at $1,000 each - and install them on the passenger side as well as the driver's side. In addition, air bags and automatic seat belts will become more common in pickup trucks, minivans and sport and utility vehicles.

title: Holtzman Haste, Albany Urgency
description: New York City was bound to have a rough time getting the State Legislature to authorize its package of new and higher taxes. But this week, because of a remarkably clumsy move by the new City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, the task got harder still. Now, unless Albany quickly meets its responsibility, the city is likely to miss the June 30 deadline for a new budget. That would create new fiscal problems and ultimately hurt the city's credit standing.

title: I.B.M.-Kodak Venture Set
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that they had formed an alliance to develop advanced publishing systems for newspapers and magazines.

title: Author Is Told To Pay Millions For '81 Slaying
description: A Manhattan jury awarded $7.57 million in damages yesterday to the widow of a young aspiring actor who was stabbed to death nine years ago outside an East Village restaurant by the jailhouse author Jack Henry Abbott.

title: Critics Notebook;   Laurel With and Without Hardy
description: ''Officer,'' says Uncle Piedmont (Oliver Hardy), both haughty and embarrassed, ''make those people stop laughing at my nephew.''

title: BUSH AIDE OPPOSES SANCTIONS ON IRAQ
description: While strongly criticizing the Iraqi Government for its human rights record and foreign policy, a senior Bush Administration official urged Congress today to resist growing sentiment among legislators to apply economic sanctions against the Government of President Saddam Hussein.

title: 'If I Could Be HIV Positive, Any Woman Can';   Food-Handling Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Financing Unit Established by Nissan
description: The Nissan Motor Company today established an American-based corporate finance unit, Nissan Capital of America Inc., opening a new channel for raising money to expand its activities here.

title: Welch Wins 7th in Row as A's Hold Off White Sox, 5-4
description: The Oakland Athletics, five outs away from dropping out of first place in the American League West, got two-run hits from Dave Henderson and Terry Steinbach tonight in an eighth-inning rally and slowed the surging Chicago White Sox, 5-4.

title: William Casey, 76, Theology Professor And Jesuit Educator
description: The Rev. William Van Etten Casey, a former academic vice president of Boston College and later professor of theology at Holy Cross College, died Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 76 years old.

title: Import Fall Narrows Trade Gap
description: As a softer economy cut demand for imports, the trade deficit fell 17 percent in April, to $6.94 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the second-lowest level in more than six years.

title: Writers Sue Computer Maker Over Injuries
description: Seven writers and an editor from different news organizations filed a $270 million product liability suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday against Atex, Inc. claiming the company's computer system they used on the job had caused them personal injuries.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Mortgage Rates
description: Mortgage lending rates, which were up earlier this year after falling at the close of 1989, have dropped sharply in the last month. If you are in the market for a mortgage loan, the Federal National Mortgage Association says there is plenty of mortgage money available. However, you can expect to be asked to come up with a larger down payment and more documents to show the sources of your income. Here are average rates from a sample of lenders across the country. They exclude points and fees. $ Mortgages Current Rate A Year Ago 30-Year Fixed 10.10% 10.20% One-Year Adjustable 8.50% 9.09% Two-Step (Fixed rate first 9.75% 9.825% 7 years; adjusted once.)

title: Laura Lord Scale, Retired Dean, 110
description: Laura Lord Scales, a former dean of Smith College and its oldest graduate, died Tuesday at a retirement home in Northampton. She was 110 years old.

title: Consumer Prices Show Modest Rise
description: Consumer prices rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in May, the second straight month of modest inflation after a first-quarter surge that is now clearly seen to have been an aberration.

title: Guetterman Loses Battle and Yanks Lose, Too
description: Lee Guetterman could not sustain the dramatics, missing by an inch or so last night. And so the Yankees extended their sorry American League record by bowing, 5-4, to the Eastern Division leaders, the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Soviets Assail Refereeing
description: Soviet soccer officials today protested what they called biased refereeing in the World Cup matches of the Soviet team, which has been virtually eliminated from the tournament. The protest was made to FIFA, soccer's international governing body.

title: Law Firm for Lincoln To Pay to Settle Suits
description: The main law firm representing the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association agreed today to pay $20 million to settle two securities-fraud and racketeering lawsuits brought by investors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, which makes appliances, said its Sunbeam Corp. (Canada) Ltd. unit would consolidate some operations of its Solaray and Sunbeam divisions in Toronto by the end of the year.

title: Joyce Typescript Moves to Texas
description: A typescript of the opening chapter of James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake,'' with the author's additions written in by hand, has turned up in Texas after being discovered in a private collection last year in Paris.

title: THE TRUMP EMPIRE
description: Debt payments due yesterday on Trump's Castle and Bank loans were not made.

title: Miss Katz Weds Robert Kasanof
description: Stephanie S. Katz, a psychotherapist, was married yesterday to Robert Kasanof, the chairman of the New York City Board of Correction, at the home of Yolanda Mestre, a friend of the couple, in Valle de Bravo, Mexico. Judge Mario O. Alvarez of the Civil Court of Valle de Bravo officiated.

title: Florio Battling For Fiscal Plan In Radio Appeal
description: Gov. Jim Florio began an unusual radio campaign today to win the hearts and minds of middle-class voters in New Jersey as political pressures mounted for a crucial vote in the Legislature next week on his plans to raise taxes and drastically change the way state spends money on schoolchildren.

title: Pakistan Fans Flames of Kashmir Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Krishna Procession, Fifth Avenue from 59th Street to Washington Square Park will be closed today from noon until about 3 P.M.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanians Ponder Burst of Violence
description: Ion Ratiu, an opposition leader in the Romanian Parliament, surveyed the wreckage left by a band of marauding miners who occupied his house on Thursday. Amid the papers strewn across the floor, the broken pictures and the ripped-open boxes, he pondered his next step.

title: Lewis Blasts to a Victory Over Witherspoon in 100
description: The sports director of KHYS-FM in Houston was up at 4:30 this morning to tape his 7:20 and 8:20 A.M. shows. He talked about the National Basketball Association playoffs, gave the baseball scores and told how good he felt after running his first real races in nine months.

title: Executive Raises Stake in Ultimate
description: Norman Elowitz, a New York fashion executive, has raised his stake in the Ultimate Corporation to 8.4 percent from 7.2 percent. Between May 1 and June 5, Mr. Elowitz bought 64,500 shares for $5.25 to $7.125 each. The company's stock slipped 25 cents today, to $6.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Visa Loses British Suit
description: A high court judge today backed the Government's plan to allow retailers to charge cash customers less than those who use credit cards.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Newtown Creek sewage treatment plant in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the area it serves. It accepts waste from much of northern Brooklyn, but not from downtown Brooklyn.

title: Ballesteros Rediscovers Magic Wand
description: Someday there should be a golf museum to celebrate Seve Ballesteros the magician. His wedge out of a parking lot to the 16th green at Royal Lytham and St. Anne's in winning the 1979 British Open. His 7-iron over a leaderboard to the 17th green at Augusta National in winning the 1980 Masters. His birdie 3, eagle 3, par 4, birdie 2 start in the final round in winning the 1983 Masters. His bag of tricks in creating so many other improbable shots.

title: 'Junk Bonds' for Casino Fall On News of Missed Payment
description: ''Junk bonds'' of casinos owned by Donald J. Trump fell sharply yesterday on the news of a missed interest payment to holders of two junk bond issues by Trump's Castle. But the decline did not spill over into the rest of the market for low-rated bonds, where traders called the action quiet.

title: Hispanic Growth in California Makes State a Testing Ground
description: The vibrant prosperity of California has drawn and rewarded many waves of migrants, both American and foreign, but some see a gloomy alternative prospect if more is not done to absorb the state's fast-growing Hispanic work force.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the retirement of Bertram A. Powers as president of the New York Typographical Union misidentified his successor in some copies. He is James Grottola, not Grattola.

title: Executive Charged With Selling 'Star Wars' Data
description: A software company executive was arrested today after allegedly selling ''Star Wars'' technology to a Federal agent posing as a buyer for South Africa.

title: Inside
description: Romanians Take Stock

title: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Supporter Voted Russian Premier
description: A national bureaucrat was elected Prime Minister of the Russian republic today, defeating an ally of the republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Baking Soda Maker Strikes Again
description: Nearly 150 years after the family-run business that became the Church & Dwight Company began making baking soda, a new and more aggressive management and the environmental movement are breathing new life into the company's famous Arm & Hammer trademark.

title: Brooklyn's Representative Renamed to School Board
description: Despite indications that he was considering new candidates for the Board of Education, Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn yesterday reappointed Dr. Irene H. Impellizzeri, who has served on the board for the last 10 years.

title: About New York;   At Age 98.6, Love and Laughs In Large Supply
description: ''A lot has changed since 1891,'' remarked Sigmund Sternfeld, sipping a whiskey sour.

title: Two Citibank Couriers Held in Aborted Heist
description: Two couriers for Citibank were arrested yesterday on charges implicating them in an aborted bank robbery in Manhattan on Wednesday that ended in a shootout with bank guards. One suspect died, another was arrested and a guard was wounded in the incident.

title: Who's Afraid of Foreign Ideas?
description: Exposure to Western ideas helped undermine Communism in Eastern Europe. So it's scarcely surprising that Communist regimes in Cuba, North Korea and Vietnam now worry about infection from Western visitors, cultural imports and educational exchanges. Perversely, U.S. law helps hard-liners exclude American ideas by restricting the right of Americans to travel to these lands.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Exhausted by their revels on the party circuit this spring, organizers of the annual gala to benefit MERCE CUNNINGHAM's dance company had an idea: would-be patrons are being invited to stay at home and watch Mr. Cunningham's video ''Changing Steps.'' For a $300 donation, they get a free copy.

title: Pathe Again Extends Offer for MGM/UA
description: The Pathe Communications Corporation said yesterday that it was again extending its $1.2 billion offer for of MGM/UA Communications.

title: Contel to Offer 900 Early Retirement
description: The Contel Corporation said it was offering early retirement to about 900 employees in a previously announced cost-cutting program. The company said it was using the program to avoid layoffs while reducing its work force. Under the plan, a retirement ''window'' will be created in July, during which retiring employees will have three years added each to their ages and to their service dates in determining individual benefits.

title: Financial Decontrol in Japan Slowed by Negative Report
description: A long-awaited report on furthering financial deregulation in Japan was released by the Ministry of Finance today, but if anything it struck a blow against swift progress by supporting continuing protection for the securities industry against competition from banks.

title: Clerics at Odds on Excommunication for Abortion
description: Roman Catholic clergymen and scholars are voicing widely varying views on John Cardinal O'Connor's warning to Roman Catholic politicians that they risk excommunication if they persist in supporting a woman's right to abortion.

title: Pistons Get a Taste Of N.B.A. History
description: One championship was not enough to satisfy the Detroit Pistons' thirst for winning, their thirst for respect or their thirst for a place in history.

title: KENNEDY CENTER NAMES A TV CHIEF
description: James D. Wolfensohn, chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, has announced the appointment of Carolyn Reynolds as director of television and special projects. The position is new; the only regularly scheduled Kennedy Center television program in the past has been the annual Kennedy Center Honors show.

title: Iranian Accord With Amoco Lifts a Barrier to U.S. Trade
description: Iran removed one of the biggest obstacles to a renewal of trade with the United States today by agreeing to pay an American oil company $600 million for installations seized in the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: No Word for Harrison On Tony Broadcast
description: To the Editor:

title: Praising Mandela, Dinkins Shakes Fragile Coalition
description: For David N. Dinkins, political tempests over the approaching visit of Nelson Mandela have proved again just how hard it is to hold together the tiles of the city that the Mayor never tires of calling a gorgeous mosaic.

title: Patents;   New Frozen Dessert Is Based on Rhubarb
description: Using rhubarb, sugar and fruits, an inventor in New York City has patented a frozen dessert that he said tastes like ice cream but contains no fats or cholesterol and about one-third as many calories.

title: Sri Lanka Rebels Raid Vital Airfield in North
description: Tamil rebels today fired mortars at a vital airfield in the Jaffna peninsula at the north of this island nation, minutes after a Government minister had left at the end of a round of peace talks, military officials said.

title: Your Money;   'Junk Bond' Funds Seem to Glimmer
description: ''Junk Bond'' funds, after a bruising first quarter, seem to be on the mend. And with high-yield, high-risk funds making money in the last couple of months, instead of losing it, more investors are buying fund shares than redeeming them.

title: U.S. TO BACK FUND TO PROTECT OZONE
description: Reversing a policy decision, the White House said today that it would support a new international fund to help poorer countries phase out chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone layer.

title: Louise Howlett, Chaplain, Weds
description: The Rev. Louise Howlett and G. Lindsay Brown were married yesterday at the Williams College Chapel in Williamstown, Mass., by the Rev. Kenneth Coleman, an Episcopal minister.

title: Ryszard Cieslak, Actor, 53
description: Ryszard Cieslak, an actor and a central figure in the Polish Laboratory Theater, died Thursday at the Burzynski Research Institute in Houston. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patents;   A No-Needle Method For Inoculating Eggs
description: In an attempt to help newborn chicks ward off contagious illness, two researchers at Iowa State University have invented a method for inoculating unhatched eggs without puncturing them with needles.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES A BILL AND MAKES THREAT ON SECOND
description: President Bush today vetoed a bill that would have relaxed restrictions on partisan political activity by Federal workers. The White House said Mr. Bush would also veto another hotly debated piece of legislation mandating unpaid leave for workers with new babies or facing a family emergency.

title: Clyde Allison Jr., 31, A Manhattan Lawyer
description: Clyde H. Allison Jr., a former special counsel to the Congressional subcommittee investigating allegations of mismanagement at the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan Administration, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 31 years old. Mr. Allision died in his sleep, apparently of a stroke, said Martin London, a partner in the Manhattan firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, where Mr. Allison was an associate.

title: Joe Wright, Civil Rights Protester In North Carolina, Is Dead at 37
description: Joe Wright, one of 10 people whose arrests and jailing for the firebombing of a grocery store became a rallying point for the civil rights movement, died on Wednesday at Hanover Memorial Hospital here. He was 37 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1990
description: Companies

title: Review Set on Harrods
description: The British conglomerate Lonrho said today that it had been granted permission for a new court challenge in connection with its failed effort to take over Harrods, the London luxury department store.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East Germans Seize 4 Tied to Terror in West
description: The East German police said today that they had arrested four more people suspected of being West German terrorists.

title: Tyson in (New) Shape
description: Some big questions about Mike Tyson remain to be answered as he prepares for his first bout since he lost his heavyweight title to James (Buster) Douglas in February in Tokyo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want a sacred Nicaragua, which instead of burying its sons in a war between brothers will forever bury its arms so that the cannons will never roar again.'' - President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. [1:5.]

title: Island's Hushed Scandals, Unhushed
description: After years of hushed scandals that failed to spoil the calm of this tourist haven, the discovery that a shipment of Israeli arms was sent through Antigua on its way to Colombian drug traffickers has shaken the nearly five-decade dominion of Prime Minister Vere C. Bird.

title: When a Tick Takes a Bite
description: When you spend time outdoors this summer, a real concern should be ticks that might carry Lyme disease. If you are bitten, removing the tick or ticks quickly and cleanly is vital, but can be a problem. A new instrument, the Tick Solution, makes it easier to remove the pinhead-size deer ticks that spread the disease, thus decreasing the possibility of further infection.

title: Chrysler Pact With Honda To Sell Jeeps
description: The Honda Motor Company Ltd. has agreed to make part of its dealer network in Japan available to the Chrysler Corporation to sell two Jeep sport-utility vehicles, the companies said today.

title: Holyfield Sends Manager Packing
description: Evander Holyfield, who is scheduled to fight James (Buster) Douglas in September for the heavyweight title, said yesterday that he had dismissed his manager, Ken Sanders.

title: Second Manuscript Turns Up in German Hands
description: A second illuminated manuscript from the hoard of medieval treasures stolen from the German town of Quedlinburg in the closing days of World War II has just been sold to a West German art dealer.

title: Lobster Dealer Guilty in Insurance Plot
description: The president of the largest offshore lobster business in Connecticut, James P. Garbo, was found guilty today of scheming with a captain to sink a company boat to collect $270,000 in insurance.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Final Months of Berlin Wall
description: East Germany has set a deadline of December for total demolition of the Berlin wall, which sealed citizens off from the West for 28 years. The state press agency quoted Maj. Gen. Dieter Teichmann, chief of the border troops, as saying that the concrete barrier would be gone by December. On Wednesday, East Germans began knocking out wall slabs all over the city to reopen blocked streets.

title: PAYMENT DEADLINE MISSED BY TRUMP, BUT TALKS GO ON
description: Donald J. Trump failed to pay about $73 million that was due yesterday to banks and bondholders, but bankers said substantial progress was made during the day on a deal to provide new loans to keep the Trump empire afloat.

title: Harry F. Bliss Jr., 75, Executive at Cyanamid
description: Harry F. Bliss Jr., a former president of the international division of the American Cyanamid Company, died last Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 75 years old. His family said he died from bone cancer.

title: Undersea Police Protect Fragile Reef Off Florida
description: Reef rangers prowl the depths here, armed with grease pencils, plastic slates and scuba tanks, ticketing any who abuse the fragile coral heads that make up the third largest barrier reef in the world and the only one in the continental United States.

title: Nine Hours, Nine Killings, No Answers
description: At 3 P.M., 14-year-old Shawn Chapman saw two friends being harassed by another teen-ager on a Bronx street. He tried to intercede. Without a word, the teen-ager pulled out a revolver and shot him.

title: Tim Simpson Leads as Records Fall at Open
description: Like a groggy prizefighter struggling to recover from a brutal knockdown, Medinah continued to take a pummeling from the world's best players today as record scores mounted up after two rounds of the 90th United States Open.

title: Braniff Asset Sale Brings $59 Million
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved bids totaling $59 million for Braniff Inc.'s most valuable assets. The airline, based in Orlando, is liquidating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code and has received $7 million more than originally planned for the assets.

title: Western Union Plan Approved
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a plan by the Western Union Corporation to swap $530 million in debt for new notes and stock in an effort to avert bankruptcy.

title: FLASH FLOODS KILL AT LEAST 11 IN OHIO
description: Torrential thunderstorms sent a flash flood surging through a valley and into this Ohio River town Thursday night, killing at least 11 people and leaving dozens missing and dozens more Homeless.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: 'If I Could Be HIV Positive, Any Woman Can'
description: To the Editor:

title: Guy Paulin Is Dead; Clothes Designer, 44, Created Casual Style
description: Guy Paulin, the Parisian fashion designer, died on Wednesday at Pitie-Salpetriere hospital in Paris. He was 44 years old. The cause of death was not made public.

title: CHANCES SEEM DIM ON CANADIAN PACT
description: With about a week to go before a June 23 deadline, Canada's chances of approving a package of constitutional measures to keep Quebec in the confederation appear to be diminishing.

title: Slaney, 'Not Fit to Race,' Bows Out
description: It was uncharacteristic. It was almost embarrassing. But it could have been predicted. To be brutal, Mary Decker Slaney, the best middle-distance runner in American track history, looked awful Friday night in the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships. She barely qualified for tonight's 1,500-meter final, and she decided not to run.

title: Lee R. Jamieson Becomes a Bride
description: Lee Reddan Jamieson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Jamieson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday at the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School to Ronald Jerome Kane Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kane of Princeton. The Rev. Michael J. Maruca, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on June 3 about Katmandu, Nepal, misstated the address of one of two craft shops named Haftakala. The store near the Annapurna Hotel coffee shop is on Durbar Marg.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: Only on the Nets is a breakaway dunk an iffy proposition. The Nets need to get the best shooter they can. Thank God that Harry Weltman is gone. At least we know the Nets won't use the pick to trade for Keith Lee again.

title: Cape Cod
description: To the Editor: As an avid Cape Cod auction goer and bargain hunter, I enjoyed the article on Cape Cod auctions (Travel, May 13). Unfortunately, you did not mention the Eastham Auction House (Holmes Road, North Eastham; 508-255-9003). They run monthly antiques auctions in the summer, have their share of bargains and, in Bill Fidalgo, easily the cape's most entertaining auctioneer.

title:
DINING OUT;

A New Italian Spot Opens in Ossining
description: LEAD: GUIDA'S does not, at this time, quite live up to the classy dining room created originally for the now defunct Cafe Keenan. We hope that with some reworking of its overly ambious menu, Guida's will be more deserving of its suave surroundings - the subtle cream-and-peach color scheme, the gilt mirrors and the soft lighting of the lofty main dining room.

title: Cakes, All Kinds of Cakes, From Casual to the Computerized
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY! To the greatest dad...Congratulations to the graduate!

title: FICTION
description: PIRATE JENNY. By April Bernard. (Norton, $18.95.) Can a teen-age girl obsessed with Bertolt Brecht, Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya survive on the streets of Manhattan? The amoral antiheroine of this frustrating first novel by the poet April Bernard is immediately familiar: bored, alienated Connie Frances LaPlante is the product of a broken home in a dull New England town. Taking drugs and stealing pass the time until, ''enticed by the sinful looks of the striped skirts and rouged faces on the cover,'' she discovers a recording of ''The Threepenny Opera'' in the local library. The music ''was like absolutely nothing she ever heard before - a raggedy, wild sound'' with ''dark, fast ballads advertising a life of theft and agility.'' Especially entranced with Lenya's devilishly droll singing of ''Pirate Jenny,'' Connie transforms herself into a ludicrous caricature of Brecht's cynical demimondaine, renaming herself Jenny Freuhoffer. As Jenny, Connie affects a ''Cherman'' accent, steals her mother's car, pockets her boyfriend's buddy's money, robs a shopping mall for clothes, has her hair dyed blood red and lights out for the big bad city. There, in what we would expect to be a comedy of errors, Jenny slinks into New York society; what we get, unfortunately, is an unsavory rogue's progress as Jenny victimizes friends and foes alike. A temporary job assisting a catered birthday party for rich Upper East Side brats leads her to a full-time position as governess to a creaky family of bigoted White Russians, whom she milks for everything she can get. She lets her elderly employer fondle her so she can investigate the family finances. He gives her money for classes, which she uses as an excuse to leave the house and haunt the city's sleazier corners. She seduces the spoiled older granddaughter's gutless boyfriend and rifles the family's possessions, carrying on with such chilly disregard that, like a character from Brecht, she begins to evoke a rakish charm. But when her sad-sack mother eventually tracks her down, roguery gives way to villainy, blackmail and a capricious marriage. ''Pirate Jenny'' ends on a nihilistic downbeat with Ms. Bernard's heroine neither paying for her crimes nor deriving wisdom from her experiences. She merely survives: a pirate in a world of easy, eager victims.

title: James Bell Weds Miss Whittemore
description: Jeannette L. Whittemore, the daughter of Dr. Jeanne M. Whittemore of Stamford, Conn., and the late Edward W. Whittemore, was married yesterday to James W. Bell, the son of Doris Bell of Framingham, Mass., and the late Walter Bell. The Rev. Edward Wright performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Flying Cloud Farm in Petaluma, Calif.

title: Mt. Sinai Deal Causing Concern
description: Your recent article concerning bulldozing of state-owned land (''Mount Sinai Enraged by Dispute Over Land,'' May 20) failed to include that only the residents and civic associations of the neighboring communities, not the State of New York (the land owner), are concerned about the raping of the environment that took place on this property.

title: Facing Prejudice In the Suburbs
description: I am responding to Mary C. Curtis's article, ''That Awful Question at the Store'' (Opinion page, April 29). How saddened I was to read this poignant article on discrimination.

title: Soviet Jews In U.S. Don Blue Collars
description: For 15 years, Rafail Fishman taught violin, and his wife, Shelya, taught piano in a high school for talented youths in the Black Sea city of Odessa. But when they emigrated from the Soviet Union last year, they soon learned that there was no demand for Ukrainian music teachers in New York City.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

He Set an Example, Unknowingly
description: LEAD: ''IF you would learn to turn off a light once in a while, we wouldn't need all these nuclear plants.'' Such were the words from a man who never wore the badge of ''environmentalist'' to me, his son, a college-aged opponent of the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: FICTION
description: SECONDS. By Lois Wyse. (Crown, $19.95.) Leave the tough times to the first wife, Lois Wyse's contemporary fairy tale asserts. Let her suffer her husband's arduous climb to the top. Then, when she exits (or is dumped), move in and pick up his wealthy pieces. The smart ones are the ''Seconds.'' Here they are Sienna, Anne and Bronwyn, second wives of men with billion-dollar fortunes and hopes of becoming ambassadors. These fortyish women learn that ''the best job for a very smart woman was marriage to a very successful man,'' a lesson passed along by a widow named Virginia Payne North, who has made them her protegees in social climbing. But while each of the ''seconds'' is enterprising and grows wealthy in her own right, they all share a haunting guilt over a tragedy that occurred many years earlier at a camp for troubled teen-agers. The camp's director, Gregory Sawyer, who has ''made a living out of being sensitive to rich women's needs,'' re-enters their lives to prey on Virginia by blackmailing her three friends. Will Gregory wreck their opulent new lives? Can they continue to reign at New York's most chic charity luncheons? Unless you're fascinated by the life styles of the rich and liposuctioned, you may not want to know. But just when you're ready to hurl this paean to ulteriority and the Junk Bond Generation aside, redemption seeps in, in the form of love. Sienna does love her husband, the only worthy man in the book. Anne, whose ''carefully nursemaided'' children were taught ''not to expect their parents more than twice a week,'' begins to nurture them. Bronwyn pursues a dream of romance. Ms. Wyse, an advertising executive who is the author of several nonfiction books, provides a warm, if slick and predictable turn to a novel that seems tailor-made for its own second life as a television mini-series.

title: An Album is Judged Obscene;   Rap: Slick, Violent, Nasty and, Maybe Hopeful
description: RAP music now has a criminal record. On June 6, United States District Court Judge Jose Gonzalez of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., declared that ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' an album by the 2 Live Crew, a rap group that is based in Miami, was obscene in the three counties under his jurisdiction, making it the first recording to be declared obscene by a Federal court. In the next few days, a record-store owner who had continued to sell the album was arrested; two members of the group were also arrested for performing one of the album's songs before an adults-only audience.

title: Deirdre A. Lowe Becomes a Bride
description: Deirdre A. Lowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Lowe Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher C. Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Burke of Chelmsford, Mass. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel.

description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Aide Has Heart Attack
description: Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, has apparently suffered a slight heart attack, doctors reported today. Mr. Levy, a 52-year-old Likud bloc member who is seen as a possible successor to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, arrived at a hospital in northern Israel on Thursday from his home in Beit Shean. He was placed in the cardiac intensive care unit, and his condition was described as good.

title: Bill Against Condo-Conversion Evictions Debated
description: A BATTLE pitting landlords against tenants is coming to a climax after five years of conflict as efforts are under way to win final agreement on a bill that aims to prevent the eviction of thousands of tenants in condominium conversions.

title: JUST PLAIN FOLK: THE ART OF EVERYDAY OBJECTS
description: Barry Cohen's 30-year-long involvement with American 19th-century folk art was reflected in the artworks he constructed and the artifacts he collected.

description: LEAD: $'GODSPELL' IN MONTCLAIR

description: HEMINGWAY'S SUITCASEBy MacDonald Harris.

title: Kezia Keeble, 48, a Top Publicist And Shaper of American Fashion
description: Kezia Keeble, a former Vogue editor and a powerful public-relations executive who helped reshape the image of American fashion, died at her home in Manhattan on Friday night.

title: Quick Help for Lost Motorists
description: Ask anyone who knows me and you will be told that I have a serious problem at the wheel: I get lost a lot.

title: Dr. Cimino Weds V. J. Gandolfo Jr.
description: Dr. Lisa H. Cimino, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Cimino of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Vincent J. Gandolfo Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gandolfo of Newton Centre, Mass.Msgr. Stephen J. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Mary Magdalene in Pocantico Hills.

title: YOUNG, GIFTED AND COOL
description: Just what we need - more jazz hype (''Young, Gifted and Cool,'' by Tom Piazza, May 20). When will this country begin to take its native art form seriously? There are improvisers who have lived in relative obscurity because they refused to electrify or pander to the fortissimo tastes of the rock-weaned generation (the late Warne Marsh and the very much alive and still-recording Sal Mosca, to name but two).

title: A Teacher Handles History as He Rolls Out His Barrels
description: LEAD: THE mailbox at Jack Culbert's home in Monroe is perched atop a large barrel. The seats and table on his back porch are made of barrels. His home is filled with barrels, which, in turn, are filled with plants, toys, onions, potatoes, books and magazines.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MAPLE MOOR GOLF COURSE;

The Sun Rises on a New Sign-Up System
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES, it is just easier to sleep at the golf course. Jack O'Shaugnessy, a banker from Harrison, does just that. ''I get here at 3, 4 in the morning,'' he said one recent foggy dawn at Maple Moor, one of the five courses run by the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. ''I sleep in the car.

title: Fathers Must Earn Their 'Rights'
description: LEAD: The anti-abortion bill vetoed by Gov. Cecil D. Andrus of Idaho contained a clause giving an embryo's biological father the right to get a court order preventing the termination of a woman's pregnancy - even if the man had raped her.

title: BLUEPRINT AN AIRPORT THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN
description: Few airports are architectural masterworks, but most are barely even tolerable as public environments. Harsh, cold, unrelentingly grim, they are designed more for the convenience of their tenants, the airlines, than for the pleasure of their users, the passengers. How often is it that people linger at airports longer than they have to, as they once did at train stations? Great train stations are celebrations of the ceremony of arrival and departure; airports are machines for shuffling people around.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Daughter Holds a Mirror On a Thorough Man
description: LEAD: ''IF Mommie and Daddy got divorced,'' my sister asked me when I was 8 years old, ''who would you go with?''

title: VOICES AT THE WALL
description: Whenever I read about the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, I am reminded of the negative uproar Yale architectural student Maya Lin's design generated when it was first revealed in 1981 (''Memorial Day 1990: Voices at the Wall,'' by Michael Norman, May 27). Many Vietnam veterans demanded a more traditional monument - a realistic statue similar to those erected for other American conflicts. They won approval for the bronze monument of three comrades-in-arms that now faces the wall, even as Lin's polished black granite wall was being erected.

title: Fact That Outperforms Fiction
description: The corporate nose has never been tweaked, or its leg pulled, to such serious and delirious effect as it is in Michael Moore's instant classic, ROGER AND ME (1989, Warner, $89.95). The brilliant feature-length documentary is now available on a videocassette that looks almost as mint-fresh as the movie.

title: The Long and Short of the N.B.A. Finals
description: The recently concluded National Basketball Association season was too long.

title: A Woman's View On Love's Trials - And Hold the Tears
description: The recording business rediscovered female singer-songwriters in the 1980's when an assortment of oddballs broke through to reinvent pop's female points of view. The Pretenders, the Eurythmics and Sinead O'Connor made a dent in rock; Madonna and Janet Jackson burned up the dance charts; Suzanne Vega, Tracy Chapman, 10,000 Maniacs (led by Natalie Merchant) and Edie Brickell revitalized folky introspection. Now, however, comes the follow-up and bandwagon-jumping, as record moguls dream of the tame, best-selling ''mellow'' songwriters of the early 1970's. Lately there has been a wave of wispy-voiced women (Wendy MaHarry, Lori Carson, the Sundays) musing over small sufferings or calling out to straying lovers or remembering lost innocence in stereotypically feminine ways.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions on page 14 of The Long Island Weekly today about plans for the former Roosevelt Raceway property are reversed. The upper picture shows a scale model of the raceway project, and the lower photograph shows plans for a mall and the renovation of a Fortunoff store.

title: The Region;   Why It Costs So Much To Run New York State
description: WHEN New York State's politicians hit the campaign trail this summer, voters can expect to hear some nasty exchanges about the state's financial problems. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is already blaming the difficulties on a national economic slowdown presided over by a Republican President. And the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, is almost certain to attribute them to years of overspending under Democratic governors.

title: As Artists Saw the L.I. Landscape
description: LEAD: OVER the years, the Long Island landscape has meant different things to different artists. For example:

title: Edwin Ayscue 3d Weds Ms. Mahoney
description: Kathleen Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Mahoney of North Hampton, N.H., was married yesterday in Exeter, N.H., to Edwin Osborne Ayscue 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ayscue Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Daniel J. Mahoney, a Roman Catholic, and the Rt. Rev. Frank H. Vest Jr., an Episcopalian, officiated at the Phillips Church at Phillips Exeter Academy. The bride and her husband are Exeter graduates.

title: In Job Interviews, Both Sides Have Rights
description: THE thousands of college graduates who start touring personnel offices this month should know their rights as employees as well as the rights of their prospective employers, says Felix J. Springer, an employment litigation specialist in the Hartford law firm of Day, Berry & Howard.

title: For Today's Fathers, Their Holiday Seems a Bit Set in Its Ways
description: Poor dad. He just wants to stretch out on a hammock and watch the clouds roll by. But no one will leave him alone. Not today.

title: Reflections on the Family for Father's Day;   Isolated and Disaffected
description: To the Editor:

title: READ HIS LIPS: NO MORE TAXES
description: If Gov. Jim Florio needs more money to run New Jersey, why doesn't he get it from his constituents who live in New Jersey but work across the river (''Read His Lips: More Taxes,'' by Peter Kerr, May 20)? It's not hard to find people in New Jersey earning $100,000 in New York City. The irony is that they pay (in one instance I know of) $6,000 in state taxes to New York and $400 to New York City, but not one penny to New Jersey. Multiply that by the tens of thousands of people who travel on New Jersey's roads, buses and trains to get to their jobs in New York, and you've got enough for New Jersey to enjoy a surplus position instead of increasing the tax burden on those of us who are already doing more than our share.

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: COMPANIES

title:
Glen Rock Journal;

Borough Fights Costs To Save July 4 Parade
description: LEAD: LONGTIME residents speak fondly of this borough's past Fourth of July celebrations as extravagant affairs. Years ago, they say, spectators thronged the streets of this quiet northwest Bergen County community of 10,800 people to cheer the marching bands and floats at the annual parade and then to join an all-day fair at Memorial Park sponsored by the borough's administration.

title: Equality for Women On the Golf Course
description: I am all for equality for women on the golf course.

title: Sir Richard's Curious Career
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rental Market Loosens Up a Bit
description: ACROSS the New York region, there is good news for renters. There are many more apartments and houses available for rent; rents on market-rate units are either stable or falling, and landlords are courting tenants with aggressive promotions.

title: PBS Plans More Time for Candidates
description: Public television is planning to provide air time to Presidential candidates in 1992 as an antidote to the commercials and brief news squibs that now dominate political campaigns.

title: Ex-K.G.B. Officer Asserts Spy Agency Is Unchanged
description: A recently retired senior officer of the K.G.B. appeared today before a gathering of Communist Party insurgents to accuse the leadership of the state security police of a continuing campaign against Soviet nonconformists.

title: Tunis at Impasse on Political Change
description: When word of Algeria's election results began to filter to its neighbor here, the people in the offices at 26 Gamal Abdel Nasser Street and 2 Madrid Avenue began drawing comparisons. While Algeria is pressing ahead with liberalization, they said, Tunisia has halted.

title: Hard-Hitting Pirates Turn Tables on Mets
description: The Mets, who hit .381 in their last eight games and won seven of them, finally got bashed by somebody else tonight: the Pittsburgh Pirates, who outhit them, 15-10, and outscored them, 11-6.

title: Sasha L. Iglehart Wed in Maryland
description: Sasha Lonsdale Iglehart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Corning Iglehart of Glyndon, Md., was married yesterday to Michael Elliot Richardson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot L. Richardson of McLean, Va. The Rev. William P. Baxter Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Garrison Forest, Md.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The hot-water heating system in our house is very noisy, especially at night when we are trying to sleep. When the heat comes on, there are annoying gurgling and gushing sounds. Plumbing and heating contractors have told us that we needed a new expansion tank, which we added. The problem continued, however, and so they flushed, purged and ''bled'' air out of the system three times. This helped, but there is still much more noise than there was before. Do you have any suggestions?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Thrill of Working

title: Cynthia Johnson and Patrick Rogers Are Married
description: Cynthia Cole Johnson, a daughter of Mrs. H. Alden Johnson Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Mr. Johnson, was married yesterday in Marblehead to Patrick Joseph Rogers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. John Rogers of Rochester, at the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew. The Rev. Howard W. Gamble Jr. and the Rev. Frederick W. Bush, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Cairns Weds Christian Sampson
description: Megan Clifton Cairns, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Clifton Cairns of Montreal and Prouts Neck, Me., was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck to Dr. Christian Edward Sampson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jennings Sampson of Carlisle, Mass. The Bishop of New Jersey, G. P. Mellick Belshaw, performed the ceremony.

title: Josephine Berrafati Weds
description: Josephine Berrafati, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Berrafati of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday in Harrison, N.Y., to Kevin S. Tice, the son of Mr. and Mrs Donald Tice of Denver. The Rev. John J. Leonard officiated at St. Gregory the Great Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Tice, 26 years old and a graduate of Tufts University, has an M.B.A. from New York University, as does her husband, and is an assistant product manager at the Lehn & Fink household products company in Montvale, N.J. Mr. Tice, 28, a graduate of Colorado State University, is an associate at Salomon Brothers in New York.

title: In Mamaroneck, Softball Under Lights Is a Contest
description: A BITTER, communitywide dispute over the proposed installation of night lighting at a softball field in this village appears to be winding down. But hard feelings between those on either side of the dispute - described as a ''class struggle'' by some residents - may linger, along with anger at the Village Board of Trustees for the way it has handled the matter.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The Fifth Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, played nine days ago in more than 80 countries, fulfilled hopes of its organizers with a record participation of about 88,000. But there were some unusual problems.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Lessons in Building Connecticut Schools
description: IN the wake of the 80's housing boom that brought development to the hinterlands, a surge of school construction has begun, spurred by the coming of age - kindergarten age - of baby-boomers' children.

title: Carmen Chuidian Becomes a Bride
description: Carmen Chuidian, the daughter of Consuelo Sayson of Manila and the late Juan T. Chuidian, was married yesterday in Garrison, N.Y., to Lawrence Hui Cheng Chao, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Chao of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Francis H. Geer officiated at the Bird and Bottle Inn.

title: THE GUIDE
description: SPECTACULAR GARDENS

title: Other Ways at the Shakespeare Festival
description: With the recent naming of JoAnne Akalaitis as artistic associate, and the possibility that she will succeed Joseph Papp as artistic director, the New York Shakespeare Festival has taken a bold step into the future. For years, Ms. Akalaitis, a founding member of the Mabou Mines experimental theater company, has been one of the most innovative - and one of the most controversial - figures in the American theater. Nothing she does is safe and in no sense is she a director in the mainstream.

title: Aftershock in San Francisco
description: In my public-transit youth, i called it the 22 Fellini, the crosstown bus that begins at the edge of San Francisco Bay, in the industrial flatlands that surround China Basin. From there the bus travels west on 16th Street and north on Fillmore, cutting a sociological cross-section of one of the world's more ethnically diverse populations. It rolls first through neighborhoods of Salvadoran, Guatemalan and Honduran refugees (legal and otherwise); catches a corner of the city's gay neighborhood; then crosses Market Street, the wide diagonal that divides the city and operates as the main thoroughfare for its burgeoning population of homeless.

title: Caroline King Becomes Bride of Robert Chang
description: Caroline King, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas King of New York, was married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York to Robert Chang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wei Kong Chang of Livingston, N.J., by the Rev. William H. Pindar.

title: A LITTLE IN LOVE, A LOT DISILLUSIONED
description: LEAD:

title: A Master Glassmaker's Legacy
description: ACKNOWLEDGED as one of the master American glassmakers of the 19th and early 20th centuries, Christian Dorflinger is still remembered in his adopted northeastern Pennsylvania home. He was one of those extraordinary Victorians who dedicated a long life to the perfecting of the craft that he learned as a 10-year-old apprentice in his native Alsace. His legacy of fine cut and engraved glassware can now be better appreciated by admirers of early American glass at the Dorflinger Glass Museum, which opened just west of Hawley, Pa., in May 1989.

title: WIFE LEFT IN '88
description: WINTER VISION

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Fathers Can Be Parents, If They Try
description: LEAD: WHEN I was growing up, looking for the perfect Father's Day tribute meant three choices - vehicles, animals or sports equipment. Fathers were thought of as incompetents on the domestic front, incapable of the simplest household chore. It didn't seem to matter that my dad could cook and clean.

title: Jennie McGregor Weds Andre Bernard
description: Jennie Francis McGregor and Andre Philippe Bernard, book editors in New York, were married yesterday at the Church on the Hill in Lenox, Mass., by the Rev. Douglas L. Moschella Clark, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: Streetscapes: IRT Stations;   Underground Art the Way It Was Meant to Look
description: THIS is an interesting time to tour the older IRT stations in Manhattan. The Wall Street and Astor Place stations and a few others are landmarks and have received fairly intelligent attention, almost restoration.

title: Where Budapest Indulges Its Sweet Tooth
description: HUNGARIAN cuisine is not all paprika and salami. The people of Budapest especially relish tortes, strudels and fine pastry. Their craving for sweets may be a legacy from the Turks who were overlords of the Danubian city for nearly 150 years in the 16th and 17th centuries and are believed to have substituted sugary concoctions for alcohol, which their Muslim faith forbade. Another theory is that Budapest's taste for yummy desserts is due to the influence from nearby Vienna. At their best, the Budapest bakers turn out treats that are as good as those in a first-class Viennese confectionery.

description: Q. The hot-water heating system in our house is very noisy, especially at night when we are trying to sleep. When the heat comes on, there are annoying gurgling and gushing sounds. The problem continued, however, and so they flushed, purged and ''bled'' air out of the system three times. This helped, but there is still much more noise than there was before. title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: REAL FANTASY

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service has announced that four more Olympians will join Jesse Owens on the commemorative issue, July 6. They are Ray Ewry, Hazel Wightman, Eddie Eagan and Helene Madison. The stamps will be printed se-tenant, five in a row, seven rows in a pane.

title: Page P. Vincent Becomes a Bride
description: Page Pendleton Vincent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Vincent Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Duncanson Walker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Walker of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. William Foley officiated at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Plan Heads for First Test
description: LEAD: THE first formal step in a comprehensive $1 billion plan to develop the last massive tract of developable land in Nassau County will be presented to the Hempstead Town Board on Tuesday.

title: The Nation;   The Stakes Are Raised For Catholic Politicians
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York raised the abortion controversy to new heights last week, putting the authority of the church over Roman Catholic politicians on the line with threats of excommunication for any Catholic who persists in supporting a woman's right to abortion.

title: Talking: Rentals;   Bargaining For Better Terms
description: RENTALS used to be in such short supply in the New York area that few people even considered haggling over the advertised rent or lease terms. Renters just assumed that the landlord's offer was carved in granite.

title: Bill on Radon Seeks Testing of Schools
description: MEMBERS of Congress are battling Federal officials over how to protect schoolchildren from radon, which the Federal Environmental Protection Agency ranks among the nation's most serious environmental health hazards.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Today, the highest valued American circulating note is the $100 bill. Congress has even authorized a study to see if discontinuing it and the $50 note would hinder illicit drug transactions.Not too long ago, $50 and $100 bills were considered small potatoes. Notes from the last century and the early part of this one carried denominations of $500, $1,000 and even $5,000. The grandest was the $10,000 note - the largest denomination ever issued by the United States Treasury.

title: Kate Judge Wed To Joseph Longo
description: Kate Judge, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis H. Judge of Seabrook Island, S.C., and Joseph E. Longo, the son of Alberta Longo of Mamaroneck, N.Y., were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Gary P. Fertig.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

GRAND ALEUTIANS
description: LEAD:

title: A NEGATIVE VOTE ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: Shelby Steele is out in ''right'' field in his put down of affirmative-action policy (''A Negative Vote on Affirmative Action,'' May 13). In the past, many affirmative-action programs, while not targeted toward particular ethnic groups, were targeted toward them de facto, through administrative rules and practices. This occurred from the 1920's on in affirmative-action programs relating to worker's compensation, Federal housing policies, Government contracts, mortgage assistance, etc. - a tilt toward white groups that disproportionately excluded blacks well into the 1960's. Of course, affirmative-action programs like the Homestead Act and barn-building legislation in Woodrow Wilson's Administration favored target groups such as farmers.

title: Americans Still Don't Want to Give Up the $1 Bill for a $1 Coin;   Canada's Success Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: Cordelia Pitman Wed to W. J. Furber
description: Cordelia Taylor Pitman was married yesterday to Winslow James Furber. The Rev. Joseph Tyrell, a Roman Catholic, and the Rev. Edward Gammons, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Dick Zuver, in Bay Head, N.J.

title: SPEAKING THE TRUTH
description: DISTURBING THE PEACE

title: A Cup Rehearsal For New Zealand
description: The first of many rehearsals for the next America's Cup match, scheduled for May 1992, has drawn Michael Fay's yachting team to San Diego for the first time since losing the controversial 1988 cup series.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Aren't the Formative Years Wonderful?
description: LEAD: EVEN today, it is most often the mother who is a child's ''primary care-giver.'' She feeds the baby, bathes it, burps it and changes its diapers. And what are the baby's first words? Right: ''Da-Da.''

title: Correction
description: The number for information on the New York Antiquarian Coin Show to be held Saturday is 201 288-3910.

title: Domesticating the 'Ring' For the Home Audience
description: Though Wagner's operatic cycle ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' has been staged repeatedly since its first production at Bayreuth, Bavaria, in 1876, its presentation has never become entirely routine even in the theater. Quite apart from the difficulty of sustaining musical and dramatic continuity through four evenings, each of the operas - ''Das Rheingold,'' in one act lasting 2 3/4 hours, and ''Die Walkure,'' ''Siegfried'' and ''Gotterdammerung'' in three acts running four to five hours - is epic in scope and dimension. Grandeur and romance are of the essence. Excess is in order, expense inevitable.

title:
Focus: California Wineries;

Northern Operations Expand Southward
description: LEAD: THE Kendall-Jackson winery, which has been producing wine in Lakeport, in northern California, for eight years, will open a new operation 320 miles south this August - the first time a Northern California operation has built a winery so far from Napa County. Lakeport, in Lake County, is about 35 miles north of Napa County.

title: Equality for Women On the Golf Course
description: Recent articles have highlighted the question of women's access to golf facilities in New Jersey and the metropolitan area (''Golf on Saturday, but Not for Women,'' Opinion page, March 25, and Letters to the New Jersey Editor, April 29).

title: Thomas Is Named In Betting Report
description: An angry Isiah Thomas denied reports today that he ran high stakes dice games in his home and was the target of a Federal gambling investigation.

title: Style Makers;   Marc Black and Ed Bialek, Creators of Commercials
description: For Marc Black and Ed Bialek, who produce music for commercials, the catchy jingle is passe. They compose musical mantras - music and chants - for such clients as A.T.&T., Converse sneakers and the Mets.

title: Dr. Sheehy Wed To Dale Hamel
description: Dr. Mary Beth Sheehy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Sheehy of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn., to Dale M. Hamel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hamel of Big Rapids, Mich. Canon Charles W. Stubbs officiated.

title: Careers Explored Through Summer Jobs
description: WHEN he was 17 years old and newly graduated from Yonkers High School, Joseph Dahdal landed a summer job as a trainee at McDonald's on South Broadway in Yonkers.

title: Commercial Property: Assessments;   Class B Building Owners Call Tax System Unfair
description: THE owners of secondary commercial properties in New York City - those smaller prewar structures at less-than-choice locations where rents and amenities tend to be low - are banding together to battle tax assessment practices that they believe to be illogical and discriminatory.

title: Czech Nuns Are Leaving Their Decades of Hiding
description: Sister Milada, a Franciscan, did not have a nun's habit to wear yet, and on her nurse's uniform she still displayed the regulation badge that declared, ''We Serve the Health of the Nation,'' topped by a red Communist star. But she and the other nuns of her order have come out of the shadows.

title: DAT Decks Stand Ready for Shipment
description: The free market, as an economic principle, has been gaining new friends in many places lately. But nowhere are unbridled enterprise and competition more evident than at the Consumer Electronics Show held in Chicago every June.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

300 Years of Fanciful Quimperware
description: LEAD: WHO has looked at a Quimper mug and not wanted to hold it? There's something about the earthy, cheerful ware that attracts the touch. In the ancient town of Quimper in westernmost France where the faience is made, there is far more of it - to see, to touch and take home - than in any other place in the world.

title: Mets Blamed Wrong Person
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Of Jobs and Jails
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle;   Killer Croquet Games in Central Park
description: They sauntered across the lawn in their summer whites, armed with mallets and cordial handshakes, prepared for a civil game of killer croquet.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If early spring bulbs are dug up by mistake when planting annuals and perennials, put bulbs back in place promptly as they should reroot and flower next spring. Use water-soluble fertilizer at half-rate on seedlings and window boxes to boost growth and flowering. Pinch back succulent tip growth on chrysanthemums so plants are full to produce abundant fall flowers. Plant beets, chard and carrots for late summer crop. Last call to sow seed of sweet corn, lima and pole beans.

title: Paddlers' Olympic Dreams Ride the Housatonic's Rapids
description: LEAD: TWICE a day, seven days a week, Stephen Dunlap stands on a boulder called Coach's Rock on the banks of the Housatonic River in Falls Village. With a stopwatch or video camera in his hands, he scrutinizes the performances of the half-dozen or more canoeists and kayakers below him, as they manuever their boats upstream and down, through pairs of poles suspended by wire above rushing whitewater.

title: Switchbacks Make a Lively Ride for a New I.B.M. Line
description: The market for the AS/400 family of minicomputers introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation two years ago hasn't exactly developed in a straight line.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Farmingdale $75,000

title: WAR OVER KASHMIR IS FEARED BY U.S.
description: Despite a recent easing in tensions, Bush Administration officials say they are still worried that war could break out between Pakistan and India by early fall unless the two countries take further steps to defuse their confrontation over Kashmir.

title: Caroline Campbell Weds
description: Caroline Cushing Campbell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Campbell Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to John Sanford Bouton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Bouton of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Charles A. Cesaretti officiated. Mrs. Bouton, a freelance artist, graduated from Colgate University. Mr. Bouton, a sales representative of Life magazine in New York, graduated from Dickinson College.

title: Campus Life: Michigan State;   Protest Shanties Are Torn Down; 5 Are Arrested
description: Michigan State University last week tore down five plywood shanties that had been built on campus to promote various causes, and the campus police arrested five students who protested the move.

title: U.S. Bike Title Is on the Line
description: The annual CoreStates United States pro cycling championship, a grueling 156-mile race through the streets of Philadelphia on Sunday, will match those traditionally strong American teams, Coors Light and 7-Eleven.

title: Panel Faults Westchester G.O.P. on Patronage
description: The New York State Government Integrity Commission last week criticized the Westchester County Republican leader's influence over the county government, saying it was a ''case study'' of an overly close relationship between political parties and government.

title: 2 Bystanders Shot as Gangs Clash
description: A confrontation between two rival Chinese gangs on a busy street in Chinatown erupted into gunfire yesterday, leaving one one gang member critically wounded and two bystanders injured, the police said.

title: Laura Robinson and James Young Wed
description: Laura Cecilia Robinson and James Bernard Young were married yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. Msgr. William A. Genuario officiated.

title:
ART;

An Intersection of Art and Nature: 18 Sculptures by the Hudson
description: LEAD: BECAUSE it is taking place at the Hudson River Museum here, the sculpture exhibition ''A Natural Order'' speaks with authority. The museum's best asset is its setting, right on the Hudson across from the venerable Palisades. The main point of this show, however, is that nature is fragile; its former ''naturalness'' may exist for future generations only in works of art, such as the 18 sculptures in the show.

title: Shopping at East Germany's Going-Out-of-Business Sale
description: LEAD: EAST BERLIN is holding a closeout sale that would shame Crazy Eddie.

title: Hardy Leaders Arrange Far-Flung Vacations
description: THE usual kind of touristy vacation does not satisfy Bill and Joanne Russell, of Fairfield. They say they would rather explore out-of-the-way places, preferably on foot or on skis, and share the experience with like-minded members of the Appalachian Mountain Club.

title: Fashion;   New Wheels in Town Set Styles and Sell Band-Aids
description: New waves of rolling people now weave in and out of traffic, adding speed and precariousness to city life, as well as flashes of fashion. They wear Rollerblades, a new generation of roller skate with a single row of polyurethane wheels that has transformed this archetypal urban pursuit.

title: U.S. Horse Team
description: An experienced champion named Walzertakt and three other competitors, Gifted, Dimitrius and Unanimous, have been named to carry the American hopes in the dressage division of the world equestrian championships in Stockholm next month. Their riders were also named to the team, including, Robert Dover of Lebanon, N.J., a two-time Olympian who rode Walzertakt to the 1989 and 1990 national dressage championships. The others are Carol Lavell of Fairfax, Fa., (Gifted), Marie Meyers of Newbury, Calif., (Dimitrius) and Betty Steiner of Sherrard, Ill. . . . Jeff Chiang of Columbia University has been named the 1990 Volvo Tennis/Senior Player of the year in voting by collegiate tennis coaches. . . . Michael Hayes, a wide receiver, has signed a new contract with the Atlanta Falcons along with two other starters, John Settle, running back, and Tim Green, a linebacker.

title: Ideas & Trends;   With Catalogues and Cookies Nonprofit Groups Seek Profits
description: MERCY HOSPITAL in Toledo, Ohio, decided two years ago that it could help support the cost of its vast kitchens by going into the private catering business, but it wasn't easy at first. Customers would order 40 lunches one day and 200 lunches the next, and the people at the new venture, the Mobile Chef, didn't know how to cope. ''We were sort of amateurs at this,'' said Ron O'Neal, a hospital vice president.

title: Miss van Pallandt Becomes a Bride
description: Beatrice van Pallandt, a daughter of Frederik Baron van Pallandt of Manila and Dorthe Holm Jensen of London, was married yesterday to Jeffrey-Werner Graf von der Schulenburg, a son of Susanna von der Schulenburg of Fishers Island, N.Y., and London, and the late Friedrich-Werner Graf von der Schulenburg of Cologne, West Germany. The Rev. Desmond Tillyer, an Anglican priest, officiated at the Reformed Church in Ruinerwold, the Netherlands.
