title: On Language;   Pop Me No Pops, Pop
description: What word, of onomatopoeic origin and more than six centuries of use in English, has been taken to the bosom of ballplayers and bakers, warriors and drug abusers, cartoonists and concertizers, each group having its own special sense of it? What unappreciated little word deserves the honor of scholarly examination on this day?

title: A Disruption of IRT Service
description: There will be no uptown subway service on the Nos. 1, 2, or 3 lines between the 42d Street and 96th Street stations today or for the next two weekends, the Transit Authority has said.

title: Review/Dance;   Chapman In 'Giselle'
description: With his boyish blond looks and stripling frame, Wes Chapman is more Romeo than Albrecht. And so his success was impressive in the latter role, which he danced for the first time in New York on Wednesday night, when American Ballet Theater presented ''Giselle'' at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Ballet Theater's Season: Hints of What Lies Ahead
description: Everyone can agree that American Ballet Theater is winding up an exceptionally well-danced season, ornamented by individual performances of top caliber and, more unexpectedly, with a great leap forward on a stylistic level by the entire corps.

title: Video and Theater Shape a New Madonna
description: Platinum hair perched in an ''I Dream of Jeannie'' ponytail, she first appears as a vision, a goddess amid the drones. She descends a steel staircase into a sinister cityscape straight out of Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis,'' a landscape of metal girders, turning gears and gritty, urban smokestacks.

title: More States Trying to Curb Teen-Age Pregnancies
description: Fearing the high long-term costs of adolescent pregnancies, more than two-thirds of the states have taken steps to reduce their incidence and enhance the lives of teen-age mothers and their children, according to a new study by the National Governors' Association.

title: Review/Music;   Jean Genet's 'Balcony' Makes Debut as Opera
description: At the time Robert DiDomenica completed his opera ''The Balcony,'' in 1972, atonality was still the dominant compositional style in this country, and serialism was not yet a dirty word. It is a very different world that Mr. DiDomenica's opera entered this evening, when the Opera Company of Boston presented its premiere under the musical and artistic direction of the endlessly enterprising Sarah Caldwell. ''The Balcony'' exploits the serial method with a calculated thoroughness that now seems mildly quaint.

title: Review/Dance;   Mellower 'Swan Lake' In Baryshnikov Staging
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov's new staging of ''Swan Lake'' did not have the kind of success that American Ballet Theater must have wished for when it opened in New York last season. But last year's novelty has grown older gracefully, as evidenced by the production's return to the repertory on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Reviews/Jazz;   Elvin Jones's Drumming Inspires Quintet of Soloists
description: It took one tune to soak the drummer Elvin Jones's shirt in perspiration in his first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday night. Mr. Jones, who revolutionized jazz drumming in the early 1960's as a member of the John Coltrane quartet, beats up his drums, hitting them with mallets, brushes and sticks. The music he played with Mr. Coltrane's band often burst with a tumultuous energy that, at the time, defied a whole set of jazz and social conventions. Nearly 30 years later Mr. Jones hasn't retreated: his music, loud and brash, keeps a transgressional quality to it.

title: Co-op Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings: Avoiding Problems;   Co-op Seminar
description: ''We have already seen many serious problems,'' Frederick K. Mehlman, assistant attorney general in charge of the New York State Real Estate Financing Bureau, said earlier this year about financial difficulties at converted cooperatives and condominiums. ''Unless the real estate market picks up, we expect more problems over the next few months.'' Those who would like to avoid such problems can attend a three-hour seminar on June 27. Discussions will involve potential financial losses from unsold or foreclosed apartments and how they might be eased or resolved. The seminar is for owners and managers of co-ops and condos, members of their boards of directors and people considering buying or selling a unit.

title: 'The False Prophet'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 3 about Czechoslovakia misidentified the Slovak leader who helped found the Czechoslovak Republic in 1919. He was Milan Stefanik, not Miroslav Stefanik.

title: Postings: Homes and Sports;   Putnam Project
description: A 338-acre country club near the Hudson River in the village of Garrison in Putnam County, N.Y., is going to be redeveloped by a Japanese company as both a sports center and a housing development. The Garrison Golf & Country Club in the Town of Philipstown, about 40 miles north of Manhattan, was purchased in February by the Urban Life Company of Osaka for $18 million, according to a broker involved in the sale, William H. Stern of the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation in Manhattan.

title: Alyson Grunder Marries
description: Alyson Lynn Grunder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Grunder of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to William Varick Bassett Jr., a son of Eloise W. Miller of Bethlehem, Pa., and the late William V. Bassett. The Rev. Van S. Merle-Smith Jr. officiated at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood. The bride, a graduate of Yale University, is an editor for the Dow Jones News Service in New York. Mr. Bassett is a doctoral candidate in music composition at Columbia University. A graduate of Yale, he received a master's degree in composition from the New England Conservatory of Music.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: According to Canon, I'm holding the future of photography in my hands. Actually, I'm holding the Canon Photura, a new 35-millimeter ''hybrid'' camera that may or may not auger the shape of things to come.

title: New Jersey Jokes Fill 'Mikado Inc.'
description: FOOLING around with ''The Mikado'' is nothing new. ''The Swing Mikado'' and ''The Hot Mikado'' go back to the 1930's, ''The Black Mikado'' even further, to the 1880's. ''Mikado 2001'' is but a few years old, and a touring version of the 1982 Stratford (Canada) Theater Festival's modernized ''Mikado'' replete with references to insider trading, beepers, joggers and Jane Fonda was seen on Broadway three years ago.

title: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Action
description: Shelby Steele has made it and he tells us he thinks that ''affirmative action has shown itself to be more bad than good and that blacks . . . now stand to lose more from it than they gain.'' Steele would close the door on the aspirations of some who haven't yet made it, simply to enhance the ease with which he interacts with his new peers. What an attitude.

title: Recycling And Recycling
description: As a civic leader of a community in South Westbury which has been environmentally aware long before it was fashionable to be so, I could not agree more with Alan Fortunoff that we can no longer continue to be a throwaway society. (''Recycling Property for the Future,'' May 20).

title: Has Bayreuth Become 'Just Another Opera House'?
description: ''Richard Wagner wanted his Bayreuth Festival to be an avant-garde cultural center, European as well as German, where there would be give-and-take among all the arts. But in this century his concept has never been realized. The festival has become just another opera house.''

title: A Garden for All the Seasons
description: LEAD: FOURTEEN years ago, when Alex and Carole Rosenberg bought a home in Water Mill, they had no idea how they wanted to landscape their acre on Burnett's Creek, a tributary of Mecox Bay.

title: U.N. Panel Backs 3 Translators Ousted at Beijing's Request
description: In a ruling likely to have far-reaching consequences for Chinese and Soviet staff members here, a United Nations tribunal has said the organization had no right to dismiss three Chinese employees at the Beijing Government's request earlier this year.

title: Preston Carter Rise Is Wed To Louise S. Lionberger
description: Louise Shepley Lionberger and Preston Carter Rise were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Michael and St. George in St. Louis by the Rev. William K. Christian 3d. Mrs. Rise, 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Lionberger Jr. of St. Louis. She and her husband are University of Virginia graduates.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing last Sunday for a play, ''Everybody Knows Your Name,'' appended a critical comment erroneously. The reference was to a different play, ''A Quiet End.'' ''Everybody Knows Your Name'' has not been reviewed by The Times.

title: Politicians Forced to Confront Issue of Defacing Flag
description: From one end of the country to another, candidates are suddenly finding themselves forced to take a stand on just the kind of visceral, uncompromising issue that politicians like to avoid: whether the Constitution should be amended to outlaw the desecration of the flag.

title: 'Mr. Huggy' Crusades for Self-Appreciation
description: REACHING into the back of his red Subaru station wagon stamped with ''Give Peace a Chance'' stickers, Paul Thomas pulled out four canvas bags stuffed with his band of furry crusaders. After slipping a harmonica into his shirt pocket, he swung the bags over his shoulders, crept through the doors of the Dorothy C. Moore Elementary School in East Haven and down a hallway that led to a kindergarten classroom.

title: A Morality Musical For the Modern Era
description: THEATER 3 in Port Jefferson, which is presenting the Long Island premiere of the Stephen Sondheim musical ''Into the Woods,'' has always boasted the finest musical comedy talent on the Island.

title: Ann K. Fleming Married
description: Ann K. Fleming, the associate dean of admissions at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., and Michael S. Brown, the director of financial aid there, were married yesterday at the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. James T. Burtchaell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Brown, 31 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Fleming of Princeton. A graduate of Bryn Mawr College, she received a master's degree in French from Middlebury College. Mr. Brown, 36, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl H. Brown of Silver Spring, Md. He graduated from Cornell University.

title: Americans Still Don't Want to Give Up the $1 Bill for a $1 Coin;   Think Bigger
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SITTING HER STRANGELY, ON TOP OF THE SUNLIGHT'
description: ABOVE THE RIVER

title: He's Still Out
description: As commissioner of baseball, Fay Vincent has enough decisions to make, thank you, without second-guessing his most storied predecessor, Kenesaw Mountain Landis.

title: Bimbos Embody Retro Rage
description: In ''Bird On A Wire,'' Goldie Hawn plays a high-powered lawyer who talks tough to her adversaries, then can't decide which brand of bottled water she wants with lunch. She wakes up wearing skimpy black lingerie, then scampers through one of the film's many chase sequences wearing a pink satin wrapper that flies upward in a strong breeze. In the film's final adventure episode, set in a zoo, she is moved to rescue Mel Gibson from hungry tigers. What gives her that last boost of energy is the possibility that Mr. Gibson's character, having long ago left her at the altar, is finally ready for marriage.

title: Can Perestroika Produce a Good Map of Moscow?
description: EXPERIENCED travelers say good maps of Moscow have always been scarce, but with increasing interest in traveling to the Soviet Union, any map is now hard to find. When I was in London in the middle of March, Foyle's, at 113 Charing Cross Road, was out of the popular Falk English-language street map of Moscow, although a salesman in the travel department suggested that I take Baedeker's Moscow, then $:5.95 (about $10), which included a Moscow city map on the base used by Falk, created by Cartographia in Budapest. Collets, at 129 Charing Cross Road, was out of the Falk map, too, but expected a supply in any day. My order for a copy was filled in May, with the 12th edition, at $:4.50, or about $7. The map is 23 by 32 inches.

title: Currency;   Losing Steam at the Close
description: The dollar fizzled as the week ended. It closed slightly lower against the German mark, after managing to trade at times above the key level of 1.70 marks to the dollar. Dealers said the dollar still appeared to be locked in a fairly narrow band of trading, despite the release of a slew of economic indicators in the United States. The reason: The dealers were doubtful that the latest batch of data would spur a change in the Federal Reserve's credit stance. On Friday, a large dollar sale in Europe, rumored to be by West Germany's Bundesbank, slowed whatever momentum the currency had gained from the positive economic data released early in the day. At the close of trading, the dollar finished the week lower against all major currencies.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Auctions of three- and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Everybody Stands Up For 'Rose Garden' Piece
description: WHEN the Hartford Symphony offers the premiere of David Macbride's ''Rose Garden'' at 6:30 P.M. on Friday, a standing ovation is virtually guaranteed, because nobody, except possibly the cellists, sits down.

title: Nice Ladies Work for Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Employer Responsibility and Early Retirement Offers
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Arizona State;   Racist Graffiti Leads to a Ban On Harassment
description: The governing board of the three Arizona state universities has approved an addition to the schools' code of conduct that prohibits ''engaging in harassment or unlawful discriminatory activities.''

title: Preventive Medicine, Soviet-Style
description: ''DAVAI! DAVAI!'' or ''Go on! Go on!'' shouted the young female obstetrician to the woman in labor at Leningrad's Obstetrics Polyclinic.

title: Mary L. Beardsley Is Wed to Kent A. Kelley
description: Mary L. Beardsley, a daughter of Mrs. Alling P. Beardsley of Slingerlands, N.Y., and the late Mr. Beardsley, was married yesterday to Kent A. Kelley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kelley of Harlingen, Tex. The Rev. Stephen G. Kendrick officiated at the Universalist Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: The Great Divide
description: For as long as I can remember, there has been a mean-spirited proposal to settle the problems New York City presents for the rest of the country. It is this: Loose the island of Manhattan from its moorings and let it float out to sea. Goodbye dirt, noise, crack dealers, street peddlers, fast talkers, big spenders.

title: Trial to Start in Killing of 2 Detectives
description: Last November 13, two New York City police detectives were driving a prisoner back to Rikers Island from their squad room in Queens Borough Hall. As the car headed west on the Grand Central Parkway, shots rang out from the back seat, where the handcuffed prisoner had been sitting alone.

title: Michael Haimsohn, 34, Dancer and Puppeteer
description: Michael Anthony Haimsohn, a dancer, actor, puppeteer and set designer, died on Thursday at the University of Southern California Medical Center in Los Angeles.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: HE began courting her on a warm morning in March, swelling his brick-red breast and shaking his wings with all the urgency and desire of spring. She wasn't impressed.

title: Dr. Hatterer Wed To Dr. M. L. Gelb
description: Dr. Julie Anne Hatterer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Hatterer of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Michael Lawrence Gelb, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Gelb of New York and Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Martin J. Zion officiated at the home of the bride's parents in Pawling, New York.

title: India's Embattled Leader Struggles With Rising Violence and Party Rivals
description: For Prime Minister V. P. Singh, leading an alliance of diverse opposition parties to victory in national elections nearly seven months ago was the easy part. Consolidating his new Government's power over this fractious nation of 840 million people is proving to be much more difficult.

title: Review/Piano;   American In Recital At Gould Hall
description: Elizabeth Wolff's piano recital at Florence Gould Hall on Thursday night was an intermittent struggle between a considerable musical intelligence and some intrusive nervous energy. It was a serious, substantial program - Beethoven sonatas early and late, the Schubert A-minor Sonata (D. 845) and Andrzej Panufnik's ''Pentasonata.'' For all her pieces, Ms. Wolff had a sympathetic comprehension.

title: Fan Violence at World Cup Finals
description: Two hours before the kickoff of the World Cup match between England and the Netherlands on Saturday night, Italian police officers and about 1,000 English soccer fans exchanged rocks and tear gas during a clash.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA INVESTIGATION
description: Between the lines of Arthur L. Liman's rebuttals, Liman basically admits he abused his discretion in handling the first Iran-contra investigation (Letters, May 20, in response to ''The Iran-Contra Committees - Did They Protect Reagan?'' by Seymour Hersh, April 29). Why else would he need geopolitical rationales? All the players, including Liman, had sworn to uphold the United States Constitution, but then apparently decided it was obsolete in the ''nuclear era.'' Closing a complex investigation quickly, while steering clear of certain lines of inquiry, might have seemed convenient. But, as with the Nixon pardon, grave damage was done to our national moral fabric.

title: Elizabeth Davis Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Pyper Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle Ragland Davis Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., and New York, was married yesterday in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to Hartley Raymond Rogers, a son of Dr. Adrianne E. Rogers and Hartley Rogers Jr. of Winchester, Mass.

title: The Cardinal Gets Tougher
description: It's not for outsiders to judge the moral discipline that John Cardinal O'Connor imposes on Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York, including those holding public office. Teaching on abortion is surely church business; as a prince of the church, he speaks with resonant authority.

title: Wills for Single People, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Decades in the Ancient Sport of Curling
description: LEAD: DONALD G. McKAY has spent a good part of his adult life on thin ice. It has been worth it, he says, because it has placed him a stone's throw from greatness.

title: On the Run All the Time
description: For the last year, Edwin Moses has been serving many masters.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: A Plea For Remorse
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Forsythe Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Cooke Forsythe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dall W. Forsythe of Stockport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lewis George Perry, a son of George Lewis Perry of Washington and Jean M. Perry of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Christopher Powell officiated at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in Stockport.

title: A FEMINIST MEMOIR
description: The outcry over Vivian Gornick's article ''Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?'' (April 15) is really a testimony to the importance of The New York Times Magazine. One can understand that when it appeared, complete with a delightful tongue-in-cheek photograph of major feminists on the cover, every feminist in the country eagerly prepared herself or himself for a definitive essay on the movement.

title: The Reverse LBO Survives, but in a Downsized Model
description: The tumult in the equities market and the wreckage of the 1980's ''junk bond'' market has brought many of the nation's financial wizards back down closer to earth. Their leveraged buyouts are no longer flying as high as they were - and selling them back to the public is much harder than it was.

title: Ice-Cream Cone Catches Drips (and Prize)
description: LEAD: WHEN five sixth graders at the Herma Simmons Elementary School here set out to build a better ice-cream cone, all they wanted was to protect their clothing from sticky drips.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Oberammergau Ticket Frauds Are Reported BONN

title: TYSON WINS IN 1st ROUND
description: Mike Tyson, in his first bout since losing his heavyweight title, detonated a right hand on the chin of Henry Tillman and knocked him out at 2:47 of the first round of a scheduled 10-round bout tonight at Caesars Palace.

title: Scanning Device Speeds Taking of Tolls
description: LEAD: AN electronic scanning device that enables motorists to pay tolls without stopping is being looked to by transportation officials as a way to ease backups on some of the state's most heavily traveled roads, bridges and tunnels.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Woman in Fetal Alcohol Case Gives Birth to Healthy Infant
description: A woman who was cleared of child abuse charges arising from her drinking while pregnant has given birth to an apparently healthy boy, a doctor said.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DAY WE MET YOU

title: A Father and a Bicycle
description: The first bicycle, a stylish black, gleamed from its hooks in the shop. The son, then in high school, insisted he had to have it, even though its price, in the hundreds of dollars, exceeded anything the father had ever thought a bike could be worth.

title: Senate Campaign Finance Talks Break Down
description: Senate negotiators have abandoned efforts to reach common ground on changes in campaign financing, raising doubts that a partisan deadlock over the legislation can be broken in the months ahead.

title: Miss Bush Weds M. P. McAllister
description: Ethel Walker Smith Bush, a daughter of Mrs. Byron Cleveland Herbert of Edenton, N.C., was married yesterday to Malcolm Percy McAllister, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hoitt McAllister of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Let's Be Frank About Fairness And Accuracy
description: Two watchdogs over television and the press - Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting (FAIR) and Accuracy in Media (AIM) - have taken exception to a recent column of mine that suggested they were less interested in the ideals advertised in their titles than in promoting their ideologies. They seem to be especially irked by having been mentioned in the same breath.

title: The World;   Moscow Rethinks The Art Of the Deal
description: AN old negotiators' adage has it that Americans play poker, Russians play chess.

title: Altered States;   Free Choice Revives the Best And Worst of Eastern Europe
description: STRETCHED out on a cot in the Emergency Hospital, his head and left hand bandaged, a Romanian student leader who had been beaten by a squad of pro-Government vigilantes last week was asked about democracy's chances in Romania.

title: An Exhibition That Is Really An Exhortation
description: In 1941, the captive leaders of the Terezin Ghetto in Czechoslovakia convinced the Nazis that the Jewish artifacts being confiscated daily should be preserved as the museum of an extinct race. Seeing the propaganda potential in this move, the Germans assigned the task to the curators at the Central Jewish Museum in Prague.

title: In Managua, Fresh Hope
description: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's three-week-old Cabinet was exasperated, ready to give up.

title: Malle Uncorks the '68 Crop
description: The last time Louis Malle dug deeply into his memory and his conscience, the result was ''Au Revoir les Enfants,'' his remarkable, highly praised testimonial to a childhood schoolmate taken away from occupied France by the Nazis and killed at Auschwitz. The mood now has changed. An earlier Louis Malle has returned. The director, whose film subjects have ranged from India and Atlantic City to incest and collaborationism, has reached into his own past again, coming up this time with ''May Fools,'' a lighthearted, ironic comedy of bourgeois manners set deep in the wine country of southwest France.

title: 34 Still Missing in Ohio Town Ravaged by Flood
description: Twenty-six dog teams, closely followed by National Guardsmen with shovels and earth-moving equipment, searched along 12 miles of creek shoreline today for 34 people still listed as missing after a flash flood.

title: City Plan for a Huge Sewage Tank In a Park Divides Queens Groups
description: A plan by New York City to clean up some of its most polluted waters by building a mammoth underground sewage tank in a major Queens park is dividing environmentalists and parks advocates.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: The Nets have floundered more from a lack of leadership than a lack of talent. They should trade the No. 1 pick for a proven veteran (or two) from a winning program. Maybe they can make it a point guard to pull the reins in on Dennis Hopson, and to get the ball to Sam Bowie. Fat Lever and Sleepy Floyd might be available.

title: All About: Discount Brokers;   Now Fewer Firms Are Chasing Small Investors Discount Brokers
description: Like most of their more glamorous Wall Street cousins, discount brokers have never fully rebounded from the 1987 stock market crash. They are uniquely dependent on the small investor, who remains stubbornly aloof even as the market reaches new heights. While a few firms continue to profit, the industry is being buffeted by consolidation and change.

title: More Support Urged for Soccer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Baudelaire the Visionary
description: To the Editor:

title: LAST SEEN INTHE DESERT, WRITING
description: LEAD:

title: New World, New C.I.A.
description: The cold war is over. And some now argue that in this dramatically changed world, intelligence services like the C.I.A. are costly anachronisms that should be sharply reduced. In fact these changes have increased, not decreased, the need for the right kind of intelligence. What's called for is not less intelligence activity but the acquisition of new and different kinds of information.

title: Miss Rose Weds Craig W. Hupper
description: St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Annapolis, Md., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan Kent Rose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Rose of Annapolis, to Craig William Hupper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hupper of New York. The Rev. Mark Gatza performed the ceremony.

title: There's Comedy Tonight
description: IN a room where stars are born, dreams don't seem so impossible.

title: Recollections Of a Combat Medic
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigerian School Collapse Is Said to Kill 100
description: A private school collapsed in the eastern oil city of Port Harcourt on Friday, reportedly killing at least 100 people.

title:
ART;

Social and Political Situations
description: LEAD: BOTH the East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art and the nearby Vered Gallery are currently offering exhibitions intended to honor the career achievements of an individual artist.

title: Detour Off a Well-Worn Chinese Route
description: DO you have a yen for Chinese food, but would rather not travel the moo shu pork/egg roll route? Fu Ho in Syosset is tempting diners with the likes of black pepper veal, fresh banana chicken and shredded jellyfish. Long Island standbys are also available, but Chinese food fanciers who want to abandon well-worn culinary ruts can do so at this attractive newcomer.

title: Hers;   A Good Dad In Any Age
description: I was only 3 when my mother, having given birth to my baby brother, fell victim to postpartum complications and returned to the hospital for several weeks. I was convinced that she was going to die; the cruel hospital rules of the 1940's, which prohibited visits by children, confirmed my worst suspicions. Only my father, who was gifted with perfect pitch when it came to childhood fears, seemed to understand what I was going through.

title: Great Pianists From the Past Re-emerge
description: Benno Moiseiwitsch, who died in 1963, is a 20th-century piano immortal, and there were cheers about two years ago when APR in England started a project intended to transfer all of his many records to LP and CD. Thank goodness it does not seem to have been an abortive effort. Now comes a two-disk CD album, APR 7005 (also available on LP), containing solo piano recordings made between 1938 and 1950.

title: Postings: East 85th Town Houses;   All in the Family
description: A New Jersey woman with an interest in the arts whose husband is an estate developer has decided to strike out on her own by building two single-family town houses on the Upper East Side that will be priced at $6 million when they are completed early next year. The houses are being designed by the New York architectural firm of Gwathmey Siegel and Associates, which first gained renown for its designs of vacation homes in eastern Long Island.

title: Blending the Rigid And the Flowing
description: EDWARD HOPPER was born here, most likely at 82 North Broadway. This is the house the artist grew up in, attending the local high school, hanging out at the shipyard, sketching the yachts made there and, at the age of 15, building a boat of his own.

title: JUST ANOTHER SACRIFICE
description: HOMESICK

title: New Study Says AIDS Bias Grows Faster Than Disease
description: Acts of discrimination against people with AIDS have steadily increased even though most people realize that the disease cannot be spread by casual contact, the American Civil Liberties Union said in a report made public today.

title: Quieting Ghosts
description: To the Editor:

title: WRONG MAN FOR THE JOB?
description: THE RELUCTANT KING

title: Managing;   Getting the Brightest to Go Abroad
description: William L. Godsey had headed the General Dynamics Corporation's European operations in Brussels for three years when he got a call from Frederick S. Wood, a vice president at St. Louis headquarters. Mr. Wood thought Mr. Godsey should apply for the newly opened job of vice president for international programs at the company's Pomona, Calif., division.

title: Total Objectivity Is an Old Centrist Canard
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL
description: Braxton Banks missed the 1989 Notre Dame football season because of a leg injury. Banks, a running back, toiled last March over a delicate decision: whether to return for his final season at Notre Dame and earn his degree in English, or enter the National Football League draft in April and lose his Notre Dame fscholarship and eligibility.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Topics of the Times;   Promises in Myanmar
description: The electoral triumph of Myanmar's democratic opposition last month was so complete that the rejected military regime scrapped earlier plans to delay the transfer of power for as long as two years. Yet power remains in military hands, Myanmar remains a police state and promises of change remain promises.

title: KINDRED SPIRITS WHO NEEVER MET
description: LEAD:

title: Some Like It Better In a Box
description: In video a film like ''Always'' (Reviewed on this page) happens hardly ever. Rarely is a movie tape released in the letter-box format only, without a panned-and-scanned version usually adapted for television. With bands across the top and bottom of the screen, letter boxing preserves the perspective of the theater screen. Film makers - in this case Steven Spielberg (his ''Empire of the Sun'' was also letter boxed only) - naturally favor letter boxing as a truer representation of the original.

title: Virginia Tibbitts and Peter J. Srere Are Married
description: Virginia K. Tibbitts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Tibbitts of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Scarsdale Community Baptist Church to Peter J. Srere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benson M. Srere of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Jim Morrison officiated.

title: Reflections on the Family for Father's Day;   Women at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeremiah Evarts Weds Kara Cater
description: At the Community Church in Landgrove, Vt., Kara Patricia Cater, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peter Cater of Westerly, R.I., was married yesterday to Jeremiah Maxwell Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove. The Rev. Nicholas Van Dyck, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational service.

title: In Defense of Circumcision
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Ragtime Program In an Outdoor Series
description: ''Spring Into Summer,'' a series of free outdoor concerts in the midtown area, is to continue on Tuesday at noon with a performance of ragtime music by Cynthia Sayer and the Crazy Rhythm Jazz Band at 2 Grand Central Towers, 45th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. The concert is sponsored by the Grand Central Partnership and 2 Grand Central Towers.

title: Steven Rattner Weds Beth Stevens in Tarrytown
description: Beth Stevens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Stevens of New York, was married last evening to Steven Rattner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rattner of Pittsburgh, at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Alan Fuchs.

title:
World Markets;

Deutsche Bank's Self-Deprecating Style
description: LEAD: To hear the executives at Deutsche Bank A.G. describe the institution's financial health, one would think West Germany's largest commercial bank was plugging steadily along, somehow managing to eke out higher earnings in a business fraught with more perils than prospects.

title: Waging Guerrilla Warfare Against the Art World
description: The group known as The Guerrilla Girls turned five a few weeks ago, but if they held an anniversary celebration, it was typically secret. Since 1985, this mysterious band of art-world women, who boldly - some would say presumptuously - call themselves the ''conscience of the art world,'' has regularly papered sections of lower Manhattan with smartly designed black-and-white posters. These communiques, bristling with sarcasm, statistics and bold graphics, level charges of sexism and racism at various quarters of the art world, including galleries, museums, collectors, critics and white male artists.

title: Tech Notes;   A Silicon Chip's Acidity Test
description: A company in Menlo Park, Calif., has developed a technology combining living cells and a silicon chip which it says will reduce the need for live animals in chemical and drug toxicity testing, help physicians select drugs for cancer therapy and facilitate the discovery of new drugs. The device sandwiches a small chamber for living cells, an insulator and a chip called a light-addressable potentiometric sensor. The Silicon Microphysiometer, developed by the Molecular Devices Corporation, is based on the discovery that changes in the metabolic rate of living cells alters their ph, or acidity, level. It uses a new type of sensor chip that can measure minute changes in the ph of samples as small as 1,000 cells. By measuring changes in ph, scientists can determine the efficacy or toxicity of drugs and other chemical agents.

title: Phone Charges
description: To the Editor: Reader Paul Prager's problem (Letters on Travel, April 29) with undisclosed phone surcharges is not uncommon for even the most careful traveler. Last year, a similar problem came up with the Marriott-Twin Bridges in Washington, D.C.

title: Marri Davis Wed To David Moffly
description: Marri Heller Davis, a daughter of Marvin W. Davis and the late Nancy Turcott Davis, was married yesterday at her father's home in Southampton, L.I., to David Wesley Moffly, a son of Louisa Peace Egleston and William Tennant Moffly 3d, both of Fort Washington, Pa. The Rev. Peter Heist, a minister of the American Fellowship Church, officiated.

title: Belgians and Dutch Seize 2 Suspected of I.R.A. Activity
description: The Belgian and Dutch authorities arrested two people suspected of being I.R.A. members today after a local farmer reported hearing target practice in the woods along the border.

title: Robert Gold Wed To Amy Barrett
description: Amy Elizabeth Barrett, the director of the New York office of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, was married yesterday to Robert Lowell Gold, a vice president of Ridgewood Energy, an oil- and gas-investment concern in Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi Charles Lippman and Msgr. John F. Casey officiated at the Fort Totten chapel in Bayside, Queens.

title: Technology;   The Rising Popularity Of Home-Built Planes
description: A new generation of high-performance kit-built aircraft is leading a rebirth in light plane design. As traditional producers of single-engine aircraft have either left the market or continued to market decades-old designs, kit manufacturers have stepped forward to fill the void.

title: Costa Rica's Fierce Pacifist
description: If Costa Rica has eluded the familiar afflictions of Central America - war, poverty and repression - much of the credit belongs to Jose Figueres Ferrer, a fighter for democracy who died recently at the age of 83.

title:
Style Makers;

Sandra Dal Borgo and Bianca Allevi, Copywriter and Art Director
description: LEAD: A highly successful advertising campaign for a men's fragrance has stirred up some controversy about the way it portrays women, even though there are no women shown anywhere in the ad.

title: One Sunny Day a Seatbelt Saves a Future
description: NOV. 13, 1989. Warm and sunny, unusual weather for this time of the year. On this day, my life might have been taken had I not been wearing a seat belt. The memories are vivid, still new, clear in my mind.

title: Data Bank/June 17, 1990
Patricia D. Funt Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia D. Funt was married yesterday to Kenneth J. Oxman at the Monterey, Calif., home of her father, Allen Funt. The Rev. Charlie Moore, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: 'Kindness of Strangers' Sustains Playhouse
description: AS its 60th anniversary season begins, the Westport Country Playhouse's real cause for celebration is that it's still here.

title: Where's The Cash, Mr. Trump?
description: Is Donald a deadbeat?

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Drive-Ins Endure, and Woo Back Some Old Fans
description: Along a suburban highway, just a few hundred yards from the concert hall at the Westbury Music Fair, is a remnant of a quickly disappearing - and somewhat less highbrow - form of American popular culture: the drive-in movie.

title: Well Into Midlife, Woman Finds Recognition in Two Careers
description: LEAD: FOR Charlotte Mandel, poet and publisher, recognition has come rather late in life. In an era when the fast track can lead to success at the age of 25 or even at 18, Ms. Mandel represents a different approach. She began both her careers well into her middle years.

title: Sir Richard's Curious Career
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisconsin Is No. 1
description: The Wisconsin crew caught up with Harvard at last today at the Cincinnati Regatta and beat the Crimson eight in a 2,000-meter race to decide the nation's best college heavyweight crew.

title: Style Makers;   Julie Jordan Fleps and Laura Ledford, Clothing Designers
description: Julie Jordan Fleps and Laura Ledford often use thrift shop finds to inspire their Julie Laurie collection of dresses and sportswear. Details like covered buttons and rounded collars may derive from the past, but the way the designers mix the eras together makes the clothes distinctly modern.

title: Saugerties Lighthouse Being Restored on Hudson
description: A half-mile out into the Hudson River, the old Saugerties Lighthouse, abandoned 36 years ago, is getting a new lease on life as a historical landmark, a tourist attraction and a restored aid to navigation.

title: Portland, Me.;   Gassing Up At the Lobster?
description: TWO designs, one featuring giant lobsters and one with canopies that float in the wind, were judged the best of 160 entered in a nationwide contest to design a gas station here, but it remains to be seen whether either will be built.

title:
Postings: Modulars in Williamsburg;

105 Affordable Co-op Apartments
description: LEAD: A development group that includes church, private business and state and municipal agencies will use $13.7 million in public and private funds to erect 105 affordable cooperative apartments in a cluster of nine modular buildings in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The project, called Williamsburg Partnership Homes, will cover most of a site bounded by South Eighth and Ninth Streets, Driggs Avenue and Berry

title: Hawkins Redeems Himself but Yanks Lose
description: Andy Hawkins might have been down to his final chance, but last night at the Stadium, just eight days after it appeared he might be released by the Yankees, Hawkins rose and gave a performance worthy of an ovation.

title: Mutual Funds;   When You Have a Choice of Fees
description: When it comes to fees, mutual funds get you coming or going. But you may be able to start picking the direction.

title: Topics of the Times;   California's Message on Ethics
description: California voters, rebelling against the corrupting influence of special-interest money in politics, have approved sweeping ethics and campaign finance reforms. The results ought to inspire members of Congress still stalling similar Federal measures.

title: Poetry as an Inexact Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;   For Breakfast-Oversleepers, A Sampler of Midday Menus
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Sara S. Barrett Becomes Bride
description: Sara Shaffer Barrett, a photographer, and Alec Wilkinson, a staff writer at The New Yorker, were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev. Lisa Keppeler.

title: Court Ruling to Give More Drivers Experience With Sobriety Checks
description: ''What are those empty bottles on the floor?'' the police officer asked the young man in a Yankee cap who sat behind the wheel.

title: Sportsmanship And Golf Balls
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How to Hold On Till 'Gotterdammerung'
description: Among those who spend any time thinking about Richard Wagner and his works, there seem to be only two points of view. One is exemplified by a friend of mine whose attitude toward Wagner might be called, in polite understatement, devotion. Another friend - literate, musical, no mere Philistine - takes the contrary stance. His attitude is the one Nancy Reagan suggested that schoolchildren take toward illegal drugs: Just say no.

title: Athletes Reflect Their Treatment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Madison Avenue will be closed today from 37th to 56th Streets from noon until about 3 P.M. for the International Immigrants Parade.

title: Philharmonic Summer Tour
description: The New York Philharmonic will give eight concerts on its summer tour before returning to New York on Sept. 1 to prepare for its 149th season. The orchestra, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, will play in these places: Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va. (Aug. 22-23); Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass. (Aug. 24); Ravinia Festival, Highland Park, Ill. (Aug. 26); Midland Center for the Arts Auditorium, Midland, Mich. (Aug. 27); Roy Thomson Hall, Toronto, (Aug. 29); Hancher Auditorium, Iowa City (Aug. 30), and the Meyerson Symphony Center, Dallas (Aug. 31).

title: Miss Streeter Marries Anwar Wissa Jr.
description: Cornelia Van Rensselaer Streeter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Streeter of Wenham, Mass., was married yesterday in South Hamilton, Mass., to Anwar E. Z. Wissa Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wissa of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. William T. Lovell officiated at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ellen Oltman Wed to Charles Kellner
description: Ellen E. Oltman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Oltman of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married to Charles R. Kellner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil M. Kellner of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., in a Jewish and Quaker ceremony yesterday. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated at the Warwick hotel in New York.

title: Unleaded Fuel
description: To the Editor: Last year I spent six months touring Europe in rented automobiles and was surprised to find that 95 percent of the cars in the larger group, such as Mercedes-Benz and B.M.W., ran on unleaded gas. I was surprised at the availability of unleaded gas, even though some of my friends tell me that I must have been asleep on my previous trips, as they have had unleaded for years.

title: Miss Woods Weds Michael Leonard
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elisabeth Barrell Woods, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Appleton Woods of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Michael George Leonard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Leonard of Stuart, Fla. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony.

title: The Region;   It Isn't Easy To Design A Board of Education
description: ROBERT F. WAGNER JR., the New York City Board of Education's departing president, likes to fantasize about how the next board might be picked.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: Chances are that if the Nets draft Derrick Coleman, he'll have more of an impact than did Chris Morris, Dennis Hopson or Mookie Blaylock, the Nets' first-round picks the last three years. However, the Nets need an experienced veteran who can score and become a leader in the clubhouse. This can be accomplished only by trading their first pick.

title: Is Poland Getting Bad Advice?
description: Poland is the only country in Eastern Europe that is attempting to rush from a command-and-control economy to a free-market economy. All the other countries have chosen a gradual transition. My prediction is that Poland will not make it. I base my prediction on sociological, psychological and political factors as well as economics. This broader perspective is a long way from American neoclassical economic theory, on which the ''jump now'' advice to Poland is based.

title: The World;   Canada's Crucial Seven-Day Countdown
description: TO many Canadians, it seems scarcely credible that it could have come to this. After 123 years, the nation stitched together from the British colonies that shunned the American revolution faces a real possibility of being sundered at its core.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Travel section today and headlines on pages 1 and 14, about the French city of Nantes, refer to it incorrectly. Nantes is the capital of the Loire-Inferieure department and not of Brittany, which is a region.

title: As Summer Nears, a Rabies Reminder
description: If a raccoon or a fox wanders into your campsite or backyard this summer and seems to show no fear of you, don't try to feed or pet it: you might be dealing with a rabid animal.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

The Little Blue Toyota Is Gone, but Hope Remains
description: LEAD: MY little Toyota is gone. It's been three weeks since I held its shining blue steering wheel in one hand while applying lipstick and balancing a cup of coffee between my knees, three weeks of wondering what happened to the car that was once so very mine.
