title: George Nakashima Is Dead at 85; Designer and Master Woodworker
description: George Nakashima, the master woodworker and designer who sought to capture the noble character of trees in chairs, tables and cabinetry, died on Friday at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 85 years old. His family said he died after a brief illness.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on May 27 about tours from Fiumicino Airport in Rome misidentified a company offering tours to Ostia Antica. It is Italia Tour.

title: Ship Burned All Week; Salvagers Explain Why
description: Salvage officials said today that once the stricken tanker Mega Borg was fully ablaze, crews had little choice but to spend a week slowly cooling it down while it spilled crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Headliners;   It's Been Years
description: Miriam Makeba is still an expatriate, but she can go home again and she has. Just months ago, after Nelson Mandela's release, Miss Makeba said she wanted to be ''on the first plane home'' from Brussels but remained too leery of the South African authorities. But last week she was on the plane, for her first visit in 31 years, and when she stepped off a crowd began the anti-apartheid anthem, ''God Bless Africa.'' Exile has been a success, professionally speaking. In the 1960's, Miss Makeba became one of the first African performers to gain a popular following in the United States. More recently, she joined Paul Simon's Graceland tour, and in March she sang at the Apollo Theater. She has lived in the United States, Europe and Guinea, and represented Guinea at the United Nations. After she gave an anti-apartheid speech there in 1976, her songs were banned on South African broadcasts for 13 years. Miss Makeba planned no performances on this trip. She said she would be ''even happier when I can come back to sing before my people, where I'll not have to explain my songs.''

title: Elizabeth Varley Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Burch Varley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Varley of Winnetka, Ill., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka to Gregory Talcott Camp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Camp of New York. The Rev. A. Nichols Taylor officiated. Mrs. Camp is a limited partner in the investment firm of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen in New York. She graduated cum laude from Williams College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and she and her husband have master's degrees in public and private management from Yale University. Mr. Camp, a principal in New York of Charles Street Securities, graduated magna cum laude from Yale.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: Yes. While there are many talented players in the upcoming college draft (Derrick Coleman, Dennis Scott, Gary Payton, etc.), there are no ''franchise players'' such as Patrick Ewing and David Robinson. The Nets are in need of a prolific scorer, and can trade their first selection to the Clippers for Ron Harper, along with one of their selections.

title: 'Don Giovanni'
description: The June Opera Festival of New Jersey will give a performance of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' today at 3 P.M. at the Allan P. Kirby Arts Center of the Lawrenceville School, Route 206 in Lawrenceville. The production, directed by Edward Berkeley, has James Busterud in the title role, Dale Travis as Leporello, Carmen Pelton as Donna Anna and Linda Wall as Donna Elvira. Tickets: $15 to $42. Information: (609) 737-7722.

title:
Chevy Chase, Md.;

Retirement Apartments
description: LEAD: A HYATT Hotels Corporation subsidiary has opened a retirement residential community in this well-to-do municipality less than two miles north of Washington - its fifth such community.

title: Corrections
description: A report on June 10 about the engagement of Susan Ilene Jacobson misidentified the university where she is studying for an M.B.A. degree.

title: Food;   Sweet Heat
description: Having been raised by a sugar fiend, i've always had a pretty jaded attitude toward sweets. My mom baked a cake virtually every day of my childhood, and all it did for me was create cravings for spicy food. Given a choice between a chili and a chocolate, I would head for the heat every time.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. S. ALAN WEINSTEIN;

Diagnoses by Photographing Body Heat
description: LEAD: DR. S. ALAN WEINSTEIN was recently named director of the thermography division at the New Jersey Medical School in Newark. The division is the first of its kind in the country.

title: 275,000 Pieces of Theater History
description: Sarah Bernhardt's headdress from ''Cleopatra,'' Moliere's walking stick, tens of thousands of playbills and a scale model of a theater, complete with working footlights, are among more than 250,000 items to be auctioned next weekend, just a stage shout away from President Bush's Kennebunkport estate.

title: NONFICTION
description: JACQUELINE DU PRE: A Life. By Carol Easton. (Summit, $19.95.) From the ages of 16 to 28, Jacqueline du Pre was one of the most sought-after cellists in the world. The music stopped in 1973 when she was found to have multiple sclerosis. She lived almost 14 years in a wheelchair until her death at the age of 42 in 1987. Carol Easton's biography, the first since du Pre's death, is brimming with wonderful quotations from more than 100 friends, teachers and musicians. ''She was like champagne, freshly uncorked, all the time,'' says the violinist Hugh Maguire. ''She had more than us,'' says her dressmaker. ''She had more of everything: more body, more heart, more talent, more energy, more soul, more emotion.'' Ms. Easton, the author of two previous biographies, provides a readable story of du Pre's life and work, not a scholarly biography. She does not attribute all quotations, is vague about dates and neglects both a bibliography and a discography of available recordings by du Pre. Worse, Ms. Easton - perhaps because she is seeking conflict, not paeans - conjectures that du Pre, who had been a child prodigy, led an unfulfilled life. This pop-psychology theory is often contradicted, even by du Pre herself, who loved the concert experience: ''Walking on stage - the recognition, the applause, the rumble of interest from the audience when I appeared. . . . I thought of the audience as a group of friends who had come to hear me play, and I found that very moving.'' The tragedy was not her life but the silencing of her genius.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Business section on May 13 about printing inks discussed health hazards that could lead to restrictions on the use of some colors in packaging. A chart with the article, showing where inks are used and which colors contain dangerous metals, was headed ''Hazardous Inks.''

title: Liberia and Rebels Call Jointly for Restraint
description: The Liberian Government and the rebels fighting to overthrow President Samuel K. Doe called jointly for ''self-restraint'' today after five days of talks but did not order a cease-fire in their conflict.

title: Presidential Nominees To Get PBS Air Time
description: The Public Broadcasting Service plans to offer air time for talks by the major parties' Presidential nominees in 1992.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   A Springtime That for Once Is Truly Diaphanous
description: Right in step with the sunny, breezy spring days we've been enjoying recently comes a fashion look for daytime that suits the weather perfectly. It combines airy, transparent skirts with opaque tights in a silhouette that is at once modern and romantic. The effect makes one feel, well, very springlike. The style is most dramatic in sheer black, especially when the skirt is long and knife-pleated, like the one at the far upper right, so that when the wind picks up it sets the skirt to billowing nicely.

title: The World;   In the Middle East, Stability Means More of the Same
description: IN a season when conflict resolution seems to be the order of the day, from South Africa to Nicaragua and from the Iron Curtain to Angola, one area of the world seems to stubbornly resist this trend: the Middle East.

title: THE GROUND RULES SHIFT WHEN MUSIC JOINS WORDS
description: Music is a tyrant whose grip on the listener is nowhere stronger than in opera. With just a few notes a skilled composer can establish an atmosphere that a great novelist or playwright might still be working to evoke after a hundred pages. Is that fair? Certainly not, but it helps explain why so many attempts to stage old operas in trendy dress fail, no matter how inventive the director's concept, how craftily remodeled the libretto or how striking the scenery.

title: A London Group Helps Heal Torture Victims
description: Efiler Ocak needed someone to bear witness.

title: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Action
description: Much is commendable in Shelby Steele's insistence that blacks be considered capable of achievement without preferential treatment. But I was saddened because he has, unwittingly, done hundreds of thousands of blacks, and other minorities and women, a great disservice.

title: Jacqueline A. Sheahan Weds Arthur J. Holly
description: Jacqueline A. Sheahan and Arthur J. Holly were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York in a ceremony performed by Msgr. John J. Barry. Mrs. Holly, 27 years old, is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Sheahan. Mr. Holly, 27, is the son of Mrs. Arthur J. Holly of Bloomfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Holly.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bellmore $160,000

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Houses With Equity in a Country Club
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPMENT concept widely found in Sun Belt states but new to the metropolitan New York area is being tested in Hauppauge by Kabro Associates of Massapequa Park.

title: After AIDS Diagnosis, Some Embrace Life
description: Eric Sorensen, a tall blond from Nebraska, was acting in New York in ''As the World Turns'' and other television shows when he learned that he had the AIDS virus. Although he was well, he was forced to admit that illness and death could come any day.

title: French Debate Armed Role in Africa
description: Long accustomed to playing keeper of the peace in its former colonies, France hardly blinked last month when the Government ordered troop reinforcements to Gabon in response to anti-Government riots in the tiny West African nation.

title: A ROACH CLIP WITH EVERY PAID SUBSCRIPTION
description: ROLLING STONE MAGAZINE

title: Patience in St. Louis
description: The Yankees are not the only team that may be performing beneath their stat-sheet potential, but the man who built the St. Louis Cardinals into the last-place team in the National League East is getting more time to turn things around.

title: No. 120 Gives Shilton Record
description: Make room in the trophy case. Another royal-blue cap is about to be delivered to the home of Peter Shilton.

title: Bonn Links Detainee in East to G.I. Killings
description: A suspected member of the left-wing Red Army Faction arrested in East Germany is wanted for killing three United States servicemen in 1985, the West German authorities said today.

title: STREAKING GIANTS ROUT BRAVES FOR 7TH STRAIGHT
description: The San Francisco Giants continued their June rampage today as Scott Garrelts pitched a three-hitter and Matt Williams drove in three runs in a 7-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Wrigley Isn't the Only Place Balls Are Going, Going, Gone
description: Whitey Herzog, the outspoken manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, noted the deluge of runs that the Mets and the Chicago Cubs produced at Wrigley Field last week - 80 in four games - and didn't hide his disdain for the quaint old park.

title: Morality in Media Takes On Adult Stores
description: LEAD: AS proprietor of Nanlee's, a store in Huntington Station, Leo Gieser says he has been making an honest living selling magazines for 25 years.

title: Brazil Advances To Second Round
description: Brazil outplayed Costa Rica today, 1-0, but could manage only one goal, scored by Muller in the first half.

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   Math Professor Inspires Women By Her Example
description: For the last six years, Diane Herrmann has been encouraging and supporting female mathematics students at the University of Chicago. Her efforts now appear to be paying off.

title: Campus Life: Washington and Lee;   N.A.A.C.P. Seeks Dormitory Space For Urban Poor
description: An influx of students from Washington and Lee University into low-income neighborhoods is creating friction with black residents, who charge that the movement has driven up rents to a point where some families can no longer afford to live here.

title: Nation's Mayors Assail Governors Over Control of Anti-Drug Funds
description: Members of the United States Conference of Mayors, gathered here for their annual meeting, accused the nation's governors today of scuttling talks that the mayors had hoped would give cities more control over how Federal anti-drug dollars are spent.

title: Cynthia Murphy Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia A. Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Murphy of Sterling, Mass., was married yesterday to Gregory E. Dermksian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Dermksian of New York. The Very Rev. Anoushavan Tanielian, assisted by Archpriest Vahrich Shirinian, officiated at SS. Vartanantz Armenian Apostolic Church in Ridgefield, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   After Complaint, Aid is Cut Off To Hispanic Paper
description: A battle is shaping up over a decision by the University of Texas to stop financing a Hispanic student newspaper accused of trying to influence public policy.

title: Americans Still Don't Want to Give Up the $1 Bill for a $1 Coin
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Riverfront Homes at an Old Brick Works
description: LEAD: WHEN it opened along the Raritan River in the mid-1880's, the Sayre and Fisher Brick Company gave Sayreville its start as an industrial center in Middlesex County and, eventually, its name. Bricks from its Main Street factory in what was then the heart of its downtown were used in such structures as the Manhattan Life Building at 66 Broadway.

title: Full House at Gallery in Marlborough
description: THE Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough has a full house, with solo shows by the late Yannis Maltezos and Deborah Muirhead and a roundup of 21 other artists.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Roadside Hunt Finds All Kinds of Trash
description: LEAD: THE Clean-Your-Mile campaign is a yearly affair in New Canaan. This year, the program was tied in with Earth Day and, for the first time, I volunteered. Setting out with a box of heavy-duty leaf bags, I brought along a long-handled contraption that, if squeezed at one end, will pull together a pair of claws at the other - very handy for retrieving trash.

title: Review Jazz;   Marlon Jordan, Trumpeter, Keeps His Cool Under Fire
description: Marlon Jordan, the young New Orleans trumpeter, has learned something about jazz cool. Mr. Jordan performed at the Blue Note on Monday night; his three sets were being videotaped, and he was making his first appearance with his own band in New York. In front of a room full of fans, critics and other musicians, his trumpet broke. He never lost control, and though he played the first part of the second set with a malfunctioning trumpet, which he later replaced, he sounded fine and was a model of grace under adversity.

title: Army Compensates Soldier Terrorized by Officers
description: A soldier who was terrorized by superior officers after reporting his rifle stolen last year and who was then stripped of rank and thrown out of the Army has now received an honorable discharge and been granted back pay of about $10,000.

title: Wall Street;   gold Is Not the Safe Haven It Used to Be
description: Gold is supposed to be a safe haven in times of turmoil. But those who fled to it last winter as Communist regimes dissolved in Eastern Europe have suffered since. Last week, gold traded as low as $341 per ounce in London, a four-year low.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: My Left Foot

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Huntington Township Art League exhibition misidentified an artist. She was Norma Friedman, not Norman.

title: Headliners;   Peronist vs. Peronist
description: Not one for politicking in the family values department, President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina has called himself ''a seducer'' and says his marriage doesn't work. Now Argentines can see - and their appetite for the story is enormous - that it indeed doesn't. President Menem's marriage to Zulema Yoma has become so nasty that last week he locked her out of the presidential mansion, she threatened to sue him, and the couple's 21-year-old son said on a television talk show that his father's household administration was ''worse than a dictatorship.'' Things were not going well anyway - she can't stand his friends, he fired her assistant, his affairs are more or less public - and the two have lived apart for half of their 23-year marriage. But their principal differences are political. With his wife repeatedly calling Mr. Menem's associates corrupt, while her friends and relatives angle for influence in the Government, something had to give. The Justice Secretary says Mrs. Menem ''is reserving her rights in such a way it could be understood she could apply for a divorce.''

title:
Your Own Account;

How to Buy Life Insurance
description: LEAD: If you decide to combine insurance protection with an investment product, you face this problem: You want a careful company, one that will be around to make good on its promises 30, 40 or even 50 years from now. But because your insurance company will also be your money manager, you don't want one that is overly cautious.

title: Alexandra F. Anderson, Editor, Weds
description: Alexandra F. Anderson, a daughter of Marion Fuller Brown of York, Me., and the late Henry Morrill Fuller, was married yesterday to Samuel O. J. Spivy, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Dixon F. Spivy of Chicago. Town Justice Thomas Gibbons of Claverack, N.Y., officiated at the bridegroom's home in Kinderhook, N.Y.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Checking Out the Most Democratic Credit Card
description: LEAD: THE most important of my credit cards is not Visa or Mastercard or American Express or Carte Blanche. It does not provide accidental death insurance when I charge my airline or train tickets. It does not provide traveler's checks without fee. It does not charge me an annual fee, or extravagant interest if I fail to return the loan within a specified period.

title: INSIDE
description: Paris and the Africans

title: Golf's Hot Question: One Tour Ball?
description: On any United States Open course, the greens are always faster and the rough is always thicker than at other tournaments. But for the golfer, the Open is also different in subtle ways.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

To Increase Affordable Housing, Let's Use Imagination
description: LEAD: THE office building market is saturated. The luxury condominium market is saturated. Schools are crying for more occupants to fill their empty spaces, as are many shopping centers, hospitals, hotels and religious institutions.

title: A Capital Offense; Reagan's America
description: The 1980's were the triumph of Upper America - an ostentatious celebration of wealth, the political ascendancy of the rich and a glorification of capitalism, free markets and finance. Not only did the concentration of wealth quietly intensify, but the sums involved took a megaleap. The definition of who's rich - and who's no longer rich - changed as radically during the Reagan era as it did during the great nouveaux-riches eras of the late 19th century and the 1920's, periods whose excesses preceded the great reformist upheavals of the Progressive era and the New Deal.

title: In Lithuania, An Old Trouper Called Resistance
description: A few weeks before the Lithuanian Parliament defiantly declared its independence from Moscow, four actors stood on the stage of Lithuania's Revolutionary Museum and sang a toast to Stalin. Waving their arms to the jaunty accompaniment of a red accordion, they lavished syncopated praise on the man who had sentenced thousands of their countrymen to death in Siberian labor camps:

title: After Weeping for Mandela, Many Prepare to Savor Visit
description: For 30 years Willard Johnson fought an often thankless battle in Boston, protesting racial inequities in a country most Americans knew little about. He helped organize some of the earliest demonstrations against South Africa's system of racial separation and was even arrested for it once.

title: Data Update
Corrections
description: An article on May 13 about Genesee Country Village in Genesee, N.Y., characterized the 158-mile Genesee River incorrectly; it is not America's longest north-flowing river, as a reader has recently written to point out. That distinction belongs to the Yellowstone River, which the United States Geological Survey puts at 678 miles.

title: They're Drilling in the Oil Patch Again
description: Lord, they ask here in West Texas, let there be one more boom. Oil boom, of course. Then, again, no one here is exactly sure whether West Texas or the rest of the nation could actually produce one more boom. The oil people are asking themselves whether the nation has conceded too much power over oil prices to the Persian Gulf or whether too much of their old boom-time rigs and labor has simply disappeared.

title: LITHUANIA LEADERS URGE SUSPENDING INDEPENDENCE BID
description: The government of Lithuania endorsed a proposal today that it suspend the republic's declaration of independence, provided that the Gorbachev Government end economic sanctions and begin negotiating a compromise settlement of the sovereignty crisis.

title: From France, Fruits Rouges Offer a Vivid Difference
description: THE French have a handy term, les fruits rouges, or red fruits, for mixtures of summer berries and cherries. Jams are sometimes labeled that way and the term is often used on menus. Some restaurants list desserts made with red fruits separately from those using other fruits like apples or pears.

title: HE DRANK THE MILK OF PARADISE
description: COLERIDGE

title: New Director Offers Continuity at Purchase Theater Complex
description: IT is a time of flux for the Westchester arts community, with at least eight major institutions either looking for a director or easing a new one into the job. But Christopher Beach, who was recently named the director of the Performing Arts Center on the State University campus here, is not really new at all.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

When The Music Stopped
description: LEAD: AS I waited outside in the car for my daughter's piano lesson to be over, I listened to the romantic strains of a waltz on the car radio. It was Johann Strauss' ''Roses From the South.'' I knew it well, because as a young girl studying the piano it was one of my favorite pieces.

title: The World;   The World Is No Longer Unthinkable
description: THE mood is changing in the Middle East. From the seaside cafes of Tel Aviv to the presidential palaces in Damascus and Baghdad - and in Jordan, in Egypt and in Libya as well - political discourse is no longer of the peace process. It is about how a new Arab-Israeli conflict has become feasible, and about how safeguards against it have been evaporating.

title: Rare Gold Ingot Is Raised From Sunken Galleon
description: An extremely rare type of gold ingot plucked from a sunken wreck off southwest Florida appears to offer the strongest evidence yet that the ship is a treasure-laden Spanish galleon from a fabled, ill-fortuned fleet that set sail from Havana in 1622.

title: Susanna Shore and John Le Boutillier, Students, Are Wed in Harvard Church
description: Susanna G. Shore, a daughter of Dr. Miles and Dr. Eleanor Shore of Needham, Mass., was married yesterday to John Le Boutillier, a son of Mrs. Gilbert Lincoln of West Hartford, Conn., and Martin LeBoutillier of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Preston Hannibal performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We want to give him goose bumps. We want him to know he's not alone, that we're with him. Whatever the Pope means to Catholics that's what Mandela means to us.''

title:
WHAT'S DOING ON;

The Maine Coast
description: LEAD: Mainers live for the summer. Warm winds and clear skies soften the harshness of the terrain, making the season a time for forays in the woods, sojourns to the beach, days at sea. But the appeal of the Maine coast doesn't end with the great outdoors. Now that President Bush has all but made Walker's Point the summer White House, the curious routinely descend on

title: School Board Group Facing Challenges
description: THE New Jersey School Boards Association, one of the state's most visible educational organizations, is under attack. In the wake of a blistering report by the State Commission of Investigation on its activities, a legislative assault and a revolt among some of its members, there is concern about the future of the 76-year-old organization.

title:
FILM;

'Misery's' Company Loves a Good Time
description: LEAD: ''Misery'' is explaining bobby pins in your underwear to your girlfriend, says the actor James Caan with a wink and a roar of a laugh, as he paces in his trailer, waiting to be called to the set.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: When a top player takes a layoff from the game, the first casualty when he returns is his patience. He tries to control and force everything before laying the groundwork of attack by solid, logical maneuvering. The result is a disaster.

title: Sarah Klenk Marries J. E. Chanin in Denver
description: Sarah A. Klenk, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Klenk of Denver, was married there yesterday to James E. Chanin, a son of Gerald M. Chanin of New York and the late Rima M. Chanin. Canon David F. Morgan performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral.

title: FALL RIVER LEGENDS
description: WHAT WE HAD

title: LIFE, ITALIAN STYLE
description: THAT FINE ITALIAN HAND

title: Does Visionary Business Call for a Corporate Sage?
description: An illuminating fringe benefit of going to the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago was the opportunity to chat informally with Akio Morita, co-founder and chairman of Sony. There had been rumors that, at the age of 69, this principal shaper of Japan's industrial ascent was about to retire. He quickly dispelled any such notion.

title: Works in Progress;   Needed: Grease for the Wheels
description: Surrounded by a weathered green fence, the Mullaly Rink Center in the south Bronx is a bit forlorn-looking. The structures inside it -wooden ramps of different shapes and sizes - are ramshackle. But there, in the shadow of the elevated train, a long outfielder's peg from Yankee Stadium, New York's first skateboarding and bicycling park is taking shape.

title: Melissa Shackleton Weds T. S. Dann
description: Melissa Kent Shackleton, the special assistant to the president of the World Wildlife Fund and the Conservation Foundation in Washington, was married yesterday to Thomas Semmes Dann, a lawyer in Washington. The Very Rev. Mark C. Sullivan performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Easton, Md.

title: Nina Angelene Barrigar Is Married To Thomas W. Daniel in Vermont
description: Nina Angelene Barrigar, a daughter of Mrs. David Sheppard of Jonesboro, Tenn., and Gary W. Barrigar of Elizabethton, Tenn., was married yesterday to Thomas Washington Daniel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Daniel of New York. Mary Jane Potter, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Inn at the Round Barn in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: 'Kill the Lawyers,' A Line Misinterpreted
description: In reference to the review of ''Guilty Conscience,'' (May 20) Leah D. Frank is inaccurate when she states that when Shakespeare had one of his characters state ''Let's kill all the lawyers,'' it was the corrupt, unethical lawyers he was referring to. Shakespeare's exact line ''The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers,'' was stated by Dick the Butcher in ''Henry VI,'' Part II, act IV, Scene II, Line 73. Dick the Butcher was a follower of the rebel Jack Cade, who thought that if he disturbed law and order, he could become king. Shakespeare meant it as a compliment to attorneys and judges who instill justice in society.

title: A Celtic Slice of France
description: LEAD: BRITTANY, like Cornwall, is an arm thrust out into the Atlantic and it has both a north and a south coast. Both the north coast and the inland areas contain many famous towns and many delectable peaceful places, but if you go there for a holiday you'll probably make for the south coast, where most of the resorts are.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 27 about Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses misstated the sum that represents 1 percent of their combined annual sales. It is $50 million.

title: Tatyana Yassukovich, An Actress, Is Married
description: Tatyana Alexandra Eugenie Yassukovich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanislas M. Yassukovich of London and Bibury, Glouchestershire, England, was married yesterday to Charles Stewart Dubow, the son of Isabella Breckinridge Dubow of Washington and Arthur D. Dubow of East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Francis Bruce officiated at St. Mary's Anglican Church in Bibury.

title: The World;   Is There a Reformer In China's Future
description: AS Chinese and foreigners puzzle over the future of China, a fundamental question is this: Is there a Chinese Gorbachev lurking within the leadership?

title: J. P. Thibault Bouet, Designer, 42
description: J. P. Thibault Bouet, a fashion designer, died on Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 42 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Opening Hearts And Homes
description: Too often we hear and read only about the bad things our neighbors are doing. It is refreshing to read about people like the Andersons, who are opening their hearts and homes to less fortunate people (''Harlem Boy Finds 'Big Hugs' in Jersey,'' May 13). Congratulations to them and the Fresh Air Fund for their efforts.

title: Anita MacMillen Wright Is the Bride Of James R. Bird Jr. in New Jersey
description: Anita MacMillen Wright, the admissions director at the Hewitt School, and James Raymond Bird Jr., an English teacher at the Spence School, both in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bird Sr., in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Edward B. Gammons Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Next Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Headliners;   The Defendant Stops Running
description: EVEN though Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was on trial last week, he gave many Washingtonians reason to stop paying attention to it. Before the questioning of prospective jurors had been completed, Mr. Barry announced that he would not run for a fourth term as mayor.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DOROTHY ALLENSWORTH;

Steering the Disadvantaged Into College
description: LEAD: TAKE a severely economically disadvantaged youngster and you have, with this one ingredient, the recipe for a possible high school dropout. But add Dorothy Allensworth to the recipe and, if the young person has the motivation, that student is going to be a college graduate.

title: Upgrading Electric Outlets
description: IF your home has old-fashioned, ungrounded, two-slot electric wall receptacles, you can can easily determine whether the wiring will accommodate newer, more convenient and safer three-slot grounding models. You can also perform the replacement if local building codes permit.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: The reference made by Maureen B. Fant in her story on Rome (Travel, April 22) brought back some unforgettable memories about that famous or infamous No. 64 bus, which goes from the Stazione Termini, the beautiful main train station in Rome, to St. Peter's, a favorite of American tourists but a prolific source of pilfering for the pickpocket.

title: New Twist on Tax Revolt: Voters Demand More Spending
description: LEAD: FOR the last six months, Bonnie Leach of North Haven has been doing her best to insure that her town will never see another school year like the one that ended on Friday.

title: Q and A
description: Storm Windows

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

African Sports Programs Need U.S. Support
description: LEAD: In 1967, the State Department's budget for assisting the development of international sports programs in Africa was $300,000. Today, that budget is $330,000 (a 10 percent increase while inflation is up 300 to 400 percent). Meanwhile, in the 1970's the Peace Corps eliminated the funding of sports volunteers worldwide and no other agency has ever replaced this loss.

title: Strange Closes In On Open Leaders
description: The United States Open has begun.

title: Some Riffs on a Dream Jazz Festival
description: Of all the cities in the world, New York ought to have a great jazz festival. It's the jazz capital of the world, with most of the major jazz musicians in residence and a sophisticated audience to hear them. New York has been a fountainhead for jazz innovation and a magnet for out-of-towners with new ideas.

title: LOOKING BETTER AND BETTER
description: GENERAL OF THE ARMY

title: Carolyn Nourie Weds D. B. Aspinall Jr.
description: Carolyn J. Nourie and Donald B. Aspinall Jr. were married yesterday at Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Edward Jarvis performed the ceremony, assisted by Deacon Edward L. Doyle, an uncle of the bride, and the bridegroom's sister, the Rev. Barbara Aspinall, a Presbyterian.

title: Israeli Election Reform Awaits Another Crisis
description: The flags still flutter, the posters still scream and the blank petition forms still lie on a folding table, waiting for more signatures from angry citzens.

title: Steaming Along To a Swedish Castle
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to forms of locomotion, you may keep your diesels, your jets, your 0-to-60, four-on-the-floor, fuel-injected ''driving machines.'' Just give me steam. Let me inhale the fragrance of a coal fire, and rejoice in a shower of cinders; let me hear the shrill song of a whistle coming round a bend, and the gentle snort of pistons and drive shafts.

title: Overachieving?
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Bourgeois Romanticism

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: As a maniacal lover of Syracuse Univarsity basketball, and an equal zealot of Derrick Coleman and his skills, I would love for the Nets to trade their top pick. It would be a shame for such an outstanding talent to play for the poorest-run team in organized sports outside of the Bronx.

title: Jay Jennings Wed To Jessica Green
description: Jessica Hawkins Green, a daughter of Helen Spaidal Hawkins of Somerville, Mass., and Edwin Hall Green 3d of Portland Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Earp Franklin Jennings 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Clark Jennings of Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. Edward O. Miller Jr. officiated at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Belmont, Mass.

title: State's Cavalry Gallops Out of History
description: LEAD: EVERY Thursday night, a group of men and women who are on call to defend the state report for training with their horses in Avon, preparing for a military campaign they will probably never see.

title: Schools in Tarrytowns Go Back to the Voters
description: VOTERS in Tarrytown and North Tarrytown return to the polls this week, for their second opportunity to approve financing for the joint school system the two communities operate.

title: LET GO, BREAK LOOSE, TAKE A CHANCE
description: LEAD:

title: Disney World Without Tears
description: DIRECTLY behind Cinderella's Castle, at the center of the Fantasyland section of Walt Disney World's Magic Kingdom, is a merry-go-round of 10 cross-eyed flying elephants, soaring and swooping, each holding two or three squealing children. The ride lasts 90 seconds. The wait one Sunday afternoon last month was 35 minutes. By local standards, this is moderate, and fans of Dumbo find it worthwhile.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Farmingdale
description: LEAD: JAMES G. HICKS and his two children are the fourth and fifth generation of his family to live in Farmingdale, a 1.1-square-mile village on Nassau County's eastern border.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There's a ubiquitous new accessory around. It's not what one might call fashion. It's not good-looking. It adds nothing to any outfit. It's bulky, heavy and, in fact, a nuisance. It has to be replaced daily. Most of the looks it attracts are of astonishment or amusement.

title: Fashion: European Report;   Milan
description: Poor sybilla! arguably the most inventive of the new guard designers to exhibit their fashions in Milan, she may also be the most misunderstood. Maligned by many of the professionals who clambered up steep bleachers for a glimpse of her fall line, Sybilla Sorondo, who is known simply by her first name, has developed a protective front. Slight, waifish and withdrawn, the Spanish designer makes few public appearances, and fewer pronouncements on the state of modern style. Her fashions, it seems, have to speak for themselves.

title: Alice V. Perera Weds David P. Lucey
description: Alice Victoria Perera and David Phillips Lucey were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston by the Rev. Spencer Morgan Rice, assisted by the Rev. Alexander S. Daley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Thacher Perera of Boston. Her husband is a son of Maureen T. Lucey of Jupiter, Fla., and Donald E. Gasiorowski of Holyoke, Mass.

title: Signa V. Merrill Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Signa Vernon Merrill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Merrill of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Ringen Hermann Jr., the son of Lilly Busch Hermann and Mr. Hermann, both of St. Louis. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery officiated at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Action
description: There is much in Shelby Steele's argument that is persuasive. But as a former staff member of the 1968 National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders (also known as the Kerner commission), I must raise a question. The commission criticized ''our nation . . . moving toward two societies, one black, one white - separate and unequal.''

title: Bucky II?
description: If Bucky Dent knows anything, it is recent Yankee history. So it should come as no surprise that less than two weeks after he was replaced by Stump Merrill in the 18th managerial switch of the George Steinbrenner era, Dent was already talking about returning to his old job, although not right away.

title: The Phoenix Is Rising As Others Are Falling
description: THE artistic theme of the Phoenix Theater Company is ensemble, but its new emphasis is expansion.

title: Sri Lanka Rivals Declare Truce; Toll Is Put at 376
description: The Government and Tamil rebels declared a cease-fire today in a new attempt to end a seven-year separatist campaign that has claimed more than 11,000 lives.

title: The Man Who Writes What the Mayor Means
description: When the formal, soft-spoken Mayor who leads New York City speaks out formally in public these days, the words he utters are often the work of John Siegal, a liberal young lawyer who toils in a spare aerie above him with a black pen, a yellow legal pad and a single dictionary.

title: Andrea Suess and Jonathan Taylor Are Married
description: Andrea Maija Suess, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Suess of Pepper Pike, Ohio, was married yesterday to Jonathan Billings Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Taylor of Lockport, N.Y., and Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Ernest DuRoss performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Chagrin Falls, Ohio.

title: The Executive Computer;   A Program That Harnesses Other Software's Strengths
description: It has been less than a month since the Microsoft Corporation introduced Windows 3.0, a major upgrade of its software ''environment'' that overlays the DOS operating system with a quilt of windows, graphical symbols and English-language command menus. Even as Windows 3.0 is being hailed as a breakthrough for office personal computers, however, the Hewlett-Packard Company has come up with something that promises to be even better.

title: Q and A
description: Volcano in Hawaii

title: Perspectives: Rent Guidelines;   Gathering Data for a Board's Judgment
description: A CURIOUS thing happened this year on the way to the annual hearings of the New York City's Rent Guidelines Board. The board met May 9 and proposed new guidelines, doing so before it had in hand the cost study that is supposed to play the key role in formulating the guidelines.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended June 2

title: Boat People's Plight Seen as Likely to Worsen
description: Despite a dramatic drop in the number of Vietnamese boat people seeking asylum here and in other parts of Southeast Asia in recent months, Hong Kong officials and international relief workers said this week that they expected to see scores of the fragile Vietnamese boats pushed back to sea this summer by angry Asian governments.

title: Spare the Shears and Spoil the View
description: THINK of pruning as a form of plant discipline. If this important deed is considered from this viewpoint, gardeners will overcome their fear of cutting anything and will proceed with confidence.

title: Jean R. Weinberg Weds
description: Jean R. Weinberg, a daughter of Mrs. Raymond Weinberg of New York and Tamarac, Fla., and the late Mr. Weinberg, was married in New York yesterday to Thomas C. Pedersen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Pedersen of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Amstein officiated at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Pedersen, a graduate of Colorado College and Brooklyn Law School, was until recently an associate at the New York law firm of Breed Abbott & Morgan. Her husband founded and heads Rheochem Inc., a chemical manufacturing company in Annandale, N.J. He graduated from the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

title: A Time for Everyone to Take Responsibility
description: In some of the articles I've read, one of the reasons for high dropout rates for many students is the lack of consistent, positive and literate role models. By contrast, some successful students, when asked if they have a role model, say there are many people whom they admire and to whom they give credit for their achievements.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   The Synergy of Tuna, Peas and Tomatoes
description: There is a synergy to this simple dish of tuna and peas that produces something far more interesting than it sounds. The sweetness of the peas and the onion takes the edge off the acidity of the tomato puree. Put the individual elements together, add the ease of preparation, and fresh tuna with peas becomes a recipe staple.

title: Wright Fires a 64 In L.P.G.A. Event
description: Pamela Wright shot a six-under-par 64 today - the lowest round of the year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour - to move into a three-way tie for the lead in the Atlantic City Classic at the Sands Country Club.

title: Lynn Kennedy Wed To Robert P. Macrae
description: Lynn Haviland Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Haviland Kennedy of Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Preston Macrae, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Allan Macrae of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. George B. Higgins officiated at the Briarcliff Congregational Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: East 86th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion;   Out of Africa: Beads With a History
description: In centuries past, European traders bartered brightly colored handmade beads in Africa for natural resources like gold, ivory, cocoa, coffee and palm oil. Beads were taken by traders to Africa as highly specialized currencies as late as the 1950's. Today, vintage and antique glass, ceramic and early plastic strands, and more recent interpretations, are among Africa's most popular exports to the United States.

title: Review/Dance;   Charles Moore Group and Drums of Africa
description: Happy people are often dancing people. That became evident on Monday night when the Charles Moore Dance Theater presented ''Dances and Drums of Africa'' at Marymount Manhattan College. The program of celebration featured works derived from traditional African dances, and there was also a dance from Trinidad.

title: New Taxes Add To Regional Burden
description: LEAD: NEWLY imposed state taxes that nick here and gouge there are raising gasoline prices, cutting into corporate profits and jacking up rates for a night in an East End resort as summer begins in earnest on Long Island.

title:
MUSIC;

2 Operas in Festival Pose a Contrast
description: LEAD: THE June Opera Festival of New Jersey involves 10 performances of two contrasting productions this season. The season, which runs through July 8, consists of an ''American Songbook'' concert and five performances each of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' and Strauss's ''Fledermaus,'' at the Kirby Arts Center at the Lawrenceville

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

A Man Who Doesn't Know His Son Is Married
description: LEAD: IF my memory serves me, the radio commercial for a fancy briefcase store went this way. It's a dialogue between a father and a son who haven't spoken to each other for a long time.

title: Headliners;   No Hitting
description: Last week, Nolan Ryan made people over 40 happy, especially if they were not Oakland fans. The A's were on the receiving end as Ryan pitched his sixth no-hitter, at the age of 43, in his 24th major league season, but even they were approving as Ryan and the Texas Rangers beat them 5-0. ''A masterpiece,'' said Carney Lansford, a former teammate of Ryan's, who struck out as a pinch hitter Monday night. President Bush, talking about the game at a Rose Garden ceremony the next day, said, ''What's Nolan, 43?'' Then he called with congratulations. Tommy John, formerly of the Yankees, who stopped pitching last year at the age of 46, admiringly called Ryan a ''freak of nature.'' Ryan has been pitching no-hitters for so long that it's been 15 years since he tied the career record of four held by Sandy Koufax. But while he is the oldest person ever to throw a no-hitter, Ryan is not the only old person to have done it. When Cy Young pitched his third and last no-hitter, in 1908, he was 41.

title: Campus Life: Purdue;   A Short Course In Farm Advice Follows Storms
description: Because it is a land-grant college, Purdue University found itself last week dispensing advice on how to save and plant crops after devastating floods and tornadoes ripped through Indiana in the last month.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: Yes. Since there isn't a bona fide ''franchise'' pick in the draft, the Nets might be better off trading the pick for an established player or two. I think the Nets could pry loose Chris Mullin from Golden State.

title:
ART;

A Venerable Gallery Keeps High Standards
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH many art galleries on the Island seem to last only a season or two, there are a few well-established ones that defy the law of averages. Among the most venerable is Gallery North, which is now celebrating its silver anniversary.

title: NONFICTION
description: OUTCATS: Jazz Composers, Instrumentalists, and Singers. By Francis Davis. (Oxford, $22.95.) In ''Outcats,'' the jazz critic Francis Davis has collected a number of the articles he wrote in the late 1980's. He casts a wide net, covering renowned musicians like Cecil Taylor, Sun Ra and Wynton Marsalis; lesser-knowns like the Parisian expatriate Steve Lacy; and jazzwomen like Jane Ira Bloom and Michele Rosewoman. The tissue connecting these disparate musicians is Mr. Davis's conviction that jazz experimentation succeeds not as an end, but as a means of measuring good craft. Elements of reportage and portraiture give his better critical assessments a sense of intimacy. Writing of the South African exile Abdullah Ibrahim, ''a mesmerizing pianist whose rhythms splash across the keyboard in thunderous ostinato waves,'' he notes, ''As with Ellington, you can hear the colors of an orchestra bleeding together and separating in the voicing of each chord.'' Although references to Duke Ellington do not dominate these pages, the Ellington leitmotif courses through like a bright minor chord. His prose may be dry in parts, but Mr. Davis has the considerable gift of focusing our attention on the tiny pools of influence that musicians enlarge via spontaneous melodies. Another of the strengths of ''Outcats'' is that it exposes readers to jazz artists who have not yet become well known.

title: Ms. Powers Weds George B. Ligeti
description: Jennifer Sieglaff Powers, a daughter of Mrs. Walter M. Hupfel Jr. of Waterford, Conn., and Ralph A. Powers Jr. of New London, Conn., was married yesterday to George Bela Ligeti, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Ligeti of Vancouver, British Columbia. The Rev. David J. Robb, an Episcopalian, officiated at the Pequot Chapel in New London.

description: Tennis

title: Their Yard Now a Pond, Couple In Chappaqua Assail Planners
description: THE backyard of the Lopez home on Brevoort Road here used to be quite pleasant. It had a vegetable garden, a badminton court and lawn chairs, and it was large enough that Rudy Lopez bought a lawn tractor to mow the grass.

title: The Cardinal's Crusade
description: Suddenly, John Cardinal O'Connor has become an important part of the political lives of non-Catholics as well as members of his church.

description: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A DRUID PRINCE

title: Public Services Go Private in Beirut
description: In this city of endless civil war, the collapse of public services has given rise to a new class of entrepreneurs who have taken control of international communications, the mail and power generation.

title: Antarctica
description: To the Editor: Magazine and newspaper articles plus TV programs have decried the impact of tourism on Antarctica. Having just completed a cruise on the Illiria to that area, the following observations are offered to contradict many erroneous allegations.

title:
DINING OUT;

Creatively Presented Regional Dishes
description: LEAD: FOR several years, Cape May has been a center of cosmopolitan dining. The gingerbread village at the southern tip of the Jersey Shore has enough engaging restaurants to keep an adventurous diner busy for a week - places like 410 Bank Street and its sibling, Frescos; Water's Edge and such newcomers as Globe and Es-Ta

title: Campus Life: Vermont;   Lab Workers Exposed To Minor Radiation
description: A University of Vermont biomedical laboratory and four of its workers were found to be slightly contaminated by radiation earlier this month during a routine unannounced inspection by university radiation safety officials.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: A Child's Invitation to Summer Camp Provokes a Crisis
description: The search for summer shoes began in February, when the city was cloaked in gray and the streets were slick with ice.

title: FERNANDEZ TAKES CHARGE
description: New York City's new schools chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, cannot abide mess and disorder. He keeps his desk in a reproachful state of tidiness, and has trouble understanding why others can't do likewise. And so he wasn't just miffed, he was genuinely upset when he saw graffiti on the back of an elementary school, P.S. 234, as he drove down the West Side Highway last January. To Fernandez, the graffiti symbolized the slackness, the tolerance for low standards, of a system that he had sworn to change when he left his job as superintendent of schools in Miami. When he arrived at his office in the Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, Fernandez instructed an aide to call the school principal and get the graffiti removed.

title:
The Executive Life;

Seeking a Family Feeling At a Summer Ritual
description: LEAD: About this time every summer, a sacred corporate ritual gets underway. Dressed in shorts, sweatshirts and sunglasses and doused in equal quantities of suntan lotion and dread, executives and their families head for America's baseball diamonds, wooded groves and picnic grounds to eat hamburgers and corn on the cob under the eyes of their employees.

title: HOW WELL DO WE KNOW THIS MAN?
description: GORBACHEV

title: A Conversation That Made Me Rich
description: Five years ago, I had a second-rate job in the publicity department of a publishing company in Montreal. I hadn't finished college and didn't own a house or drive a decent car. Now I am a millionaire.

title: In Sports, a Gulf Between Sexes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Robin D. Smith Is Wed To Charles Swanberg
description: Robin D. Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Smith of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles H. Swanberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Swanberg of New Canaan, Conn. The ceremony at the Unitarian First Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass., was performed by the Rev. Joseph Bassett and the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., a Presbyterian minister.

title: POLLUTION IN EAST DESCRIBED AS GRIM
description: Environment ministers from Central and Eastern Europe today painted a grim picture of pollution in their countries, saying it was killing their citizens and destroying their cities, rivers and seas.

title: Chernobyl Hero Turns Gravely Ill in Seattle
description: A Soviet helicopter pilot is in critical condition at the Seattle hospital where he recently underwent a bone-marrow transplant for the leukemia he developed after his heroics in the Chernobyl nuclear disaster four years ago.

title: Incentives for Improving Health Care
description: I believe that business and government - working together - can maintain or improve the quality of the country's health care system, while making it more accessible to many uninsured Americans. And, most important, America could very substantially reduce the cost of universal health care coverage.

title: East 86th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Caramoor Festival at 45, From Orchestra to Jazz
description: IN 1946, three recitals in the Music Room at Caramoor began what has become one of the most prestigious and esthetically satisfying summer series in the country, the Caramoor Music Festival. Now, for the 45th season in Katonah, there are six orchestral programs (one of them with full chorus and soloists), five solo recitals, fifteen chamber concerts, a half-dozen matinees for children and even two jazz sessions.

title: Brittany's Rich Capital
description: NANTES, capital of Brittany, is a town of white stone sculptured buildings, with wrought-iron balconies, cobblestone streets and lovely gardens. There is a whiff of sea air, and all roads lead to a river or a river view - although many of its once intensely active quays are now flowery promenades.

title: The Nation;   Designing Tankers To Minimize Oil Spills
description: Lately, and to everyone's disgust, oil and water do mix. As oil globules wash ashore from a spill in the Kill van Kull and fan out from the smoldering tanker in the Gulf of Mexico, America's latest oil import crisis, getting the stuff safely to shore, is stirring new interest in tanker safety. Engineers have proposed several steps, but they often contradict each other.

title:
IN SHORT: NO FICTION;

WARM, SNUGGLY MEMORIES
description: LEAD: Walking barefoot on hot concrete, taking 15 books out of the library, coming home in sneakers filled with sand, being obsessed about love or a suntan - these are the subjects of SUMMER (Addison-Wesley, $35), a lyrical collection of essays and poems by contemporary writers, assembled by Alice Gordon, a writer and editor, and Vincent Virga, a picture editor.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Any journalist who has worked in Moscow will instantly recognize many of the things Robert Cullen is writing about in SOVIET SOURCES (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95). There is the journalistic compound, that ghetto in which reporters are stationed. There is the Soviet bureaucracy, the bugged rooms, the difficulty of reaching contacts. All this remains so in the period of glasnost, though it is in the immediate future that Mr. Cullen has placed his novel.

title: Anti-AIDS Idea in France: Revive Bordellos
description: Should brothels be reopened to help prevent the spread of AIDS by prostitutes?

title: Mary Martin Weds Robert Livingston
description: Mary P. Martin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Martin of Houston, was married there yesterday to Robert E. Livingston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Livingston of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. John C. Perusina officiated at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Brown University, and her husband, a Harvard University graduate, are Ph.D. candidates at Yale University, she in English and he in comparative literature.

title: A SHIMMERING PRESENCE
description: LEAD:

title: K.G.B. Abuses Still Reported
description: A retired senior official of the Soviet security agency accused its leadership of continuing a campaign against citizens perceived as political enemies. Page 12.

title: Music Abroad
description: To the Editor: With events in Eastern Europe happening at breakneck speed, it is not surprising that your information on the Prague Spring Festival (Travel, April 29) was not 100 percent up to date. In your listing of conductors scheduled to perform, you omitted Rafael Kubelik. Maestro Kubelik was the conductor of the Czech Philharmonic until 1948 when he fled Czechoslovakia after the Communist coup.

title: Evening Hours;   Closing The Season With a Flourish
description: The spring party season closed with a flourish Thursday night as guests turned out for charity all over New York City. There was a spectacular ball at the New York Botanical Garden in a vast tent with no poles, a setting that suggested an 18th-century fete at the court of Versailles. The two dance floors were painted to resemble Aubusson carpets, and enormous swags of roses and greens in the della Robbia style were suspended from the tent top.

title: West Side Subway Work Has Riders Lost and Late
description: Hundreds of thousands of subway passengers heading for stores, picnics, weddings, work or wherever were caught in a straphanger's nightmare yesterday when they discovered there was no uptown West Side service on the Nos. 1, 2 or 3 trains between 42d and 96th Streets.

title: More Than One Sluggish Met
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 2-Wheel Commuters Bypass Gridlock
description: SANDY JEFFREY'S rush-hour commute from her home in Milford to her job in New Haven hardly ruffles her, she says. She travels the 20-mile round trip by bicycle and on back roads. ''It's such a great way to relieve tension,'' said Ms. Jeffrey, an administrator at the Yale University School of Medicine. ''Actually, I prefer the ride to a hot cup of morning coffee.''

title: Miss Sargent and T. J. Corcoran Wed
description: Elizabeth A. Sargent, a daughter of Diana Woods Sargent of Penllyn, Pa., and Hugh A. A. Sargent of Gwynedd Valley, Pa., was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Theodore J. Corcoran, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Corcoran of Somers, Conn. The Rev. Charles A. Carter 3d officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Macedonians Blocking Greek-Yugoslav Border
description: Tens of thousands of Macedonian nationalists blocked the border between Yugoslavia and Greece with trucks and trailers today, putting new strains on already difficult relations between the two states.

title: Mark E. Ventling Weds Miss Bean
description: Emelie R. Bean, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin T. Bean Jr. of Buffalo, was married there yesterday at the Westminster Presbyterian Church to Mark E. Ventling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Ventling of Dodge City, Kan. The Rev. Rex T. Stewart officiated, assisted by the Rev. Thomas D. Doyle, a Roman Catholic.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE COCKROACHES OF STAY MORE, by Donald Harington. (Vintage Contemporaries, $9.95.) Dwelling within the cracks of a small Arkansas town, a society of cockroaches undergoes a religious upheaval. This is ''a truly captivating and appealing book,'' Harry Middleton said here last year, ''one that probes the transitory and fragile worlds of man and cockroach alike.''

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Guilford, Conn. $265,400

title: Headliners;   New York on the Moskva
description: Plenty of Americans are baffled by the commodities markets, the Producer Price Index, M-1 and M-2 and so on, so one could expect serious difficulties in explaining it all to the average Soviet citizen. The average Soviet citizen will nevertheless have ''Adam Smith's Money World,'' just like Americans do, starting next fall on the Soviet Central Television Network. Mr. Smith, whose real name is George J. W. Goodman, began this cultural exchange with an hourlong television special last fall on how American entrepreneurs might benefit from perestroika. Further (off the air) discussions led to a sale of broadcast rights for Mr. Goodman's show to a Soviet film distributor. ''Money World,'' which is produced by Alvin H. Perlmutter Inc. and WNET, the major public television station in New York, will be dubbed in Russian. In one respect, the show will have a more capitalistic tinge than it does here: the Soviet broadcasters are going to sell ''image'' advertising to American companies doing business in the Soviet Union.

title: Residents Alarmed by State Plans for Town
description: CHESHIRE is the site of two state prisons. Now that two more are under construction, slated for completion in the fall, and the state has proposed taking over almost half of a condominium project in the town for low- and moderate-income housing, people in Cheshire are saying that they are being asked to shoulder too much of the state's social responsibility.

title:
Nashua, N.H.;

Mill Project In 2d Phase
description: LEAD: FIVE brick buildings that once were part of a cotton mill are on their way to becoming apartments with government help. The project has a $10.2 million Housing and Urban Development grant, tax-exempt bonds issued by the Nashua Housing Authority and a 20 percent Federal historic renovation tax exemption.

title: Trades Steal Show In N.H.L. Draft
description: Dale Hawerchuk and Joe Mullen, two of the National Hockey League's top scorers in the 1980's, found new homes today in a pair of draft-day trades.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should the Nets Trade The No. 1 Draft Pick?
description: The Nets should draft Georgia Tech's Dennis Scott with their No. 1 pick. Trading this pick for a veteran player would not benefit the club over the long run. At 6 foot 8 inches, Scott could provide the long-distance 3-point shooting that they expected from Dennis Hopson.

title: Bonni Orgler Wed To Jay D. Gottlieb
description: Bonni Gaye Orgler, a daughter of Edith Orgler of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., and Joel W. Orgler of Point Pleasant, Pa., was married last evening to Jay David Gottlieb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen S. Gottlieb of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Boca Raton. Rabbi Robert A. Raab officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE HELMSLEYS: The Rise and Fall of Harry and Leona. By Richard Hammer. (NAL Books, $18.95.) The estimated value of the fortune shared by the real estate entrepreneur Harry B. Helmsley and his wife, Leona, ranges from $5 billion to $10 billion. So it seems perfectly logical that they'd want to save a few bucks on their taxes. To the Helmsleys, every dollar was as precious as a piece of prime midtown property; as Mrs. Helmsley was reported to have remarked to her housekeeper: ''We don't pay taxes. Only the little people pay taxes.'' In 1989, Leona Helmsley and two employees, Joseph Licari and Frank Turco, were tried in Federal court for the evasion of in excess of $4 million in Federal and state income taxes, fraud, conspiracy and extortion. (Harry Helmsley was excused from prosecution because he was incapable of aiding in his own defense.) After several months of testimony, Mrs. Helmsley was found guilty on 33 counts of tax evasion, conspiracy, filing false tax returns and mail fraud. Along the way, the public was treated to a view of Leona Helmsley that showed her to be petty, self-absorbed and mean-spirited. This was a woman, writes Richard Hammer in ''The Helmsleys,'' who, upon hearing of the death of her son, turned to an assistant and screamed, ''Don't let them print how old he was.'' Even her own attorney admitted, ''There's no doubt about it, Mrs. Helmsley was a very tough person to do business with, and people went to any lengths to avoid dealing with her.'' Richard Hammer, whose previous books include ''The CBS Murders'' and ''The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano,'' will never be accused of being an accomplished prose stylist: many of his sentences are unwieldy and convoluted. Still, he has done a thorough job of research and is able to put forth his case in a straightforward manner, easily understood even by those of us to whom finance is a foreign language. But if you're looking for revelations here, you won't find much you couldn't have read in the daily newspapers. And for most of us, that was more than enough.

title: Miss Walsh Weds Grant Lippincott
description: Donna Marie Walsh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Walsh of St. James, L.I., was married yesterday to Grant Edward Lippincott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Lippincott of Riverton, N.J. The Rev. Mark H. Earl, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Patrick Earl, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Seaville (N.J.) United Methodist Church.

title: Campus Life: UCLA;   Professor Joining Reopened School In Lithuania
description: The city of Kaunas was home to Lithuania's premier university before the Soviet Union annexed the Baltic country in 1940 and the school closed.

title: Morning to Night in Moscow: Waiting, Ever More Angrily
description: It's morning in Moscow and the streets are a tangle of lives: bureaucrats riding to their jobs in black Volga sedans, housewives rushing between stores, trying to forage meals for their families; streetworkers clogging traffic in their vain attempts to repair the gaping holes in the city's main roads.

title: Wall Street;   A Dark Side to New York City Bonds
description: Municipal bond underwriters and city officials are congratulating themselves for the success of the New York City bond issue sold last week. The $710.5 million offering was ''oversubscribed,'' the lead underwriter, Merrill Lynch, announced sedately. Privately, traders say the bonds were ''a blowout,'' snapped up before they hit the shelves.

title: WHAT WENT WRONG, WHAT TO DO
description: PERIL AND PROMISE: A Commentary on America. By John Chancellor. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) As John Chancellor, the television commentator, looks at the United States, he sees a country facing a complex and competitive world with great power but failing confidence. This loss of faith results, he writes, from ''years of hopes raised and hopes dashed'' - defeat in the ''moral blunder'' of Vietnam, the Arab oil embargo, Watergate, the hostage crisis, inflation and the ''wanton mismanagement of the nation's finances.'' The result of this moral, political and financial battering, he writes, was the Reaganism of the 1980's and its greed, its emphasis on short-term profits, its falling savings and rising debt, and the feeling that we will be even worse off in the future. But this country is still No. 1, he writes. It can remain No. 1, and there is no reason why it shouldn't be. Mr. Chancellor offers several remedies, like all-year schooling, compulsory national service, Congressional campaign reform, a Government ''technology policy'' to aid research and development, a means test for Social Security. None are new; even his most startling idea, the abolition of Presidential primaries and the return of the nominating process to the convention floor, has been proposed before. But they are interesting ideas, and it is disappointing that Mr. Chancellor did not devote more time to them. People who have been paying attention to current events may find little to engage them. But the book seems to be aimed at the people who aren't paying attention. It is written in such simple language and assumes so little knowledge on the part of the reader that some may find it off-putting. On the other hand, if it's true that 24 million Americans cannot find their own country on a map, many people need such a user-friendly book. If they can be induced to read it, they will find it valuable and interesting.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

A Renaissance for the
description: LEAD: What is it about lilacs? For some there are fond childhood memories of lilac fragrance filling the air. They are becoming part of a renaissance for the shrub. Others, who are serious collectors, find a challenge in growing favorites selected from 23 species with over 1,800 cultivars.

title: F.D.A. Warns Beef Producers On Use of a Veterinary Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has warned beef producers against using a non-prescription veterinary product intended to prevent copper deficiency in beef cattle.

title: Deborah Diver Marries
description: Deborah F. Diver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Diver of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to J. Scott Kephart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Kephart of San Anselmo, Calif., The Rev. James R. Bennett 3d officiated at Westminster Presbyterian Church. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College with an M.B.A. from Duke University, Mrs. Kephart is an assistant marketing manager at Tiffany's in New York. Her husband, a graduate of California Polytechnic State University, is a vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.

title: Fashion: European Report;   Paris, Mixing It All Up
description: It would be facile to say that the Paris fall showings were a mess. It would be more candid, though, to describe the mise en scene as an eclectic melange. The collections were full of clothes that were, by turns, scrambles of rearranged themes from the past, reruns of 1960's affectations, lifts from theatrical turns, references to L. L. Bean and other such sporty territories, quick tours of costumery from formerly Iron Curtain countries and contented continuations of status quo style.

title: The Cost of Letting Phone Companies Enter Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Mr. Trump Have Cold Feet?
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Residents Ready To Move On After Barry
description: As the long-running drama of Marion S. Barry Jr. sputters on in court, residents of the nation's capital are increasingly tuning out, wearily grateful that the Mayor's titillating but troubling saga will soon be off the air.

title: Prescription For Boredom
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Pining for Yellow Velvet
description: LEAD: I HAVE always wanted a yellow velvet couch.

title: Pure Groundwater Could Succumb To Developers
description: MANY Long Islanders are more familiar with the source of water for New York City than their own source of water. This can be accounted for by the world-renowned reputation of the city's water supply system.

title: Review/Music;   Florilegium's Zoological Analogies
description: Presumably meant to be varied and diverting, the concert by the Florilegium Chamber Choir on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall came off as half-baked and mostly tedious. The program had a zoological theme of sorts. But its major offering, Schubert's late cantata ''Mirjams Siegesgesang'' (D. 942), has nothing to do with animals other than as an analogy to a shepherd and his flock. And a good thing: the chorus, reflecting all too faithfully the brutal cuts and thrusts of its director, JoAnn Rice, gave the finale a thrashing that might have roused the ire of the A.S.P.C.A.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Campus Life: Washington;   Making Science More Appealing To the Young
description: To junior high school students here, classroom visitors can be as much a novelty as the knowledge they bring. ''You look like the guy in 'Back to the Future, Part II,' '' a seventh-grader told Patrick C. Gibbons, a Washington University associate professor of physics who ventured into Brittany Woods Junior High School recently.

title: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Actionv
description: Shelby Steele's article is the most sensible analysis of affirmative action I have seen. His statement, ''Preferential treatment does not teach skills, or educate, or instill motivation. It only passes out entitlement by color, a situation that in my profession has created an unrealistically high demand for black professors,'' is the direct answer to Professor Derrick Bell, of Harvard Law School, who said that until the school hires a black female professor with tenure, he would go on an unpaid leave of absence.

title: Black Group Assails Giving Bleach to Addicts
description: Saying that giving bleach to drug addicts has never been shown to prevent the spread of AIDS, a group of black professionals and religious leaders in New York City has denounced its distribution to intravenous-drug users.

title: The Task Facing Lowey's Challenger
description: WHEN Nita M. Lowey decided two years ago to challenge Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, the two-term Republican from Westchester's 20th Congressional District, she faced some formidable obstacles: it was her first run for elected office, her opponent was well-financed and two other Democrats were seeking the post.

title: Corinne Ham Is Married
description: Corinne M. Ham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Ham of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dwight T. Collins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Collins of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Harvey Ballance officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Providence, R.I. Mrs. Collins, 24 years old, graduated from Boston University and is the marketing production coordinator in New York for the Spanish-language television network Univision. Mr. Collins, 32, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and is a vice president of a family-run real-estate company in Stamford, Conn.

title: Portuguese Fare and Value in Waterbury
description: FOR people who like to dine out but lament the rapid escalation of restaurant prices, there is still some basis for hope: think ethnic. Many ethnic restaurants are less expensive than other types. And among these establishments, none offer more reasonable prices or greater value than the Portuguese.

title: Bats In Bronx: A Yankee Caper
description: Members of the Yankees' front office, acting under orders from George Steinbrenner, have for several years checked the visiting clubhouse late at night after games to see if the opposition's bats were altered, former Yankee employees say.

A woman voices the 92 personalities that live within her. 4 * 2 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 5 347 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 6 6 LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Bantam, $4.95.) Observations on romantic relationships. 7 2 MEET THE NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK. (Signet/NAL, $3.95.) Photographs of and commentary on the popular singing group. 8 * 6 FROM CRADLE TO GRAVE, by Joyce Egginton. (Jove, $4.95.) The case of a Schenectady, N.Y., woman whose nine children all died mysteriously. 9 2 WHY ME? by Sammy Davis Jr. and Jane and Burt Boyar. (Warner, $5.95.) The autobiography of the late entertainer. 10 * 10 SUMMER OF '49, by David Halberstam. (Avon, $4.95.) The year the Red Sox and the Yankees battled to the last game for the pennant. 11* 3 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Steve Vogel. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The case of a respectable businessman suspected of killing his family. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 19 50 SIMPLE THINGS YOU CAN DO TO SAVE THE EARTH, by the Earthworks Group. (Earthworks Press/Publishers Group West, $4.95.) Ways to combat environmental problems. 2 13 WEIRDOS FROM ANOTHER PLANET! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 93 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. 4 17 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $7.95.) The 1990 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 8 50 SIMPLE THINGS KIDS CAN DO TO SAVE THE EARTH, by the Earthworks Group. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) Solutions to ecological problems.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: DAD'S DAY OUT

title: Sarah Newman Married To Dr. Zachary G. Klett
description: Sara E. Newman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Newman of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Zachary G. Klett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Klett of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Shannon Bernard officiated at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: New Interactive TV Threatens the Bliss Of Couch Potatoes
description: New television services that capitalize on computer technology are beginning to allow viewers to become more involved in what they watch, either by controlling what is seen on the screen or by becoming armchair participants in game shows or sporting events.

title: I.R.S. AUDITS RISING FOR FOREIGN BANKS DOING U.S. BUSINESS
description: The Internal Revenue Service has sharply increased its audits of foreign banks that do business in the United States, after finding that many paid little or no income tax in the mid-1980's.

title: What Price Panama?
description: As indications of brutal U.S. overkill in the illegal invasion of Panama keep turning up, the Bush Administration is mounting only a weak case against the invasion's prime target, the alleged drug kingpin, Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Drug Policy Debate Turns to Feud Between Moynihan and Bennett
description: A disagreement over drug treatment programs has suddenly grown into a political feud between President Bush's drug policy director and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat.

title: Reroute Buses With Care
description: New York City's Transit Authority, faced with losses on bus service, does well to re-evaluate bus routes. It ought not to be deterred by the initial complaints from riders fearing abandonment.

title: Jays' Stottlemyre Has Gift for Dad
