The case worker, Bruce Matthews, 33 years old, of Jersey City, was arrested on charges of fraud, forgery, theft of services and falsifying records, said Lori Rankin, the county director of communications. The welfare clients, Dennis Jones, 29, and Rachel Childs, 34, both of Jersey City, were arrested on charges of receiving county welfare checks under false pretenses, Ms. Rankin said.

title: College;   Big College Football Leagues Are Trying to Get Bigger Still
description: Like superpowers dividing up the globe to expand their empires, the nation's major football conferences are raiding other conferences and courting independent schools for stronger teams. Inspired by the lure of larger television market shares, the conferences are setting the stage for regional college football monopolies by the middle of the 1990's.

title: Studies Don't Support Passive Smoking Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: For Theatrical Palaces Of 42d St., a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Viola Wins 10th as Mets Pull Within 3 of Pirates
description: Len Dykstra blew into town with his .384 batting average last night and made his first appearance of the year in the old ball yard. But neither he nor Ken Howell nor the rest of the Philadelphia Phillies could slow the streaking Mets, who rammed across five runs inside two innings and bowled on past the Phillies, 5-1.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Sir Tom Hopkinson, Photojournalist, 85
description: Sir Tom Hopkinson, a pioneer in British photojournalism, died on Wednesday at his home in Oxford, his family said today. He was 85 years old. Mr. Hopkinson was editor of the now defunct magazine Picture Post from 1940 to 1950 and of the South African magazine Drum, which was aimed at black readers, from 1958 to 1961. He specialized in the use of bold, observant photographs to raise awareness of society's ills.

title: Review/Music;   Mims and Kraus in 'Traviata' in Park
description: Circumstances seemed to conspire against the Metropolitan Opera's free performance of ''La Traviata'' on the Great Lawn of Central Park. The Verdi opera was to have been heard on Tuesday, but a thunderstorm forced the company to postpone the performance until Thursday evening.

title: Two Summer Places
description: We started coming to this island in summertime 25 years ago because it was beautiful, oceanic and hard to get to, but within our price range, which was not extensive.

title: Court Ruling on Patronage Gets Some Mixed Reviews
description: To get his job, Jim Weyrick never submitted a resume, never took a test. He just knew the right people. And he volunteered to distribute the right political literature.

title: Milt Hinton at 80: A Celebration
description: Milt Hinton, who is being honored tonight at Town Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival for his 80th birthday, can still walk a bass line that awes other musicians. The fat and firm Hinton sound is propelled by an unfailingly perfect beat in which notes fall in the sort of geometric perfection that few can equal.

title: Henley May End Its Stake in Itel
description: The Henley Group Inc. said it might dispose of its 38.5 percent stake in the Itel Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Henley said it planned to register to sell between 8 million and 16.7 million Itel shares through a public offering. The remaining two million Itel shares will be contributed to its Fisher International Inc. subsidiary. Henley did not give a reason for the proposed sale in the filing, which came after the close of trading today.

title: Durables Orders Up Last Month
description: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods jumped 3.9 percent in May, the Government reported today. Analysts said it was further evidence that the economy's sluggish manufacturing sector might be bouncing back.

title: Your Money;   Family Businesses Helped by Ruling
description: Financial advisers to family-owned businesses are taking heart from a court decision in March on the estate of the publisher Samuel I. Newhouse. The court held that the younger generation of the Newhouse family had been actively involved in managing the business, and therefore some of its value was attributable to them, rather than to the pater familias.

title: Affirmative Action Is at Least on the Right Track
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Yesterday was fund-raising day in New York as 1,700 experts in coaxing money for worthy institutions held their 11th annual conference. As usual, they tossed some bouquets at luminaries in the philanthropy field.

title: An F.D.R. Memorial Finally Wins Approval
description: The Commission of Fine Arts has approved a $47 million memorial to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, ending a quarter-century of controversy and stalemate over its design.

title: Liberia Talks in Lull; Rebels Take Town
description: Efforts to reach a peaceful settlement of the Liberian crisis made little headway today, and there were indications that the rebel forces are poised to advance on Monrovia unless major political concessions are offered soon.

title: Regents Exams Called Secure
description: Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol said today that Regents examinations had been completed this week without a repetition of last year's stolen tests. The state shipped 1.6 million examinations and 900,000 answer keys to high schools, and not one was reported stolen, Mr. Sobol said. The one-week testing period ended on Thursday. Last June, a chemistry Regents exam was called off after The New York Post, demonstrating the market in stolen tests, published the answer key on its front page.

title: Coniston Pool For Investing Is Disbanded
description: Coniston Partners has run out of companies to raid. Coniston, one of the best-known and most-feared corporate investors of the 1980's, said yesterday that it planned to dissolve its $700 million investment pool and return the money to its limited partners.

title: Brooklyn Museum to Cut Staff, Hours and Exhibits
description: Anticipating a sharp cut in financial support by New York City and a projected deficit of more than $1 million, the Brooklyn Museum plans to eliminate 15 percent of its 300 staff positions, cut its visiting hours and effectively keep one of its finest collections from public view.

title: Thompson Will Stay As Coach of the Hoyas
description: John Thompson, the basketball coach at Georgetown, yesterday chose to remain at the school, where victories seem to come easily, rather than become general manager of the Denver Nuggets, a National Basketball Association franchise in search of consistent winning ways.

title: A Brazen Assault on Legal Services
description: The Legal Services Corporation is a survivor. It's been attacked by losing litigants and Ronald Reagan, who felt that providing lawyers for the poor was an exercise in radical social engineering. President Bush, urged by his right wing to press the assault, has instead pursued moderation, appointing a mixture of friends, foes and the uncommitted to the corporation's board.

title: Testing the Testers: Questions Raised About Labs' Accuracy
description: At a time of rapidly growing demand for tests of environmental hazards, many commercial laboratories are producing misleading and inaccurate information.

title: CANADA ABANDONS ACCORD ON QUEBEC
description: The Canadian Government conceded tonight that a long and divisive effort to confer a special constitutional status on Quebec had failed.

title: Who Should Control Professional Tennis?
description: FOR tennis people June is a time to ask, ''Where do we go from here.'' For the top-flight players, the answer is easy. They go where the money is, and that means they go to Wimbledon, and from there to the remaining Grand Slam events and other major tournaments around the world. For the spectators, the answer is much the same. They go where the action is, to Wimbledon, particularly if they can get a ticket for the Centre Court, then to subsequent Grand Slam tournaments and other major events.

title:
DINING OUT;

In N. Salem, a Reputation Is Maintained
description: LEAD: EVER since its opening 13 years ago, Auberge Maxime has managed to maintain its deserved reputation for being one of the better restaurants in the area. The continuing enthusiasm and embellishments lavished on this establishment by the chef and owner, Bernard LeBris, and his wife, Heidi, have made it a gracious dining place of much refinement and natural elegance, formal, yet clearly and beautifully of the provinces.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: At the Other End of Poetry

title: Article 630990 -- No Title
description: The American Museum of Natural History has announced a $2.5 million pledge from the Exxon Corporation for the renovation of its fossil halls and library. Plans for the renovation, which is expected to cost $40 million, are to be announced in the fall. At that time the museum will also announce plans for its fund-raising drive.

title: Susan Yannella and Jeffrey Harrigan Are Wed
description: Susan A. Yannella, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Donald Yannella of Marlton, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey J. Harrigan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Harrigan of Corona del Mar, Calif., at Our Mother of Consolation Roman Catholic Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. The Rev. Ray Jackson officiated.

title: Karen Kesselman, Ad Executive, Wed
description: Karen Ruth Kesselman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Kesselman of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Lindsay Adam Gardner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gardner of Beverly Hills, Calif., at Alger House in New York, by Cantor Ellen Math.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin;   Officials Criticized For Failing to Give Crime Statistics
description: Of ficials at the Uni versity of Wis consin here are drawing criticism for failing to release sexual-assault statistics to incoming students, as required by a new state law. The University of Wisconsin system is required to include such statistics as well as safety information in orientation programs to new students under the law, which was enacted last April.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Most people have security blankets. Security blankets, plural - because rarely is it only one thing that provides a sense of tranquillity.

title: Amy Bartlett Marries Robert A. Regan
description: Amy C. Bartlett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Bartlett of Bolton Landing, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert A. Regan, a son of Mildred M. Regan of Binghamton, N.Y., and the late Martin P. Regan. The Rev. Peter Young officiated at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Bolton Landing.

title: From Japan, an 'Italian' Car
description: YOU say you want a Lamborghini Diablo but the $200,000 tag seems a bit steep? And you'd settle for a new Ferrari 348, except that the kids need braces? Is that your problem? Is that your trouble, Bunkie?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 27 about the Eisenhower Museum in Abilene, Kan., misidentified an artillery piece. It was a 57-millimeter antitank gun, not a 50-millimeter howitzer.

title: India: Getting Back Into Old Habits
description: There is no commercial broadcasting in India, so national television news, broadcast for a half-hour in both Hindi and English, is a Government monopoly. The program hit rock bottom in credibility under former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, whose ministers made it a propaganda machine. When the Government of Vishwanath Pratap Singh came to power in December, it promised to free the news by setting up a public corporation something like the BBC. The television news department took heart, and for a few weeks the news improved dramatically.

title: THE BROWN-RICING OF AMERICA
description: APPETITE FOR CHANGE %How the Counterculture Took On the Food Industry, 1966-1988.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: A DISCORDANT INTIMACY
description: BLOOD, CLASS, AND NOSTALGIA

title: Gardening Equipment Provokes a New Look At Noise Ordinances
description: SOME residents complain that spring and summer arrive in this suburban community not with the gentle sound of birds chirping in the treetops and children gamboling in the yards but with the deafening sounds of high-powered garden equipment going full blast, as crews of landscape maintenance workers mow lawns, trim bushes and blow away the debris.

title: Campus Life: Indiana;   Anti-Bias Policy Could Start R.O.T.C. Conflict
description: Indiana University has revised its student ethics code, but officials differ on whether a ban on discrimination against homosexuals can coexist with the Reserve Officer Training Corps. The revised code, which the trustees approved last month, prohibits bias based on race, sex or sexual orientation. Although the university has followed policies against racial and sexual harassment since the original code was adopted in 1969, the revision includes the first ban on discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Jazz Festival;   Dizzy Gillespie and Horn In an Exploratory Mood
description: The Dizzy Gillespie United Nation Orchestra turned in a pan-American variety show at Carnegie Hall on Friday, the opening night of the jazz festival. Mr. Gillespie was the featured performer with a big band whose players hailed from the United States, the Caribbean and Brazil, and while the show honored Mr. Gillespie's longstanding connections to Latin music, it also made room for numbers by half a dozen band members.

title: Giuseppina Lacarra Is Wed To Howard B. Bloomer 3d
description: Giuseppina Lacarra, a daughter of the late Cavaliere Riccardo Lacarra and the late Olga Ricciardi, both of Naples, was married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York to Howard Bradley Bloomer 3d, a son of Katherine Leadbeater Bloomer of Alexandria, Va., and the late Mr. Bloomer Jr. The Rev. Dr. Hayes Rockwell officiated.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   For Children: Videos, Crayons, Antelope Chandeliers and Food
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants suitable for children. Border Cafe 2637 Broadway, at 100th Street (212-749-8888) - This restaurant with a Southwestern theme is particulaly congenial for children and tries to keep them entertained with crayons, balloons and even video monitors overhead. It also has a ''grazing bar'' where children are encouraged to inspect some of the raw ingredients that go into the food. The children's menu is essentially a scaled down version of the adult bill of fare. Choices include mini-hamburgers, enchiladas, ''monster'' nachos (a big tortilla chip with melted cheese and mild hot peppers), chicken wings and barbecued chicken and ribs. Pitchers of soda and nonalcohol pina coladas are served.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 10 about the tomb of Galla Placidia in Ravenna, Italy, misstated its age. It was built in the fifth century, not the sixth.

title: Revolution's Heirs Keep Patriotism High and Profile Low
description: BENEATH the timber-beamed ceiling of Matthie's Meeting Hall on the 250-year-old Oliver Ellsworth Homestead in Windsor, 33-year-old Lynn Stewart stood at a podium next to an American flag and recited a roll call of the 55 chapters of the Connecticut Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution. With chapters named for patriotic women of the Revolutionary period, names like Abigail Phelps, Free Love Baldwin Stow and Anna Warner Bailey echoed through the rustic hall.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Sales of existing homes for May. Ten-day auto sales through June 20.

title: Reagan Rexrode Weds James Dryfoos
description: Reagan Hope Rexrode and James David Dryfoos were married yesterday at the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., by the Rev. Jeffrey Dennis May, a Lutheran minister. Ramona R. Goodwin, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor. Seth Richard Thomas 3d, a cousin of the bridegroom, was the best man.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Cambridge, Mass.;

The New Look At Harvard Sq.
description: LEAD: Construction has begun on two office/retail buildings on adjacent sites in Harvard Square, marking a major push to complete the square's 15-year-long redevelopment.

title: South Africa: News Control For Neophytes
description: When Nelson Mandela was released from prison in February, the South African Broadcasting Corporation sent a news team to provide live coverage. But Mr. Mandela emerged 75 minutes late, and SABC-TV was unprepared. While foreign networks filled the time with interviews of people in the crowd and background pieces, SABC-TV's correspondent stood in front of his camera making awkward small talk without turning to interview any of several thousand supporters of Mr. Mandela nearby.

title: Marketing 'Mama': A Little Gospel And a Lot of Savvy
description: On the seventh anniversary this spring of the black gospel musical ''Mama, I Want to Sing,'' Vy Higginsen, who wrote and produced the show with her husband, Ken Wydro, beamed her thanks from the stage to ''all of you wonderful people who have made our show the longest-running black musical in theater history.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The bathroom window inside our tub/shower area has deteriorated from exposure to dampness. For the new window, we are trying to decide between another one of wood or a vinyl one. Which do you recommend?

title: Campus Life: Tufts;   Dental Students Offer Free Exam To Emigres
description: Trying to im prove health care for some of America's most recent emigres, students from Tufts University and Boston University held a free dental screening last Sunday for children from the Soviet Union and Eastern bloc nations who have settled in the Boston area. The program was run under the auspices of Alpha Omega International, the Jewish dental fraternity. The Jewish Family and Childrens Services of Greater Boston estimates that between 8,000 and 10,000 Eastern European immigrants now live in the Boston area.

title: The Executive Computer;   The Latest Laptops: Faster, Sleeker, More Powerful
description: The inexorable trend in portable computers has been smaller, faster, cheaper, more powerful. Even so, there were a number of surprises among the latest products on display last week at the annual PC Expo show in Manhattan.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS MEMORIAL
description: When I read ''Voices at the Wall'' (May 27), I thought that my father, Tad Yoshizawa, a retired lieutenant colonel in the United States Air Force, might have contributed to the poignant reflections in Michael Norman's article. I was wrong, of course. But I would like to contribute his experience now. I should begin by saying that my father is a man of few words and even fewer stories of this nature.

title: SMALL TRAGEDIES AND ORDINARY PASSIONS
description: LANTERN SLIDES

title: The Poppers and the Plains
description: BUFFALOES THUNDER ACROSS POSTERS, POSE FOR BUMPER STICKERS and glower from coffee mugs in Frank Popper's crowded office at Rutgers University in New Jersey. There is even a sack of dried buffalo droppings. ''Genuine Virgin Buffalo Chips,'' the label reads. ''Pioneer Fertilizer and Fuel. Not for Microwave Ovens. Contents Public Domain.''

title: Staying on the Safe Side; New York
description: The Big Apple is a mecca for the arts, theater, music, nightlife and historical attractions, but an unwary visitor makes easy prey for confidence men, rip-off artists and muggers, the police say.

title: Maintaining Wicker Furniture
description: WICKER porch furniture is durable if maintained, but neglected items can rapidly deteriorate beyond the point of easy repair.

title: Miles Davis's Variations on Familiar Theme
description: Miles Davis's show at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, didn't prove much about Mr. Davis except his continuing ability to fill the hall. Mr. Davis has been playing roughly the same set for several years now, and like his previous shows recently, his context -dated jazz-funk - fell pathetically short of his abilities.

title: A Civil Rights Theme For A Writing Course Campus Life: Texas
description: Beginning in the fall, first-year students in composition courses at the University of Texas will no longer write extemporaneous essays on whichever William Faulkner short story or Henry James essay their instructor picks from their textbooks. Instead, their reading and writing will focus on landmark affirmative- action and civil rights cases, as a result of curriculum changes by the English department.

title: Staying on the Safe Side: Buenos Aires
description: Many visitors to this vast city of 11 million believe the most dangerous thing about it is the drivers, who invent the rules as they go along - always to the dismay, if not outright terror, of pedestrians.

title: Island Feeling Effects of Slump In City Economy
description: AS New York City's financial problems deepen, Long Island, an important source of labor for the city and a major market for its products, is beginning to feel the effects.

title: ABU NIDAL'S RIVALS SEEM TO BE GAINING
description: The Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal appears to be losing ground in a struggle for control of his group to rivals who say they will follow the less militant guidelines of Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Major and Minor Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Jody Koch Weds Joseph R. Megale
description: St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jody Lynn Koch, a daughter of Mrs. Paul C. Lehmuller of Mill Neck, L.I., and the late Charles G. Koch, to Joseph Raleigh Megale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Megale of Freeport, L.I. The Rev. Charles Ribaudo performed the ceremony.

title: Are There Really Any Billionaires?
description: In an age when millionaire no longer sounds very rich, billionaire still has a certain ring to it. Last week, on Manhattan's East Side, two very different men, each of whom became the best-known ''billionaire'' of an era, could reflect on shifting fortunes.

title: Leslie Hodges Is Bride Of Andrew McD. Blau
description: Leslie Fox Hodges, a teaching assistant at the Chapin School in New York, was married yesterday to Andrew McDara Blau, a stockbroker at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The Very Rev. Arnold E. Mintz performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Headliners;   No Relief
description: If Dennis Barrie's job is bringing the avant garde to the public, then he has succeeded, and he is not going unpunished. Last week, the director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati was ordered to stand trial on obscenity charges brought when the Robert Mapplethorpe exhibition opened at the center in April. ''I was hoping it would be dismissed and that we could go on with life,'' said Mr. Barrie. But a Hamilton County municipal judge sustained the indictment for displaying photographs of children ''in a state of nudity'' and deferred a ruling on charges involving homoerotic images. When Mr. Barrie was hired in 1983, ''what attracted the board to him was his reputation for bringing the community in,'' Derrick Woodham, director of the University of Cincinnati's art school, explained recently. Even before Mapplethorpe, Mr. Barrie doubled the membership of the center, which occupies a gallery above a Walgreen's store. And the Mapplethorpe exhibition drew more people (81,302 in seven weeks) than any in the city's history. The trial is to begin Sept. 24, by which time the show will be at its next stop, in Boston.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 17 about the rental market misidentified the company with three brokerage offices managed by Roberta Faulstick. It is William B. May.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

A New and Bigger Roxbury Square Mall
description: LEAD: The Roxbury Square Mall, a fixture in Roxbury Township for 20 years, is undergoing a $58 million renovation and expansion despite a state retail market that is generally in the doldrums.

title: Electric-Chair Dispute Brings Another Stay
description: A murderer who contends that Florida's electric chair is unfit for use won a stay of execution from a Federal appeals court today, one day after a Federal district judge had rejected the same argument.

title: Beaches and Tourism Go Together
description: Re: ''A Beach Fee Dispute and a Question: Is Tourism Necessary?'' May 27:

title: John S. P. Burke Wed To Mary S. Schambach
description: Mary S. Schambach, a daughter of Mary W. T. Schambach of Lexington, Va., and the late William J. Schambach, was married yesterday to John S. P. Burke, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Burke of Hilton Head, S.C. The Rev. J. Morton Biber officiated at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Lexington.

title: OFFICER CHEE HAS SOMETHING TO PROVE
description: COYOTE WAITS

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: Giap Remembers
description: WE MET AT THE FORMER FRENCH COLONIAL governor's palace in Hanoi, an ornate mansion set in a spacious garden ablaze with hibiscus and bougainvillea, where senior Vietnamese officials receive guests. A short man with smooth skin, white hair, narrow eyes and a spry gait, he wore a simple olive uniform, the four stars on its collar the only sign of his rank. Smiling broadly, he grasped me with soft, almost feminine hands and then, to my astonishment, bussed my cheeks in traditional French style.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: SHE makes an unlikely crusader, this 66-year-old former nun with gray hair and glasses who smokes too much, doesn't drive a car and hates to get up early in the morning.

title: With Regrets
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE FALL TO WONDERLAND
description: THE BARNUM MUSEUM

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Vancouver
description: Often called the San Francisco of Canada, Vancouver, British Columbia, shares more than a bracing waterfront and international flavor with the Bay Area. Western Canada's largest city also has a property crime rate to rival other Pacific Rim ports.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Customer's Right? Customer's Rude
description: LEAD: WHEN I was a management trainee at Marshall Field's in Chicago, I was taught that the customer is always right. ''Give the lady what she wants,'' they said. But, after 30 years of helping the public - first at Field's, then in my own specialty store and now as a professional horticulturist in a large garden center in Connecticut -

title: Guerrilla Says Arafat Can Penalize His Unit
description: The Palestinian guerrilla leader Abul Abbas said today that he and his faction were prepared to accept disciplinary action by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, for the raid that they staged on an Israeli beach last month.

title:
Style Makers;

Alfredo Barutti: Gilder
description: LEAD: Alfredo Barutti's first love was music, but his father insisted that he learn a trade. He became a gilder, but when he had a family of his own, he encouraged his children to study music.

title: A New Hotel and Its New Restaurant
description: AN out-of-towner staying at the new Radisson Plaza Hotel in Melville wanders down to La Prima, the hotel's dining room. He looks at the menu and sees that a veal chop costs $38.50. Does he storm out or assume that this is typical of Long Island prices?

title: Allithea Lango Married
description: Allithea E. Lango, a daughter of Allithea Cary Lango of Boston and the late Francis E. Lango, was married yesterday to Henry W. Killeen 3d, the son of Ruth Dold Killeen of Buffalo and the late Henry W. Killeen. The Rev. Ward Ewing officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Buffalo. Mrs. Killeen, 41 years old, is an assistant Attorney General for the State of New York in Buffalo. A graduate of Wheaton College, she has a law degree from Syracuse University. The bridegroom, 43, is a senior partner in the law firm of Jaeckle, Fleischmann & Mugel in Buffalo. He graduated cum laude from Harvard University and has a law degree from the State University at Buffalo.

title: Czyz and Maynard To Fight Today
description: Bobby Czyz, a former light-heavyweight champion, continues his comeback attempt Sunday with a 10-round bout against Andrew Maynard, an undefeated 1988 Olympic gold medalist.

title: Dramatic Harmony in Student Exchange
description: THREE drama students were rehearsing a scene from Tennesee Williams's play ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' Stella, played by an American, spoke English; Blanche, played by a student from the Soviet Union, spoke English with a Russian accent, and Stanley spoke Russian. When the young actors finished, their fellow students applauded, and their teacher, Sylvia Harman, smiled. ''I'm so proud of them,'' she said.

title: Toni Florin Is Married
description: Toni Florin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Florin of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday in New York to Scott V. Donahue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Donahue of LaGrangeville, N.Y., by M. Michael Grupp, an American Ethical Union leader, at Le Club. Mrs. Donahue, a Boston University graduate, is a real-estate broker with R. J. Wolff, and the bridegroom, a Colgate University graduate, a bond salesman at R. D. Smith, both in New York.

title: SOCCER'S LITTLE BIG MAN
description: As a Brazilian, I was shocked to read that after England's cup victory in 1966, there was a ''diminishment of the influence of . . . Pele.'' In 1970, Brazil had the best soccer team ever assembled - it was Pele's best cup performance and we owed nothing to the English.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Guaranteed Buybacks to Stimulate Sales
description: LEAD: Many residential developers in Westchester are resorting to incentive programs to move unsold town houses and apartments, and two are guaranteeing the resale value of their homes by offering to buy them back after three years.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: Stressing the ''W'' over the ''$'' is precisely what the Pistons are best at doing. Led by the spirit of Dennis Rodman, a man who gets his satisfaction from becoming a brick in a wall, each of the Pistons has a specific task, a particular aspect of the game that they excel in, adding up to a team that can overcome individual foul troubles, cold shooting, and injuries.

title: Headliners;   Endless Melody
description: Brunnhilde has probably never had such exposure. All week long, Hildegard Behrens was in front of the prime-time television audience in almost every city in America, along with Jessye Norman, Siegfried Jerusalem and other cast members of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' The Metropolitan Opera production, which was filmed over two years at a cost of $5 million, was quite a risk for the Public Broadcasting System. For viewers, there were several advantages: the price was right, casual dress was acceptable, and English translation was provided in concise if sometimes odd subtitles. On the other hand, to follow the ''endless melody'' core of Wagner's vision required 17 hours of attention Monday through Thursday evenings. (Opportunities for cheating included baseball, ''Roseanne,'' ''Cheers'' and ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'') At the end of the week, PBS officials were delighted to report that the four-day cycle drew about 3 percent of the audience, more than they expected and only slightly less than the average rating for public television offerings during prime time the previous week. ''Eventually, Nielsen will tell us how many people taped it,'' said John Fuller, director of research for PBS. ''Of course, what they won't be able to tell us is how many play it back.''

title: Jennifer Hoffman Wed in Rochester
description: Jennifer Y. Hoffman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin J. Hoffman of Rochester, was married there last evening to Mark Frederic Hirshorn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Hirshorn of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi Judea Miller officiated at Temple B'rith Kodesh.

title: Style Makers;   Jean Pearman: Designer of Tennis Clothes
description: If your husband happens to be a champion croquet player, you spend a lot of time wilting as you watch him play in tournaments. A tennis player herself, Jean Pearman found herself thinking about the perfect outfit to play in - one that would look as crisp after a couple of sets as when she started out.

title: Canada's Beleaguered Currency
description: The British pound is on the up and up. On Friday, it rose to $1.7330, its highest level against the dollar since March of 1989. The jump came after the release of trade figures that were slightly better than expected and another statement of commitment to high interest rates from John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchecquer. With London apparently finally committed to join the European Monetary System soon, the rally should continue. In Canada, concern over the constitutional crisis weakened the Canadian dollar so much that the Bank of Canada and the Bank of England intervened to support the bleaguered currency. After the Government said it might get an extension of the June 23 deadline for a constitutional accord, the Canadian dollar rebounded a little.

title: Power Authority Is Necessary To Oversee Lilco
description: ROBERT McMILLAN, former Republican candidate for the United States Senate, recently suggested that the State Legislature should scrap the Long Island Power Authority and allow the Long Island Lighting Company to manage Long Island's energy affairs. While Mr. McMillan may have full confidence in Lilco, I don't. That is why the Long Island Power Authority is so essential to Long Island's future.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The bathroom window inside our tub/shower area has deteriorated from exposure to dampness. For the new window, we are trying to decide between another one of wood or a vinyl one. Which do you recommend?

title: Canoe Camping, Family Style
description: IMAGINE a day without telephones, cars, newspapers, or television; a week where money means nothing; two weeks without caring to know more about the time than the sun can tell you. Now place your unharried self on a peninsula that juts out into a corner of an uninhabited lake a two-day trip from the nearest road. To your left is a marshy bay where moose come to feed at dawn. To your right, on the opposite shore, is a waterfall that invites you behind the curtain of shining water to clamber along the rock-strewn bed of its feeder stream to its source in an upper lake. You spend the afternoon fishing, scouting the rest of the lake for a place to picnic and swim, or napping in a hammock strung between two pines. In the evening, as the sun goes down in reds and golds, you find a circle of stones out on the point of the peninsula where you build a fire to ward off the evening chill. In the gathering dusk, loons call to each other. A beaver swims by; one by one the stars come out.

title: No Headline
description: MAY YOU BE THE MOTHER OF A HUNDRED SONS

title: Simona McCray Weds Kenneth R. Peterson
description: Simona McCray, the executive vice president of the WQXR radio stations in New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth R. Peterson, who will retire this month as a manager in public relations for Mobil in New York. Samuel J. Silverman, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, officiated at the couple's home in Brooklyn.

title: Lower Budget, Lower Spending?
description: Having spent a good many of my 80 years absorbing the budget talks of a good many politicians, I have just about come to the reluctant conclusion that budgets will never get smaller, and that government agencies will never leave a single budget penny unspent, no matter how unwisely.

title: Christina Margareta Swanson Is Wed
description: Christina Margareta Swanson, a daughter of Dolores Swanson of Montclair, N.J., and the late Edward R. Swanson, was married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Montclair to John Anthony Montgomery Jr., the son of Mr. Montgomery and J. Pauley Montgomery , both of New York. The Rev. Park P. Dickerson officiated.

title: From Ballplayer to Broadcaster: A Rocky Road
description: THERE is nothing so disheartening in the wrenching drama of professional sports than to watch a great athlete hang on a little too long and be humbled. It happened to Muhammad Ali when, at 38 years old, he attempted to win the heavyweight title for the fourth time, against Larry Holmes. It almost happened to Jimmy Connors when, at 36 and playing in the quarterfinals of the 1988 United States Open, he was nearly ground stroked to death by Andre Agassi in three lopsided sets. Of course, Connors returned with more zest last year and almost pulled off a miraculous comeback in the fifth, heartstopping set against the younger Agassi.

title: Mandela and Ruslan
description: The moment Nelson Mandela walked into the room at Gracie Mansion I was sure we had met before and as he talked the feeling grew.

title: Jazz Festival;   The Ragtime Piano Man, Terry Waldo
description: The JVC Festival opened its Solo Piano series at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night with a performance by Terry Waldo, a ragtime and early jazz specialist. Mr. Waldo, who studied with the pianist and composer Eubie Blake, is an amiable performer - he spent part of the show fielding questions from the audience - who never lets the archival presentation of the music interfere with the music's basic swing.

title: Frank H. Platt 3d, 77, A Lawyer and Official
description: Frank Hinchman Platt 3d, a retired lawyer and conservationist died at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital on Wednesday. He died after a brief illness, his wife, Audrey said. He was 77 years old.

title: Ideas & Trends;   For Japanese Art Collectors, Acquisition Begins at Home
description: IF high-rolling Japanese buyers are snapping up paintings by big-name Western artists - Van Gogh, Renoir and Lichtenstein -who's buying Japanese art?

title: Nina Purviance Marries Andrew West
description: Anna Harris Purviance, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Purviance of Middletown, R.I., was married there yesterday to Andrew Phelps West, a son of Patricia S. Bradshaw of New York and the late Davenport West Jr. The Rev. John Rogers performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ashton Toland.

title: HIGH-TECH GLADIATORS
description: AMERICA'S STRUGGLE FOR LEADERSHIP IN TECHNOLOGY

title:
DINING OUT;

Northern Italian Fare in a Stately Setting
description: LEAD: THERE is no longer a lake near the Pines Lake Inn; instead, the view out of the stately-looking northern Italian restaurant is that of a shallow front lawn, the parking lot that cradles the restaurant or a suburban Bergen County road.

title: Award-Winning Idea in Teaching: Getting the Students to Do It
description: LEAD: WHEN Robert G. Shamy began his teaching career as an elementary school teacher in Monroe Township in 1968, he immediately put his longstanding interest in archeology to good use. Aware that American Indian artifacts had been found in abundance in the community, which was then rural, he took his fourth-grade class on field trips to hunt for artifacts.

title: Sri Lanka Lowers Muslim Toll
description: The military said today that it erroneously reported that Tamil Tiger separatists massacred 62 Muslims. Officials said three Muslim men were killed in the raid on an eastern village. As the fighting continued today, Government troops fanned out from military camps in the country's north and east, destroying Tamil rebel hideouts and bunkers, military officials said. Officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules said the initial report of a massacre on Friday came from residents who fled the site of the slayings.

title: Drug Death Prompts Inquiry
description: Authorities are questioning a United States Border Patrol agent after the death of a man who snorted heroin stolen from the agent's van. The Border Patrol is investigating whether the agent, Scott M. Vantine, a dog handler, properly secured the drugs in his van and why he did not mention the missing heroin when he reported the van break-in to the police.

title: For the Blind
description: To the Editor: I am a caseworker for the New York State Department of Social Services, and I am also visually impaired. Like most New Yorkers, I have begun to think of vacation plans. Several of my friends who are also blind recommended that I contact a travel agent, one who according to them had been extremely helpful arranging their trips.

title: A Chinese Restaurant Branches Out
description: SEVERAL times in recent years, successful New York Chinese restaurants have opened branches in Fairfield County, and the ride from city to suburbs has been a bumpy one. The explanation is elusive. Perhaps the parent thinks that standards are lower outside the city, and that less effort need be extended. Whatever the reason, Tang's, across the road from the Saugatuck River (but lacking a water view) in Westport, is the latest to make the move, with mixed results.

title: Northeast Notebook: Freeport, Me.;   Downtown Fee Raises Hackles
description: To generate revenue, the Town Council in this coastal community has imposed a special fee on some downtown buildings to cover the cost of services. The fee applies only to downtown buildings that house retail and eating establishments and property owners call it discriminatory and illegal.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Education Is Mighty Force, Boston Teen-Agers Are Told
description: Nelson Mandela paused for a moment today in his single-minded concentration on ending South African apartheid to offer some advice to black teen-agers.

title: Britain: No Voice For Terrorists
description: British television has as many national news broadcasts as the United States, with more coming all the time on the new cable and satellite systems. Whether on the Government-owned BBC or competing commercial stations, the most widely watched news programs are all slow-paced, sober recitations.

title: Linda A. Volpert Becomes a Bride
description: Linda A. Volpert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Volpert of Sherman Oaks, Calif., was married last evening to Lawrence S. Gross, a son of Dr. Charles S. Gross of Tarzana, Calif., and Jane Fishman of La Canada, Calif. Rabbi Harold M. Schulweis officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Antonia Munroe and Jay Fischer Wed
description: Antonia Hughes Munroe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Munroe of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph J. Fischer, the son of Mrs. William D. Robertson of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Richard E. Fischer of New Haven. The Rev. Robert Simon, a Congregational minister, officiated at All Souls by the Sea Chapel in Steuben, Me.

title: Will Knicks' Picks Include Bianchi?
description: Four days before the National Basketball Association draft, the Knicks were pondering their future off the court as well as on it.

title: Rachel A. Nardin, Student, Married
description: Rachel A. Nardin and William P. Schmitt, medical students at Harvard University, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Watts in Wellfleet, Mass. Anna Marie Pluhar, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Secord, Striking New Deal, Drops Appeal of Conviction
description: Richard V. Secord, a leading defendant in the Iran-contra affair, is dropping the appeal of his conviction, the office of the independent prosecutor for Iran-contra cases said today.

title: A Court Case Weighs Down Corporate Bounce
description: A messy courtroom wrangle involving the Rite Aid Corporation, originally set for trial in April, is dragging on into the summer - a pain for investors as well as the principals.

title: Food;   Healthy Indulgence
description: EVERYONE I SPEAK TO THESE DAYS IS EITHER ON A diet, has just been on a diet or is planning to go on a diet. For most people, dieting is an act of such great sacrifice that, though they may commit to it for a lifetime, they can endure it only sporadically. It's a somber, serious endeavor, requiring strength of character, discipline and perseverance. In a word, dieting means deprivation, the giving up of something you like. And, consequently, it ends up being temporary.

title: Vibrant Dresses Recall Parties Of the 20's and 30's
description: LEAD: NAMES like the Roaring Twenties, the Jazz Age and the Swing Era conjure up the 1920's and 30's. In spite of the Great Depression, it was a vibrant time, when the radio, movies and motor cars collaborated to bring the country closer together.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Peril and Promise: A Commentary on America By John Chancellor Harper & Row. 176 pages. $17.95.

title: Italy: What's a Newscast Without Some Bias?
description: Few matters in Italian public affairs are free of partisan political considerations, and television news is no exception. Aside from one program on a relatively small private station, televised news is confined to the state network, Radiotelevisione Italiana, or RAI. But RAI is divided into three parts, each in the hands of one of the three major political parties - the Christian Democrats, the Communists and the Socialists.

title: The Draw
description: The draw for the singles fields at the Wimbledon tennis championships, June 25-July 8 (seedings in parentheses):

title: France: Making the Time For Gallic Musing
description: France has always waxed poetic about its tradition of freedom, yet, with its three main television channels state-owned, until the mid-1980's news broadcasts were presumed to favor the Government of the day. Opposition parties would, of course, complain loudly. When they took office, though, they, too, found the arrangement pleasing.

title: Staying on the Safe Side: London
description: The biggest threat to the safety of tourists in London comes from the traffic, which is increasingly heavy and moves on the wrong side of the street. Wrong, that is, if your first instinct is to look to your left and start crossing before looking to your right, which is where the traffic in England will be coming from on a two-way street.

title: Gooden Pitches 2-Hitter
description: It's hard to imagine that Dwight Gooden could start 32 games without completing one, but he did. That is, he did until last night when he not only started a game but dominated it, muzzling the Philadelphia Phillies by 3-0 and allowing just two hits and two walks for nine innings of mastery that led the Mets to their fifth consecutive victory and their 14th in 17 games.

title: National Triage: Are Cities or Countryside Sicker?
description: From the community health center where she works, Dr. Dianne C. Ritchie ministers to the poor and often-troubled people of the Bronx, taking the time to listen to the latest complaints of patients who have rarely had the luxury of seeing the same doctor twice in a row.

title: Headliners;   Divorced for Life
description: The former President for Life of Haiti, Jean-Claude Duvalier, is now the former husband for life of Michele Bennett Duvalier, famous shopper and mother of his two children. The divorce came through 10 years after their wedding, which held all Haiti in thrall for its sheer ostentation, and four years after their countrymen sent them into exile and ransacked their palace. From their home in France, Mr. Duvalier filed for divorce in the Dominican Republic, accusing his wife of immoral acts. (That was some time after the couple had set up housekeeping on the Riviera with, among others, Mrs. Duvalier's first husband.) The divorce was granted last October, but Mrs. Duvalier contested the decision, flying to the Dominican Republic to obtain a reversal before her husband prevailed in a third court. She has until July 7 to file an appeal, but her lawyer said last week that she probably would not. Mrs. Duvalier is now living with another man in Cannes, according to a report in Le Figaro, and she was awarded alimony and child support. Mr. Duvalier is taking it easy and settling into his new villa, which rents for $150,000 a year.

title: Owners of Stranded Satellite Send Another Aloft
description: A $150 million communications satellite similar to one that became stranded in a uselessly low orbit three months ago was launched on Saturday, officials said.

title: The World;   Central Asia Rediscovers Its Identity
description: THERE wasn't much publicity. The subject was not at the top of the news. But when a distinguished Soviet academician on a diplomatic mission was persuaded recently to give an informal talk on Central Asia, there was standing room only in the hotel banquet hall that a local scholar booked.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: Detroit is the best football team ever to play basketball. In an era when guarding means hand-checking, pushing, and holding, when setting a pick means putting up both hands and throwing a block, when offensive players are allowed to palm the ball and take six steps before they shoot, Detroit is a master. It is a team that consists of several benchwarmers, several O.K. players, a half dozen or so muggers, and one basketball player, Isiah Thomas.

title: PICTURE THIS: FRAMES WITHOUT PAINTINGS AT THE MET
description: Walking home from the remarkable exhibition of Italian Renaissance frames that can be seen through Jan. 6 at the Metropolitan Museum, I realized all over again that a frame is not just there to make a picture look good. It can have in it elements of painting, architecture, sculpture, furniture and the decorative arts. It can, in fact, have a subtlety to which many paintings do not aspire.

title: Fashion;   Under The Sun And Out Of It, Too
description: Some women wear hats all the time and some women never wear hats. Other women don them for special occasions - a wedding or a funeral, maybe. Then there are those for whom hats are purely functional, something to keep their heads warm in winter or dry in the rain. But there is one time everyone should think about wearing a head covering: when out in the sun, whether sitting on the sand or strolling through town.

title: A Living Will
description: This living will applies to New York State. Forms for other states are available from the Society for the Right to Die, 250 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10107.

title: Deregulation Is Nothing but a License to Steal;   We Can Go Further
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying on the Safe Side Bangkok
description: Unlike certain European populations, the Thais actually like tourists and are renowned for their grace and desire to help. Still, there seems to be something about the tropical heat and exotic surroundings (a monk in sneakers or a family of six on a motorbike) that causes some Western tourists to lose all judgment.

title: Review/Rock
description: The English group Depeche Mode, which played at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night, knows how to get an audience screaming. The lead singer, David Gahan, pays it a bit of attention.

title: Francesca K. Pomerantz Weds George Vining 4th
description: Francesca Kazan Pomerantz and George Joseph Vining 4th were married yesterday at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vining 3d, in Barnard, Vt. The Rev. Bruce W. Robins, of the United Methodist church, officiated at the interfaith ceremony.

title: Capturing a Family's Shattered Life
description: LEAD: MARK AND LAURA GERBER are a Long Island couple who seem to have everything - three lovely daughters, a strong marriage, a prosperous business, and a beautiful home in the Five Towns area. One bright August afternoon, a drunken driver crashes into a van driven by their youngest daughter, Bobbi, and she is killed on impact.

title:
All About: Recreational Vehicles;

Will Motor Homes And Trailers Tempt A New Generation?
description: LEAD: A few miles south of Disneyland on Interstate 5, in Irvine, Calif., lies what some consider to be the real Magic Kingdom: Traveland U.S.A., billed as the world's largest sales lot for recreational vehicles.

title: Tech Notes;   How Does the Micro-Motor Wear?
description: Researchers at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology and the University of California at Berkeley have been working for years to develop micro-motors. Now, they say, they know a bit about how these tiny engines wear. ''We are beginning to get a foothold in understanding the wear process and in learning how bearings hold up,'' said Jeffrey Lang, an associate professor of electrical engineering at M.I.T., who is building the motors. The latest version of the micro-motor (below) is 100 microns wide with rotors spinning on bearings as small as 10 microns. (A human hair is about 75 microns thick.) The motors, etched from the same silicon compounds as computer chips, can achieve speeds of millions of rotations a minute.

title: Eliza Knowlton, Teacher, Marries
description: Eliza Courtney Knowlton, a daughter of Grace Knowlton of Palisades, N.Y., and Winthrop Knowlton of New York, was married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y., to Mark Nevill Oursler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Oursler Jr. of Nyack, N.Y. The Rev. Hillary R. Bercovici officiated. Mrs. Oursler, 28 years old, a Sarah Lawrence College graduate, teaches at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York. Her father, a managing director at the Family Partners & Company investment firm in New York, has been the chairman of Harper & Row, publishers in New York, and a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Her mother is a sculptor and photographer.

title: James Dearden's Latest Fatal Attraction
description: A dusty amber light fills the air in Stage H at Shepperton Studios in Middlesex, where, high in the rafters, in what is supposed to be the windowed cab of a crane, the American actress Sean Young stands staring down into a massive steel cauldron below. She does not speak; she barely moves. She just looks down, watching.

title: Mandela's Visit, New York's Pride
description: SINCE at least 1927, when a startlingly large crowd of 30,000 waited outside a Harlem funeral parlor to pay respects to the entertainer Florence Mills, the black community in New York City has bathed its heroes in the most public expressions of love and support.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Going Out for Coffee and Leaving Tension at the Door
description: LEAD: THERE are two things to know about me. The first is that I have a learning-disabled child. The second is that I hang out at this sweetshop for coffee. The boy's disability is mild, the coffee strong -all in all, not a bad arrangement.

title: Rising Party in Italy's North Wants to Get Rome and the South Off Its Back
description: On a chilly spring evening in this northern Italian town, a dozen leaders of the new local government gathered on the front porch of the Coba Bar, talking about revolution.

title: Simon Fill Wed To Miss Cumming
description: Llewellyn Cumming, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Milledge Cumming of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Simon Charles Fill, the son of Meiling Yeh of Bel Air, Calif., and Dennis C. Fill of Seattle and New York. The Rev. John W. Bishop officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Dr. Lynda Smith Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Lynda Marie Smith, a daughter of Delores Preston Smith of St. Albans, N.Y., and Paul David Smith of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Theodore Harris, a son of Rosetta Long Harris of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Hugo Harris of Bridgeport, Conn. Patricia A. Williams, an Acting Justice of the Supreme Court in New York County, officiated at Flutie's restaurant.

title: Rebecca Chase Marries W. L. Hughes
description: Rebecca Ellis Chase, a daughter of Alison A. F. Chase of New York and the late Ryland Ellis Dickinson Chase, was married yesterday to William Leggette Hughes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Hughes of Durham, N.C. The Rev. Dorsey McConnell performed the ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany in New York.

title: Business Books for New-Age Bosses
description: I think of books as leading indicators. The ideas people grapple with today shape the future. But the books business readers are reading and the ideas writers are writing about tell me that traditional management ideas may no longer be relevant. The marketplace says traditional ideas about business and management don't excite much passion anymore.

title: WHERE GENGHIS KHAN IS IN
description: Having traveled through Mongolia in the summer of 1989, I was quite taken by your article ''Where Genghis Khan Is In,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (May 27). I was there just before the events of the last six months; however, there were some signs of democratic stirrings. When my companion and I crossed the border between the Soviet Union and Mongolia, we were stopped by border guards. We had been told that the guards were strict and we braced for the worst. To our surprise and relief, a smiling, young soldier stepped into the car, looked over our passport and, recognizing that we were Americans, proceeded to name Western rock groups like the Rolling Stones and the Who.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: The Pistons rank with the top five teams in the history of the N.B.A. But even though their record is strong, their contribution to the development of the game is not as great as some other outstanding teams. The Lakers with George Mikan led to the widening of the three-second zone; the Celtics of the Bill Russell era revolutionized defensive play; the Knicks of the 70's emphasized teamwork, and the short reign of the 1977 Trail Blazers emphasized Bill Walton's passing from the post. These teams all contributed to changes in the game more far-reaching than the Pistons' recent success.

title: Hazards At the Keyboard: A special report:   Automation: Pain Replaces the Old Drudgery
description: For nine years, Paula Tydryszewski has operated a video display terminal in New Jersey's tax collection office. She types numbers and names from tax returns at woodpecker speeds into a keyboard that is tied to a big computer in the center of the room.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;

Abuse, Adultery Revenge, Murder
description: LEAD: Dmitri Shostakovich's second opera, ''Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk'' (1934), incurred Stalin's displeasure and exposed the composer to vicious attacks. It was banished from Soviet stages for the remainder of the Stalin era. To this day, no complete recording of this troubled creation has emerged from the Soviet Union, but Shostakovich's own watered-down edition, under the title ''Katerina Ismailova,'' was allowed to be performed and recorded after Stalin's death.

title: WORLD COURT PLAN MEETS DIFFICULTIES
description: An attempt by the United States and the Soviet Union to expand the authority of the World Court has run into difficulties, with Britain and other critics contending that the initiative might reduce the role of international law rather than enhance it.

title: Helen Edwards, Account Executive, Weds Michael D. Ryus, Art Director
description: Helen Munro Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Edwards of Brunswick and Orr's Island, Me., was married yesterday to Michael Denslow Ryus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Denslow Ryus 3d of New York and Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Dr. William Imes, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Hamilton.

title: Pursuing Fathers' Roles After Divorce
description: LEAD: JOE PISCOPO'S son, Joey, lives in the Florida Panhandle now but keeps his watch on New Jersey time, his father says.

title: Rona Stein, Physician, Wed To S. H. Kaufman, Lawyer
description: Dr. Rona L. Stein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Stein of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married last evening to Stephen H. Kaufman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kaufman of Henrietta, N.Y. Rabbi Stanley Platek officiated at the Hewlett East Rockaway (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: Japan: Controversy Saved For Late Night
description: In a society saturated with information, there is television news virtually every hour of the day. Most surveys show that television is the primary source of news for the Japanese, and many newscasters are celebrities. By far the most popular nightly show is News Station, broadcast for 78 minutes by TV Asahi, one of the major networks. Its popular team of newscasters is led by Hiroshi Kume, the closest thing in Japan to Ted Koppel, who makes witty and sarcastic remarks about the news and doesn't mind posing what Japanese might consider an insolent question to someone in power.

title: Ann S. Copeland Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Stuart Copeland, the daughter of Ann Bellah Copeland of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and Gerret van Sweringen Copeland of Greenville, Del., to Andrew Carnegie Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Harden Rose of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., has been announced by Miss Copeland's parents. A September wedding is planned.

title: Neuberger Examines Effects of Modernismo on Graphic Arts
description: ''A Gothic tavern for those in love with the North.'' The quote comes from George Heard Hamilton's ''Painting and Sculpture in Europe, 1880 to 1940'' and the place it describes is El Quatres Gats. This cafe in Barcelona was frequented by the artists and writers of Modernismo, which resembled the Pre-Raphaelite and Arts and Crafts movements in England but was at the same time a manifestation of Catalan separatism.

title: Tragic Chapter In Cup Story
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Some Pitching Rotations Seem Like Revolving Doors
description: LIKE replacements for canceled shows in the middle of the television season, new pitchers have been inserted into starting rotations in abundance this year.

title: Postings: On the Beach in the Hamptons;  $1.5 Million and Up
description: Resort property prices may be in a slump, but when four of his 12 new houses sit on the last buildable lots on the ocean beach, and the beach in question is in the Long Island Town of Southampton, their developer believes there is nothing to worry about.

title: Kersti E. Magi, Editor, Marries
description: Kersti Ellen Magi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Magi of Bellevue, Wash., was married yesterday to Harden L. Crawford 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Crawford 3d of Far Hills, N.J. Canon John T. Morrow performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Peapack, N.J.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   The Whalebone-Free Summer Corset Look
description: Madonna's ''Blonde Ambition'' tour has received almost as much attention for the costumes the star wears as for the music. No wonder. It's kind of hard to ignore someone whose attire leans toward exaggerated cone bras and turn-of-the-century corsets as outerwear.

title: SUBURBIA COMES TO ISLAM
description: LEAD:

title: In Defense Of the Irish
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Say, Bud, Do You Own That Burning Flag?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street;   Broker vs. Investor: The Scorecard
description: The first year's worth of public statistics are out on how investors have fared in the securities industry's highly controversial broker-investor arbitration hearings. And the results, although they offer a wealth of detail about how the process works, remain distinctly unencouraging to outraged customers.

title: Legal Aid Beats Second Bidder to Renew Contract
description: In New York State's first competitive bidding process for legal representation of the poor, the Legal Aid Society last week won a renewal of its state contract to represent indigent children in New York City's Family Courts.

title: Celtics Change Dividend Plan
description: The Boston Celtics used to pay their fans yearly dividends. Now, the Celtics' limited partnership will reward its shareholders in the same way.

title: Tory Lord Weds Mark Eckenwiler
description: Victoria Marie Lord, a daughter of Athena V. Lord of Albany and the late Victor A. Lord, was married yesterday to Mark W. Eckenwiler, the son of Leah Eckenwiler of Tulsa, Okla., by the Rev. Patric Legato at St. Sophia's Greek Orthodox Church in Albany. The bride, who is known as Tory and is keeping her name, is a doctoral candidate in medieval history at Columbia University. She graduated from Yale University and received a Master of Philosophy degree from University College in Dublin. Her father was a senior partner in the Albany law firm of McNamee, Lochner, Titus & Williams and a vice chairman of the New York State Liberal Party. Her mother writes children's books.

title: Reading, Writing and Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Ashley as Firebird In City Ballet Program
description: ''Firebird'' burned brightest when Merrill Ashley was dancing on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Although the New York City Ballet's production of Stravinsky's musical fairy tale has choreography by both George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, it is only intermittently compelling. Nevertheless, a fine dancer can make the role of the Firebird electrifying.

title: Kubelik in Prague - and in the Catalogue
description: After an absence of 42 years, Rafael Kubelik returned to Czechoslovakia several weeks ago to conduct the CzechPhilharmonic Orchestra in the two performances of Bedrich Smetana's symphonic cycle ''Ma Vlast'' (''My Country'') that opened this year's Prague Spring Festival.

title: PASTIMES: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: FITGWeed, weed, weed. These unwanted plants usurp valuable soil moisture and soil nutrients. Check cucumbers and tomatoes to be sure they are securely fastened to their supports. Prune hedges. Dig, divide and replant wild flowers after the soil has been enriched. Plant the seed of biennials.

title: Curator Questions 'Pollock' Review
description: As curator of ''From Pollock to Polyester,'' the exhibit at Wunsch Arts Center, I have been urged to reply to Helen A. Harrison's intemperate and scattershot attack on it ( May 6) and to reject the more egregious of her assumptions. But before doing so I really must deny the intention imputed to me to ''steal the Modern's (The Museum of Modern Art's) thunder'' in mounting this exhibit. A comparison of Wunsch's very modest resources with those of the Modern renders, at the outset, such a hubristic suggestion laughable.

title: Q and A
description: Rent Overcharge Payment

title: Co-op Converters' Money Woes Spread
description: New financial disclosure filings are revealing widespread problems in New York co-ops and condominiums, where bank loans on unsold units are in arrears, maintenance payments are behind schedule and other shortfalls are emerging.

title: Reviews/Music;   Rarities Of 1700's In Berkeley Festival
description: Despite some financial instability, the biannual Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition has pretty much had the field to itself in the United States when it comes to combined performance showcases and trade exhibitions for early music. Now, the University of California at Berkeley has inaugurated a mirror event to take place during Boston's off-years entitled the Berkeley Festival and Exhibition: Music in History. The proceedings got under way on June 10 and ended last Sunday, and although there is room for improvement, the event must be pronounced a success.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: GARY MAZART;

Advising the Elderly on Health Costs
description: LEAD: GARY MAZART, a 32-year-old lawyer, tries to help families deal with the catastrophic financial problems incurred when an extended illness incapacitates an elderly family member and necessitates long-term care.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DONALD W. BASS;

Giving Marrow to Save a Stranger's Life
description: LEAD: A MAN in the Middle West with leukemia might just recover, thanks to a stranger from New York.

title: Miss Armstrong Wed in Pennsylvania
description: Elisabeth Ely Armstrong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Armstrong Jr. of West Chester, Pa., was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity to Robert Hattersley Connell, the son of Philip G. Connell Jr. of Village of Golf, Fla., and the late Nancy Somerville Connell. The Rev. William J. Fishler and the Rev. Edward L. Carter officiated. Mrs. Connell, 25 years old and a graduate of Middlebury College, is a senior advertising account executive at Hospital News in Burlington, Vt. Her father is a vice president of Armstrong Engineering Associates, a designer and manufacturer of industrial equipment in West Chester.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Tokyo
description: LEAD: A major selling point for Tokyo as a tourist town is its safety. Indeed, an official at the Japan National Tourist Organization said the agency's advice to travelers is ''Don't worry. Even a woman can walk in the city at midnight.''

title: On Language;   The Bonding Market
description: MRS. GORBACHEV and Millie FITGbondedFNMG.'' That good news was the word from Barbara Bush and must have caused much head-scratching at Tass. They knew that Millie was the name of the Bushes' (which should be pronounced bush-iz-zizz) English springer spaniel, sometimes referred to irreverently as the First Dog, but what means FITGbondedFNMG?

title: Foiling Theft
description: To the Editor: The pickpocket always seems to be with us, but my husband and I solved this problem long ago with a petticoat with ''his'' and ''hers'' pockets.

title: Staying on the Safe Side;Moscow
description: LEAD: Despite a rise in crime in the last few years, the criminal in Moscow is more likely to be you. If you arrive in the Soviet Union without a tour group to shelter, guide and feed you, you will be warmly welcomed at the airport by various individuals offering taxi rides into town for dollars (about $50), francs, pounds, a carton of cigarettes - anything but rubles.

title: Beckenbauer Looks to Final and Beyond
description: THE television producer asked him for just five minutes.

title: Reports From Phnom Penh Indicate New Instability
description: With the Cambodian Government this week announcing a failed coup attempt and dismissing an outspoken editor, there is a new period of instability in Phnom Penh that can only benefit the Khmer Rouge guerrillas, Asian diplomats and political analysts say.

title:
MUSIC;

Waterloo Fete to Honor American Composer
description: LEAD: THE Waterloo Music Festival's 15th classical concert series will open the season with a special weekend Diamond Jubilee in honor of the American composer David Diamond.

title: The World;   Can Central America Win a War on Poverty?
description: THE futility of efforts to attack the basic causes of Central America's endemic poverty preoccupied President Vinicio Cerezo one day three years ago as he sat in a hotel room with friends. Some topics, he complained, were so explosive they could not even be mentioned. Asked for an example, he paused. Then he replied, ''agrarian reform.'' In that instant, the chandelier fell from the ceiling with a crash.

title: THE JOURNALIST AND THE DICTATOR
description: STALIN'S APOLOGIST

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The bathroom window inside our tub/shower area has deteriorated from exposure to dampness. For the new window, we are trying to decide between another one of wood or a vinyl one. Which do you recommend?

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended June 9

title: Manholes by Another Name
description: Sacramento city officials, having found the word ''manhole'' sexist, have now come up with a new name for those utility holes in streets. Without fanfare, the City Council adopted the term ''maintenance hole'' this week to replace ''manhole'' on official maps and documents. Public works officials had proposed finding a non-sexist term in jest, but Mayor Anne Rudin liked the idea and the debate quickly spread.

title: Tracy, Tracy - Aaaugh!
description: Warren Beatty. Warren Beatty and Madonna.

title: Data Bank/June 24, 1990
Voice of Experience
description: COLLEGE basketball stars who don't make it to the National Basketball Association the first time around often look to the Continental Basketball Association.

title: Elizabeth Howell and Ian MacCallum Jr. Marry
description: Elizabeth Warren Howell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Warren Howell of Winnetka, Ill., was married yesterday to Ian Barrie MacCallum Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. MacCallum of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Brian A. Lathrop officiated at Grace Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Brucie Ketcham Is a Bride
description: Mary Bruce Ketcham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas M. Donahue, a son of Beatrice Donahue of Barre, Vt., and the late Howard Donahue, at Trinity St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I., by the Revs. Earle W. Pratt Jr. and Edyth Baker. The bride, 28 years old and known as Brucie, teaches at the Leland-Grey Union High School in Townshend, Vt. The bridegroom, 34, is a general contractor.

title: Alleghany's Record Speaks for Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mandela Visit;   Not All Felt Invited to Mandela's Party
description: While Nelson Mandela's visit may have been a special celebration for black New Yorkers, some whites in middle-class neighborhoods far from the throngs watched his triumphal tour with the sense that it was not really their party, and described the guest of honor with a mix of admiration, wariness of his intent and, occasionally, hostility.

title: China: The Product Is the Party
description: Chinese television news programs have no commercials, but then the entire program is pretty much a commercial for the Communist leadership. Only rarely are there interruptions for the news.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: Robert D. Kaplan's article on Ljubljana, Slovenia (Travel, April 1), paints an inaccurate picture of Yugoslavia's currency situation. His figures of 125,000 dinars or $2.50 for two plum brandies and a cup of coffee probably put his visit in October of last year, when the dollar was valued at 50,000 dinars.

title: New Battles Over Disclosure
description: William Steiner of Great Neck, L.I., and Morton Levine of Brooklyn get angry when a company withholds information they believe they have a right to know. What sets them apart is that they may be at the vanguard of a new class of courtroom confrontation: shareholders claiming to have been financially damaged by corporations that have failed to disclose environmental problems.

title: Campus Life: Penn State;   Bilingual Teachers Aim for Posts As Principals
description: Joseph Prewitt Diaz does not believe he or anyone else should have to give up a language or a culture.

title: Theresa E. Heaney Becomes the Bride of Jan Galla
description: Theresa E. Heaney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Heaney of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jan Galla, a son of Anne Galla Hutchinson of Lighthouse Point, Fla., and the late John Galla. The Rev. Joseph Kukura officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Oradell. Mrs. Galla, a graduate of Lafayette College and the University of Alabama in Birmingham, is a surgeon's assistant in New York at Mount Sinai Medical Center, where her husband is a heart surgeon. Her father is a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. The bridegroom graduated from Florida Atlantic University, where he received a master's degree in biological sciences, and has a Ph.D. in experimental hematology and an M.D. from Baylor College. His father was a general manager's assistant at International Business Machines in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Lisbon
description: A visitor can still venture into any nook or neighborhood in Portugal without fear of violent crime. But gone are the days, a dozen years or so ago, when people could leave valuables in unlocked automobiles.

title: AIDS Experts Tell of Work on Possible Vaccines
description: Optimistic after a string of laboratory successes, researchers are assembling potential vaccines against AIDS and may start preliminary testing within a year, scientists at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS said today.

title: Research Lab And Budget: Striking A Balance
description: UNAWARE of the shadow that had been cast over their fate in recent weeks, hundreds of thousands of insects from places like India, Korea, Yugoslavia and South America eat, sleep and energetically reproduce in climate-controlled cages at the Phillip Alampi Beneficial Insect Rearing Laboratory.

title: How the Building Slump Affects the Trades
description: SOME are bartenders. Some are security guards. Others drive taxicabs. Two years ago they were working in the construction industry, but today many of the 32,000 members of the building trades in Westchester and Putnam Counties are ''taking whatever they can get,'' said Arthur Colasanto, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, which represents 16 building crafts.

title: Empty Nests on the Tappan Zee Disappoint Bridge's Falcon Fans
description: THE nest is empty. Weeds grow in the gravel that covers the bottom of the peregrine falcon's nest box on the west tower of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: High-Tech Monarch for National Insect
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners;   Extra Curriculum
description: Optimism is necessary to any undertaking to improve the nation's educational system, and Wendy Kopp, graduated from Princeton one year ago, is the type for the job. Ms. Kopp decided to start a teacher corps, then actually did it, setting up a program for 500 new graduates to start next fall. ''I really have this attitude that things will all work out,'' Ms. Kopp said. So far, they have. First, having established contacts among business leaders as president of a student organization, she parlayed them into advice and money for her project, which she also turned into her senior thesis. She coaxed more than $1 million from sponsors like the Mobil Corporation and Union Carbide, formed a nonprofit corporation called Teach for America and set it up in donated office space in Manhattan. She recruited on the theory that the more selective the competition the more top students would compete, and 2,500 applied. She talked school districts into hiring the new teachers, who begin training this week at the University of Southern California. Meanwhile, Ms. Kopp and her 23 employees are looking for more money.

title: Staying on the Safe Side: Los Angeles
description: In the cultural cacaphony of the new Los Angeles, which has become the nexus between Latin America and Asia, slick bands of thieves flourish, taking advantage of the city's enormous numbers of foreigners and travelers. At Los Angeles International Airport, several families make their living preying on visitors. Their tactic is distraction, though their method is almost never confrontational. The distraction can be as simple as borrowing a pencil or dropping a batch of coins, or as noisy as having a decoy purposely try to go through revolving doors the wrong way and start banging on the glass. In any case, the traveler's briefcase or luggage disappears before he or she knows it. From 600 to 800 visitors report such thefts to the airport police every year.
