(There were 30,705 robberies reported last year for the city as a whole.) Capt. Bernard Wilson of the airport police urges travelers to avoid pulling luggage behind them, to limit carry-on bags and never to walk away from property.

title: Moscow Street Trade Heats Up
description: The Intourist bus pulls to a stop at the foot of Red Square and is immediately surrounded by young men hawking military hats, military belts and watches. The prices range from $5 for a belt (pungently scented leather with a handsome brass hammer-and-sickle buckle) or hat (several services are represented, all with colorful badges) to $20 or $25 for a watch (some bear the legend ''Perestroika,'' while others are of the military model). All prices are quoted in dollars.

title: 'A Teacher Affects Eternity'
description: AFTER being asked to speak at my former high school English teacher's retirement dinner, a quote by Henry Adams, which I used in a senior English class, came to mind: ''A teacher affects eternity: he can never tell where his influence stops.'' How true, I thought.

title: ALABAMA BOUND
description: So the secret's out - the world knows that I and my fellow Alabamians live in a time warp dreamily reliving the Wallace years. Howell Raines's article ''Alabama Bound'' (June 3) contains a laundry list of everything that is wrong with the state. Granted, Alabama has problems, but it does not have a monopoly on substandard medical care for the poor and other items that Raines cites.

title: Perspectives: The Shift at Clasons Point;   Adding a Simplex to Broaden the Market
description: Two years into construction, the largest low-rise residential development ever undertaken in the Bronx is tacking with the winds of the sales market this summer.

title: Commercial Property: Office Leasing;   A Wall Street Law Firm Stays in the Neighborhood
description: Contrary to the prevailing uptown drift of downtown law offices, Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton has decided to stray no farther than three blocks from Wall Street. Last weekend, the firm moved into six of the upper floors of One Liberty Plaza - 253,000 square feet altogether.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: David Bailey Lee Is Wed To Hallie B. Stephenson
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Woods Hole, Mass., Hallie Buford Stephenson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Eustis Stephenson of West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to David Bailey Lee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Holman Lee Jr. of Middletown, Conn. The Rev. Myrick T. Cross officiated. Mrs. Lee is the assistant circuit executive of the Federal Court of Appeals in Atlanta. A graduate of Wellesley College, she has a master's degree in administration, planning and social policy from Harvard University. Mr. Lee graduated from Princeton University and received an M.B.A. degree from Harvard. He is the senior vice president of the Magazine Publishers of America, a trade group in New York.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 10 about executives who are out of work because of mergers and acquisitions misstated the age of Charles M. Anson. He is 54.

title: Dana K. Cairns and Robert N. Watson Are Married
description: Dana K. Cairns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Cairns of Walnut Creek, Calif., was married yesterday in Canoga Park, Calif., to Dr. Robert N. Watson, a son of Dr. Barbara Bellow Watson of New York and the late Dr. Goodwin Watson. The Rev. Donald E. Hartsock, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Ideas & Trends;   A Stroll in the Country For City Dwellers Starting Downtown
description: WHEN people here speak of the Oregon Trail, the name of the route that brought thousands of settlers to the West nearly 150 years ago, chances are they are not nostalgically evoking history but advocating a vision of the future.

title: Tom Stoppard's Version Of an Old Reliable
description: A COMPOSER eavesdrops upon an actress - his inamorata and the star of his new operetta - who is carrying on a real-life love scene with an actor, her former lover. It looks like curtains for all, until a playwright, who is also a busybody, takes down the overheard lines, drafts them into the script and convinces the composer that the seduction scene was but a late-night rehearsal.

title: Northeast Notebook: Wilmington, Del.;   Sears Moving To a Mall
description: After 40 years as a free-standing store in the northwestern part of town, Sears, Roebuck & Company will move to a suburban mall whose owner is planning a $70 million expansion over a two-year period. It will be the first major anchor store to move in as part of the expansion of the Concord mall off Route 202, but delays in getting approvals for the mall expansion may delay the move.

title: Cabaret Pieces for Norfolk's Opening
description: MUSICAL performances at Norfolk goes back to the early years of the century, when Sibelius, Rachmaninoff, Kreisler and Caruso were among the notables appearing in the Music Shed. But officially this year is the golden anniversary of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, the 50th time that the Yale Summer School of Music has convened on the 70-acre grounds of the Ellen Battell Stoeckel estate in the Litchfield foothills.

title: Longer School Year: Some Disadvantages
description: Although I'm sure Assemblyman Pascrell has our students' best interests in mind, I'm not convinced that extending the school year by 20 days is the best solution. What we really need is an educational system that is attentive to the varied needs, learning styles, and abilities of its students.

title: Postings: Wertheimer's Branch;   New Retailer For Jamaica
description: Wertheimer's, a retailing name long familiar to shoppers on Brooklyn's Fulton Street and in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, has thrived in the last decade as other small department stores throughout the country withered in the face of competition from factory outlet malls and discount specialty stores.

title: Handy Sauces and Relishes for Dishes From the Grill
description: WHEN grilled foods need a dash of something, one doesn't have to look far to come up with an interesting sauce or relish. For grilled lobster, scallops or vegetables, a simple aioli flavored with red peppers and garlic makes a superb dipping sauce. Grilled chicken, veal chops or fish steaks go well with a relish served on the side made from roasted tomatoes, mixed with olive oil and tarragon. An olivada with garlic and capers is good on fish or chicken, too, spread on top just before it is served and sprinkled with a few leaves of rosemary. This can be eaten hot or cold.

title: Another Look at That Record
description: Recently Alleghany announced it was discontinuing its fight to own 20 percent of St. Paul Companies Inc. and selling its stock back to the company. No mention of this was made at the recent annual stockholders meeting. This should double the unrestricted cash held by Alleghany. Can stockholders at least expect a cash dividend? Probably not, since the chairman's salary and bonus approaches $1 million every year. It was interesting that in the quarterly report the chairman hid the negative vote count for his re-election as a director. It was the lowest of the three men standing for re-election!

title: Mary K. Donohoe Marries
description: Mary K. Donohoe and Jonathan A. D. Morisseau, graduates of Franklin and Marshall College, were married yesterday at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Summit, N.J., by Msgr. Hugh J. Phillips and the bridegroom's father, the Rev. Robert E. Morisseau, the rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in New City, N.Y. Mrs. Morisseau, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Donohue of Short Hills, N.J. The bridegroom, 25, is also a son of Caroline B. Morisseau of New City. The bride is a claims approver at the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Parsippany, N.J. The bridegroom is a teacher, sports coach and the director of residents at the Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Believing in Mao
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street In Search of Itself on the Yampa
description: The band of Wall Streeters and other executives had already scaled 100 feet of the side of a mountain, when Al Brown yelled the news. The group had to name the next two climbs, he said, adding that they would be difficult.

title: Moody and Torn, Quebecers Explore a Future Quite Apart
description: Bright blue and white flags bearing the fleur-de-lis were already aloft and fluttering throughout Montreal today in anticipation of the Quebec national holiday of St. Jean Baptiste, which will be celebrated on Sunday.

title: PASTIMES: CAMERA
description: Workshop season beckons now that summer has officially arrived. From now until September many photographers, neophyte to seasoned, will take to the hills and beaches to improve their skills by attending a short but intense workshop session.

title: Theater Takes To the Streets
description: What are the Brothers Karamazov doing in the meat-packing district of Manhattan? Beginning Wednesday, Dimitri, Alyosha, Ivan and Smerdyakov can be found sitting at a 120-foot-long dining table in the middle of West 13th Street. But Dostoyevsky's characters are not the only dinner guests. They will be joined by a variety of real and fictional characters who, with an audience of up to 200 a night, will become part of En Garde Arts's new production, ''Father Was a Peculiar Man.'' The play will be presented through July 21 at 9 P.M. Wednesdays through Saturdays. Unlike En Garde Arts's last production, ''Crowbar,'' which took place inside the abandoned Victory Theater on West 42d Street, ''Father Was a Peculiar Man'' will take the audience on a two-hour journey through four city blocks. In keeping with the peripatetic nature of the work, tickets will be sold from a red convertible parked at the corner of Little West 12th Street and Ninth Avenue before show time. (Advance tickets are available from Ticket Central.) ''This is not a literal adaptation of the novel,'' said Reza Abdoh, the 26-year-old Iranian-born director. ''Themes from the book, the disintegration of the family, killing the authority figure and our perpetual and futile attempts to regain lost innocence are important to this work.'' Mr. Abdoh wrote the script with Mira-Lani Oglesby, his collaborator on previous avant-garde theater pieces in Los Angeles, where he lives.

title: Blasphemy, Italian-Style
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: City Officials and Airport Operator Debate Airfield's Future
description: FORTY-FIVE years ago, low-flying aircraft were a welcome sight in this blue-collar industrial city. The Navy fighter planes produced at the General Motors Corporation plant along Route 9 here helped to employ thousands of workers in the name of the war effort. And when the war ended, the city got to keep the airfield across the highway that had been used as a test strip.

title: Deregulation Is Nothing but a License to Steal
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 10 about monthly charges in co-ops and condominiums carried an incorrect given name for David Clurman, a lawyer who wrote New York State's current law governing conversions.

title: Greenport Faces Mounting Problems
description: LEAD: AN ailing Mayor, a dying downtown, a lack of affordable housing and mounting problems with drugs and alcohol have convulsed the previously quiet political scene in historic Greenport.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Restaurant's Leftovers Help to Feed the Poor
description: LEAD: THREE months ago, when Linda Ringenberg decided to ask restaurants and other commercial kitchens in Hartford to donate their leftovers to a food bank, she did not know what kind of response to expect. Now, she has more offers than she can handle.

title: Honoring A Father's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodman Alumnus in Salute
description: LEAD: AS long as they never let their ''chops go down'' by practicing at least an hour every day, older saxophone players never retire.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Dublin
description: The Irish are such a friendly lot that it often seems that the most serious crime in Dublin is the reluctance of Dubliners to let a visitor get a word in edgewise.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   City Hears Harmony, With a Few Jarring Notes
description: A ragtag army of AIDS protesters joined hands today with researchers and policy makers from the Sixth International AIDS Conference and marched through downtown San Francisco to tell the world that they shared an agenda to help people with AIDS by speeding treatment, improving health care and ending discrimination.

title: Never Too Old to Travel Light
description: THIS is the story of two somewhat over-the-hill physical fitness buffs who traveled through Europe for four weeks last summer, carrying nothing but small backpacks.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: The Pistons, who look like the team of the 90's, will go down as one of the best, if not the best defensive team in the history of the game. This opinion comes from the biggest Michael Jordan fan.

title: Miss Gibson Wed To J. P. Bailinson
description: Nancy S. Gibson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis S. Gibson of Indianapolis, was married yesterday to James P. Bailinson, the son of Jean Paaswell Bailinson of New York and Frank Bailinson of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Richard Simpson, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Concord Country Inn House in Woodstock, Ill.

title: Arrests of Drivers for Drugs Up Sharply
description: THE number of Long Islanders arrested for driving under the influence of drugs more than doubled from 1987 to 1989, the police say.

title: INSIDE
description: Mandela Tours Boston

title: Competition Grips Mothers And Daughters
description: THE competition between mother and daughter is hard to explain. It is certainly far more than the Electra Complex purports to encompass. And, while this competition may be labeled a stage in the young girl, we have no adequate description of this behavior in the adult female.

title: CRIME
description: You wouldn't want to be in Peter Scattergood's loafers, despite their snazzy shine.

title: PASTIMES: Gardening;   If Insect Pests Are on the March ...
description: Now that the gardening season is well under way, and plants are growing, the insect pests that feed on them are increasing in numbers. What is to be done? One reaction is to reach for a spray can and knock the population out. Never mind about identifying the insects or learning about their life cycle. Just get rid of them.

title: Despite Tensions With Iran, Americans Aid Quake Relief
description: Despite tensions between the United States and Iran, relief officials say American citizens and businesses are offering money, medicine and other aid to victims of the earthquake that struck northwestern Iran on Thursday.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION: HEADING HEADLONG INTO THEIR EIGHTIES;

For Some Men Life Is a Stroll At Playland
description: LEAD: DURING our productive years most men have the same problems, more or less. We are caught up in the pursuit of meaningful goals. Spring used to make a young man's fancy turn, but even that changes by the time you reach the age of 80.

description: Some lesser-known stories pertaining to the Wimbledon championships:

title: Refugees in the Soviet Union
description: LEAD: It was no ordinary invitation to tea. Mrs. Sakharov apologized in advance when she invited me: ''I've invited people who really know our problems. I want you to see how very great our crisis is.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about the use of roadblocks to find drunken drivers referred incorrectly to two standard blood alcohol levels.

title: Phone Line Has Answers for Mothers-to-Be
description: LEAD: LAST winter, Linda Hatten, of Farmington, was alarmed when an analysis of her tap water showed abnormally high levels of copper and manganese. Mrs. Hatten, who was several months pregnant, said she feared that the concentration of minerals in the water may have harmed her developing fetus.

title: Ms. Chung Weds John F. R. Smilgin 4th
description: Christina Laisheung Chung, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chung Sing of Hong Kong, was married yesterday to John F. R. Smilgin 4th, a son of Carol Hill Smilgin and Mr. Smilgin 3d of New York. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray, assisted by Msgr. George F. Bardes, officiated at St. Thomas More Church in New York.

title: 5 Die in Taiwan as Typhoon Sweeps In From Philippines
description: A typhoon struck eastern Taiwan today with 86 mile-an-hour winds and heavy rain, killing at least five people. The storm earlier took 30 lives in the Philippines and forced tens of thousands to flee their homes.

title: Miss Nields Wed To David Jones
description: Nerissa Franklin Nields, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Nields Jr. of McLean, Va., was married there last evening to Michael David Jones, the son of Dr. and Mrs. William Burns Jones Jr., also of McLean. The Rev. John Sonnenday officiated at Immanuel Presbyterian Church.

title: Baby Makes 3, and Condos Strain to Make Do
description: LEAD: WHEN Frann and Carl Kravats bought a two-bedroom condominium in Danbury in 1986, they figured that by the time they had their first child, they would be able to sell their unit for a profit and move into a house. It would be ''the mythical little house with the white picket fence and a nice little yard for the children to run around in,'' Mrs.

title: Corey Rohr Shanus Wed To Amy Gayle Wagner
description: Amy Gayle Wagner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wagner of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Corey Rohr Shanus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Shanus of Delray Beach, Fla., at the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., by Rabbi Arnold Turetksy and Cantor Jack Mendelson.

title: Expeditions in the Boundary Waters
description: MY husband likes to go places he's been before and I like to go places new to me so when we began discussing a late summer holiday I said we could compromise and go someplace where neither of us had ever been. And then, before he could examine that compromise too closely, I began talking about canoeing in the boundary waters. The term boundary waters refers to the water and land lying astraddle the Minnesota-Ontario border. It includes but is not encompassed by, on the American side, the Boundary Waters Canoe Area, and, on the Canadian, Quetico Provincial Park.

title: GOODBYE, YELLOW BRICK ROAD
description: FADE OUT

title: Ms. Klinges Wed To M. D. Kraus
description: Jane A. Klinges, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Karl G. Klinges of Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew D. Kraus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving R. Kraus of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Wolfe performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Cemetery Baffled By Theft of Vases
description: LEAD: OVER two years, more than 4,000 bronze vases have been stolen from grave sites at Pinelawn Memorial Park in East Farmingdale, and police say the case has them baffled.

title: Past As Prelude
description: To the Editor:

title: Priscilla S. Reed Becomes a Bride
description: Priscilla Shattuck Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Reed of Amherst, Mass., was married yesterday to Jerome Ward Anderson, a son of Duane B. Anderson of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Lois G. Anderson. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen officiated at the Episcopal St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: Thinking Too Precisely?
description: To the Editor:

title:
FORUM: Alfa Romeo Ads: The Strategy . . .;

. . . And an Assessment
description: LEAD: In my experience, even in the best of times, good automotive advertising is difficult to create. It is even more difficult when you don't have a big budget, you have a client - Alfa Romeo - with a terrible customer satisfaction marks from its ratings agency and no previous advertising campaigns memorable enough to build on.

title: Race Tracks Seek Edge On Rivals
description: NEW JERSEY is the only state to have all three of the most popular forms of legalized gambling found around the country - horse racing, casino gambling and a state lottery - and at times the competition for the gambling dollar threatens to put one of the industries in the hole.

title: STREET-SMART DRESSING: OUR OWN WAY
description: Jusuf Andrews, a one-time model who makes jewelry with an African cast, has a penchant for mixing things up. ''I like a rough look and a smooth look at the same time,'' says Andrews, whose outfit on any given day makes an eloquent case for eclecticism. His Wrangler work shirt falls open to reveal a cascade of African-mask pendants, Moroccan trading beads, gold chains and cowrie shells. He belts his jeans with an Hermes scarf and tops this ensemble with a hunting cap that all but conceals his Rastafarian dreadlocks. Andrews admits he is a walking culture clash, and that's the way he likes it. His style, an ongoing experiment in self-expression, is simply the visual extension of a particular point of view. ''It represents my being American, and Indian and African,'' Andrews says. ''It represents my personality.''

title: Review/Dance;   How to Turn Nothingness Into Humor
description: The humor in the comedies that the Eva Dean Dance Company offered Thursday night at St. Mark's Church derived from the way people in them always started to do things, yet only seldom managed to get them done. Ms. Dean invented many amusing ways for nothing to happen in her choreography.

title: Data Update
DESERTION FROM THE HOME FRONT
description: LEAD:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/DINOSAURS PLUS
description: TRACES OF LIFE

title: WHEN IT WAS DANGEROUS TO TALK
description: KONSPIRA

title: ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN: A Photo Essay by James Nachtwey
description: PERHAPS the harshest legacy of the Ceausescu regime fell to the children. In 1966, a year after Nicolae Ceausescu came to power, Romanian State Decree No. 770 declared abortion illegal for any woman under 45 who had not yet produced four children. Last year, still in pursuit of a larger work force, the Communist dictator increased the number to five. Birth control was virtually unavailable, except for those with access to the black market. Ceausescu's harsh economic measures made it impossible for many to support their children. Tens of thousands of infants were abandoned. Today, six months after Ceausescu's downfall, the grim truth is gradually being revealed.

title: What's Art All About? Truth, Beauty, Unruliness
description: Truth alone is not good enough in art. The camera and audio and video recorders have taught us that. Art is not only truth and beauty and any number of other, often unpremeditated things, but also the consideration of those things in equations that refine and rearrange to suggest something more than verifiable reality.

title: 'A Fearful Freedom'
description: To the Editor:

title: At Fresh Air Camp, a Chance to Play in Safety
description: Getting Barbara O'Brien to join the Fresh Air Fund was not easy. Last summer, when Catherine O' Brien tried to convince her daughter to leave the Brooklyn housing project where they live to take a Fresh Air vacation in the countryside, Barbara thought she was being punished for something bad she had done. The tall, thin 12-year-old couldn't think of what she had done to deserve such treatment. She begged her mother not to make her go.

title:
THEATER;

Back to 'Falsettoland' in the Age of AIDS
description: LEAD: In 1981, as AIDS was beginning to rampage through the country, Playwrights Horizons produced a quirky five-character musical with a gay man as its protagonist that became an unexpected Off Broadway hit. ''March of the Falsettos,'' written by the composer William Finn and staged by a novice director, James Lapine, told the bittersweet story of a Jewish man named Marvin who leaves his wife and young son for a male lover.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Nairobi
description: Nairobi, where most people stay for just a few days before or after a safari, is no longer a town on the edge of the African bush. It is a city of two million people with marked distinctions between rich and poor and, consequently, crime. But with simple precautions, most visitors leave unscathed.

title: The Old Man Waited for the Shadows
description: IN Yaounde, the capital of Cameroon, they were already taking up a public collection to erect a statue of Roger Milla. Donations will surely go up today.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Freehold $229,000

title: OUT OF THE KITCHEN
description: In ''Out of the Kitchen'' (Fashion, May 20), Carrie Donovan writes that the clothes associated with ''cooking and cleaning up . . . menial, even demeaning duties'' can kindle ''deliciously romantic visions. . . .''

title: Soviet Union: Soliloquies Still, But With a Smile
description: Mercifully, the changes sweeping Soviet news organizations have thus far stopped short of happy talk breaking out on the main nightly television news program. But the anchors on the 40-minute broadcast, which is a major source of Government-controlled information, have started to smile a bit more and dress more brightly, and there is less Orwellian authority in their voices as they present a changing mix of stories that always pay heaviest attention to the words and pictures of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's presidential day.

title: The Jazz Passengers on a Trip Beyond Hard Bop
description: The saxophonist Roy Nathanson, who leads the Jazz Passengers with the trombonist Curtis Fowlkes, couldn't hold his tongue at the end of the septet's superb set. ''Thanks a lot for coming at this ridiculous time to this very odd place,'' he said to the audience Friday afternoon at the Equitable Auditorium, at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street.

title: Mutual Funds;   STAID MUNIS LEARN THE P-BOP
description: For the most part, municipal bond investors are an ultraconservative breed. They look not for appreciation but for income, and managers of muni bond funds crank it out, quietly but steadily, year in and year out. Innovation rarely rears its head.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Mandela Sees Links to de Klerk
description: Nelson Mandela appears to have held out the possibility of a political alliance between his African National Congress and President F. W. de Klerk's National Party in South Africa, if Mr. de Klerk can extend voting rights to the black majority.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS/DINOSAURS PLUS
description: THE LITTLEST DINOSAURS

title:
The Executive Life;

Weighing the Fast Track Against Family Values
description: LEAD: Susan Lawley seemed to have it all. As a vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Company, Mrs. Lawley earned $250,000 a year in 1988 supervising the administration of the firm's mortgage securities department. She and her husband, Robert, then a vice president at Bankers Trust Company, owned a four-bedroom house in New Jersey, drove to work in a Mercedes-Benz and a Lincoln Continental, tooled around the waters off their Long Island beach house in a sleek new motorboat and even wore matching Rolex watches.

title: Testing of Homeless Saves $400,000
description: THE county saved $400,000 in costs associated with the homeless during the first six months of the year, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week,by having applicants undergo three-day physical and mental evaluations.

title: Trappings of Affluence Draw Crowd to Auction
description: The glitziest remnants of Florida's glitziest, but now bankrupt, savings and loan went on the block here today, as eager bidders carted off such necessities of modern American business as 1,440 Baccarat crystal goblets, a sprinkling of gold-washed serving dishes, pounds of silver flatware and a mahogany cigar humidor.

title: The Nation;   Campaign-Fund Limits: Congress Blushes, States Act
description: FRUSTRATED and fed up with the state of American politics, they say, Minnesota legislators have done what the politicians in Washington are apparently afraid to do. They have tried to put a brake on the costs of campaigns by enacting a law that allows candidates for Congress in Minnesota to receive public subsidies if they limit their spending.

title: Shanley Examines Pleasure and Pain
description: IF it is a visceral, confrontational, obscure play you are after, the Penguin Rep would be a likely place to find it. And even though John Patrick Shanley has hit the big time as a screenwriter with ''Moonstruck,'' most of his plays - and screenplays - are little known and less noticed.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Travel Advisory column on page 3 of the Travel section today, about per diem allowances for Federal employees traveling abroad on business, mislabels the fourth column from the right in some copies. The figure of $177 is for Rome, not Paris.

title:
SUBURBIA COMES TO ISLAM;

The Pleasures of the Harem
description: LEAD:

title: Evening Hours;   At MOMA, Morocco And Matisse
description: Moroccan music wafted through the garden of the Museum of Modern Art Wednesday night at the gala opening of the Matisse in Morocco exhibit.

title: The Danes Prize American Jazz. Why Don't the Americans?
description: A month ago, the gifted American tenor saxophonist and composer David Murray won a $30,000 prize. And along with the money, he won the chance to perform concerts in France and Denmark and spend a week rehearsing with a Danish group - Pierre Dorge's New Jungle Orchestra - and other Danish musicians for the performances. He also won the financial backing to release an album.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Rio de Janeiro
description: Rio's irreverent citizens love a spectacle, but a photograph in newspapers here last summer was a bit downbeat: 26 foreign tourists on a hunger strike after thieves cleaned all their valuables out of a hotel safe.

title: Case of the Missing Holmes Society
description: It certainly was exciting to see the interview with Tom Stix, now titular leader of our beloved Baker Street Irregulars (''New Leader Carries On Sherlockian Tradition,'' May 6). I am always pleased to see recognition of Sherlock Holmes and his devotees.

title: Israel: A Nation of News Hounds
description: It's hard to imagine how a national news program could have a wider or more interested audience. Viewership of ''Mabat'' (''View'') -Israel's nightly news program - exceeds 90 percent of the population. The program is similar in style to its American counterparts, but the environment is far different. Israel has only one, state-run television network, with one Hebrew-language news program, and Israelis are voracious consumers of news.

title: Indy-Car Race Set For Australia
description: An Indy-car race - the first ever outside North America - will be staged in Surfer's Paradise in Queensland next March 17.

title: Will a Morning Star Continue to Shine at Night?
description: For 13 years, television viewers have looked into Jane Pauley's smiling eyes and seen exactly what they wanted to see. The hip have detected a suppressed soulmate, restraining herself in deference to the bland requirements of morning television; traditionalists have perceived a fresh, levelheaded young woman forced to cope with - but miraculously unchanged by - the fast-track world she inhabits.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Mexico City
description: Because of its proximity to the United States, Mexico City has long been one of the favorite destinations of American tourists. The welcome is usually warm, but foreign visitors also rank among the favorite marks of Mexican petty criminals. Pickpockets, for example, often prey on Americans emerging from museums, especially as they board buses or enter the subway near Chapultepec Park or on Paseo de la Reforma. Another favorite scam, practiced in connivance with shoeshine boys, is to lift the billfold of the unwary visitor whose shoes are being buffed.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FIRE ON THE RIM: A Firefighter's Season at the Grand Canyon, by Stephen J. Pyne. (Ballantine, $4.95.) During 15 summers at the Grand Canyon, the author learned about the most awesome of nature's wonders, the runaway chemical reaction called fire. ''Stephen J. Pyne is to fire what Theodore White was to American politics,'' Andrew H. Malcolm said here last year, ''an insider who can explain how his subject works and affects our lives.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   At East Europe Nuclear Plants, Blame for Soviets
description: Experts describe the hair-raising incident at an East German nuclear-energy plant like this: 11 of the 12 cooling pumps of a nuclear reactor were knocked out by fire and power failure, and workers scrambled to work a last remaining pump. Without that pump, the core of the reactor would overheat, begin to melt down and set in motion a near unstoppable process. The nearby town of Greifswald would be in radioactive peril.

title: Anglers Hail a Salmon Limit
description: THE decision to restrict the harvest of Atlantic salmon by commercial fishermen in Newfoundland has been greeted with delight by sport-fishing interests and condemned by the netters.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The other extreme from the player who can't wait to attack before he gets his pieces out of the box is the one who meanders around with infinite patience, move after move, without undertaking anything. That does not necessarily mean he is not interested in winning; it could mean he is willing to let perseverance play its part.

title: Sometimes Light Comes From Dark Places
description: Viewers who enter movie theaters to see Pedro Almodovar's ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' or Garry Marshall's smash Hollywood success ''Pretty Woman'' or the recent revival of Bertrand Blier's 1974 ''Going Places'' also enter into a tricky bargain with the film makers. Audiences are asked to leave their scruples at the door. Mr. Almodovar uses kidnapping and bondage as fodder for a romantic comedy; ''Pretty Woman'' makes prostitution funny; Mr. Blier creates two rampantly misogynistic heroes who charm the pants off nearly every woman they meet.

title: Under the Spreading Sycamore Tree, the Village Arborist Stands
description: SPRING in this village brought a worrisome sight. Three large sycamore trees along the sidewalk outside the post office seemed to be dying.

title: FINE STEREO COMES IN A SMALL PACKAGE
description: It used to be said that what this country needs is a good five-cent cigar. But in the course of cultural evolution, perceived needs change, and cigars no longer seem quite as vital. Nowadays, at least if you listen to audio salesmen, the primary need is for a good sound system for people who hate gadgetry - something that's all music and practically no hardware.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Two Mandela Daughters Still Wait for Their Turn
description: After 27 years of waiting for their father's release from prison, two of Nelson Mandela's daughters will just have to wait a bit longer for a quiet family reunion.

title: Tracy Peck Weds Thomas Phillips
description: Tracy Ann Peck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Peck of South Yarmouth, Mass., and Pittsfield, Vt., was married yesterday to Thomas Notter Phillips, a son of William E. Phillips of New York and Paula W. Shamberg of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. David Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Geneva
description: Street crime is so rare in Geneva, the cosmopolitan Swiss city that houses the European headquarters of the United Nations, that an occasional purse-snatching will be reported in the ''Faits Divers'' columns of the local newspapers.

title: The Ultimate Punk Rocker as a Prodigal Son
description: In 1982, an Australian rock group called the Birthday Party arrived in New York on its first tour of the United States. The music was harsh and hellish, a mess of screaming guitar and relentless rhythms that was as chilling as a mangled corpse.

title: LARGER THAN LIFE, DEADER THAN DEAD
description: KILLING MISTER WATSON

title: Question of the Week: Next Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JAZZ AND ROCK

title: PHILADELPHIA CARVES OUT A NEW SKYLINE
description: The battle for Philadelphia's skyline is over, and now it is time to talk about the spoils. Nearly three years have passed since the completion of One Liberty Place, the first skyscraper to rise higher than the statue of William Penn atop City Hall, and it's been longer still since the unveiling of the plans for that building by the Chicago architect Helmut Jahn caused the biggest disruption in town since the Athletics left for Kansas City.

title: 20 Years Later, a Photograph Brings Vindication
description: On a January night 20 years ago, a Northeastern University physics student named Malcolm Emory stopped on his way home from the library at an anti-Vietnam War rally nearby. In moments, Mr. Emory was on the ground, his head bleeding and his hands cuffed behind his back. His supposed crime: assault and battery on a police officer.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: To the Editor:

title: STAYING POWER
description: ONE OF MY FAVORITE FAMILY pictures is of my mother, taken in the early 1950's. Clad in a chic parka and stretch pants, she is poised atop a tall mountain. ''I didn't know you skied,'' I shrieked as the picture was being glued into a framed collage.

title: 'S' Is for Scribbler
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Party Elects Quebecer
description: Electing a new leader to reverse its election fortunes, Canada's opposition Liberal party today chose Jean Chretien, a Quebec lawyer and former finance minister.

title:
ART;

Works by Contemporary Soviet Artists, in Ridgefield
description: LEAD: AN air of celebration hangs over the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, in Ridgefield, for its current exhibition, ''Adaptation and Negation of Socialist Realism: Contemporary Soviet Art.'' There is even a T-shirt for sale with a bold Perestroika motif designed by one of the exhibition's artists, Erik

title: No Safe Way To Dispose of Ash
description: The Long Island Regional Planning Board has finally discovered the problem and enormous expense of incinerator ash disposal. Proponents of full-scale-recycling have long contended that, besides the critical problem of hazardous emissions created by mass-burn incineration, there is no safe and economical way for disposing of ash.

title: WORLD ECONOMY: THE PROPHET OF BOOM
description: THE COMING GLOBAL BOOM

title: Irene Piskor, Teacher, Wed
description: Irene Teresa Piskor, a teacher at the Burns School, and Theodore Burnham Lewis Jr.,a grants and contracts manager at the Connecticut Department of Human Resources, both in Hartford, were married there yesterday at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. David W. Lonergan. Mrs. Lewis is the daughter of Mrs. Michael Piskor of Wethersfield, Conn.; her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of New York. His previous two marriages ended in divorce.

title: Headliners;   Prime Time Breakthrough
description: Along with calculating pi to the zillionth decimal place, a favorite sport among mathematicians is factoring gigantic numbers into primes. A prime is a number like 3 or 67 that has no divisors other than itself and 1. The prime factors of 15, for example, are 3 and 5.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Mortgage Is Paid Off, but Life's Debts Remain
description: LEAD: I RECENTLY received notice, after 300 monthly payments, that my mortgage was fully discharged. I suspect fewer loans are thus paid off - down to the last installment - now than in stabler days gone by. Today, a borrower often assumes a new debt as soon as a lump sum pays off the old loan. Families are busy moving up, moving on or breaking up and moving out and haven't time to retire a mortgage.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: On paper, the Detroit Pistons may not stack up against the Bill Russell Celtics, but 12 players have never played so well as a team. With Isiah Thomas as the catalyst and Chuck Daly at the helm, this team had such a shrewd grasp of the game that it made up for any weakness. Each player did whatever was needed to win, evincing unique skills as the demands varied from game to game.

title:
Your Own Account;

Switching Health Care Plans
description: LEAD: Companies that offer a variety of health care options - and about 90 percent of major companies do so now - typically allow employees to change from one plan to another once a year. July 1 and Jan. 1 are the most common dates for these changes, so many people are facing an important decision this week.

title:
Focus: Boston;

A Union-Employer Housing Fund
description: LEAD: With Federal legislation having paved the way for union-management housing trust funds, a hotel workers union and several downtown hotels are setting up a fund here to help workers rent an apartment or buy a house and to stimulate union-sponsored construction of low-cost housing.

title: Staying on the Safe ; Rome
description: Rome has such a deep-rooted reputation for being a city of pickpockets and purse snatchers that it is easy to lose sight of the fact that travelers generally are quite safe there. In the historic center, one can venture forth alone at night without fear, even down desolate alleys that in New York would scream out danger.

title: Rock From Inspiral Carpets
description: Manchester, England, has lately been the center for the latest British rock furor: all-night dance parties with a strong tinge of psychedelia. The music revolves around a drone and a beat. It can draw on current synthesizer-driven club styles (as does one leading Manchester band, Happy Mondays) or on 1960's models, as do the Stone Roses.

title: FICTION
description: A GENTLEMAN'S GUIDE TO THE FRONTIER. By Joanne Meschery. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) ''You've lost your wife,'' Reg Vickers tells the recently widowed Andrew Marsh, ''and worse yet, your idea.'' So Reg, a pedantic, stubborn old black man who's lost his son, invites Marsh to share their idea - the plan they had made to retrace the routes that Algie, Reg's father, had taken as an Indian fighter on the Western frontier with the all-black Ninth Cavalry. And Marsh, a wealthy, overly responsible loner who's estranged from his own son, surprises himself by going along on Reg's odyssey from California to Kansas, Nebraska and South Dakota. A wacky single mother and her children, several recreational vehicles full of free spirits and Marsh's pregnant and confused daughter-in-law soon join their caravan. Reg gradually tells the group the story, at least as he knows it, of Algie's life, from educated black Englishman to American handyman, teacher and Congressional Medal of Honor winner - and there are lots of helpers along the way to ferret out new secrets. As the pilgrims relive the Battle of the Little Big Horn and see the site of the Wounded Knee massacre, the reality of the white man's past and present treatment of the black and red man rolls out too. By the time they're headed back to California, new frontiers of involvement have opened for a loosened-up Marsh; for Reg, there's a fuller understanding of his identity as a black man. Joanne Meschery, the author of a previous novel, ''In a High Place,'' is such a cracking good storyteller that it hardly seems to matter that more than one incident in ''A Gentleman's Guide to the Frontier'' strains credulity, or that the book is too chock-full of themes, characters and plots ever to jell. Vitality, a playful imagination and authentic detail make her sympathetic and good-humored romp great fun to read.

title: Mets Go South With West
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: June Christy, Singer, 64, Is Dead; Gained Fame With Kenton's Band
description: June Christy, whose wistful, foggy alto epitomized ''cool'' jazz singing in the 1940's and 50's, died Thursday at the age of 64 at her home in Los Angeles.

title: Maggie Koenig Weds Michael Mongeau
description: Margarette Whittemore Koenig, the senior nurse practioner at Benjamin Rush Medical Associates in Philadelphia, and Michael E. Mongeau, the dean of faculty and head of the middle school at the Moorestown (N.J.) Friends School, were married yesterday at the Westbury (L.I.) Friends Meeting House.

title: Quebec Could Easily Prosper On Its Own, Economists Say
description: Whatever the outcome of Canada's crisis over Quebec, the French-speaking province has slowly developed an economy strong enough to allow Quebec to separate and become a nation three times the area of France, taking with it nearly a quarter of Canada's wealth.

title: Explosion on Dead Sea Beach
description: A bomb in a trash can exploded today on a Dead Sea beach, wounding four people, the police said. The explosion occurred at the Ein Gedi campground, a beach frequented by tourists and run by the Ein Gedi kibbutz. The area is south of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. No group took responsibility.

title: Mexico: The Word According To Jacobo
description: Every weeknight television sets in lavish mansions and humble cantinas are tuned to a dour middle-aged man in glasses and an elegantly tailored suit. All of Mexico knows it is again time for ''24 Hours,'' the main news program of the perpetually top-rated Televisa network, and when the anchorman Jacobo Zabludovsky speaks, Mexico pays attention.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   A Chicken Dish for Parties Is Trimmed to Supper Size
description: This chicken and bulgur recipe was originally designed for entertaining. But with a few nips and tucks it is simple enough to put together for a Sunday supper or for a meal to make quickly after work.

title: White Sox Halt A's And Inch Closer
description: Ron Karkovice snapped a sixth-inning tie with a bases-empty home run as the Chicago White Sox spoiled the return of Jose Canseco to the Oakland lineup by defeating the Athletics today, 5-3.

title: Pilot Computer Program For Adults May Expand
description: LEAD: LOCAL and state education officials are seeking to expand and replicate a year-old pilot program in White Plains to improve adults' academic skills and better prepare them for jobs or further education in their occupations.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Flights of Fancy On a Dirt Runway
description: LEAD: LAST Jan. 25 Mahopac Airport, a small field with a dirt runway that had served pilots for more than 40 years, was closed. Soon it will be leveled, graded and in general mauled, to emerge in a few years as a housing development.

title: Czechoslovakia Gains
description: Tomas Skuhravy scored two goals tonight as Czechoslovakia eliminated Costa Rica from the World Cup finals, 4-1.

title: Ellsworth Kelly Loads the Dice at the Modern
description: It is not every artist who is allowed to go into the most important museum of modern art in the world, select the art in it that defines his modern artistic heritage and his esthetic beliefs, install it in one of the museum's galleries, and set one of his own paintings in the center so that it seems to conduct all the other works, or hover over them like a bird, or stand over them with raised hands like a priest.

title: CANADIAN LEADER APPEALS FOR CALM ON QUEBEC DISPUTE
description: With the collapse of a deal that many here thought might be the last chance to keep Quebec in Canada, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney appealed today for calm while new ways were sought to keep this bitterly divided country intact.

title: The 'Girls' Gather to Write And Reflect
description: THE ''girls,'' as they call themselves, are gathered in the living room of my mother's small Mount Kisco apartment on a cloudy Friday afternoon. Each has a notebook and pencil in hand, and on this day some time ago Marguerite begins:

title: The Nation;   Arms Debate Flares Anew As Critics Deploy Their Second-Striking Capabilities.
description: THE Berlin wall has fallen, the military budgets of Moscow and Washington are in decline, and the cold war is over. But as a new treaty to cut strategic arms is emerging, many of the debates that surround it have not changed. Since the new treaty was approved in principle at the summit meeting earlier this month between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the decade-old debate over Soviet ''heavy'' missiles and other ancient arms control issues has taken on new life.

title: Alfa Romeo Ads: The Strategy . . .
description: We had a creative challenge. The world was hardly waiting for another luxury car, even a high-performance luxury car, and we had one to sell. We knew this: If a product is going into an already crowded market, you had better do everything you can to set it apart.

description: Nostalgic play clothes are offering an alternative to high-velocity summer wear. Loose-fitting one-piece rompers with roll-up sleeves and legs evoke the sandbox.

title: The World: U.S.-P.L.O. Talks;   An Unlikely Dialogue Comes to an End
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S decision last week to suspend the dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization for its failure to condemn a terrorist raid by one of its factions brought to an end an 18-month relationship that was probably doomed from the start.

title: Gate Keeping
description: THE WILD CELEBRATIONS AT THE Berlin Wall last New Year's Eve damaged the already corroding Quadriga, the copper statue of the goddess Nike in a chariot drawn by four horses (below) that has ridden atop the famed Brandenburg Gate for nearly two centuries. The statue was a particularly ambiguous symbol for the 28-year existence of the wall; Nike is the Greek goddess of victory, and King Frederick William II of Prussia remarked on the Quadriga's unveiling in 1795 that the goddess represented the triumph of peace.

title: Review/Dance;   Baryshnikov's 'Swan Lake' With Harvey and Graffin
description: Both sleekly modernistic and full of dramatic detail, Mikhail Baryshnikov's production of ''Swan Lake'' took on a reverberant extra passion in the hands of Cynthia Harvey and Guillaume Graffin when American Ballet Theater presented the ballet classic on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Stoppard's New Version Roasts an Old Chestnut
description: A COMPOSER eavesdrops upon an actress, his inamorata and the star of his new operetta, who is carrying on a real-life love scene with an actor, her former lover. It looks like curtains for all, until a playwright, who is also a snoop, takes down the overheard lines, drafts them into the script and convinces the composer that the seduction scene was but a late-night rehearsal.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: The Adirondacks' Friendly Race
description: LEAD: FOR canoeists, choosing a lake or river in the Adirondack State Park is like selecting a book from a library full of best sellers. The park's six million acres have weeklong wilderness trips and afternoon family paddles to fill a lifetime. There is no better introduction to the diversity of the park than the Adirondack Canoe Classic.

title: Elizabeth Colston Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Maria Colston, an M.D. and Ph.D. candidate at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, was married yesterday to Leo Danni Titus, a consultant with ALK Associates, transportation specialists in Princeton, N.J. Msgr. John F. Corr officiated at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Carroll Colston of Morristown, N.J. She graduated cum laude from Princeton University. Mr. Titus, 26 and a Princeton graduate, is a son of Murray Titus of St. John, New Brunswick, Canada, and Nancy Titus of Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada.

title: County Parks Prepare For Ethnic Festivals
description: THE county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will present a summer of diversified outdoor music and other cultural activities. The most ambitious cycle is the nine-week series of Heritage Celebrations - festivals celebrating ethnic traditions and accomplishments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I agree with those who say we must hurry quickly away from Marxism-Leninism, through Socialism, to Reaganism.'' - Pyotr S. Filipov, an economist on the Leningrad City Council. [1:4.]

title: The Region;   As Floria Changes Politics, His Foes Are Overwhelmed And His Allies Are Nervous
description: RELENTLESSLY over the last five months, Jim Florio, who took over the governorship of New Jersey on Jan. 16, has overwhelmed his enemies and unnerved his allies with a series of initatives that, as of last December, most politicians said a governor should not, would not or could not get done.

title: The Wimbledon Dropout Delays His Education
description: WHEN the first splash of cream sweetens the first dish of strawberries at Wimbledon tomorrow, all of the world's best tennis players will have gathered on the All England Club's grass courts for the world's best tennis tournament. All except Andre Agassi. For the third consecutive year, the mop-haired American has chosen not to enter Wimbledon after having been eliminated in his first match there by Henri Leconte of France in 1987.

description: Farmingdale $145,000

title: The Mandela Visit;   MANDELA'S TRIP IS TRIUMPH AT HOME
description: As he was hailed with a ticker-tape parade and other festivities in New York this week, Nelson Mandela was treated in the press back home as a son of South Africa who had made good.

title: SCIENTISTS REPORT FASTER OZONE LOSS
description: New scientific evidence that the earth's ozone layer is being destroyed more quickly than previously reported is being presented in London to negotiators working on a treaty to speed the elimination of chemicals that cause the problem.

description: THE former political prisoners who run this country dispatched a squadron of police officers backed by water cannon and armored personnel carriers the other day to break a farmers' blockade of the main Warsaw-Gdansk highway.

There is little about this office in the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building in Harlem to suggest that it is an outpost of the Manhattan District Attorney in the fight to stem the tide of crime swamping upper Manhattan.

title: Brazil: The Show Belongs To Globo
description: Across this continent-size nation, the single largest source of news is ''Jornal Nacional,'' a 30-minute nightly news program produced by Globo Television, the world's fourth largest network. Low literacy levels, high rates of television set ownership and a long-dominant market position by Globo have combined to give the news program enormous power in Brazil, where an estimated 55 million of Brazil's 140 million residents watch Globo news every night.

title: Sprinklers in the Home Gain Support High Death Toll in Fires Cited by Local Officials
description: Joseph and Karen Jenkins went apple picking one Sunday in the fall of 1985, and the next morning, as Mrs. Jenkins rushed to get to work, a bag of the fruit on the kitchen floor of their Westchester County home blocked her way. She picked it up and dumped it on the kitchen counter, next to the toaster.

title:
DANCE;

Graham's Ideas Put Into Action
description: LEAD: A PERFORMANCE on Saturday by the Martha Graham Dance Company will bring to a close the dance portion of the Rutgers SummerFest. The program includes a selection of works that reflect the diverse and monumental themes that have informed Miss Graham's choreography for more than 60 years.

title: Some Eggheads Have Their Sunny Side, Too
description: When I was in high school, my secret weapon for gaining admittance to the college of my choice was competing on a television talk show called ''The World Youth Forum.'' Broadcast weekly on CBS, the forum was in my mind a mini-version of ''It's a Wise Child,'' the radio program on which all the members of J. D. Salinger's Glass family were participants. In other words, my network appearance brought me closer to the bright and sensitive Franny and Zooey.

title: NONFICTION
description: CAT AND I. By Doris Schwerin. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The protagonist in Doris Schwerin's deeply felt memoir is an uppity gray feline named Miss Willow, a moody, highly opinionated creature with a distinctive voice and many roles. Like the pigeons in her earlier autobiographical work, ''Diary of a Pigeon Watcher,'' the cat is a mirror of the author's moods, an extension of her psyche, as well as an object of her projections. At times she acts as Ms. Schwerin's alter ego, the self-doubting inner voice who prods her as she works, posing vexing questions: why does she write? and for whom? At other times she serves as the author's muse, the source of her daydreams as well as her memories. For it is in the act of telling Willow's story that the author unearths her own: the saga of Willow's rape by a tomcat in a dank city cellar sparks long-buried memories of her elderly aunt's murder by the Boston Strangler. An almost fatal encounter between Willow and another tomcat spirals back into the writer's recollections of her own emotional collapse, as well as thoughts about a near-drowning one childhood summer and the premature death of her older sister. Yet happily Ms. Schwerin succeeds in making her cat more than a convenient narrative prop. Because the reader is privy to the emotional interdependence between master and pet, there is always a logic to their intertwined stories. And though there are times when the weaving of Willow's biography with her own seems gratingly self-indulgent, the honesty with which the author confronts such difficult subjects as aging, marital infidelity and death makes these lapses forgivable. Ms. Schwerin is an observant writer whose layered prose beautifully evokes the salient details of time and place. Indeed, some of the most transporting moments of her book are those in which she describes New York City in the 1950's, particularly the underground life of Greenwich Village, with its jazz clubs where Pete Johnson and Art Tatum held sway. If the contrapuntal character of this memoir is often reminiscent of music, it may be because Ms. Schwerin is also a composer.

title: Concerts Expanding at the Shore
description: AS bandmasters strike up their concert orchestras this month and string bands plunk their way down the boardwalks, they are maintaining a summer tradition of live music at the Shore that is more than 120 years old and growing.

title:
About Men;

The Czar's Missing Gem

My eye would detect what Czar Alexander III, his court and the master jewelers of the age had somehow failed to notice - a gem smaller and more irregular in its shape than the superb rubies and emeralds surrounding it.

And mixed in with the throngs, the police say, are growing numbers of pickpockets from both East and

For general chores, gardeners can protect themselves by spraying clothing, hats and exposed areas (particularly the back of the neck) with insect repellent. It will also help to discourage ticks, especially if long pants are worn tucked into socks.

title: Talking: Mediation;   Resolving Disputes In Condos
description: More than 30 million Americans now live in condominiums, cooperatives and homeowner associations. And increasingly their internal disputes have been clogging the courts and bringing pressure for alternative forms of dispute resolution.

title: Longer School Year: Some Disadvantages
description: Assemblyman William Pascrell's recent article concerning the extension of the school year into the summer (''Needed: A Longer School Year,'' Opinion page, May 6) fails to take to account that the schools are not educating students within the 10-month time period. Extending the school year for two months will mean that there will be two more months of schools' failing to educate.

title: Staying on the Safe Side: New Delhi
description: The capital of India is really two or more cities, a fact worth remembering for safety sake. New Delhi, the imperial capital built by the British in the 1920's and 30's, is still mostly a spacious city of tree-lined streets where tourists walk comfortably at almost any hour of the day or night without problems. Old Delhi is a teeming jumble of back alleys and bazaars where foreigners are always warned to look out for pickpockets and purse snatchers.

description: IT is the lot of many travelers to find the rapture of reaching journey's end modified by a heartfelt desire never again to see a car, plane or train. The feeling soon passes, but respite can be sought meanwhile in the kind of hotel that offers real tranquillity in which to relax and refresh the spirits. A number of historic hotels in Britain provide not only comfortable rooms but also elaborate garden landscapes in which guests can unwind.

Can You Read? Some People Can't

He holds a manila envelope on which his name and mine are typed. When I approach, he takes out his certificate. Together we read my words: ''For continued progress and motivation.

title: One by One, Ohio Town Buries Dozens Lost in Flood
description: James Moore spent his last days building a windmill along the east bank of WeeGee Creek, where he met his wife and reared their children. Today, more than a week after tumultuous rains made the placid creek malicious as a mad dog, the 72-year-old welder and tinkerer was buried.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Madrid
description: Petty crime against tourists in Spain appears to be rising, but the level is hardly high enough to deter visitors, and violence remains rare.

description: To the Editor: In the May 13 Travel section there was a photo illustrating an article by Susan Allport with the caption ''Robert Frost Farm in Shaker Village, New Hampshire.''

title: Recycle Now, Before It Is Ash
description: The report ''Study Urges Recycling Ash from Municipal Incinerators'' (May 6) provided one of the best illustrations of why trash incineration should be the least desirable solid waste management option: 25 percent to 30 percent of the burned garbage - by weight - remains as ash and will be expensive to dispose. The report, however, missed two important points.

description: LEAD:

title: Irwin Tied for Lead in Buick Classic
description: Just when it appeared that fatigue was setting in on Hale Irwin in the hectic days after his United States Open triumph last Monday, he rallied this afternoon with birdies on the last two holes for a share of the lead in the Buick Classic.

title: SOCCER'S LITTLE BIG MAN
description: My compliments to George Vecsey for the fine article ''Soccer's Little Big Man'' (May 27). Vecsey mentioned that Diego Maradona's education stopped in his early teens, and that this is ''typical'' of world-class players. However, there have been a few exceptions. Carlos Bilardo of Argentina, a national team coach and former professional player, is a medical doctor. Two famous Brazilian players of the 1980's, Socrates and Zico, are a pediatrician and an accountant, respectively.

title: For Chichester, Greater Expectations
description: The Chichester Festival Theater achieved its heights in the 1960's when the newly formed company was directed by Laurence Olivier in conjunction with his leadership of the Old Vic. Since then, Chichester has survived - with highs and lows - under what has sometimes seemed to be a revolving-door management. The last director, Robin Phillips, exited before he had a first season. Chichester receives no public financial support, in contrast to the Royal Shakespeare Company, the National Theater and other companies. The festival exists on income from ticket sales and corporate support and has managed to be financially stable, drawing a faithful local audience as well as theatergoers from London, which is less than 90 minutes away from this cathedral town. In recent years, Chichester has specialized in revivals of popular plays and lighter classics, some of which have moved to London's West End.

title: With a Family of 'Fruit Tramps'
description: LEAD: IN America's fields and orchards of plenty, malnourished men, women and children labor nearly nonstop from sunup until sundown, hand-harvesting the produce that ends up on America's tables.

title: No Headline
description: ASSEMBLYMAN JOHN C. COCHRANE, the Suffolk Republican leader for the last two years, has emerged from the tortuous process of selecting a state Republican ticket as a major state politician and a prospect for state party chairman.

title: No Wedding, But the Cake Isn't Wasted
description: Kathleen Gooley was to have been married today. The wedding was called off, but the reception went on. Instead of friends and relatives, Ms. Gooley's guests were 150 people from homeless shelters, soup kitchens and drug rehabilitation centers in Norwalk, Stamford and Bridgeport.
