description: Carol L. Rosenau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Rosenau of White Plains, was married last evening to Scott V. Truncellito, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Truncellito of Manchester, N.H. The Rev. Clifford M. Lawrence Jr. officiated at the Congregational ceremony at the New York Botanical Gardens.

title: Doctors Use Ham Radios To Save a Life in Russia
description: LEAD: AN INTERNIST from Briarcliff Manor is among several doctors from the United States responding to an unusual call for help from the Soviet Union. Their efforts may not only save a man's life but also increase medical cooperation between the two countries.

title: NOWHERE TO HIDE
description: THE ART LOVER. By Carole Maso. (North Point, $18.95.) Dedicated to a friend of the author's who died of AIDS, Carole Maso's second novel reads like an anguished meditation on the insufficiency of art as a refuge from life. Fragmented and hesitant, as if unsure of its powers, ''The Art Lover'' eventually centers on a character named Caroline, herself a writer, whose novel-in-progress turns out to have peopled the opening pages of the book we are reading. Like Carole Maso, Caroline has a friend who dies of AIDS. Her recently deceased father, Max, an eminent critic, taught her that art is all that matters; instinct tells her to agree, yet she worries that her mother's suicide may have been encouraged in some way by Max's esthetic distancing. Faced with the awful reality of her friend Steven's terminal illness, Caroline begins to feel that retreating into art may in fact be nothing but an exquisite form of betrayal. (Toward the end of the book, as if repenting her own fictive nature, Caroline actually dissolves for a time and is replaced by Carole Maso herself.) The novel's locus of pain, on many levels, is Greenwich Village; the restoring oasis is an artists' colony in Cummington, Mass., where shattered characters measure emotional losses against the recurring patterns of art, religion and nature. The narration moves brokenly from speaker to speaker, sketching thoughts, dreams, memories. Newspaper clippings on various topics - star maps, artists' lives - are patched in throughout, often as ironic counterpoint. When the story draws to an end, characters from different imaginative levels seem to be melting into one another. Yet none of this is jarring. On the contrary, though it takes the incoherence of grief as a compositional principle, ''The Art Lover'' in its realization is fully coherent, moving and elegiac, a genuine consolation.

title: The Elbowing Is Becoming Fierce For Space on the Radio Spectrum
description: The pizza-delivery business, the cellular telephone industry and futuristic high-definition television have something unfortunate in common. All covet the same bands on the already crowded spectrum of broadcast frequencies.

title: Expos Overtake Pirates
description: Montreal moved into first place in the National League East tonight as Zane Smith pitched seven strong innings to help the Expos beat the slumping Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-1.

title: Lifestyle;   Perils of a Musician's Life in the Month of Weddings
description: If Andrew Bolotowsky could change the words to just one song, it might well be ''A Policeman's Lot is Not a Happy One'' from Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Pirates of Penzance.'' A musician's lot is not an easy one. Especially not in June.

title: The 3 R's Are Romance...
description: Julius Portnow (''Romance Time in a Nursing Home,'' May 27) was right! Residents at most health-related facilities on Long Island will tell you that the 3 R's are not the Risk/Reward Ratio; it's Romance/Romance/Romance - with a capital R. For true Romance aficionados like Molly Goldberg, an 89-year-old ''snow-bird'' from Plainview, bring on Johanna Lindsey, Janet Dailey, Eugenia Price, Kathleen E. Woodiwiss, and Catherine Coulter. During a recent trip to Waldenbooks, she confessed that she began reading romance books in her 80s. Tempted to buy Lindsey's book, ''Defy Not the Heart,'' she confided that the book cover was so sensual that she was embarrassed to present it to the cashier. ''A 60-year-old retired school administrator recommended Coulter's ''Night Storm,'' but the cover looked too sexy'' she said.

title: Narrowing 400 Entries Down to 29: A Fine Job of Selection
description: THINGS are looking up in the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, or at least in the department that deals with sponsoring exhibitions. The fine-arts annual, now in its sixth edition, at the Jersey City Museum appears to have been chosen not by the usual electronic scanner programmed for the unexceptional, but by informed human sensibilities.

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Cairo
description: The traveler told his tale like this: He had been strolling in central Cairo when something unpleasant spilled on his leg and a man seemed to materialize from nowhere to help clean it away. Only when this self-appointed benefactor had disappeared in a car that also seemed to come from nowhere did the man realize that his wallet, stowed in a back pocket, had gone too.

title: Juliet Brigitte Karelsen, Art Student, Is Wed to William F. Roorbach, Writer
description: Juliet Brigitte Karelsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Karelsen 3d of New York, was married yesterday in Enfield, N.H., to William Forsyth Roorbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Roorbach of New Canaan, Conn. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York, officiated at the summer home of bridegroom's family.

title: Nilan Says He's Leaving
description: THERE was no official announcement, but Chris Nilan, the personable hockey enforcer who was sidelined with injuries for most of his two and a third seasons with the Rangers, said yesterday that the team would trade him to the Bruins this week.

title: FICTION
description: PAPER PRODUCTS. By James W. Hall. (Norton, $18.95.) Satire is the most difficult of literary pursuits, yet in many ways the most rewarding. It requires that the writer have a well-wrought sense of irony and an intelligence that strikes but isn't cruel. If this kind of writing pleases you, try spending some time with ''Paper Products,'' James W. Hall's first collection of short stories. Mr. Hall, who has four books of poetry and two novels to his credit, seems to have had his satirical blade honed on Eudora Welty's wheel, with perhaps a turn or two from Walt Kelly. His territory is mainly the South; his characters live in places like Sinking Fork, Ky., and they are often very funny. One of the most amusing stories is ''The Miracles,'' the tale of a man who comes to a small Kentucky town and promises to make the football team a winner by teaching the girls a kind of Zen cheerleading. But Mr. Hall's writing can be dark as well. In the title story, for example, a plumber from a small town in Tennessee drifts down to Mexico, marries an American woman and returns to her home in Florida to live, only to put his profession to a most macabre use. Occasionally Mr. Hall's characters can seem too country cute, a trait that cloys. But most of the time he has everything firmly under control. With satire, that's a must.

title: Staying on the Safe Side: Athens
description: LEAD: Though crime has been rising in Greece for several years, the country as a whole still says it has one of the lowest crime rates of Western European countries and the United States, according to Notis Martakis, the spokesman for the National Tourist Organization of Greece. ''A woman can walk alone in any part of

title: Travel Advisory
description: New Hotel Tax Is Protested In New York

title: Man Who Headed Crock-Pot Concern Is Beaten to Death
description: I. H. (Hack) Miller, who brought the name Crock-Pot to millions of households, was killed in his home Friday, and a grandson was charged in the slaying, the police in Kansas City, Mo., reported yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Student Reports She Was Raped At a Fraternity
description: Officials at the University of Southern California and the Los Angeles police are investigating a student's report that she was raped in a fraternity house while on a date last December and later subjected to a parade of mostly undressed members.

title: JEFFERSON AND THE PRESIDENCY
description: As a Jefferson enthusiast, I felt I should write to you concerning the statement in Christopher Hitchens's article ''Why We Don't Know What We Don't Know'' (May 13), that ''the stone obelisk at Jefferson's grave . . . modestly and perhaps ironically omits his Presidency from the list of accomplishments.''

title: Traffic Alert
description: Central Park South from Columbus Circle to Fifth Avenue, and Fifth Avenue from Central Park South to Washington Square North will be closed today from 9 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. for the Gay Pride Parade.

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   Student Group Seeks Closer Ties To Neighborhoods
description: Taking their cue from a long-dor mant neighborhood organization, students at the University of Chicago have formed a community action group that aims to dissolve what they see as racial and economic barriers separating the university from surrounding neighborhoods. The group is modeled on the Student Woodlawn Area Project, founded in 1966 with the same objectives. Students in the new organization, called Student Neighborhood Action Project, or SNAP, hope to combine community service with scholarly research and discussion to promote greater understanding between town and gown.

title: The Germanys: Influential, Serious And Hold the Glitz
description: For many years, West German programs have also brought news to East Germany. Since the fall of the old regime in East Germany, that country's news programs have become sources of serious information, but most East Germans still tune in from habit to the evening West German newscasts.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: North Salem, N.Y. $300,000

title: Review/Pop;   Jennifer Holliday Shares Stage With Johnny Mathis
description: When the Broadway musical ''Dreamgirls'' made a star of Jennifer Holliday in 1981, it was immediately apparent that the singer with a mountainous pop-gospel voice possessed a singular talent. Finding a place for that talent in the sleek world of commercial pop-soul music, however, has proven a frustrating task because her rugged, idiosyncratic delivery couldn't easily be confined within pop formulas. Perhaps at last she is ready to make the transition.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: A FAMILY INSTITUTION
description: MENNINGER: The Family and the Clinic. By Lawrence J. Friedman. (Knopf, $29.95.) In 1919, Karl Menninger joined his father's medical practice, changing its emphasis to his own specialty, neuropsychiatry. By 1973, the Menninger Foundation, with a budget of nearly $15 million, employed 900 people in 39 buildings across two campuses. It became in the process ''one of the most significant and innovative psychiatric institutions in America,'' writes Lawrence J. Friedman, but then sacrificed some of its creative pre-eminence by transforming itself into a bureaucracy. A professor of history and American studies at Bowling Green State University, Mr. Friedman provides in ''Menninger: The Family and the Clinic'' a comprehensive biography of American psychiatry's first family. Readers receive a psychological analysis of the family's intricate - some might say compulsive - ties to its work. The author benefited from nearly unlimited access to family members, employees and colleagues, along with the family's personal and professional papers. In most instances, he shapes the voluminous data well. Mr. Friedman convincingly argues that Karl Menninger, the innovative, volatile older brother, and Will, his gentle, charming sibling, struggled with one another for control of the institution throughout their lifetimes. Students of the field will be fascinated with descriptions of the Menningers' techniques, from Will's highly structured, Freudian-based milieu therapy to the foundation's novel, contemporary programs in child psychiatry and other disciplines. With its clear if unstylish prose, the book is obviously designed for readers with a keen interest in psychology. Even they may occasionally tire of the excessive space devoted to short-term employees. Still, ''Menninger: The Family and the Clinic'' is a thorough, accomplished addition to the history of American mental health treatment.

title: Thailand: More Democracy And More Control
description: The American happy-talk model for television news has been embraced in Thailand, too, even by those stations whose job it is to reflect the military's views of the news.

title: PASTIMES: STAMPS
description: LEAD: Watermarks have nothing to do with water, but to understand what they are, two paragraphs on papermaking are required reading.

title: On the Home Front
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Go To the Rescue Of the Guard
description: THE other night I picked up a newspaper and there it was: an article predicting virtual elimination of the 50th Armored Division, an Army National Guard unit based in New Jersey. Many of the division's fighting battalions have roots that go back to World War II.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Moldavia Assembly Declares Sovereignty of the Republic
description: The Parliament of Moldavia approved a declaration of the republic's sovereignty today, asserting that its laws supersede those of the Soviet Union, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Miss Sullivan to Wed William Galvin
description: The engagement of Catherine Ann Sullivan to William P. Galvin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Galvin of Forest Hills, Queens, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Donal Sullivan of Rockville Centre, L.I. A September wedding is planned. Miss Sullivan, 25 years old, graduated from St. Agnes Cathedral High School in Rockville Centre and Providence College. She is an account executive at NBC-TV in New York. Her father is a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York.

title: Backers Push Louisiana Abortion Bill Toward Supreme Court Test
description: For national strategists on both sides of the abortion debate, the broad legal concerns raised in a restrictive new bill under consideration by Louisiana lawmakers are of critical importance.

title: Rescuers Dig for Survivors of Iran Quake
description: Weary disaster teams dug for survivors with fading hope and buried uncounted bodies in mass graves in earthquake-stricken northwestern Iran yesterday. Foreign emergency aid poured in and official estimates of the toll of death and destruction continued to climb.

title: Hero Hunger
description: America's adulation follows Nelson Mandela everywhere. Ticker tape, created for the occasion; shouts of joy; TV talkathons, a crunch of celebrities and an effusion of politicians - such is the affectionate ordeal that he is expected to endure. This is an undoubted tribute to Mr. Mandela's unfailing grace under exhausting pressure. But the warmth of his welcome says something about America as well as South Africa. Call it the power of positive heroism.

title: BRIGHTNESS BELOW
description: As a child I used to wander through the biggest art gallery in the world - the London Underground stations - enthralled by the colorful posters that not only promoted travel by ''tube'' but also encouraged me to go to plays and concerts, visit the zoo or take a trip to the countryside. The posters were commissioned by London Transport (then the Underground Group) starting in 1908, with displays of as many as 40 posters a year. More than 200 are beautifully reproduced in ART FOR THE LONDON UNDERGROUND: London Transport Posters, 1908 to the Present (Rizzoli, Paper, $29.95), by Oliver Green, who was the first curator of the London Transport Museum. From the beginning, the standard of poster design was extremely high. The copywriters borrowed liberally from literature - a 1909 poster promoting the train as a refuge from the English climate had as its slogan ''Winter's Discontent Made Glorious.'' A poster from World War I reads, ''Why Bother About the Germans Invading the Country? Invade It Yourself by Underground and Motor-'Bus.'' This sentiment was not repeated during World War II, when fewer and smaller posters were issued because of a paper shortage and because unnecessary travel was discouraged, and publicity posters were largely discontinued. Instead a set of pictorial posters entitled ''They Also Serve'' commemorated the efforts of the Underground staff who kept the system running under difficult wartime conditions. Present-day posters emphasize contemporary art and young artists, and are continuing to turn every Underground station and bus shelter into a venue for constantly changing exhibitions of modern art - free.

title: 'The Proper Measure' Insults Men
description: Regarding ''Taking the Proper Measure of a Man'' (May 20): Barbara Klaus's article is full of prejudicial statements and insulting remarks in regard to our male counterparts.

title: Lenin's City of Revolution Is Turning Its Back on Him
description: This city still bears Lenin's name, but these days it seems to have lost patience with his revolution.

title: Correction
description: A photograph on June 10 with a review of ''Naked by the Window: The Fatal Marriage of Carl Andre and Ana Mendieta'' was published in error. It shows the artist Hans Breder, not Carl Andre.

title: Where the Quiz-Show Mania is Hot
description: RANDY PIRO, the manager of the Tiffany Wine and Cheese Cafe, had a telephone in his hand, a reporter at his back and a group of prospective customers charging towards him.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Woman Dies and 5 Are Hurt After A Nightclub Shooting
description: A 23-year-old woman was killed and five other people were wounded early yesterday morning at a popular reggae club in lower Manhattan when a patron opened fire on the club's bouncers, the police said.

title: Style Makers;   Nicholas Treadwell: Art Dealer
description: In the 1960's, Nicholas Treadwell crisscrossed England with a mobile art gallery - two furniture vans and a doubledecker bus. ''I've never found a better way to sell pictures,'' said the art dealer, who has operated galleries in London and Amsterdam, as well as an ''art safari park'' in a Canterbury mansion where artists lived and worked. He now lives in this northern English city where last September he opened Treadwell's Art Mill. The former cotton mill houses three stories of highly individualistic works of art that Mr. Treadwell calls ''superhumanist.'' It also has a vegetarian cafe, a cinema, a theater and studios for young artists in whom Mr. Treadwell sees promise. Eight have been offered one-year residencies; the mill has room for 14.

title: A Musical Partnership Forged on L.I.
description: CRAIG CARNELIA, a songwriter and performer, says he ''often invents reasons'' for going back to Floral Park.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Detroit Needs Better Cars, Not Hype
description: LEAD: HAVE you ever wanted to talk back to a television commercial? I had that experience recently, watching Lee Iacocca bash the Japanese auto industry.

title: In Portugal, Fresh Sardines
description: When the Portuguese talk about sardines, they generally don't mean those tiny skinned and boned creatures compressed into a minute can. They are referring to fresh, succulent sardines, the bigger, the fatter - the better. In Portugal, more than 60 percent of the national sardine catch is consumed fresh: 12 pounds a person, on average, compared to only 2 pounds of the fish canned.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   It's 'Chinese,' But It Has A Latin Twist
description: Don't take the name of this pork dish too literally; the Chinese don't use rum in their cooking and are unlikely to use lime juice either. But the combination of ingredients is certainly Chinese in flavor, and if you like very hot food, add more chili paste.

title: Miss Hohn Weds Bradley L. Brehm
description: Patricia La Rosa Hohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hohn of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York, was married yesterday to Bradley L. Brehm, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Brehm of Coram, L.I. The Rev. William H. Pindar officiated at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Kerry Garon Wed To J. P. Burns Jr.
description: Kerry Lee Garon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Garon of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Patrick Burns Jr., a son of Mr. Burns of Rumson, N.J., and Joan Burns of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. Francis Courneen and Msgr. Patrick Sheridan officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Taking Aim at the Swans

title: Libya
description: To the Editor: Regarding a recent letter (Letters on Travel, April 8), your readers should be advised that travel to Libya is subject to severe restrictions under Federal law.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: A couple of new coins have been announced in recent weeks. The most startling is the production of a new gold coin by the Soviet Union. The legal tender gold pieces in denominations of 50, 100 and 200 rubles are expected to be released later this year. Called ''Glasnost/Perestroika,'' the coins have the word peace in English, German, French, Japanese and Russian and the reverse shows the dove of peace with the motto ''Glasnost.1990.Persestroika.'' The three coins will be sold separately or together in a collector's set. After the minting, the dies will be destroyed.

title: A Plot Line That Becomes Defused
description: OF all the news stories chronicling carnage and trauma, among the most frightening are those that involve violence toward children.

title: Mr. Nickerson Beats Sewickley by a Bob
description: Mr. Nickerson bobbed his head back down after being passed by Sewickley in the penultimate stride and won the $85,600 True North Handicap by a nose yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The bathroom window inside our tub/shower area has deteriorated from exposure to dampness. For the new window, we are trying to decide between another one of wood or a vinyl one. Which do you recommend?

title: Intriguing Mix Offered In Three One-Act Plays
description: GROWING up heterosexual has seemed just fine to the twice-married Marcy, until Joan reminds her of a sexual experience they shared when, as fourth graders, they were playing doctor under the dining room table.

title: Hartford Losing a Link to Past Heads of State
description: AS Sam Lubka reels off a list of past customers, you can see the faces of Connecticut's history going by. ''We've supplied hats to Governor Ribicoff, Governor Dempsey, Governor Meskill . . .,'' says Mr. Lubka, pausing in silence over the current Governor, William A. O'Neill. ''Governor O'Neill does not wear hats,'' Mr. Lubka said. ''You never see him in a hat.'' In November, Connecticut will elect a successor to Mr. O'Neill, but Mr. Lubka won't have to worry about whether the state's new Governor favors hats. After 43 years of selling hats to Connecticut's notables and not-so-notables, Mr. Lubka is retiring. Come July, his store, Calfas Hatters, will be only a memory.

title: Technology;   The Lure of Digital Television
description: As recently as last year, proponents of a futuristic union between high-definition television and computers were being dismissed as woolly headed idealists who did not understand business. Today, however, these radicals are gaining credibility in their push to combine HDTV - with its crisp, film-like images and sound - and the interactive capacities of a computer work station.

title: Postings: 70 Units in Stamford;   'Mutual Housing' Complex
description: City and state officials in Stamford, Conn., are planning a ''mutual housing'' complex whose 70 one- to three-bedroom units are to be owned and managed by a not-for-profit mutual housing association. Tenants will pay $2,500 to join the association and rents will average $400 a month, with higher rents for larger apartments. The membership fee is refundable when a tenant moves.

title: New Drugs for Long-Time Travelers' Maladies
description: EFFORTS to protect the health of United States travelers have advanced two big steps, although one step was more like a stumble for a while. The first is Federal approval of an oral antityphoid vaccine that in tests produced fewer side effects (1 person in 100,000) than the customary injections. The second is arrival on the market of a new drug against malaria that is effective against protozoa that have developed a resistance to older drugs. It is now the top antimalarial choice of the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title:
ART;

Large Prints, but Not Oversize
description: LEAD: THE premise behind ''The Larger Print,'' the current exhibition at the Midge Karr Art Center of New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, is that contemporary printmakers often work on a scale rivaling that of paintings. Although this is certainly true, few of the works on view prove the point.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Russian Party Elects Hard-Liner; Gorbachev to Keep Political Post
description: The hard-line heart of the Communist Party chose Ivan K. Polozkov, an outspoken regional boss, as its leader today, and he immediately set a militant course for the coming party congress by criticizing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as too tolerant, slow and cautious in dealing with the nation's turmoil.

title: The Robbins Festival: A Panorama of Humanity
description: The New York City Ballet season, which continues through next Sunday at the New York State Theater, has been unpredictable. Peter Martins's superb ''Fearful Symmetries,'' a cannon shot of propulsive energy to a post-minimalist score by John Adams, will apparently not be the only premiere during the engagement. Lincoln Kirstein, the company's co-founder with George Balanchine and now its general director emeritus, has commissioned a Mass from Michael Torke, the young composer with whom Mr. Martins has previously worked. This music, ''Missa Sicca,'' is reportedly to be staged as a movement piece (not a classical ballet) by Mr. Martins on Tuesday and Sunday.

title: HAS THE CLOCK RUN OUT FOR EARLY MUSIC?
description: In the late 1940's, the coincident arrival of two technological advances, high-fidelity sound and the LP record, created a synergetic wave that engulfed every aspect of music. It changed how, why and when we listen to music. The flood of recorded works, new and old, forced millions of listeners to realize that musical history did not begin with Bach and end with Brahms. Older music had been pursued by a few connoisseurs for centuries before this confluence of 20th-century technologies - Baron von Swieten introducing Mozart to the contrapuntal wonders of Bach and Handel is a familiar example. But early music as a popular cause is only about 40 years old, which apparently is not too soon to experience a midlife crisis.

title: Anne W. Gudaitis Is Wed
description: At the Wellesley (Mass.) College Chapel, Anne Wentworth Gudaitis, an administrative assistant to the associate provost at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, was married yesterday to Robert Roy Evans, an artist. The Rev. George Chapman, an Episcopalian, officiated. The bride, 34 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Gudaitis of Ocean City, N.J. She graduated from Western Kentucky University. Mr. Evans, 32, is a son of Robert Reese Evans of Cambridge and Alison Ridley Garfield of Sudbury, Mass. He is a summa cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College.

title: Visiting Au Pairs Shine East-West Relations
description: LEAD: AFTER his first day in the United States, Simon Kravanja said the greatest difference he had noticed between life here and at home in Yugoslavia was in how kitchens are set up. ''So far, everything else looks not so different,'' said the 23-year-old Mr. Kravanja, who is spending the summer working as a family companion and caring for 8-year-old Morgan Patterson, of

title: Staying on the Safe Side; Paris
description: Along with all the other superlatives that it proudly attaches to its name, Paris can probably claim to be one of the safest capitals in the world today. In how many major cities, after all, can an unaccompanied woman take the subway at midnight without being considered foolhardy?

title: What's Doing In;   San Francisco
description: While there was an automatic assumption that he would, of course, love it, most people in San Francisco never guessed that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would emerge as the city's biggest booster. But on his visit earlier this month, the Soviet president declared that if he were President George Bush, he would charge a tax for the privilege of living here.

title: A New Effort For Holocaust Memorial
description: A PLAN has begun to take shape for building a memorial here to the victims of the Holocaust, to ''document the past as a commitment to their memory,'' as Stefan Weinburg, a concentration camp survivor put it.

title: Storage Tank Rules Aim to Retain Water Purity
description: LEAD: WHEN more than 500 business executives and state and local government officials recently attended a conference in Woodbury to gather advice on meeting strict regulations for underground storage tanks, the large turnout underscored the widening impact of environmental measures designed to protect Long Island's groundwater.

title: U.S. Sued in Death of a Journalist in Panama
description: In a case that is beginning to strain relations between Washington and Madrid, the family of a Spanish photographer killed during the United States invasion of Panama last December has filed an administrative claim for wrongful death and damages from the United States Government.

title: Cheryl Nassberg Wed To Jeffrey L. Haiken
description: Cheryl M. Nassberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Nassberg of Dix Hills, L.I., was married yesterday evening in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to Jeffrey L. Haiken, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Haiken of North Bellmore, L.I. Rabbi Morris Shapiro and Cantor David Hiesiger officated at the Cold Spring Country Club.

title: Two Old Stars, One Obsession
description: IN what is part soap opera, part epic and very much a dual quest for a specialized silver grail, Martina Navratilova and Ivan Lendl both seem to be wearing their hearts on their sleeves as they take on Wimbledon for what they hope will be a full two-week engagement.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Trenchcoats, Then and Now
description: On Christmas Day in 1933, Joseph Stalin conferred this orchid on his favorite Western journalist:

title: Yankees' Streak Ends at 4
description: If he could have picked a moment for his troubles to end suddenly and finally, this would surely have been it: ninth inning, bases loaded, the Yankees down by four runs, the crowd on its feet.

title: INTRODUCTION
description: Turn on a television set in Tel Aviv or Mexico City or about anywhere else in the world and one would instantly recognize the nightly news. These newscasts, as much or more of a fixture abroad as they are in this country, generally assume the same form and habits. In many countries there is one broadcast in the early evening, usually a half-hour to an hour long, and another program later. Studio sets may not be the sleek extravaganzas they often are here, but the electronic paraphernalia is roughly equivalent. While reporting flows from camcorder-toting teams in the field, news programs are dominated by anchors who are frequently revered personalities if not the celebrities they sometimes are in this country.

title: Three Infants Dead After Hospital Gives Them Wrong Drugs
description: Three critically ill infants died last week after they were given the wrong intravenous solution at a hospital, which announced the deaths today and said it had discharged two pharmacy workers.

title: Blood Service Prepares for Summer
description: LEAD: SUMMER is here - and the blood supply will be dwindling. June, July and August are traditionally months in which shortages occur, said Dr. David Ciavarella, director of the Hudson Valley Blood Services, which collects blood and distributes it to hospitals in the area.

title: Letter Carriers Name National Hero of the Year
description: LEAD: JAMES KINNEY, a letter carrier, was walking his route on Charles Street and Union Avenue in New Rochelle when he heard glass shattering. At first, he thought someone was breaking into a nearby six-family house. But then he realized that the windows had broken from heat, and flames were shooting through them, toward the roof.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Singular Home, In Pink and Orange
description: LEAD: THE suburban nursing home rests on a cul-de-sac tucked quietly behind a residential neighborhood. From the grounds, if you listen carefully you can hear the rhythmic clatter of an approaching Long Island Rail Road train.

title: Cecilia Capuzzi Marries
description: Cecilia M. Capuzzi, a freelance writer, and James F. Simon Jr., a senior lawyer in the New York office of the Natural Resources Defense Council, were married yesterday in Philadelphia at the Sugar Loaf estate. Richard Kiniry, the leader of the Philadelphia Ethical Culture Society, officiated. The bride, 33 years old, is the daughter of Rachel Capuzzi of Upper Darby, Pa., and the late Edmund C. Capuzzi. She graduated from Pennsylvania State University and received a master's in journalism from Temple University. Mr. Simon, 33, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon of Stamford, Conn. He is a graduate of Yale University and the Harvard University Law School.

title:
WHEN IT WAS DANGEROUS TO TALK;

THE LATE WARSAW PACT
description: LEAD:

title: Staying on the Safe Side: Hong Kong
description: LEAD: In this British colony where 98 percent of the 5.7 million residents are ethnic Chinese, the crime rate is relatively low, and most violent crimes involve Chinese against Chinese. For foreign visitors, this is an unusually safe territory, a place where tourists can wear gold chains, diamond rings and expensive watches without fear and take the subway or ferry even late at night.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 27 about the Eisenhower Museum in Abilene, Kan., misidentified an artillery piece. It was a 57-millimeter antitank gun, not a 50-millimeter howitzer. An article last Sunday about the Maine coast misstated the dates of the Maine Lobster Festival in Rockland. It will be held from Aug. 3 to 5, not in July.

title: Thomas Edison's Florida
description: THE most important day in Fort Myers history, many believe, was March 6, 1885, when Thomas Alva Edison landed in what was then a sleepy tropical village on Florida's west coast. Edison, then 38 years old and widely known for his invention of the incandescent lamp and the phonograph, came for rest and sunshine and to shake off a lingering illness. His health recovered, he purchased a small house and 14 acres on the banks of the Caloosahatchee River. The following year, he was joined by his bride, Minnie Miller Edison, and then by such famous guests as Henry Ford and Harvey Firestone thrusting the quiet settlement into the headlines and launching the tourist industry that has transformed it into a thriving city.

title: Joseph Murumbi, Kenyan Politician, 79
description: Joseph Murumbi, who served briefly as Kenya's second Vice President in 1966, died on Friday after a long illness, Kenyan newspapers reported. He was 79 years old. Mr. Murumbi, who had been confined to a wheelchair since damaging a nerve in a fall eight years ago, died at his home, the papers said. The cause of death was not announced. Mr. Murumbi was Vice President under this former British colony's first President, Jomo Kenyatta, from March 1966 until November of that year, when he quit politics, citing health. Mr. Murumbi was succeeded by Daniel arap Moi, who became President on Mr. Kenyatta's death in 1978.

title: The Region;   As Token Lines Lengthen, Fare-Beating Rises
description: FARE-BEATING has become so serious in New York City's subways that the Transit Authority expects a $55 million deficit this year, mainly because of the record number of people who are riding without paying.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 24, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On WWeek List Fiction 1 5 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) The tensions and bonds shared by Chinese- American women and their immigrant mothers. 2 4 CREATURE, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.95.) A siege of horror besets a high school football team. 3 4 WARRIOR'S WOMAN, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.95.) The adventures of a woman determined to rescue her native planet. 4 3 A KNIGHT IN SHINING ARMOR, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.95.) A 20th-century American woman finds true love through an encounter with a 16th-century English nobleman. 5 4 DAY OF THE CHEETAH, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $5.50.) America's most advanced weapon falls into the hands of a K.G.B. mole. 6 1 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $5.95.) Espionage changes its ways as glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 7 8 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A schoolboy turns into a prophet with a message for our times. 8 9 THE SERVANTS OF TWILIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.50.) The ordeal of a woman whose young son is declared the Antichrist. 9 4 MIRROR IMAGE, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $4.95.) An airplane accident and plastic surgery give a woman an astonishing new life. 10 62 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) Three generations of a family. 11 3 SINS OF THE FLESH, by Fern Michaels. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The tangled lives of two men and two women, from the French Resistance to Hollywood, in the 1940's. 12 1 GARDEN OF LIES, by Eileen Goudge. (Signet/ NAL, $5.95.) Two women - one born to wealth, one to poverty - whose destinies are forever linked by a mother's reckless act. 13 3 DOCTOR'S ORDERS, by Diane Duane. (Pocket, $4.50.) Dr. McCoy commands the Enterprise on a ''Star Trek'' mission. 14 2 THE BLUE BEDROOM, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $3.95.) The author's first collection of short stories. 15 * 7 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Pocket, $5.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through 5,000 centuries. Weeks This On WWeek List Nonfiction 1 31 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 5 A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE, by C. David Heymann. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) A biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. 3 3 WHEN RABBIT HOWLS, by Truddi Chase. (Jove, $4.95.) A woman voices the 92 personalities that live within her. 4 3 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen Hawking. (Bantam, $9.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 5 348 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 6 7 LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Bantam, $4.95.) Observations on the elations and frustrations of romantic relationships. 7 11 SUMMER OF '49, by David Halberstam. (Avon, $4.95.) The year the Red Sox and the Yankees battled to the last game for the pennant. 8 * 3 WHY ME? by Sammy Davis Jr. and Jane and Burt Boyar. (Warner, $5.95.) The autobiography of the late entertainer. 9 * 4 REASONABLE DOUBT, by Steve Vogel. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The case of a respectable Bloomington, Ill., businessman suspected of killing his wife and three children. 10 7 FROM CRADLE TO GRAVE, by Joyce Egginton. (Jove, $4.95.) The case of a Schenectady, N.Y., woman whose nine children all died mysteriously over 14 years. Ways to combat environmental problems. 2 14 WEIRDOS FROM ANOTHER PLANET! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 3 94 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 18 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $7.95.) The 1990 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 7 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) Ways to reduce fat in one's diet.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Deep in Brooklyn, a Slave Plantation Illustrates How Both Sides Lived
description: Surviving more than 200 years in Brooklyn has given the Lefferts Homestead a timeless quality. Its hedges have outlived generations of gardeners, and the slender columns, wide porch and detailed dormer windows of this historic Dutch colonial farmhouse in Prospect Park still retain an aura of plantation life. Built between 1777 and 1783, the Lefferts Homestead is now open to the public, offering a glimpse of life when it was owned by the largest slaveholding family in Kings County. The current main exhibit, ''Black Roots on a Brooklyn Farm,'' explores African-American history in the post-Colonial era.

title: INVENTING INNOCENCE
description: GONE PRIMITIVE

title: Guatemala President Stars in Political Drama
description: This country's most avidly watched drama features a dashing executive, a coterie of young women and a cabal of high-living friends whose reputations make J. R. Ewing look like a choirboy.

title: Michele A. Brown Wed to Steven L. Sweetwood
description: Michele Ashley Brown, a senior at Brandeis University, and Steven Louis Sweetwood, a financial investment consultant at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York, were married at the Pierre last evening by Rabbi Judah Nadish. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lewis Brown of Norwood, N.J., and Madeline M. Redstone of Concord, Mass., and the late Ira I. Sweetwood.

title: Mary J. Hoene Is Married To Nathaniel M. Floyd Jr.
description: Mary J. Hoene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David D. Hoene of Boise, Idaho, was married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York to Dr. Nathaniel M. Floyd Jr., a son of Dorothy H. Floyd of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Mr. Floyd. The Rev. Seymour J. Flinn officiated. Mrs. Floyd, who is 40 years old, graduated from Seattle University and earned a law degree at the University of Notre Dame. She is the general counsel at Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management and Paine Webber Mutual Funds in New York. Her two previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: Wendy Goldberg Marries Derek Pew
description: Wendy Lynn Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Goldberg of Westfield, N.J., was married last evening to Derek Nicholas Pew, a son of Richard Glenn Pew of San Diego and Lydia Geacintov of Springfield, N.J. The Rev. Brenda Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Ms. Esmay Weds Macauley Taylor
description: Kimberly Jean Esmay, a daughter of Dr. Richard F. Esmay of Troy, N.Y., and Mrs. Esmay of Guilderland, N.Y., was married yesterday to Macauley Robert Taylor, a son of June Irmiger Taylor of Chicago and Macauley Worth Taylor of Washington, Conn. The Rev. George A. Phillips officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Albany.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NORWICH;

'Rose of New England' Dreams Of Economic Bloom
description: LEAD: IN the mid-19th century, the scholar and abolitionist Henry Ward Beecher compared the five hills of Norwich with rose petals. The city still calls itself ''the Rose of New England,'' and the flower appears on everything from street markers to police cars, although Norwich's bloom has faded - and has been restored - a few times since

title: A School of Today, With Yesterday in Mind
description: Tanglewood opens Friday, and for nine weeks concertgoers will stream in with picnic hampers to relax to the strains of the classics played by - and under - the stars. Across the lawn, students at the Tanglewood Music Center will learn a Grail-like dedication to their art. While the past is always present at the Boston Symphony Orchestra's big weekend concerts, the music of today is central to the school. But in celebrating the new, the music center practices a conservatism that parallels the orchestra's.

title: FROM RUSSIA, 300 YEARS OF GLASS
description: The dazzling and colorful exhibition of 300 years of Russian glass at the Corning Museum of Glass - the first such comprehensive presentation held in the West - was conceived in Moscow on Christmas Eve in 1980. What was not foreseen at that meeting - between Nina Asharina, now vice director of the State History Museum in Moscow, and Dwight P. Lanmon, now Corning's director - was how long the show would be delayed by the political climate that separated the Soviet Union and the United States following the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. ''About five years ago, we thought, maybe now the time is right for the show,'' Mr. Lanmon recalled. The Soviet Ministry of Culture agreed and requested that an exhibition of American glass be organized to travel in the Soviet Union while the Russian glass was on display at the Corning Museum.

title: Jamie Wade Wed To Nyr Indictor
description: Rebecca French Wade, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeptha H. Wade of Bedford, Mass., was married yesterday to Nyr Indictor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Indictor of New York, at the bride's parents' home. Judge Rudolph Kass, an associate justice of the Massachusetts Court of Appeals, officiated.

title: Mei Chu Is Married
description: Mei F. Chu and Christopher R. Morin were married yesterday at the Fay Club in Fitchburg, Mass., by Michael K. Bolock, a justice of the peace. Mrs. Morin, 26 years old, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wai Chu of New York, is a Bryn Mawr College graduate with an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago. Mr. Morin, 26, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Orin of Leominster, Mass., has B.A. and M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University.

title: No Easy Path Over This Grass
description: Like so much pretty patchwork, the lawns at Wimbledon, as well groomed as the royalty that gathers yearly at Centre Court to anoint new champions, await an onslaught of tennis players intent on capturing the most prestigious of the Grand Slam tournaments.

title: Bodies of Two Crew Members Lost in Navy Crash Are Found
description: Searchers today found the bodies of two of the four crew members lost when their helicopter crashed off the Virginia coast.

title: Church Lawyers Say Stolen Art Was Moved
description: Lawyers of the Church of Quedlinburg have charged in Federal District Court that minutes before a judge ordered that stolen church artworks not be moved, there was suspicious activity at the bank vault where they are stored.

title: Staying on the Safe Side
description: An American woman was enjoying a midday walk on a quiet side street in Florence when a motorcycle roared by, slowing just long enough for the motorcyclist to grab the woman's leather shoulder bag. She clung to the strap, but it broke and the motorcyclist sped off with her passport, her traveler's checks, wallet and camera.

title: Wedding Plans For Kyoko Ono
description: Mr. and Mrs. Tokuyuki Ono of Tokyo have announced the engagement of their daughter Kyoko Ono to Peter Stenwall Kirby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kirby of Forest Hills, Queens. Miss Ono, 27 years old, graduated from Amherst College. She is an account executive at Backer Spielvogel Bates Japan, the Tokyo subsidiary of a New York advertising agency. Her father is the former senior managing director of Sumitomo Bank's New York branch. Her mother, Akiko Ono, is the founder and director of the U.S.-Japan Music Exchange Association.

title: When the Business of a Family Is Business
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: AUTHENTIC RAGTIME

title: Postings: Razing Times Square;   The First Casualties
description: Almost always in New York, before you can build up you have to tear down, and that is what is happening with the long-delayed Times Square redevelopment project. In preparation for demolition, tenants are now being cleared out of properties along the east side of Broadway between 43d and 42d Streets, where the first and tallest of four new office towers will be erected in about three years.

title: Business Diary: June 17-22
description: THE ECONOMY

title: SHE KNEW HOW TO WHISTLE
description: SLIM

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE MIANUS RIVER GORGE WILDLIFE REFUGE;

Soviet Guests Take Notes on Conservation
description: LEAD: THE sky cleared just in time for the environmental specialists from the Soviet Union. The rain had been pouring in dismal gray sheets at the Mianus River Gorge Wildlife Refuge and Botanical Preserve, but, as if on cue, when the visiting Soviets arrived, the clouds parted, revealing patches of blue, and golden sunlight suddenly bathed the green leaves.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Oakwood
description: A stroll down tree-lined Oak Avenue is all a visitor needs to see how Oakwood got its name. But some residents say the name could also apply to the town's solid family life; three and four generations of some families live on the same streets. The Oakwood Girls, a group of 20 women who grew up in the Staten Island community and have known each other for more than 50 years, meet monthly.

title: Hungary: Loosening Up On a Longer Leash
description: Hungarian television news, which even before the democratic reforms was on a longer leash than most Communist broadcasts, has loosened up considerably in the last year as the Communist Party went into retreat.

title: ALABAMA BOUND
description: Howell Raines is to be congratulated for a thoughtful article on the backward state of affairs in Alabama. If anything, the article understated the extent of the problem.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Do The Pistons Rank in N.B.A. History?
description: The Pistons' three guards are possibly the greatest rotation in history. Thomas, Dumars, and Johnson can all score, defend, and control a game. Rodman and Laimbeer are strong rebounders. But the lack of one great scorer or rebounder among the league leaders is one reason why the Pistons have not been fully recognized for their ability. The other main reason is, of course, their distance from a major media market. The Bad Boys' image has obscured the Bad Boys' accomplishments.

title: Streetscapes: The Leake & Watts Orphan Asylum;   A Castoff in the Path of a Growing, Great Cathedral
description: As masons lay course after course of stone for the south tower of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for the first time in decades, it seems that this huge structure may actually, someday, be completed.

title: Kathryn Wood Becomes Bride
description: Kathryn Patricia Mai Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Douglas Wood of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to George Vaz-Ferreira, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Raul Vaz-Ferreira of Montevideo, Uruguay. The Rev. Edward J. Howley officiated at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Rapid-Fire Real-Estate Auction Enters Manhattan
description: The real-estate auctioneer's gavel finally fell on Manhattan yesterday as $17 million worth of prime condominiums in the heart of midtown went on the trading block.

title: Carol E. Sawyer Is a Bride
description: At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Chocorua, N.H., Carol E. Sawyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Sawyer Jr. of Worcester, Mass., was married yesterday to Alexander G. Grant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Grant of Dedham, Mass., by the Rev. George Majka. Mrs. Grant, 28 years old, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and has a master's in education from Harvard University. Mr. Grant, 32, a cum laude graduate of Middlebury College, has an M.B.A. from Dartmouth College and is a vice president of Salomon Brothers in Boston.

title: Big Science, Little Gain
description: The space station will cost $40 billion to build and $80 billion to operate. The bill for the supercollider has climbed to $8 billion. The human genome project will cost $3 billion. These enormous projects are justified in the name of science, yet many scientists have serious doubts about their merit. At a time when the United States is fast losing its technological edge to Japan, why is Washington so intent on funneling the nation's critical technical resources into dubious extravaganzas?

title: Elizabeth Harwood, A British Soprano, 52
description: Elizabeth Harwood, one of Britain's best-known sopranos in the 1960's and 1970's, died of cancer on Friday, her family said. She was 52 years old. Miss Harwood, who died at her home in Fryerning, 20 miles northeast of London, specialized in lyric and coloratura roles and in the music of Mozart.

title: PROTECTING THE WORLD'S 'SPECIAL PLACES'
description: SUSAN MERROW, of Colchester, was recently elected president of the Sierra Club, one of the nation's oldest and largest environmental groups. Founded by John Muir in 1898, the club has grown to 560,000 members from 182,000 in 1981.

title: Debra J. Lee Weds Dean W. Fichtner
description: Debra Jeanne Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Lee of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dean Walker Fichtner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Wales Fichtner of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Merton Rymph officiated at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: Laws Quiet the Ice-Cream Bells of Summer
description: Jonathan Zahm had just handed a couple of Disney Pops through the window of his ice-cream truck when he spied the police car at the curb and thought to himself, ''Here comes trouble.''

title: World Markets;   Where to Gain From the Dollar's Loss
description: While the dollar has been relatively tame this year, it has still raised the returns of some Americans who invested away from Wall Street.

title: Art, Love and a Refrigerator Door
description: IF it's a visceral, confrontational, obscure play you're after, the Penguin Rep would be a likely place to find it. And even though John Patrick Shanley has hit the big time as a screenwriter with ''Moonstruck,'' most of his plays - and screenplays - are little known and less noticed.

title: Shared Space;   Germany Again Forces a Redefining of Europe
description: FIFTY years ago this summer, Germany had traumatized Europe for the second time in this tragic century: Austria had been annexed; Poland, France, Holland, Norway and Belgium had been defeated, Czechoslovakia and Denmark were occupied, and British troops had been driven into the sea from Dunkirk. The Battle of Britain in the skies over London lay ahead, as did the subsequent decision to turn instead on the Soviet Union. In the 12 short years of the Thousand-year Reich, Hitler, Himmler, Goebbels and Goering destroyed their country's good name and nearly destroyed the European civilization that had been marked indelibly by Germans like Bach, Beethoven, Goethe, Kant and Leibniz.

title: Two Children Are Wounded By Stray Shots in Flatbush
description: Two girls walking in front of a Brooklyn variety store were wounded last night, one critically, as they were hit by stray shots fired in an argument, the police said.

title: PASTIMES: BRIDGE
description: For tournament players and the American Contract Bridge League, which provides for their needs, the 1990's began much better than the 1980's ended. Last year saw the climax of a dispute about gender-based events and a national championship in Lancaster, Pa. that spawned complaints. This year began with successful Spring Nationals in Fort Worth a month ago.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Marketing Concepts at $1 Million-Plus
description: LEAD: Two projects for the affluent that are under way on Hegemans Lane in Old Brookville are taking very different approaches to marketing developments where houses will cost $1 million or more.

title: N.B.A. Must Pick Up the Pace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Deregulation Is Nothing but a License to Steal;   The View From the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Managing;   Soliciting the Foreign Perspective
description: A couple of weeks ago, Tenneco Inc.'s directors flew to Europe. First they held their regular board meeting. Then they held a meeting of an entirely different sort: They brainstormed about economics, about markets, about products, about all kinds of things with the chief executive of Switzerland's F. Hoffman-La Roche & Company, the chairman of West Germany's Ruhrgas AG, and a half-dozen other distinguished European businessmen who sit on Tenneco's European Advisory Council.

title: The Civil Rights Act: White Men's Hope
description: President Bush and Congress have overlooked an important reason why they should immediately enact the Civil Rights Act of 1990: to help white men overcome their feelings of inferiority.

title: Books of The Times;   Recounting a Battle Against Death's Harbingers
description: Wrestling With the Angel

title: Peter A. Binney Weds Miss Jacobs
description: Nehama Jacobs, a duaghter of Sidney J. Jacobs of Culver City, Calif., and the late Helen Jacobs Goosey of Dalton, Pa., was married Friday to Peter Appleton Binney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Binney of Brookline, mass. The cremony was performed at the Harvard Club in New York by Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appelate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: Criminal Type Beats Sunday Silence
description: Sustaining a stretchlong drive to beat Sunday Silence by a head, Criminal Type won the $1 million Hollywood Gold Cup today at Hollywood Park, gaining his third upset victory in a row.

title: Elizabeth F. Otey, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Elizabeth Frances Otey, a daughter of Sara-Marie Otey and Charles Otey, both of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Vicente Ernesto Garces, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Garces of Los Angeles, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The ceremony was performed by Judge Gerard Rosenberg of the Brooklyn Civil Court.

title: Savings Unit Sold in Texas
description: Lewis Ranieri, the New York investor, has broadened his holdings in the Texas savings industry by acquiring the deposits and a portion of the assets of the insolvent Metropolitan Financial Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: Miss Bernstein Becomes Bride
description: Constance P. Bernstein, the daughter of Cecile F. Bernstein of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Dr. Robert S. Bachner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bachner of Delray Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Howard Graber and Solomon Gordon.

title: New Duo Opens for Greg Osby
description: Greg Osby, an alto saxophonist, and his quintet, Sound Theater, played a strangely bifurcated set on Saturday afternoon at the Equitable Auditorium as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. About half of the compositions were attempts at pop-jazz - breezy, midtempo funk vamps akin to the music of Kenny G. or Najee, but without their smooth inevitability. In those tunes, Mr. Osby played breakneck solos that invoked dissonant harmonies and fought the easygoing rhythms, for results that sounded clumsy and wrongheaded; pop-jazz resists such striving. Junko Onishi on piano and Chan Johnson on guitar, who followed the flow, were more effective soloists, as Gary Foote on bass and Rod Gross on drums cruised along.

title: Face to Face With a Split
description: As Canada assessed the collapse of the Meech Lake accord, its leaders' attempts to soothe anxieties ran into an accumulation of concerns today: Have the strains with Quebec finally gone too far? Has Canada moved beyond the point of no return? And has Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's leadership been destroyed?

title: Question Box
description: Yank Home Homers

title: Dr. Bonnie Bermas Marries
description: Dr. Bonnie L. Bermas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mitchell Bermas of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Capt. Mark S. Link, U.S.A.F., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Link of Sioux Falls, S.D. The interfaith ceremony was performed by Rev. Theodore G. Hoskins, a United Church of Christ minister, at the Birchwood Country Club in Westport, Conn. The bride, who is keeping her name, graduated from Princeton University and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. She is a fellow in rheumatology at Brigham and Women's Hospitalin Boston, and she and her husband completed internal medicine residencies at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. Captain Link, a graduate of Dordt College, received an M.D. from Tufts University and is stationed in Adana, Turkey.

title: Closing Statements Set in Marcos Theft Trial
description: Closing statements are to begin today in the Federal racketeering trial of Imelda Marcos, with the jury expected to get the case by Thursday.

title: Let's Not Add to East European Pollution;   Unsavory Exclusion
description: To the Editor:

title: A. J. Montgomery, 77, Retired Army General
description: Austin J. Montgomery, a retired brigadier general who commanded Army cargo traffic and terminals in the Atlantic in the 1960's, died on Wednesday at the Hospice of Northern Virginia in Arlington. He was 77 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va. His death resulted from lung cancer, family members said.

title:
The Korean War, 40 Years Later;

But at What Cost?
description: LEAD: Forty years ago today, the army of Communist North Korea invaded the Republic of Korea, whose independence had been guaranteed by the United States and the United Nations. In the predawn flash of North Korean artillery along the 38th Parallel dividing the two regimes, no one in the world grasped the consequences of this aggression - in particular, how it was laying the foundation of future U.S.

title: Metro Matters;   15 'Mega-Cities' Joining to Learn From Each Other
description: If you can make it here, the song says, you can make it anywhere.

title: In Canada, An Appeal For Calm
description: As anxiety spread among Canadians about a possible push for independence by Quebec, Finance Minister Michael H. Wilson of Canada today appealed to investors in the United States and elsewhere to recognize the ''basic strength'' of the country's economy and not to overreact to the political concerns of the moment.

title: Let's Not Add to East European Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: New Bianchi Pact Helps Knicks a Bit
description: As the Knicks prepare for Wednesday night's draft, it seems as if everybody else has an idea about how to make the team better.

title: Jazz Festival;   Steve Reich And World Saxophone Quartet
description: Saturday night's show at Carnegie Hall, part of the JVC Jazz Festival and featuring the World Saxophone Quartet and Steve Reich's ensemble, operated on the premise that enough open-minded people exist in New York to bring together two vanguard acts from the Afro-American and Euro-American traditions to justify renting the hall. This premise was partly right: Carnegie Hall seemed three-quarters full, and the show was competing against a hard bill at Town Hall featuring the bassist Milt Hinton. But it didn't stop people from leaving during Mr. Reich's overlong closing number.

title: Militant Muslims Grow Stronger As Algeria's Economy Weakens
description: Shifting his feet nervously, Nasreddin stands in a busy alley, scanning the crowd for a plainclothes policeman who might arrest him or a customer who might buy the decrepit portable cassette player that he is peddling.

title: Metro Datelines;   Man Is Shot to Death On Subway Platform
description: A 28-year-old man was shot twice in the back of the head and killed yesterday as he stood on a subway platform in the Bronx, the police said.

title: N.B.A. Draft Aspirants Look Back
description: Once they gathered with other youngsters to watch the older ones play. On neighborhood playgrounds, in recreation centers and in schoolyards, they watched in awe. But now they themselves have become the dazzlers.

title: Review/Music;   From Pianos Tiny to Tinier, Noise From Loud to Louder
description: The composer and conceptual artist Wendy Chambers tends to think big, filling the great spaces of Manhattan with arresting sounds and images. In the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, she has mustered 100 timpani as part of a much larger ensemble, and on another occasion 30 harps. She has massed 10 pianos on the Lincoln Center Plaza. She has deployed large groups of performers on the World Trade Center Plaza and, with the help of rowboats, in and around the Central Park lake.

title: His Widow Reveals Much Of Who B. Traven Really Was
description: Who was the man who wrote under the pseudonym B. Traven? One of the most intriguing literary mysteries of the century may at last have been solved, and a new puzzle opened, because of the willingness of the widow of the secretive author of ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'' finally to reveal what her husband had told her of his past.

title: World Follows Bishops on a Retreat
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops gathered in this city founded by Christian missionaries for a few days of spiritual reflection, prayer and recreation. But the real world kept intruding.

title: An Eagle Shows Some Panache
description: THERE are a couple of points of view about those feathered, furry, or otherwise costumed characters who cavort on the sidelines of sports events.

title: Vento Trial Jury Expected to Get The Case Today
description: For the jury that is to begin deliberation today in the trial of John S. Vento, one of eight youths charged in the Bensonhurst racial attack that left 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins dead, the case is likely to pivot on the legal concept of acting in concert.

title: Miss Brown Weds Robert L. Garner
description: Tracy Ann Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Brown of East Amherst, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Garner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney N. Garner of Monmouth Beach, N.J. Justice Leo J. Fallon of State Supreme Court in Buffalo officiated at the Country Club of Buffalo in Williamsville, N.Y.

title: Excalibur Halts Production
description: The Excalibur Automobile Corporation, manufacturer of neoclassic automobiles, suspended production last week after being rocked by layoffs, lawsuits, bounced paychecks and allegations of mileage tampering.

title: G.M. Chief Defends Record As His Retirement Nears
description: Should Roger B. Smith be blamed for the General Motors Corporation's woes of the 1980's or should he be praised for a strategic vision?

title: Metro Datelines;   Jumper Talked Down From Raritan Bridge
description: A man threatened to jump off the Driscoll Bridge over the Raritan River on the Garden State Parkway in Woodbridge last night as hundreds of commuters tried to return from weekends at the New Jersey Shore. The State Police shut down the northbound lanes of the parkway, backing up traffic for nine miles, a parkway official said.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Washington, About to Receive Mandela, Is Worried About de Klerk
description: When Nelson Mandela meets with President Bush and other officials on Monday, he will receive a warm welcome but polite resistance to his call for maintaining or increasing sanctions against South Africa, officials say.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 25, 1990:

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Friday of major 20th-century earthquakes carried an outdated magnitude figure for the California earthquake last October. Originally placed at 6.9 on the Richter scale, it was later revised to 7.1.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Mandela Assails U.S. Aid to Savimbi
description: On the eve of his meeting with President Bush, Nelson Mandela condemned one of the President's African policies, support for Jonas Savimbi's rightist rebels in Angola.

title: Man Who Headed Crock-Pot Concern Is Beaten to Death
description: I. H. (Hack) Miller, who brought the name crock pot to millions of households, was killed in his home Friday, and a grandson was charged in the slaying, the police in Kansas City, Mo., reported yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Arthur J. Crockett; Editor, 69
description: Arthur J. Crockett, a writer and crime magazine editor, died on Friday at Jamaica Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: What Secrets?
description: EAST GERMANY'S decision to hold what amounts to a clearance sale of the secret technology behind the nation's stunning athletic achievements has American Olympic officials rubbing their hands and reaching for their checkbooks.

title: And Maradona Was Waiting
description: HE wore the fabled yellow jersey of Brazil like a trophy from a primitive war. He waved it at the stands as if brandishing the pelt of a vanquished enemy.

title: Aggressive Discounting Pays Off for Crown Books
description: Crown Books' policy of discounting every book has long made the retailer a burr under the saddle of its rivals. But the book chain especially aggravated them recently when it announced a 40 percent discount on hardcover best sellers.

title: Elizabeth Ann Steyer Is Married to Fred Graver
description: Elizabeth Ann Steyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Steyer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married at the Pierre yesterday to Fred Graver, the son of Jeanne Graver of Chicago, and the late Fred Graver. Rabbi Richard Chapin officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the savings and loan failures misstated the political setting in which Congress increased deposit insurance for each account to $100,000, from $40,000. The change was made in 1980, when both houses of Congress were controlled by Democrats, not just the House of Representatives.

title: Smith Feeling Cardinals' Burdens
description: OZZIE SMITH sat at his locker stall hours before one of the Cardinals' games against the Mets last week. Neatly dressed in his uniform, Smith, entertained one inquisitor after another, impeccable in his manner as well as appearance.

title: Loggers Protest Owl Decision
description: Hundreds of logging trucks adorned with yellow ribbons rolled through the heart of Oregon's timber country Saturday, honking horns to protest limits on Federal logging aimed at protecting endangered owls. Joe Trimble of Roseburg, who joined a line of 434 rigs, said, ''For a lot of us, this might be our last show.'' Federal wildlife officials gave the northern spotted owl the status of threatened species Friday, saying that logging is destroying the birds' habitats in the ancient forests of Oregon, Washington and Northern California.

title: 2 More Earthquakes Rock Iran; Rescue Efforts Stall as Toll Rises
description: Two more large earthquakes struck Iran today even as rescue workers continued combing through the rubble left by last week's violent temblor along the Caspian Sea.

title: The Korean War, 40 Years Later;   The Right Decision
description: Today marks the 40th anniversary of Kim Il Sung's attack on South Korea, after which the cold war turned hot for Americans.

title: Business and the Law;   Bankruptcy Work Is Getting Respect
description: FOR decades, the largest and most established law firms in the nation avoided bankruptcy work because it was disdained by highbrow partners as lower than divorce and criminal law and too distasteful for their practices. That attitude has changed.

title: Irwin Is Planning To Take a Break
description: There will be no more euphoria for Hale Irwin until at least the British Open, in four weeks. After two victories six days apart, including the United States Open, Irwin said today that golf would be secondary to ''more pressing interests.''

title: Inventory in Texas Case Turns Up New Works
description: A court-ordered inventory of the contents of safe deposit boxes belonging to the heirs of an Army officer who is believed to have stolen artworks from Quedlinburg, Germany, has turned up other art objects apparently taken from France and Germany during the final months of World War II.

title: The Emerging Subway-Fare Thief: Frustrated, Irritated or in a Hurry
description: As Elizabeth C. Thomas, a 39-year-old investment banker, entered the IRT subway station at 96th and Lexington on her way to work last week, she discovered that all the turnstiles were broken and that a No. 6 train was pulling into the station.

title: Lawyer Told Senator Payments Were Risky
description: Documents from a Senate hearing indicate Senator Dave Durenberger was cautioned by his lawyer in 1986 about accepting Government reimbursement for stays in a Minneapolis condominium, despite his contention this month that he had no reason to doubt the propriety of the plan.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

The Ultramarathon Can Be Ultrapainful
description: LEAD: BILL FINKBEINER vividly remembers his running infancy. After struggling through eight-mile jogs, his feelings of accomplishment were often overshadowed by another strong sensation: pain.

title: Flag Vote: The Effects Back Home
description: On the floor of Congress two days earlier, Representative Peter Hoagland had voted against an amendment to the Constitution that would outlaw burning the American flag.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Airbus Curb in India
description: Indian Airlines cannot lease out the A320 airbuses it grounded after a crash in February or sell other planes scheduled for delivery without the manufacturer's consent, an Airbus Industrie spokesman said last week. The spokesman, Robert Alizart, said that under a clause in any Airbus sale contract buyers could not reassign an aircraft still under warranty, like the 14 that have been grounded and the 4 on order, without Airbus's approval.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of my children died, and my wife and brothers and their children. I saw how the earth was trembling, like nature kicking the cradle. I saw the mountain slide toward the village and said, 'Allah akbar! I am ready to die.' But I lived, and all the younger ones were taken from me, all because of this rock.''

title: For Some, No Escape From L.I. Jet Crash
description: As life goes on for the 85 survivors of Avianca Airlines Flight 52, the return to normalcy comes in fits and starts. One passenger has carried her pregnancy to full term since the flight crashed on Long Island five months ago. And another, a 14-month-old girl, struggled to her feet recently to walk for the first time.

title: SOUTHWEST TO GET ECONOMIC BENEFITS IN SAVINGS BAILOUT
description: The Federal cleanup of the savings and loan disaster will result in a significant transfer of wealth from the Northeast and Middle West to Texas and other states in the Southwest, many economists and politicians have concluded.

title: After Stray Bullets Hit 2 Girls, Police Find Few Willing to Talk About It
description: ''Anybody here yesterday? Anybody see anything? A little 10-year-old girl was shot and killed here and we need some help.''

title: Outdoors: Surf Fishing Gear Needn't Be Complex
description: ALTHOUGH the incredible variety of tackle used by surf fishermen might well confuse a would-be participant in the sport, choosing a basic outfit needn't be too complicated.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Options Clearing Chief Backs S.E.C. Jurisdiction
description: LEAD: It would be easier to portray the continuing regulatory battle over stock index futures as a struggle between two cities, New York and Chicago, were it not for people like Wayne P. Luthringshausen, the chairman of the Options Clearing Corporation.

title: Happy 80th Birthday, Milt Hinton
description: Every jazz group in town must have been playing without a bassist on Saturday evening. Fourteen of the jazz world's finest string bassists -13 standing beside their instruments while the 14th, Rufus Reid, conducted - were crowded onto the stage at Town Hall as part of a JVC Jazz Festival program celebrating the 80th birthday of their most senior colleague, Milt Hinton, who took a very active part in performances throughout the evening.

title: Throngs Cheer at Gay and Lesbian March
description: Tens of thousands of people marched down a lavender-striped Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 21st annual Gay and Lesbian Pride March, a parade distinguished by its diversity, its broad sense of style and its lack of marching bands. It has never needed majorettes to generate festivity.

title: Don't Confuse 2 Live Crew With Black Culture;   Words of Color
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk;   High Court Saves Toughest for Last
description: The Supreme Court embarks this week on one of its time-honored traditions: the bone-crunching finale.

title: American Agencies Get 5 Gold Lions at Cannes
description: American advertising agencies won five Gold Lions at the International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France, over the weekend, six fewer than last year. A surprise winner was Steve & Warren's Excellent Adventure, for an ad for the Portland International Film Festival. Steve is Steve Sandoz, a copywriter at Wieden & Kennedy, and Warren is Warren Eakins, an art director at the agency.

title: Washington at Work;   Combative New Hampshire Senator Evokes Colleagues' Fear and Respect
description: Warren B. Rudman has heard all the indictments: He is a prosecutor in Senator's clothing. He is cold, always siding with facts over emotions. He always thinks he is right. And he is so combative that where he really belongs is back in the boxing ring.

title: ISRAEL WON'T SEND SOVIET IMMIGRANTS TO THE WEST BANK
description: In a move to allay foreign concern, the Israeli Government announced tonight that it would not as a matter of policy settle Soviet immigrants in the West Bank or the Gaza Strip.

title: Sweden's New Breed Of Corporate Raider
description: Sven-Olof Johansson is a hero and a villain in Sweden. He is a villain to the Swedes who think that aspiring to be rich is a sin - and there are many in this welfare state. And he is a hero to many young Swedes who like the idea of having money and the Ferraris that often go with it.

title: Karen Lee Kluglein Marries James David Baron
description: Karen Lee Kluglein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmuth Kluglein of Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to James David Baron, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard C. Baron of New York and Water Mill, L.I. Judge Edward Sharretts, a Southampton town justice, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Exercise Bar
description: A new design in exercise bars, the U.S.A.-U-Bar, has a padded yoke to use as a leverage point in working out. Four hand grips, two at each end, allow you to vary the way you grasp the bar. If the U-Bar yoke is around your neck in preparation for a situp, you may find the inner grips more useful. If you are doing side bends, you may want to grasp the outer grips.

title: Biggest Source of Big Shots Is (Yes) CUNY
description: In what may rank as the educational equivalent of a photo finish, a new survey found that the City University of New York has more undergraduate alumni in top-ranking executive jobs than any other school in the country. Thirty more big shots, to be precise.

title: Robin Fishkind and Keith Lehman Wed
description: Robin Deanne Fishkind, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Fishkind of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Keith Lehman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Lehman of Ontario. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated at the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Teufel's Turn to Supply Heroics
