description: The jury in the trial of John S. Vento, one of the eight young men charged in the shooting death of Yusuf K. Hawkins in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, began deliberations yesterday after closing statements from the defense and the prosecution.

title: Tokyo Journal;   She's Shy and Not So Shy, Japan's Princess Bride
description: The student dining hall at Gakushuin University was bubbling with lunchtime chatter the other day when a student in a simple print dress dropped in to pour herself some tea. As she smiled shyly to a few friends, a hush spread through the room until a young woman, abandoning years of training in Japanese decorum, gasped, ''It's Kiko-san!''

title: Grace M. Carhart; Professor, 90
description: Grace M. Carhart, an assistant professor of geology and geography at Hunter College for 50 years, died on Wednesday at the Cortlandt Nursing Home in Peekskill, N.Y. She was 90 years old.

title: A Neo-Stalinist Yearns for Old Times
description: An afternoon at home with Nina Andreyeva is an experience of cozy domesticity often interrupted by jarring moments of anachronism.

title: 90's: The Payback Decade
description: LEAD: The hero of the new television series, ''Shannon's Deal,'' begins each episode with a voiceover in which he talks about his past. ''I thought I was big time - big money, big house, big car,'' Jack Shannon, ex-corporate lawyer, ex-compulsive gambler, says. ''The whole thing was built on garbage. I started gambling big time, crazy stuff.

title: Irwin Panken; Lawyer, 82
description: Irwin Panken, a lawyer in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Sunday at his home in Plainfield, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: Knicks Give Bianchi Contract Extension
description: The Knicks announced today that Al Bianchi, the team's general manager, had been given ''a contract extension to take the Knicks to the next level.''

title: Network Executives Plan Strategy for the Summer
description: Television viewing plummets in the summer months, but television programming executives continue to devise new strategies for attracting viewers who have better things to do on a hot night than watch reruns. The executives are also concerned about getting the audience back in the fall.

title: Norwegian Oil
description: Accusing OPEC members of exceeding their oil production quotas, Norway said today that it was scrapping curbs on its North Sea oil output that were intended to help to stabilize prices. Norway, which is not a member of OPEC but is Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain, imposed the curbs voluntarily four years ago when oil prices tumbled to an average of $14 a barrel. The 1990 average price is $17, but prices have been under some downward pressure in recent weeks. Norway's decision to scrap the 5 percent reduction in its production and let North Sea oil platforms pump at full capacity starting on July 1 will push its production to record highs.

title: Patterns
description: Landlubbers Are Back

title: You Can't Expect a Space Station to Be Cheap;   Together to Mars
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Arrested in Death Of a 10-Year-Old Girl
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the death of a 10-year-old girl struck by a stray bullet while she was shopping with her mother on Flatbush Avenue on Saturday, the police said.

title: President Gets Amtrak Bill Without Takeover Provision
description: Congress today approved and sent to the White House new legislation placing a limit on Federal subsidies for Amtrak but lacking a provision requiring Federal approval of some railroad takeovers that drew a veto from President Bush.

title: Stinginess on Baby Food Will Cost Dearly
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Plane Found in Maine With Two Dead in Wreckage
description: The bodies of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Massachusetts state trooper have been found in the wreckage of a small plane on a mountain ridge in western Maine.

title: The Struggle to Revise Hospital Reimbursements
description: Few people in Albany truly understand, or want to understand, the complex formula that regulates the financing of New York's struggling hospitals.

title: Fernandez Declines to Reinstate 9 Suspended in Patronage Inquiry
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor said yesterday that he would not reinstate the nine members of a Queens community school board who were suspended last fall amid allegations of patronage abuses, estimated to have cost the school system $1 million.

title: Medication Is Tainted; 4 Die in Same Hospital
description: Four of 24 patients who had heart surgery at a hospital here have died after being exposed to a tainted solution, the authorities say.

title: Dave Brubeck Quartet Is to Perform in a Series
description: The Dave Brubeck Quartet is to perform a free jazz concert at 12:15 P.M. on Thursday at the World Financial Center Plaza, West Street south of Vesey Street.

title: Measuring the Brain at Work
description: PAYING attention dramatically increases activity in different parts of the brain, researchers have found.

title: Two Votes Show Public Is Wary of Tax Increases
description: When voters in California approved higher taxes on gasoline earlier this month, some political analysts said that the vote in the home state of the tax revolt signaled a shift in the national mood toward a new willingness to pay more for services.

title: Books of The Times;   The War of the Analysts: Ids Raging, Egos Bruised
description: Separate Hours

title: Witness Tells About Sexual Encounter With Barry
description: Weeping, her voice hardly a whisper, a prosecution witness in the drug trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. testified today that she had struggled for more than 10 minutes with Mr. Barry in a Virgin Islands hotel room in an unsuccessful attempt to fight off his sexual advances.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   British Agency Likes U.S.
description: MICHAEL GREENLEES, the co-chairman and chief executive of London-based Gold Greenlees Trott, is one British agency executive who is still hungry for acquisitions.

title: In Horn of Africa, Minorities Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Drop in Risk Seen By Hungary Fund
description: WHEN the Hungarian stock market officially opened last week, Ibusz, the former state-owned travel agency, became the first privatized company to be traded. The buyers are thrilled.

title: Slovenia Plans New Charter
description: The Yugoslav federation's republic of Slovenia said today that it would begin work on a new constitution to give it independence, a move bringing the northern republic close to secession, the official press agency Tanyug said. ''This will be the constitution of a sovereign state of Slovenia and not of a federal unit,'' said the Slovene President, Milan Kucan. Slovenia has advocated turning Yugoslavia's six republics into a loose confederation with little central control.

title: Keep Mideast Talking
description: To the Editor:

title: Asbestos Debate Re-emerges in Dispute Over Building Hazard
description: A SPIRITED argument among scientists over the health risks of asbestos has reopened an important environmental health issue once thought settled, sowing doubt and confusion about how to deal with asbestos in schools and other buildings.

title: Stinginess on Baby Food Will Cost Dearly;   Heartless Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: In bridge as in other areas, political events have severed most international contacts with China. Since May 1989 no Western bridge groups have visited China and no Chinese experts have competed in tournaments outside their borders. A bridge column of American authorship has ceased to appear in the country's largest newspaper, People's Daily.

title: Record Earnings Expected at USX
description: The chairman of the USX Corporation, Charles A. Corry, said USX's operating earnings would again be at record levels this year, despite the distraction of the shareholder proxy battle with Carl C. Icahn. The executive said he expected USX's operating profits this year to be higher than the record $1.6 billion of 1989, fueled by expected strong performances in both the energy and steel businesses.

title: Better News From Israel
description: ''We do not divert and we do not send any Russian immigrants or any Jew who comes from Russia to Samaria, to Judea, to Gaza, because we understand the seriousness of the situation.'' Those welcome words of restraint come from none other than Ariel Sharon, the Housing Minister in Israel's new right-wing Government and the man whose political trademark has been to press for Jewish settlers in the occupied territories.

title: The Azzurri Make Italy Shut Down
description: It is literally etched on stone walls that Trattoria Luigi always closes on Monday and Trattoria Pesole always closes on Tuesday.

title: 2 Tell of Gang Terror Before Rape of Jogger
description: Two bicycle riders described their terror as they were confronted in Central Park by a gang of youths who the police say minutes later raped and viciously beat a jogger.

title: Eating Well
description: REFLECTING the concerns of many readers who responded to the May 9 Eating Well column on the hazards of salmonella in raw eggs, one reader said he could ''live without chicken sashimi,'' but added plaintively, ''no chocolate mousse, hollandaise, mayonnaise?''

title: English Fans Expelled
description: The Italian police rounded up 246 English soccer fans and expelled them from the country today after riots shook this seaside resort. The fans were sent to London on an airliner chartered by the Italian Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We could not have known of your Declaration of Independence and not elected to join in the struggle to guarantee the people's life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.''

title: Reward Is Offered In 'Zodiac' Attacks
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of a man who calls himself Zodiac and who the police say has shot four people this year, killing one of them.

title: Broadway Adopts A Plan to Cut Costs And Ticket Prices
description: Broadway producers, theater owners, craft guilds and unions announced final agreement yesterday on a plan to cut costs and ticket prices to encourage the production of more plays and to develop new audiences.

title: For Trump, Seeds of a Comeback
description: Donald J. Trump has lost his aura, and a substantial amount of management freedom. But he has maintained his ownership of 100 percent of his empire. And in that small victory could lie the seeds of a comeback for the battered developer.

title: Successful Operation
description: Dr. James Andrews, who performed arthroscopic surgery on Charles Barkley's right shoulder Monday, found more damage than had been expected, but pronounced the operation a success and said the Philadelphia 76er forward should recover fully. Dr. Andrews removed a bone spur during the two-hour operation in Birmingham, Ala., and also repaired ligaments.

title: Bush's Latest On the Budget
description: Following is the statement issued by President Bush today on deficit-reduction efforts:

title: Research Grants Overrated on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Blames Avarice for Earthquake Deaths
description: In this center of farming and light industry along the Caspian Sea, not everyone is persuaded that the country's ordeal is the ''divine test'' that many Iranians believe has been visited on them by the earthquake that struck here Thursday.

title: West Germans Get Ready to Scrub The East's Tarnished Environment
description: In the halls of Bonn, where the sculptors of a new Germany are at work, one issue taking on urgency is how the orderly and scrubbed half of the country can help clean up the disheveled and polluted half.

title: Review/Television;   A Script, Some Actors And Sounds, Soulfully
description: Here's one handy recipe for a made-for-cable movie. First, you get a wailing saxophone, the kind that can make any situation seem hauntingly soulful. Then you find a serviceable script requiring only three or four principal roles and not much in the way of production values. Finally, hire actors who while far from being big stars have modest reputations. They won't be prohibitively expensive.

title: Senate Rejects New Move to Outlaw Flag Burning
description: The Senate rejected a constitutional amendment against flag burning today with critics arguing that it was already dead and being debated largely as ammunition for use against them at election time.

title: McEnroe Makes an Early Exit at Wimbledon
description: Frail, pale and stale, John McEnroe reverted to a formlessness he hadn't shown at Wimbledon since 1978 as he was eliminated today in the first round for only the second time in a career he is stubbornly refusing to identify as endangered.

title: Woman, 44, Is Killed In an Apartment Fire
description: A 44-year-old woman was killed yesterday in a fire in her Harlem apartment, the police said.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts Loan to RJR Renegotiated
description: As part of the proposed revamping of RJR Nabisco Inc., partners of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company have renegotiated how they will be repaid a $500 million bridge loan they made to the company when their firm took RJR private in 1989.

title: Eleanor Clark French, 81, Editor And a Democratic Party Official
description: Eleanor Clark French, a writer, editor and former vice chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Committee, died on Monday in Paoli, Pa. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHEYENNE BRANDO has fled to Tahiti to avoid testifying against her half-brother CHRISTIAN BRANDO, who the police said shot and killed her boyfriend last month at the home of their father, MARLON BRANDO. STEVEN BARSHOP, a Deputy District Attorney, told a Los Angeles judge on Monday that he would try to use a new California law to introduce previous statements from Miss Brando at a preliminary hearing on July 23.

title: Savings-Unit Indictments
description: The former chairman and three top executives of Midwest Federal Savings and Loan were indicted today on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges involving financial losses at the failed institution.

title: Senate and Administration Agree on Housing Bill
description: Senate and Administration negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on a bill that would revive the Federal role in housing by changing provisions that had prompted the threat of a veto by President Bush.

title: KEY RATES
Nuggets Interest Daly
description: Although Chuck Daly, the Detroit Piston coach, had previously showed little interest in becoming the general manager of the Denver Nuggets, he now says he would like to be considered for the job.

title: Israel Not So Clear Now on Settling of Soviet Jews
description: A disagreement appeared to break out today among the leaders of Israel's new Government over whether Soviet Jewish immigrants would be settled in the occupied territories. The dispute adds further confusion to Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's statement on Sunday night that the migrants would not be settled in occupied land.

title: Dow Falls 2.72, to 2,842.33, After a Surge
description: President Bush's willingness to consider a tax increase to help cut the deficit gave stocks a brief shot in the arm yesterday, but the market fell late in the day as investors decided to wait for further developments.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT was just a simple Italian dinner: roast eel, a little ravioli, a nice rack of lamb, cheese, dessert - and 70 wines. A dozen with the eel, 11 with the ravioli, a dozen more with the lamb and . . . well, you get the picture.

title: Saatchi Acts To Change Its Culture
description: AFTER a year as president and chief operating officer of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, Michael Keeshan says he is happy with some of the changes he has made, although the agency ''still has a long way to go.''

title: Board of Estimate Votes Lower Fresh Kills Fees
description: The Board of Estimate, reversing New York City's commitment to prolong the life of the Fresh Kills landfill, has moved to attract more garbage to the huge dump on Staten Island.

title: Market Place;   Lindner Promise: A Delicate Game
description: NEARLY three years ago, when the Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner took control of the old Taft Broadcasting Company, $125 million of bonds were sold with the promise that holders would be able to get their money back, plus interest, in 1990.

title: People
description: * George Constantinoff, director of medical and scientific affairs at Klemtner Advertising, has been promoted to executive vice president, as has Robert Brilliant, the company's chief financial and administrative officer.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization $ June 22 June 15 June 23 1990 1990 1989 Gasoline production, daily 7.1 7.1 7.3 Distillate production, daily 3.0 3.0 2.9 Gasoline stocks 216.2 216.6 218.8 Distillate stocks 109.8 107.4 99.1 Crude imports, daily 6.5 7.0 6.3 Product imports, daily 3.0 2.3 1.8 Crude stocks 383.9 384.4 342.4 Crude production, daily 6.9 6.9 7.3 Refinery utilization (%) 87.6 88.1 90.1

title: Louisiana Lawmakers Adopt Toughest Anti-Abortion Law in U.S.
description: The Louisiana Legislature today adopted the strictest state abortion law in the nation, prohibiting all abortions except those necessary to save the life of the mother.

title: Antitrust Break for Insurers Helps Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Right-to-Die Bill Blocked in New York State
description: The Supreme Court's decision in its first ''right to die'' case reinforces the need for a New York State law allowing adults to designate a surrogate to make health-care choices for them if they become incompetent, according to supporters of such legislation.

title: Cadwell Davis
description: The latest product to take an environmental advertising approach is the tampon. Next week Cadwell Davis Partners will begin a campaign for O.B. Tampons, made by Johnson & Johnson, that highlights what the tampon does not have: an applicator. ''No applicator to throw away means no waste,'' the commercial says.

title: Dai-Ichi Seeks 9.6% of Lincoln
description: The Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Company will acquire a 9.6 percent stake in the Lincoln National Corporation in the biggest investment yet by a Japanese insurer in a United States insurance company, Lincoln announced today.

title: About New York;   Social Intrigues Of Baby Sitters Shape the Future
description: Hilda is from Barbados and Julia from St. Vincent, and they met when the children they watch, Jessie and Max, started playing together in Central Park's 85th Street playground. The baby sitters heard each other's accent and knew they were from kindred islands.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title:
EDUCATION;

For Montessori, a Revival and a Return to Roots
description: LEAD: After more than three decades of serving mostly middle- and upper-class children in expensive private schools, Montessori education is returning to its democratic roots. More than 100 public schools now offer Montessori programs, and the number is growing.

title: G.M. Plans Project In Czechoslovakia
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was developing plans to make up to 250,000 automobile transmissions a year in Czechoslovakia. A statement said that the company was working on the project with the Czechoslovak Government and that the transmissions would be exported to G.M. plants elsewhere in Europe.

title: Frey, Zimmer Extended
description: The Chicago Cubs may be in last place in the National League East, but there is good news for General Manager Jim Frey and Manager Don Zimmer. The club has extended Frey's contract through 1992 and has picked up the option on Zimmer's pact through 1991.

title: England Scores in Overtime to Advance to Quarterfinals
description: The goal finally came not quite 30 minutes from the time the squadrons of police moved into the aisles of Dall'Ara stadium tonight. Barely 20 seconds remained in the half-hour overtime when Steve Platt scored to put England into the quarterfinals of the World Cup.

title: $775 Million Bond Offering From Dormitory Authority
description: The Dormitory Authority of the State of New York offered $775 million of bonds for the City University of New York yesterday.

title: China Exile Starts Life in Britain
description: Fang Lizhi, China's most prominent dissident, said today that he and his wife were looking forward to ''a chance to rest and recuperate and to have some medical tests'' as they started a new life in Britain.

title: INSIDE
description: Some Iranians Balking At Aid From Enemies

title: Not Near Enough
description: To The Living Section:

title: Continental Bank Plans Staff Cuts
description: The Continental Bank Corporation announced today that it planned to reduce its staff by 900 employees. It said it would establish a $50 million reserve to cover the costs and would have a loss for the second quarter as a result.

title: The Mandel Visit;   Excerpts From Mandela Speech to Joint Meeting of Congress
description: Following are excerpts from Nelson Mandela's speech to a joint meeting of Congress yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: How Distinct Is Quebec? French, and That's That
description: The stop signs here all say ''arret.'' French Canadians have their own national holidays, their own music videos, their own literature. They drink wine at lunch and still smoke with abandon in cafes, offices and public elevators.

title: White House Moves to Limit Cuts in Salvador Military Aid
description: To avert even deeper cuts in military aid to El Salvador, the Bush Administration is quietly telling Congress that it would accept a 15 to 30 percent reduction in the $85 million requested for next year.

title: Yanks Turn On Power To Rout the Brewers
description: The Yankees, who have experienced some power shortages at the plate this season, waited out a 16-minute light failure at Yankee Stadium last night, then went on to provide some impressive power in a five-run eighth inning and score an 8-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Waldron Herzberg, 84, Surrogate and Lawyer
description: Robert Waldron Herzberg, the surrogate in Columbia County, N.Y., from 1963 to 1971 who ruled in an important adoption case, died on Thursday at Monterey Peninsula Hospital in Carmel, Calif. He was 84 years old and lived in Carmel.

title: Trial Set in Booby Trap Death
description: A district court judge has ordered a warehouse owner to stand trial for rigging a shotgun booby trap that killed a teen-age intruder.

title: Gerard Appy, 69, Dies; A Public-TV Executive
description: Gerard Appy, for nearly two decades an executive at WNET, the major New York public television station, died on Sunday at his home in Lake Oswego, outside Portland, Ore. He was 69 years old.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Rose 4.5%, Nasdaq Reports
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 4.5 percent increase in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-June.

title: Economic Scene;   Broader Medicaid: Who Would Pay?
description: A RECENT Supreme Court decision is expected to add to growing pressure for changes in Medicaid. The Court ruled on June 14 that hospitals and nursing homes can file lawsuits to demand ''reasonable and adequate reimbursement'' for their services to Medicaid patients.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Warily, East Germany Stores Itself Away
description: The current task of Teterow's biggest employer is to work itself out of a job. But then that's what most of East Germany is doing these days.

title: Scot Haller, Magazine Writer, 35
description: Scot Haller, a senior editor of People magazine and chief of its Los Angeles bureau, died Sunday at the Sherman Oaks Community Hospital in California. He was 35 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Accounting Merger Deal
description: Price Waterhouse, a large accounting firm that recently picked up the Toronto affiliate of Laventhol & Horwath, a midsized rival, said yesterday it is also in merger talks with Laventhol's Vancouver affiliate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN SHERMAN COOPER was the honored guest Monday night at the American Film Institute in Washington for a screening of ''Gentleman From Kentucky,'' a Kentucky Educational Television documentary profiling the 50-year career of the 89-year-old former United States Senator, Ambassador and Presidential adviser.

title: Farley Behind on Pepperell Debt Payments
description: William Farley, the Chicago entrepreneur who used debt to build an industrial empire, could lose control of his prize, West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Georgia textile company said.

title: E.P.A. Moves to List Smoke As a Cancer-Causing Agent
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency says exhaled tobacco smoke should be officially listed as a known cancer-causing agent.

title: Company Takeover, Tokyo Style
description: If Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the maker of Subaru automobiles, were an American company it would probably be a prime takeover target these days, a slowly dying auto maker forced to merge or eventually face bankruptcy.

title: Beer Without the Tears
description: To The Living Section:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centerbank, Waterbury, Conn., a savings bank, appointed Robert T. Kenney president.

title: Europe Prices Up 0.4%
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose an average of four-tenths of a percent last month from April, Eurostat, the European statistics office, said on Monday. Despite the increase, the annual inflation rate in the 12-nation community held steady in May at a provisional 5.4 percent. The highest jump from April to May, 3 percent, was in Greece, where the annual inflation rate rose to 21 percent - the highest in the community - from 17.9 percent a month earlier.

title: Let's Outlaw C.I.A.-Style Covert Action Before It Destroys Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Zapata Nears Deal To Sell 12 Oil Rigs
description: The Zapata Corporation, an oil services company, said it was close to a deal to sell its 12 offshore drilling rigs. Zapata's chairman, R. C. Lassiter, said he was optimistic Zapata could complete the sale in four to six weeks, possibly to Norwegian investors whose identities were not disclosed. He made the comments after the company's annual meeting.

title: The Stylists Trim, Clients Cut Deals
description: WHEN Maitreya Kadre, a writer, visits the Vidal Sassoon salon in Chicago, she takes along her laptop computer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Sports section on Sunday about the New York Rangers' trade of Chris Nilan linked him erroneously to the injury to Pat LaFontaine of the New York Islanders during the Stanley Cup hockey playoffs.

title: Guards at 16 Stations To Check on Fares
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that beginning today it would assign guards at 16 subway stations to discourage people from boarding trains without paying and from vandalizing turnstiles in an effort to steal tokens.

title: Banks Approve Loans for Trump, But Take Control of His Finances
description: Wrapping up a hard-fought deal with bankers yesterday, Donald J. Trump narrowly avoided missing a payment deadline that could have led to personal bankruptcy.

title: Minorities Lead in Work Force but Lag in Pay
description: Blacks and members of other minorities now account for more than half of New York City's resident labor force, but they continue to lag behind whites in higher paying jobs, a Labor Department report released yesterday showed.

title: New York Acts to Take Over Co-op
description: New York City housing officials have moved to take over a publicly subsidized, middle-income housing cooperative on Manhattan's Upper West Side, where auditors accused the co-op's board of engaging in ''irresponsible behavior.''

title: Japan's Military Machine
description: The flap over the illegal transfer of ''Star Wars''-related software to four Japanese companies, all of them tied into the Japanese aerospace sector, underscores the growing pressures on the longstanding U.S.-Japanese security relationship.

title: Movement on the Budget But a Big Gulf to Cross
description: President Bush's statement today backing away from his ''no new taxes'' pledge may have been the political icebreaker needed to get the budget talks with Congress moving.

title: Matching Those Who Need Guidance With Those Who Have Been There
description: For at least part of a day, Tacuma Russell will escape the somber shambles of his struggling neighborhood in the Roxbury section of Boston. Today, to celebrate the boy's 14th birthday, a Boston University sophomore will drive him two hours along Interstate 90 to an amusement park, where the two plan to enjoy roller coaster rides and blue clouds of cotton candy.

title: Toxic Waste: Bacteria to the Rescue
description: In H. G. Wells's ''The War of the Worlds,'' invaders from Mars crushed the most powerful weapons the panicked human race could throw at them and were on the brink of total conquest when they were wiped out by the humblest of earthly organisms - bacteria. Now, bacteria are being embraced as potentially potent allies in a more realistic battle against a growing number of hazardous wastes in soil and water.

title: Sharpton Defense Declines to Call Witnesses
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton abruptly rested his case yesterday without calling a single witness in his trial on charges of fraud and grand larceny.

title: Corrections
description: The chart of major financial indicators at the top of the Business Digest on Monday misstated the previous week's activity. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,857.18, down 78.71 points for the week; the dollar ended at 154.90 yen, up 1 yen; gold closed at $350.40 an ounce, up 90 cents, and the 30-year Treasury bond ended at 8.47 percent, up five-hundredths of 1 percent.

title: Antitrust Break for Insurers Helps Consumers;   Mutual Life Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mandela Visit;   Europe Keeps The Sanctions
description: The European Community decided today not to lift sanctions against South Africa, despite pressure from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain to relax them.

title: I.R.A. Says It Bombed Tory Club in London
description: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility today for a bomb that heavily damaged an exclusive London club used by members of Britain's Conservative Party.

title: Tape of Barry Is Used to Rebut Defense
description: Prosecutors in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial put the defendant on the stand today via a tape-recording in an effort to prove the most serious charges against him: that he lied to a grand jury about drug use.

title: Hungarians Would Quit Bloc
description: Legislators instructed Hungary's first post-Communist Government today to negotiate the country's withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact. By 232 to 0, with 4 abstentions, Parliament backed moves begun by the Government at a meeting of the Soviet-led alliance in Moscow on June 7 and 8. Defense Minister Lajos Fur said then that Hungary would not take part in Warsaw Pact maneuvers this year and wanted to leave the organization by late 1991.

title: Nets Continue to Deal, Trading Hopson to Bulls
description: As they prepared for the National Basketball Association draft tonight, the Nets found time to make another deal yesterday.

title: Stock of Motorola Off on Phone Plan
description: The stock of Motorola Inc. dropped sharply after the company announced plans to build a $2.3 billion world cellular telephone network using satellites. Shares in Motorola fell $3.125 each in New York Stock Exchange trading, to close at $81. Tony G. Langham, an electronics industry analyst at County NatWest U.S.A., a New York brokerage, said investors appeared disappointed that the plan did not seem likely to affect the company's short-term earnings.

title: Moscow Denies It Is Moving Nuclear Arms From Regions
description: The Soviet Union denied today that it was removing nuclear weapons from the Baltic republics and other sensitive regions.

title: Harry C. Grumpelt, Accountant, 82
description: Harry Crockett Grumpelt, a former partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Young, died on Monday at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Money Fund Yields Drop
description: Bank yields on short-term certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell in the week ended yesterday. It was the fourth consecutive weekly drop. And banks in the New York area again showed larger declines in yields than those nationally.

title: HELP FOR WOMAN IN COMA IS ASKED
description: Missouri's Attorney General today urged state lawmakers to try again to pass a bill that could resolve the case of Nancy Cruzan, the comatose woman whose life-sustaining treatment was upheld by the Supreme Court on Monday.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Lithuanian in Moscow For Gorbachev Meeting
description: President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania met President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today, hours before Lithuania's Parliament was due to consider freezing the rebel republic's independence declaration.

title: Princeton to Receive $21 Million From Laurance Rockefeller
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller has pledged $21 million to Princeton University for the creation of a Center for Human Values, which will convene a range of specialists to study broad ethical questions, university officials announced yesterday.

title: Jazz Festival;   Pearl Bailey Elevates Her Philosophical Side
description: ''I'm more of a philosopher than a jazz singer,'' Pearl Bailey reflected the other day. ''When people say, 'Pearl, where did you get your style?' I tell them: 'I have no style. I just sing songs.' ''

title: Fernandez Bars a Choice To Run District
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday rejected one of three candidates to be superintendent of District 19 in Brooklyn. Mr. Fernandez based his decision on what he said was the official's flawed leadership as a principal and his personal conduct.

title: Predawn Shopping: Fish and Bonhomie
description: IT is 4 A.M. A light rain falls. The city sleeps.

title: Treasuries Rally on Tax Vow
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell in nervous trading yesterday, as dealers juggled a promise from President Bush and the onset of a flood of new Treasury issues.

title: Evolution in Europe;   European Leaders Back Kohl's Plea to Aid Soviets
description: Leaders of the European Community, under pressure from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to help speed German unification, agreed today on steps that he requested to reassure the Soviet Union.

title: Many in Poll See Worsening in Race Relations
description: New Yorkers say race relations in their city are bad and getting worse, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: Cable System Seeks Link With CBS
description: On the eve of renewed debate on a House bill to re-regulate cable television, Continental Cablevision Inc., a cable company based in Boston, said yesterday that it had requested CBS network affiliation for its cable system in Concord, N.H.

title: Article 395590 -- No Title
description: In an armored-car robbery that the Federal Bureau of Investigation called the second largest in the United States, more than $10.8 million was stolen yesterday from two armored-car guards who had stopped at a small food market in a suburb of Rochester.

title: First National Has 8.4% of Ultimate
description: The First National International Corporation, a venture-capital holding company based in Midvale, Utah, has acquired an 8.4 percent stake in the Ultimate Corporation and said in a Federal filing that it may seek control of the computer-services concern. Norman Elowitz, a New York fashion executive who also controls 8.4 percent of Ultimate's shares, said earlier that he was considering seeking control of the company, which is based in East Hanover, N.J.

title: Fixing The 'Ring'
description: Dear Herr Wagner: We have studied your so-called ''Ring'' cycle of four operas, all 17 hours of it, and propose the following changes to make it suitable viewing for Americans: 1. Rewrite opening to eliminate the insensitive treatment of dwarfs embodied in the character of the dwarf Alberich. The Rhine Maidens' calling him ugly and toadlike is offensive to dwarfs, as is the suggestion that a dwarf cannot be sexually interesting to mermaids. Having Alberich steal the Rhine gold imputes criminal instincts to dwarfs and is an overt slur.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF

title: Assassin of Robert Kennedy Denied Parole
description: The man who shot Senator Robert F. Kennedy to death 22 years ago was denied parole today for the 13th time.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Review/Rock;   60's Moods, 90's Methods
description: Genesis P-Orridge, the singer and ringleader of the English band Psychic TV, has some of the trappings of an unrepentant hippie. He writes essays about ''magick,'' and his voice can take on the throaty tone of Jim Morrison and the eccentric vibrato of Marc Bolan. He also sings about ''intoxication: wow, wow, wow'' as if the antidrug fervor of recent years was still to come. During the band's two-hour set at the Ritz on Saturday night, strobe lights flashed, and the stage was filled with variously flailing dancers.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Mandela Invokes Struggles Of U.S., Rousing Congress
description: Frequently interrupted by applause, Nelson Mandela invoked the names of American heroes as his revolutionary inspiration at a joint meeting of Congress today, warning that South Africa ''continues to bleed and suffer pain'' under apartheid.

title: Kurri May Play in Italy
description: Jari Kurri of the Edmonton Oilers, who holds the National Hockey League record for most playoff goals with 92 in 146 games, announced yesterday that he was close to signing a multiyear contract to play hockey in Italy next season. The deal with the Milan Devils would reportedly make Kurri Europe's highest-paid player. (AP)

title: Review/Ballet;   10 Dancers Win Prizes at New York Competition
description: Ten dancers from seven nations received awards at the third New York International Ballet Competition on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. The naming of the winners prompted delight, confusion and consternation. The decisions were made by an 11-member panel of dancers and teachers who judged 30 participants between the ages of 17 and 23 in 4 rounds of competitive events.

title: Book Notes
description: 'Zodiac' Sales

title: Adm. Robert B. Carney, 95, Dies; Former Chief of Naval Operations
description: Adm. Robert B. Carney, a retired Chief of Naval Operations and former commander in chief of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Southern Europe, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 95 years old.

title: Abortion Ruling Likely to Spur Judicial Hearings
description: Monday's Supreme Court decisions on parental notification for teen-age girls seeking abortions are likely to lead to thousands of court hearings every year in which girls under 18 ask permission from a judge to have an abortion rather than tell their parents.

title: The Mandela Visit;   Far Rightists Meet de Klerk in Pretoria and Come Away Dissatisfied
description: President F. W. de Klerk confronted a delegation from the far right of white South Africa's political spectrum today and left its angry representatives convinced that he was determined to share some power with the African National Congress.

title: Corrections
description: The Peripherals column in Science Times yesterday misstated the telephone number of Lexpertise Linguistic Software, publisher of a text-checking program called MacProof.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Today's Comics: No Joke
description: LEAD: In one of his routines, the comedian Lenny Bruce assaulted his audience with racial epithets directed, by all appearances, at specific members of the crowd. He called them every derogatory name in the book.

title: Steinbrenner Report to Stay Private
description: George Steinbrenner has not nor will he have access to a report compiled by the baseball commissioner's investigator, John Dowd. But the owner of the Yankees should not have any surprises awaiting him when the findings are presented in a formal hearing on July 5.

title: Doing Justice to Life;   How to Put Life in the Right to Die
description: ''Today we decide only that one state's practice does not violate the Constitution,'' wrote Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in her concurring opinion in the Cruzan case. ''The more challenging task of crafting appropriate procedures for safeguarding incompetents' liberty interests is entrusted to the 'laboratory' of the states.''

title: George Nakashima Service
description: A service for George Nakashima, the woodworker and designer, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Mr. Nakashima died on June 15 at the age of 85.

title: BellSouth License For New Zealand
description: The BellSouth Corporation said it had been awarded one of three licenses to provide cellular telephone service in New Zealand. Two consortiums identified as Ready Form No. 43 Ltd. and Write or Wrong Ltd. won the other licenses.

title: Senior Open Is for Shot-Makers and Par-Breakers
description: Now that Hale Irwin has proved that a 45-year-old can win the United States Open, then turn around and beat most of the same youngsters again the very next week, perhaps the feats of those 50 and older should be better appreciated.

title: Life Without Parole Urged by Cuomo
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called yesterday for the State Senate's Republican majority to agree to life-without-parole prison sentences for drug dealers who kill.

title: Caterpillar's Stock In Another Plunge
description: The stock of Caterpillar Inc. plunged again after the the world's largest construction equipment manufacturer announced on Monday that its second-quarter earnings would drop at least 50 percent from the first quarter. Caterpillar's stock fell $6 a share today, to $52.50, on the New York Stock Exchange after a fall of $5 on Monday. Its trading volume of 4.9 million was the highest on the exchange.

title: The Vatican Warns Catholic Theologians Over Public Dissent
description: In its strongest and most comprehensive statement on the topic, the Vatican told Roman Catholic theologians yesterday that they had no right to dissent publicly from official church teachings, even those not considered infallible or explicitly based on divine revelation.

title: Man Arrested in Death Of a 10-Year-Old Girl
description: A 21-year-old from Brooklyn was arrested on Monday and charged in the death of a 10-year-old struck by a stray bullet while she was shopping with her mother on Flatbush Avenue on Saturday, the police said.

title: Canseco Set to Become Highest-Paid Player
description: The Oakland Athletics will announce today that Jose Canseco has signed a five-year contract that makes the star outfielder the highest-paid player in baseball, his agent said yesterday.

title: At the Nations Table
description: THE Peacham Store, a classic-looking general store in this classic Vermont village, offers a menu of takeout foods steeped in tradition: Transylvanian goulash, juliette soup and stuffed peppers, to name a few. The tradition is Hungarian, and it was brought to this small town in Vermont's Northeast Kingdom by Desi and Kati Kegl-Bognar. They fled Hungary after the 1956 revolution and met in New York at a Hungarian students' gathering in 1960.

title: CUNY Teacher Tells of Shooting Bronx Neighbor
description: Sobbing uncontrollably, a Puerto Rican art professor testified yesterday that he shot his Italian-American neighbor last year while struggling for a gun he drew after the man attacked him and used an ethnic slur.

title: Measure Aids Swap Market
description: Banks and other companies active in the trillion-dollar market for interest rate and currency swaps benefited on Monday when President Bush signed legislation amending bankruptcy laws. The measure requires bankruptcy courts to recognize the validity of certain agreements used in the swap market.

title: Review/Film;   Tom Cruise and Cars, and a Lot of Them
description: For weeks it has been practically impossible to ride a bus or read a billboard without being made aware that Tom Cruise would be doing something of apparently great import today. The ubiquitous ads for ''Days of Thunder,'' Mr. Cruise's new car-racing film, have flatly declared that Mr. Cruise would be ''like thunder,'' as if he didn't even need a verb.

title: Henry Hocart Wiggins, Publishing Executive, 78
description: Henry Hocart Wiggins, a former assistant director of Columbia University Press, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Johnson's Status in Limbo
description: Ben Johnson's status remained in limbo today after the release of a report by the Canadian Government's inquiry into drugs in sport.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SUMMER CAMP

title: Pirates Defeat Phillies On Bell's Single in 8th
description: Bob Patterson and two Pittsburgh relievers ran Philadelphia's scoreless streak to 22 innings tonight, and Jay Bell's eighth-inning single drove in the only run as the Pirates beat the Phillies, 1-0.

title: Sanchez Vicario Falls; Graf Wins With Poise
description: In contrast to the men's portion of the opening Wimbledon proceedings, where seeded players made their worst showing since 1927, the plethora of women's first-round matches played today produced just one major upset, that of Arantxa Sanchez Vicario. There was also a minor one that quickened the local pulse as Sarah Gomer of England knocked off eighth-seeded Manuela Maleeva.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about the Supreme Court's ''right to die'' decision described the majority opinion imprecisely. The Court ruled that a state could require clear proof of a patient's intent; it did not itself impose such a requirement.

title: Met Officials Say Southern Was Dismissed
description: Hugh Southern's resignation as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, announced on Friday and effective this Sunday, was in fact a dismissal, executives and employees of the company say.

title: Turner Broadcasting
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said yesterday that it had asked shareholders to approve an increase in its authorized common stock to 75 million class A shares, from 25 million, and to 300 million class B shares, from 150 million. John Reidy, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, said authorizing the new shares would increase the stock's marketability. He noted that the company's chairman, Ted Turner, and several cable sytem operators have controlled a large percentage of the existing shares. Turner's class B shares gained 25 cents yesterday, to $48.875, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Are Shot in Brooklyn During Wait for School Yearbooks
description: Three teen-agers were shot yesterday in a dispute outside a Brooklyn intermediate school, the police said. The dispute appeared to begin as eighth graders at the school were waiting to receive their yearbooks.

title: Adobe Systems Profit Up 4%
description: Adobe Systems Inc., whose shares dropped sharply last month when it announced that earnings would be less than expected, today reported second-quarter results that were essentially flat compared with last year. Adobe, based in Mountain View, Calif., supplies software that controls laser printers.

title: Museum Company Chief Mixes Art and Finance
description: Floyd Hall made one of the last great fortunes from the leveraged-buyout craze when he and some investors borrowed $750 million to buy Grand Union, the supermarket chain that Mr. Hall was running, and sold the company one year later for a $350 million pretax profit.

title: Curfew in Zambian Capital
description: The Zambian Government, struggling to quell food riots in the capital, imposed a curfew today as the death toll from two days of disturbances rose to 14. Thousands of policemen and soldiers patrolled Lusaka all day after four people were killed in rioting on Monday.

title: Radius Combines TV and Computer
description: Radius Inc., a San Jose, Calif., company that makes high-resolution screens for personal computers, introduced a system that will allow Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer to display and process television signals. Called RadiusTV, the system includes a video processor board that mounts inside any Macintosh II, an external audio/video input processor and a television tuner.

title: Fertilizer Fumes Kill 2
description: A farm owner and a worker died on Monday after being overcome by fertilizer fumes in a tank on a truck in Salem County, the state police said. The owner, James Manganaro, 31 years old, of Woodstown, and the worker, Stephen Hitchner, 29, of Williamstown, were found unconscious at 6:15 P.M., the police said.

title: Republicans Fear a Kiss of Death As Bush Moves His Lips on Taxes
description: In the eyes of many Republicans, President Bush abandoned much more today than his campaign pledge not to raise taxes. With just a few words, he holstered his party's best tactical weapon in Congressional campaigns this year, a weapon that the Republicans had used to distinguish themselves since the dawn of the Reagan era.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For MARC BOHAN, there is life after Dior, and it is in London. He will become artistic director and designer at the House of Hartnell in September.

title: Syria Rejects Shamir's Call On Peace Talks in Jerusalem
description: Syria has rejected an invitation from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to President Hafez al-Assad to go to Jerusalem for peace talks, calling the gesture 'a trick.'

title: William P. Wright Jr., A Textile Executive, 78
description: William Pelton Wright Jr., a retired textile executive and former chairman of the textile section of the New York Board of Trade, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Suffolk, England. He was 78 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Family-School Partnership Has Been Working in New York City;   Examples of Readiness
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcos Was Not a Thief, Defense Says in Summation
description: Imelda Marcos ''has committed no crime except the crime of loving a man for 35 years, of raising his children, of being his First Lady, of being his ardent supporter, of taking his lavish gifts,'' Mrs. Marcos's lawyer told the jury in his closing statement at her racketeering trial yesterday.

title: Antitrusts Break for Insurers Helps Consumers;   Industry Is Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.A. Assails Nation's Export Policy on Tobacco
description: A dramatic increase in smoking worldwide has been fostered by American trade policies that ignore the health problems associated with tobacco, the American Medical Association has asserted.

title: Bandoneon and Piano in a Quintet
description: The Knitting Factory Goes Uptown series at the Equitable Auditorium offered modest pleasures on Monday afternoon - puckish, affable duets by Karl Berger on vibraphone and Cameron Browne on bass, and the ardent tone of the Argentine bandoneon (accordion) in a quintet led by the pianist Evan Lurie.

title: Books of The Times;   Havel Discusses Writers and Politics
description: Disturbing the Peace

title: Evolution in Europe;   Hard Times Discounted
description: The West German Finance Minister warned in a speech here today against predictions of a wave of bankruptcies and mass unemployment after the introduction of the West German currency on Sunday and the formal end of this country's 45-year-old centrally planned economy.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Communists Weigh Delaying Congress to Stem Conservatives
description: The Soviet Communist Party is debating whether to delay its important nationwide congress next week, in an attempt to hold back a conservative uprising that is already driving disenchanted liberals from the party.

title: Iran Debates Accepting Quake Relief From Enemies
description: Debate raged today within the Iranian Government and in newspapers over the propriety of accepting earthquake relief aid from what are seen as this nation's enemies, including the United States, Iraq and the novelist Salman Rushdie.

title: Brazil Plans To Cut Tariffs
description: In a sharp break with its protectionist past, the Brazilian Government announced today that it would open its market to imports, slashing tariffs and cutting subsidies for inefficient domestic industries.

title: Food Notes
description: A Spice Mountain

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. KARL A. MENNINGER, one of the founders of modern psychiatry, is being treated for abdominal cancer. Dr. Menninger, whose 97th birthday is July 22, was in fair condition yesterday at Stormont-Vail Regional Medical Center in Topeka, Kan.

title: Hewlett's P.C. Boss Takes Post at Apple
description: Robert Puette, the head of the Hewlett-Packard Company's personal computer operations, has been named president of Apple Computer Inc.'s U.S.A. division, filling a key vacancy at the Cupertino, Calif., personal computer company.

title: Accounts
description: * Goya Foods Inc., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, for its English-language advertising, with an estimated budget of $3 million.

title: Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, 66, Leader In Judaism's Conservative Branch
description: Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, a major leader of Conservative Judaism for four decades who helped professionalize the American rabbinate and pave the way for the ordination of women as rabbis, died yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: THE words fresh, wholesome and healthful are not often used to describe Mexican fast food. But Mrs. Mendoza's Tacos al Carbon, a white tile and light wood restaurant in the Doral Plaza shopping center here, may be an exception.

title: S.&P. Downgrades Ratings for Chase
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had downgraded its ratings on several kinds of debt of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The move follows similar action by Moody's Investors Service Inc. two weeks ago.

title: U.S. Is by Far the Homicide Capital of the Industrialized Nations
description: The homicide rate among young men in the United States is 4 to 73 times the rate in other industrialized nations, Federal researchers have reported. They said firearms were used in three-fourths of the killings in this country and in only one-fourth of those overseas.

title: Recording Academy To Protest Restraints
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the organization that gives the Grammy Awards, is planning a concert and march in Washington this summer to protest Government restraints on free expression.

title: Putting Computer Chips in a New Light
description: Computer chips are indispensable for controlling everything from chemical processes at refineries to the rudders and flaps of the newest aircraft, but they must be powered by electricity carried in wires. The wires sometimes create sparks, an explosion hazard, or pick up radio-frequency interference that disrupts the microchip.

title: Doing Justice to Life;   For the Cruzans, Pain; for Principle, a Triumph
description: The right to live free includes the right to die. That's the bold yet prudent finding from the Supreme Court. Constitutional liberty includes a right to refuse medical attention even when that could prolong or save one's life.

title: Japan G.N.P. Forecasts Up
description: Several of Japan's most prestigious private research institutes have raised their forecasts for the country's economic growth for the year that ends on March 31, 1991.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: IN citing 1903 as an important year, many Kansas Citians speak not of the Wright brothers' flight or the signing of the original Panama Canal treaty. Instead, they point to the opening of the Savoy Grill.

title: Recalling Mickey Katz
description: The show on Sunday afternoon at the Equitable Center, as part of the Knitting Factory Goes Uptown section of the JVC Jazz Festival, highlighted the clarinetist Don Byron playing the music of Mickey Katz, a composer and Catskills entertainer who crossed klezmer music with vaudeville turns.

title: New Jersey Talks Taxes
description: Everywhere New Jerseyans gather, they discuss the state's new $2.8 billion tax package, the largest rise in the state's history. Page B1.

title: Theodore Mander, 64, Insurance Executive
description: Theodore Lionel Mander, an insurance company officer who was active in British-American affairs, died on Sunday. He was 64 years old and lived in Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: Softening Stand on Spotted Owl, Administration Delays Protection
description: Just four days after the Federal Government declared that the northern spotted owl was a threatened species, the Bush Administration announced today that it was delaying action on a broad plan for protecting the birds and the ancient forests that are their home.

title: Prague Journal;   Ghosts of Old Heroes Inhabit a New Czech Paper
description: Of the barrage of new newspapers and magazines, from religious to erotic, that the revolution of last November has unloosed in Czechoslovakia, one daily stands apart. Instead of being raw with newness and struggling for a place in a bewildering spectrum of newly liberated opinion, it wears the patina of tradition and carries the weight of exceptional respectability.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the most dramatic hands in the game arise when a partnership reaches a hopeless contract by overbidding and brings it home.

title: Chrysler, in Shift, to Buy Dollar Car Rental
description: The Chrysler Corporation agreed today to buy Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc., one of the last large rental-car companies not already owned by an auto maker.

title: COOKS ON THE MAP - This Month: Leah Chase, New Orleans;   A Lover of Food Who Nurtured a New Orleans Institution
description: AT 67, an age when many of her peers have gone contentedly out to pasture, or at least to the golf course, Leah Chase is still happiest in the kitchen of Dooky Chase's Restaurant on the edge of the Treme section of this city. There she continues to turn out memorable platters of traditional Creole food, as she has since the early 1950's.

title: Saudis Expand Market For Development Bonds
description: Saudi Arabia has offered its state bonds to foreign investors in a policy turnaround aimed at widening its secondary market for the securities, bankers said today.

title: $400 Million Issue By Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation yesterday offered a total of $400 million worth of securities in two parts. Half of the issue matures on July 1, 2002. The 9 3/4 percent 12-year notes were priced at 100, which is 1.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.

title: F.D.A. Approves Heart Drug Made by Soviets
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a drug developed in the Soviet Union to treat potentially fatal irregular heart rhythms, and experts said today that the medicine was likely to become a primary treatment for the condition because of its low rate of adverse effects.

title: New Jersey Talks Taxes And Anxiety
description: At train stations, barber shops, pizza parlors and on street corners, wherever New Jerseyans gather, the talk has turned to taxes, and the largest tax increase in the state's history.

title: BUSH CUTS BACK AREAS OFF COASTS OPEN FOR DRILLING
description: Seeking to break a long deadlock with Congress over offshore oil and gas drilling, President Bush today sharply reduced the offshore acreage available to the industry for at least the next decade.

title: Liberty to Reject Life
description: The framers of the Constitution, who prohibited the Government from depriving a person of ''life'' or ''liberty'' without due process of law, had little reason to envision a day when the very act of sustaining life might itself be a deprivation of liberty.

title: U.S. Judge Assails School Officials for Neglect of Handicapped
description: A Federal judge castigated New York City school officials yesterday for their ''stubborn failure'' to provide appropriate education for handicapped children.

title: The Pop Life
description: Sundays in New York

title: Citibank Visa Offers Long-Distance Calls
description: A bitter struggle for credit card customers between the nation's largest telephone company and the nation's biggest bank took a new turn yesterday, when Citibank announced that it would offer long-distance telephone service to its 14.5 million Visa cardholders.

title: 'Scene' Restaurants Trade Their Hype for Longevity
description: TEN waiters, six busboys and three hosts huddled near the front door of the Tribeca Grill. The chef gave them a pep talk about the night's specials; the waiters scribbled notes. A host issued a reservations reconnaissance report; the waiters nodded, checking their pens, their corkscrews, their fingernails, their watches. It was 5:25 P.M. on Wednesday.

title: Killing the Rights of the Condemned
description: Congress, which is on the verge of drastically curtailing Federal appeals by death row inmates, might first want to consider the strange case of a condemned killer, Warren McCleskey - if it cares at all about fairness.

title: BUSH NOW CONCEDES A NEED FOR 'TAX REVENUE INCREASES' TO REDUCE DEFICIT IN BUDGET
description: With negotiations on cutting the budget deficit stalled, President Bush today broke with his vow to oppose new taxes and said any agreement with Congress would require ''tax revenue increases.''

title: Corrections
description: The Patterns column on the Fashion page yesterday misstated the information telephone number for shopping bargains. It is (212) 949-SALE.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: WITH produce markets bountiful with local fruits and vegetables, a cook's imagination can run wild. You can make your own version of pasta primavera using almost any combination of vegetables.

title: Mets Win in 11th for 8th Victory in a Row
description: When you're going good, you even catch Vince Coleman stealing second base. And the Mets did that tonight after the sprinting star of the St. Louis Cardinals had stolen 57 bases in six years without being caught by them.

title: Manila Looks Into Airline
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines ordered an investigation today into the operations of Philippine Airlines following accusations that the state-run company might have lost millions of dollars because of irregularities by its officials.

title: Senate Roll-Call Vote on Flag Burning
description: Following is the 58-to-42 roll-call vote by which the Senate failed today to garner the necessary two-thirds vote to pass a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag desecration. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to amend the Constitution and a ''no'' vote was a vote to leave it intact. Voting ''yes'' were 20 Democrats and 38 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 35 Democrats and 7 Republicans.

title: Family-School Partnership Has Been Working in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title:
Real Estate;

Atlanta Mall Grows in Bid To Lift Sales
description: LEAD: TO meet increasing competition from other shopping centers, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc. has begun a $140 million expansion and renovation of its Phipps Plaza shopping center in Buckhead, an affluent and fast-growing section of Atlanta five miles from downtown.

title: Clinging to Unity in Canada
description: Sadly, Canada has failed to resolve the status of Quebec, and in the emotions of the moment there's no telling what may happen next. Quebec is more likely to seek looser ties with the rest of the country than complete independence. From the U.S. point of view, some form of continued confederation is greatly preferable to a divorce.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atari Games Corp., Milpitas, Calif., a privately held video game company, said it would repurchase its stock currently held by Namco America Inc., a manufacturer of video games.

title: Son, 27, Is Arrested In Parents' Deaths
description: A Staten Island couple were slain in their home and dismembered yesterday, and their 27-year-old son was arrested shortly after the bodies were found, the police said.

title: To Eat Broccoli, Be Cunning
description: The broccoli issue continues to follow President Bush, judging from some culinary advice he has gotten in the mail.

title: Harley-Davidson
description: Harley-Davidson Inc., one of the last United States motorcycle manufacturers, is focusing on the overseas market to increase sales. Harley's chairman, Vaughn L. Beals Jr., said the Milwaukee-based company had adopted the manufacturing methods of its Japanese competitors and had now found its biggest export market in Japan. Mr. Beals said that out of the 20,000 motorcycles Harley expects to sell overseas in 1990, 3,000 will go to Japan.

title: New Leader Chosen For Lehman College
description: The trustees of the City University of New York on Monday named Dr. Ricardo R. Fernandez, an assistant vice chancellor at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, to be the new president of Herbert H. Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: Robert Bower, Social Scientist, 81
description: Robert Bower, founder of the Washington-based Bureau of Social Science Research, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 71 years old.

title: Metro Datelines;   Hasidic Rabbi Beaten By Hasidic Youths
description: A 41-year-old Hasidic rabbi was severely beaten by a group of Hasidic men late Tuesday, the police said, and authorities are investigating whether the attack is related to a schism within the Satmar community that has already resulted in several acts of violence.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 19 about the New York International Ballet Competition misidentified a dancer, Leticia Guerrero. She is a member of the Metropolitan Ballet of Caracas, not Ballet Michigan.

title: Metro Matters;   Assessing a Poll: Hints of Flight By Middle Class?
description: On and off for 15 years, Sarah Edmunds has lived on the same block near Washington Square Park. Now she is thinking of leaving not only her neighborhood in lower Manhattan, but also New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: Events: Quilts, Boxes And Pottery Classes
description: Outdoor Crafts, Lincoln Center Plaza, Columbus Avenue at 64th Street; 212-677-4627.

title: Insurers Planning Computer Link
description: A group of the nation's largest insurers has called a news conference for Thursday at which it is expected to announce that the insurers are developing a computer system that would enable independent agents to communicate with the home offices of several insurance companies simultaneously.

title: Task Force Will Investigate Savings Units' 'Junk' Losses
description: Federal bank regulators announced today that they had set up a task force to investigate whether high-yield ''junk bonds'' sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Michael R. Milken, led to huge losses at dozens of collapsed savings and loans.

title: Squeeze Apartheid, Not Mr. de Klerk
description: Nelson Mandela is a politician as well as a hero. He earned an ovation in Congress by stressing themes that unite his anti-apartheid campaign with America's own struggles to broaden democracy. He praised Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln and called the roll of the African-American champions of freedom. The one jarring moment came when, having urged that sanctions remain in force, he suggested that his followers be the judge of when to lift them.

title: Corrections
description: The Washington Talk column on June 13 about Congressional debate of a proposed Constitutional amendment on the flag referred incompletely to procedures for amending the Constitution. Amendments can be proposed by two-thirds majorities in both houses of Congress, or by a convention requested by two-thirds of the states. Amendments can be ratified with approval from three-fourths of the state legislatures or from conventions in three-fourths of the states.

title: Health;   Patients Frustrated in Research Projects
description: Many hospital patients who participate in research are unaware of its purpose and say they are inadequately informed, a study by Johns Hopkins University has found.

title: Amre Inquiry
description: Amre Inc. disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation of the company's accounting policies. Amre is a home-improvement concern based in Irving, Tex. In April, an Amre management group said that it would not make a planned $8.75-a-share bid to acquire all of the Amre shares that it did not already control.

title: HUBBLE TELESCOPE LOSES LARGE PART OF OPTICAL ABILITY
description: Engineers have found a major flaw in the main light-gathering mirrors of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope that is likely to cripple its ability to view the depths of the universe for several years, the space agency said today.

title: Summer Adventures in Naturalism
description: Among the activities offered by the Appalachian Mountain Club in New Hampshire this summer is an exploration of a wilderness lake, a field seminar in fresh water ecology, beginning backpacking and camping and an introduction to the plants of the state's White Mountains.

title: Viola and Strawberry Lead Mets to Ninth Straight
description: The Mets kept streaking in all directions tonight as they swept the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-2, won for the ninth straight time and advanced to within half a game of second place in the National League's East.

title: Sale by Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said its domestic oil and gas subsidiary had completed the sale of its Appalachian oil and gas properties to Ashland Exploration Inc. in a deal worth about $107 million. Ashland Exploration is a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc.

title: The Folly of Mega-Science
description: LEAD: The U.S. is rapidly losing its economic pre-eminence, and the main reason is not hard to discern: our manufacturing industries cannot compete with the Japanese. Moreover, Japan's extraordinary emphasis on robotics suggests that its advantages in high-tech manufacturing are only going to increase.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 20 about the factoring of a 155-digit number - its division into three smaller numbers that cannot be further divided - misidentified the site of a computer used on the problem. It was Florida State University, not the University of Florida.

title: Let's Start Modernizing New York's Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Newspapers Flourish
description: At a time when many newspapers are facing a slump in advertising, Army Times and its sister publications, Navy Times and Air Force Times, are doing well.

title: U.S. AGENCY SEEKS UNIFORM LABELING
description: In a reversal that creates a political dispute within the Bush Administration, the Health and Human Services Secretary now favors uniform Federal standards for food labeling that would pre-empt state and local laws.

title: 'Cemetery Club' Closing
description: ''The Cemetery Club,'' a comedy by Ivan Menchell, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street. The play, directed by Pamela Berlin, will have run for 10 previews and 56 regular performances.

title: Leonard M. Elstad, Educator, 91
description: Leonard M. Elstad, president of Gallaudet College in Washington from 1945 to 1969, died yesterday at a nursing home in Mauston, Wis., where he lived. He was 91 years old. The family said the cause of death had not been determined.

title: Accounts
description: * Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners, to Eisaman, Johns & Laws Advertising, Chicago, for Beefeater gin, from MacNamara, Clapp & Klein, which also lost the company's B&B liqueur and Denaka vodka accounts.

title: TLC Beatrice Continues Realigning Top Posts
description: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a privately owned multinational food company, named Dumas M. Simeus its president and chief operating officer yesterday.

title: Prague Installs Government To Build Democratic Society
description: Czechoslovakia swore in a new coalition Government on Wednesday, dominated by Civic Forum, the pro-democracy movement that swept free elections three weeks ago.

title: G.O.P., in Revolt on Taxes, Steps Up Criticism of Bush
description: The White House struggled today to contain the most serious Republican Congressional revolt of George Bush's Presidency, brought on by his decision to renounce his 1988 campaign pledge against higher taxes.

title: After 2 Steps Forward, One Back for 'Ulysses'
description: Four years after it was replaced by a new edition that claimed to be an improvement over the classic text of ''Ulysses,'' James Joyce's celebrated novel, the earlier version is being reissued by Vintage Books, an imprint of Random House.

title: Council Approves Speeding Up $1 Billion in Taxes
description: Asserting that New York City faces one of its most serious cash-flow problems in years, the Dinkins administration last night won City Council approval to speed the collection of $1.1 billion in property taxes from the city's 400 largest taxpayers.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Forget the Missing Medieval Artworks! East Germans Treasure the Marks
description: If they didn't have so much to cheer at and worry about, perhaps the 30,000 people of this townwould be rejoicing that some of its greatest treasures have been found in Texas.

title: Cable TV Rates Likely to Rise In Manhattan With New Pact
description: In a deal that will almost certainly mean a rate increase for cable television customers in Manhattan, the Board of Estimate yesterday renewed franchises until the year 2003 for the two cable companies serving the borough.

title: Union Head Wins Alabama Race
description: A teachers' union leader, Paul Hubbert, won the Democratic nomination for governor on Tuesday in a caustic runoff campaign against Attorney General Don Siegelman, and will face Gov. Guy Hunt in November.

title: Anniversary With Little to Celebrate
description: Ed Walker doesn't get out to an Atlanta Braves game very often, but when he does, he invariably leaves with a sense of deja vu.

title: Mike Jones, Boxing Manager, 55
description: Mike Jones, a boxing manager since the mid-1970's, died Tuesday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I. He was 55 years old.

title: Stock Market Bills Backed
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved two pieces of stock market legislation by voice vote and sent them on to the House floor, where passage is expected.

title: Chief of Operations Appointed by Laidlaw
description: Laidlaw Inc., the largest provider of school bus transportation and the third largest waste-services company in North America, has given Donald K. Jackson full responsibility for the company's operations. Michael G. DeGroote, founder and chief executive, plans to step down, though he will remain as chairman.

title: Closing Arguments for Khashoggi
description: The lawyer for Adnan Khashoggi conceded yesterday that his client had signed a backdated document in 1986 in connection with the ownership of four buildings in Manhattan, but he said Mr. Khashoggi was unaware of a court injunction barring the transfer of the buildings.

title: Exerpts From Court Ruling Upholding Two Affirmative Action Programs
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 5-to-4 opinion today upholding Federal affirmative action programs. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the majority opinion. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote a concurring opinion. Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy filed dissenting opinions.

title: Jazz Festival;   In Mulgrew Miller's Hands
description: Mulgrew Miller doesn't want to be a typicalmodern jazz pianist with an articulate right hand occasionally prodded by chords from the left. He can play in that virtually one-handed style, but his recital on Tuesday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall was more concerned with the possibilities of two-handed, thick-chorded harmonies.

title: Motif and Pace Set by Snail At the Chelsea
description: THE two-tone Victorian Gothic-style exterior looks just about the same, if a bit more spiffed up, thanks to a $500,000 renovation.

title: Under Threat, Peace Corps Is Leaving Philippines
description: The Peace Corps has ordered its 261 volunteers out of the Philippines after intelligence reports indicated that they had become targets of Communist insurgents, American officials and Peace Corps staff members said today.

title: Currents;   Medieval Faces Done In Mosaics
description: WHILE living in Rome the past 12 years, Vanessa Somers had the opportunity to work with Odoardo Anselmi, a mosaic artist in the studios at the Vatican.

title: A Year of Struggles, Successes and Dreams at P.S. 94
description: It was the last day of the year at Public School 94 in the north Bronx yesterday, and Randee Sacher's second graders began the final entries in their journals.

title: Ozone Fading Fast, Thatcher Tells World Experts
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned representatives of more than 100 nations today that destruction of the earth's ozone layer was proceeding even faster than scientists had feared.

title: Louisiana Measure To Block Abortions Is Sent to Governor
description: The Legislature gave final approval tonight to the strictest state abortion bill in the nation and passed it along to Gov. Buddy Roemer, who has promised a veto.

title: Jazz Festival;   Piano by Marty Napoleon
description: Marty Napoleon is a pianist whose driving, propulsive playing has an enlivening effect on the small jazz groups with which he usually plays. As an unaccompanied soloist, however, he has limitations.

title: Excerpts From High Court's Opinions on Child Abuse Cases
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today in two cases involving the issue of testimony in cases of alleged child sex abuse.

title: Shearson's Severance For Cohen
description: Peter A. Cohen, the former chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., has been granted a severance package worth about $10 million, including cash and stock from the firm and its parent, the American Express Company.

title: Dr. John Knox Sr., 89, An Expert on the Bible
description: Dr. John Knox Sr., a biblical scholar and an educator, died on Monday at his home in Medford, N.J. He was 89 years old.
